HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Using Every Trick in Fighting Sweatshops

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
YOU know you are in the presence of a certain kind of labor advocate when he begins to talk about the effective use of nuns as weapons.
"The companies really, really hate it when the nuns get involved and start writing letters," said Charles Kernaghan, smiling maliciously from behind round glasses that reflected the light of a solitary desk lamp he had turned on in his darkened office one night last week. 
 "I mean, what are they going to say against nuns, right?"
Mr. Kernaghan is the executive director of the National Labor Committee, which, despite its name, is not national at all, but a crowded, cluttered bunch of offices in the Garment District from which Mr. Kernaghan and five other people direct a militant, low-budget, much-criticized campaign against the use of sweatshop labor by large companies.
Mr. Kernaghan led a reporter through the offices, trying not to step on the high school students who were spread across the floor painting picket signs for an anti-sweatshop protest march planned for today along Fifth Avenue.
He cleared tangled piles of brand-new sweat pants and blouses and baby clothes from his couch. (He lugs these clothes around the country to use as props during speeches, comparing the retail price to the wages paid to the foreign workers who assemble the clothes.)
He had just returned from Seattle, where he went as a guest of the United Steelworkers of America. But while he was there, he broke off from the labor march and locked arms with students who were blocking hotels to protest the meeting of the World Trade Organization.
For a gloomy sort of man -- the kind who loves Kafka and Sartre and describes the empty feeling he gets even after he wins public relations wars with big companies -- Seattle was a vision of a world the way Charles Kernaghan would like it.
Except for the violence, which he condemned and would have liked to stop -- "But I was not going to get killed defending a Starbucks," he says -- the protests were the kind that Mr. Kernaghan thought died out not long after he helped shut down Loyola University of Chicago as an undergraduate in the late 1960's.
"Issues that no one in the United States really knew about -- except a tiny little minority of people -- now it's out there all across the country because of Seattle," he says. "It's like the Kathie Lee thing: now people are thinking about this."
THE "Kathie Lee thing" -- his unlikely connection with Kathie Lee Gifford, the talk show host -- is, in a way, the beginning of any story about Mr. Kernaghan, a 51-year old former psychology teacher and self-described perpetual graduate student who worked as, among many other things, a taxi driver, a carpenter, a truck unloader and a photographer before almost wandering into labor rights.
But three years ago, when he told a Congressional committee that 15-year-old girls were earning 31 cents an hour and working 75-hour weeks in a Honduran factory that made Mrs. Gifford's sportswear, he set off a makeshift publicity campaign that brought more attention to sweatshops than any other.
Mr. Kernaghan, who spent most of an interview this week talking nonstop while staring at a pen he was twisting with both hands, is the first to admit that he can be overzealous and even unfair and that his facts can sometimes be a little off.
"I'm not a trained economist. I don't come from an organizing background. I don't speak Spanish. I don't use a computer. I don't really like talking on the phone. I can't raise money. And I can't network."
He adds, "But I often think that the reason why the work is successful in some ways is because it was a mistake that I came into it."
As he tells the brief version of his life story, though, it becomes clear that it was not much of a mistake. He grew up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and then Valley Stream, N.Y., the son of a construction supervisor who emigrated from Scotland. His parents were strong Catholics who took in foster children and presented religion to him as a way of thinking about how to treat other people. "It made me a radical," he says, "really from the time I was a child."
He became interested in psychology early on, mostly to figure out "how the society operates and why certain people get shafted." But after studying it for years and then helping to teach it as a graduate assistant at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, one day he looked out the window of a classroom and thought to himself, "I just can't do this anymore."
And so he quit and got into his car and drove until he stopped driving. He got out at a pretty town of about 50 people in Pennsylvania called Ohiopyle, where he rented a house and dragged a picnic table into the woods and began to read (mostly Sartre and Kafka).
Later, he worked just enough to earn money to wander the world, and by the time he got to El Salvador in the mid-1980's, where he saw working conditions firsthand, he knew what he was going to do. (He now lives in an apartment in the East Village with Barbara Briggs, who also helps run the campaign.)
Where does Mr. Kernaghan go from here? He wants to get better at raising money, so he can hire more people and go after more companies.
"The big foundations won't touch us with a 10-foot pole," he says. "And I'll tell you, if we were doing whales or penguins, we would be funded up the gazoo."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Kernaghan and his small staff are preparing for an anti-sweatshop rally today. (Elizabeth Lippman for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Transit Strike Next Week Is Called a Possibility by Experts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
With less than a week to go before a strike deadline, an unusual confluence of factors makes a walkout by New York City's transit workers more likely now than at any time in the past two decades, union members and government officials say.
These experts said a subway and bus strike, though unlikely, remained a distinct possibility. And a strike in chilly December, during the holiday shopping season, they said, would disrupt the city far more than the union's last strike, an 11-day walkout in April 1980. 
 New York City officials say privately that their biggest fear as the new year approaches is not Year 2000 computer problems, not New Year's Eve crowds, but a strike affecting the city's 3.5 million daily transit riders. City officials have developed an elaborate 61-page contingency plan that includes allowing taxis to pick up multiple fares, and reversing the direction of traffic flow on major avenues during rush hour.
In an interview before negotiations resumed yesterday morning, Willie James, president of the union, which represents 33,000 subway and bus workers, called New York City Transit's wage offer last week an "insult" and threatened a strike.
"It doesn't look good at this juncture," said Mr. James, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. "If they're really serious, they better come up with something better than their latest offer because if they don't, I can't predict what would happen."
While Mr. James's tough talk might be calculated bluster aimed at intimidating transit officials, his tone is far tougher than it was in negotiations three years ago. The city's other municipal unions, representing nearly 300,000 workers, are urging him to take a tough bargaining stance because the transit contract could set a pattern for all of the city's other workers
A walkout could begin when the transit workers' contract expires at 12:01 a.m. on Wednesday, although New York State's Taylor Law prohibits strikes by transit workers and other government employees.
During the 1980 strike, when the city experienced severe traffic jams, the union was fined $1.25 million for flouting the law, and Mayor Edward I. Koch hailed commuters who took advantage of the spring weather by walking across the Brooklyn Bridge.
"A strike now would be worse than in 1980," said Gene Russianoff, the staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit riders' advocacy group. "It's one thing to walk across the Brooklyn Bridge in the spring, and it's another thing to do it in December when the weather's a lot harsher. I think a strike will mean severe hardship for working people. Some people will face real physical hardship getting to their jobs."
At a boisterous but peaceful rally yesterday in front of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's headquarters at Madison Avenue and 44th Street, 12,000 transit workers and their labor allies, according to police estimates, demonstrated and shouted for a generous contract. Carrying signs that read Show Us the Money, and Y2K Dec. 15, many union members blew whistles and air horns and said they were ready to walk off their jobs if transit officials made an unsatisfactory offer.
Labor experts say the chances of a strike are considerably greater than in recent rounds of negotiations because so many union members are livid about their current contract and because Mr. James faces an electoral challenge from a militant dissident faction that nearly defeated him last year.
"A strike is certainly more likely than five or 10 years ago," said Josh Freeman, a Queens College professor who is writing a book on the history of New York City's labor movement. "The union's top leadership is definitely taking a more militant stance than it has in recent years."
Mr. James's union, like the city's whole labor movement, has grown more combative, fueled in part by the more assertive tone of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and its president, John J. Sweeney, whose father was a New York City bus driver and a member of the Transport Workers Union. Mr. Sweeney talks in reverential tones about Michael J. Quill, the founder of Mr. James's union, who went to jail for leading a transit strike that began on New Year's Day 1966.
Several factors weigh against a strike, labor experts say, including fears of hefty fines, of alienating the public and of crossing swords with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The public often turns angry when city workers strike, and applies pressure to reduce the offer on the table as punishment.
In a news briefing yesterday, Mr. Giuliani said, "We have all kinds of contingency plans for all kinds of eventualities."
He said the city did not want to unduly frighten people about a strike, although he suggested that the two sides go into round-the-clock bargaining. Labor leaders and transit officials are scheduled to sequester themselves at the Grand Hyatt Hotel on Sunday to begin continuous talks until the strike deadline.
Mr. James negotiated the union's current contract, when New York City Transit was complaining of a budget deficit, and he agreed to a 3.2 percent raise in the first year, a lump-sum payment in the second year and a 3.75 percent wage in the third year.
That contract was ratified by a small margin, and with the city's economy booming, many union members are angry about receiving a lump-sump payment rather than a raise. Many say they feel they were tricked, because in their view they agreed to a modest wage increase, only to discover afterward that, according to many fiscal experts, the transit agency had a surplus of more than $200 million the following year.
"Our current contract stinks," said Delano Derek, a subway conductor who was at yesterday's rally. "For the last two contracts, they shoved it down our throat that the city was broke. Our eyes are not blind, our ears are not deaf, we know the city is doing better and we want our fair due. And I don't mind a strike if that's what it takes to get it."
The transit workers' frustration is complicating the negotiations. Like millions of other workers, they are angry that their wages have risen only a scant few percent when Wall Street is booming, stretch limousines seem to be at every corner and the city and nation are teeming with more millionaires than ever.
Mr. James said that to show his flexibility he reduced his demands to a 9 percent increase over each of three years, down from his original proposal for a 10 percent annual increase. He said the transit authority's latest offer was for a 9.25 percent wage increase over four years -- an offer he said was "an insult considering that we paid our dues in the last contract."
Disagreeing on the numbers, Marc V. Shaw, the M.T.A.'s executive director, said in an interview that New York City Transit's latest offer comes to 12 percent. He said that figure included a 9.5 percent wage increase and another 2.3 percent of each worker's salary that the authority would pay into the pension fund.
"This proposal is fair and reasonable," Mr. Shaw said. "It deals with inflation. It deals with their issues on pensions. It's a comprehensive offer. We're not looking to snooker anybody."
One transit official said the union was making unrealistic demands that would expand the deficits New York City Transit projects for its operations in future years.
Transit officials insist that their surplus is illusory, noting that fare box revenue covers less than 70 percent of their operating costs. Other government money, including a dedicated stream of revenue from the sales tax, put New York City Transit's budget into the black.
"The perception among the transit workers is, 'We agreed to a tough settlement in '96, and the transit authority has a lot of dough and now here's our shot,' " said Mr. Russianoff of the Straphangers Campaign.

HEADLINE: Ending the Brutality in Chechnya

 BODY:
In the name of combating terrorism, Russian troops are threatening to destroy anyone who does not, or cannot, leave the Chechen capital of Grozny. Of the more than 20,000 residents, who remain huddled in rooms without heat, light or even windows, many are too old or frightened to leave. Most of these holdouts are innocent bystanders, far from the "bandits" who are the declared targets of Kremlin leaders. It is time for Russia to show restraint, to start making certain its armies observe basic humanitarian principles and to begin searching for a way out of this tragic war.
The global outrage about Russian killing of civilians in Chechnya comes as Russians prepare to elect a new Parliament on Dec. 19, and with each round of international censure, anti-Westerners move up in the polls. Thus some analysts suggest that any political settlement in Chechnya cannot occur until after that date. This pressure makes the public statements of Russian leaders more understandable, but it does not relieve them of the obligation to stop troops from razing Grozny and indiscriminately killing innocent civilians. 
 This military strategy, as President Clinton noted, does not work, since it punishes Chechen civilians more than the Chechen rebels. With every Russian abuse, Chechen moderates also become more radical. Moreover, the carnage, increasingly visible on television throughout the world, damages Russia's stature as other nations come to recognize habits from its authoritarian past.
Mr. Clinton said at his news conference yesterday that he saw no workable way to impose international sanctions, since Russia has a veto in the United Nations Security Council. He argued that cutting United States aid that helps dismantle nuclear weapons or promotes democratic capitalism was not in America's best interest. The International Monetary Fund, however, has continued to delay a $640 million credit for Russia. Though the I.M.F. insists that its action is based solely on financial grounds, the delay rightly serves notice to Moscow that Western help is not entirely unconditional.
The Russians rained thousands of leaflets on Grozny this week declaring to Chechens on the ground: "You have lost!" Prime Minister Vladimir Putin and other Russian leaders should pay attention to their own message, declare their military operation at an end and quickly find a route to a political settlement.

HEADLINE: Albany Lawmakers Consider Raising Tobacco Tax

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Negotiators for Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature are considering an increase in the state's cigarette tax of at least 25 cents a pack to pay for a health care plan that would expand medical coverage for low-income New Yorkers, according to people involved in the discussions.
The talks are being driven by several factors: the looming expiration of a state law that imposes surcharges on hospitals bills to pay for care of the poor and the training of young doctors; a consensus in Albany to use a significant part of the money from the national tobacco settlement on health care; and a growing recognition among lawmakers that something should be done for the more than three million uninsured New Yorkers. 
 People close to the talks say an agreement could be reached this week, but they caution that a long list of issues remain, like the governor's call for holding the line on Medicaid spending and the demand by Democrats and labor unions for a plan that would cover most of the uninsured, rather than a smaller percentage of them, as Republican lawmakers have proposed.
At the center of the negotiations is a state law that adds $2.6 billion in surcharges to hospital bills, largely to help hospitals train doctors who are just out of medical school and to care for poor people who are not insured. The law expires on Dec. 31, and it would be a crushing financial blow to the state's hospitals if it were not renewed.
In the current negotiations, Democrats are calling for the state to provide coverage directly for the uninsured, starting with about 300,000 people. But Mr. Pataki's aides are concerned that such a plan would encourage private employers to stop paying for their workers' medical insurance and instead let the state provide it, people close to the negotiations said.
The governor wants to provide coverage mostly for the unemployed while providing incentives for private employers to expand coverage for their workers.
The lawmakers must also agree on how to pay for their plans.
All sides agree that some of the money will come from the $500 million a year that New York State expects to receive from the settlement of the national lawsuit against tobacco companies. But there are already competing plans being discussed for that money -- the State Senate, for instance, wants to subsidize the cost of prescription drugs for the elderly -- and what is left is not nearly enough to pay for the kinds of coverage for the uninsured that state leaders are negotiating.
That, in turn, has prompted negotiators for Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders to consider raising the state cigarette tax, now 56 cents a pack, according to the people involved in the negotiations. The increase was initially proposed by leaders of 1199, the hospitals and health care employees union, a major player in the negotiations.
The size of the tax increase has not been determined, but one proposal under serious consideration would increase it by at least 25 cents a pack, which would generate more than $250 million in revenue for the state.
By approving such a measure, the governor and lawmakers would be addressing criticism that the state government has been reluctant to cross the tobacco industry by approving tougher antismoking measures.
The state last adopted a significant antismoking law in 1993, when lawmakers raised the cigarette tax to 56 cents a pack, from 39 cents. At the time, that was the highest rate in the country, but 13 other states have since adopted higher ones. If the tax in New York were raised by 25 cents, to 81 cents a pack, it would be the highest in the region. New Jersey's cigarette tax is 80 cents a pack, and Connecticut's is 50 cents. Hawaii and Alaska, on the other hand, impose a cigarette tax of $1 a pack.
If New York State raises its tobacco tax, it will also mark the first time that Mr. Pataki and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, both Republicans, have agreed to a tax increase since they rose to power five years ago. Both are well known as enthusiastic tax-cutters, which could give them any political cover they might need for such an increase. A new tobacco tax would also put Mr. Bruno and Mr. Pataki in front of an issue -- the fight against tobacco -- that has been led mostly by Democrats. Antitobacco groups have long contended that the additional tax will discourage thousands of teenagers from ever smoking and will encourage thousands more people, including many adults, to quit.
But the tobacco industry has long opposed tax increases, saying they depress sales perhaps more than any other tobacco restriction. The industry also says that such a tax is regressive, hitting the poorest consumers the hardest, and that it encourages the smuggling of cigarettes from states with lower taxes.
The tax increase would be a particular blow to Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, which has long wielded great influence in Albany. But in recent months, the company has come under fire after disclosures that it has spent lavishly on gifts for scores of lawmakers.
The talks hinge on Mr. Pataki's demand to limit sharply the annual growth in Medicaid spending, the people involved in the talks said. The governor is pushing his Democratic rivals in the Legislature to cut steeply the anticipated rate of growth in Medicaid spending as part of a deal to preserve the system of surcharges that expire later this month and to expand medical coverage for the uninsured.
The size of the cuts that Mr. Pataki is seeking is not clear. But according to the people involved in the negotiations, he wants at least to maintain previously enacted spending cuts that are due to expire on April 1. If the cuts are not extended, the program would grow by more than $1 billion a year in federal, state and local financing for the program.
The state's Medicaid program, which pays for medical care for the poor and the elderly, represents the largest part of the state budget, totaling about $28 billion a year.
Mr. Pataki has proposed similar cuts in the past, only to see Democrats who control the Assembly block them. But this time, Democrats have not ruled out his proposal.
The governor's powerful allies in the business community have urged him to cut sharply the surcharges that the state now imposes on hospital bills, contending that employers end up paying most of them through higher insurance premiums for workers. But no such plan appears to be under discussion, at least at the moment.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Great Game's Victims

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The newly emboldened Russian military has now embarked on a modern version of what Rudyard Kipling in 1901 called "the Great Game" -- that struggle against the West for economic and political power in the Caucasus and Middle East.
A war on terrorism out of Chechnya is its excuse. Next week's elections to the Russian Parliament are the immediate cause of the systematic massacre of the dark-skinned Muslim troublemakers. The blood-thirstiest of the Russian politicians are getting the most support, if we can believe the easily rigged polls. 
 But there is another, longer-range game afoot. That is the old imperialist urge by Moscow to dominate the sources and lines of supply of Caspian Basin and Iranian oil and gas, and thereby to gain a stranglehold on the economic life of its adversaries.
A map tells the story. Chechnya lies astride one of the key pipelines into Russia and out to a Black Sea port through Turkey's Bosporus to the Mediterranean. That's why Moscow says it must be denied independence, no matter how many die.
The U.S., aware of Russia's ambitions, is encouraging an alternative to supply lines through Iran, Iraq and Russia. We support a proposed energy trail through Azerbaijan, Georgia and Turkey. Although it has not happened, President Clinton said yesterday it would be seen as "one of the most important things that happened this year."
Russia is putting great pressure on Georgia, independent after the breakup of the Soviet Union. Adjacent to Chechnya, Georgia has been resisting occupation by Russian troops who want to take charge of its border; that would undermine the West's proposed pipeline. Georgia's reformist president, Eduard Shevardnadze, has survived three assassination attempts that many think were K.G.B.-inspired.
Moscow recently entertained Tariq Aziz, Saddam Hussein's man. In return for Russia's support in resisting U.N. inspection of its nuclear weapon development, Iraq has cut its permitted production of oil. That has helped keep up the price of oil -- it has doubled this year -- and has given Russia the money it needs to support 100,000 troops in Chechnya.
Those are the undercurrent events. On the surface, residents of besieged Grozny, the Chechen capital, have been ordered to get out of town lest they be pulverized by bombs -- but no cease-fire was offered to let them get out safely. Thousands will die along with relatively few terrorists.
One Baltic leader said this was like answering the terrorist hijacking of an aircraft by shooting down the plane. Clinton sternly warned that such slaughter of civilians would mean "Russia will pay a heavy price for those actions."
What price? Only that its threatened atrocity "will further alienate the global community from Russia." What a weak-kneed response. The time to list the consequences is before the massacre. Such as:
1. Disinvite the Russians from next week's scheduled meeting of the Group of 8 foreign ministers.
2. Dispatch a trade-and-aid delegation to Georgia immediately.
3. Describe the suspension of the next I.M.F. loan to Russia for what it is -- retaliation for atrocity, and not for economic inaction that saves Russia's face.
4. Withdraw our scheduled Export-Import Bank guarantees.
5. Point out how Arab oil producers, now paying lip service to their Muslim brethren in Chechnya, are financing Russia's attack with their OPEC-induced shortages and inflated oil prices.
6. Begin drawing down oil from our brimming strategic reserve, replenishing the reserve when world prices drop.
7. Move quickly to bring the Baltic states into NATO. Russian imperialism is still alive and growling.
Russia has a way of responding to credible threats. What happened when John McCain and George W. Bush made plain they would withdraw from the ABM treaty if the Russians refused necessary modifications to allow limited missile defense? Russia's Duma, after four years, decided to take up ratification of Start II.
Cluck-clucking and hand-wringing have no effect. Mass killing is no game, great or otherwise. Diplomatic and economic pressure can save lives.

HEADLINE: TAKING THE CHILDREN;
A Pair of Westward Journeys By Mothers and Daughters

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:

Tumbleweeds
 
Janet McTeer, Kimberly J. Brown, Jay O. Sanders, Gavin O'Connor
Directed by Mr. O'Connor
PG-13 -- 100 minutes 
 One of two greatly similar films now in circulation (the other being "Anywhere but Here"), "Tumbleweeds" joins Mary Jo Walker (Ms. McTeer) as she is bailing out of her umpteenth violently abusive relationship. Shooing her 12-year-old daughter, Ava (Ms. Brown), into a battered car, Mary Jo heads off vaguely toward Arizona with a stop in Jefferson City, Mo., where she plans to snare a man whom she knew in high school. "Now he finally can have me," she tells her daughter.
A sweet young girl, Ava is appalled, but being deeply attached to her mother she goes along as gamely as she can. When the Missouri man is less than advertised, Mary Jo heads for California. A lusty, good-looking woman with a roving eye, she is fond of tossing clothing out the car window and yelling, "Yahoo!" Near San Diego, they go swimming and take up housekeeping with Jack (Mr. O'Connor), a conservative, bossy truck driver, and Mary Jo enchants a school chum of Ava's. "I love your life and your four marriages, and I think it's so great," the girl exclaims.
The resilient Ava blossoms and wins the role of Romeo in a school play. Mary Jo drops Jack, and mother and daughter benefit from a friendship with Dan (Mr. Sanders), a worthy, kindly fellow. Nevertheless, Mary Jo is itching to head for Arizona, the primary reason being that she no longer has a boyfriend. But then Ava makes a stand.
 
VIOLENCE -- Domestic brawls include smashed dishes and a threatened punch or two, though the men seem more laughable than menacing.
SEX -- An intensely physical woman, Mary Jo is ready to erupt around any man, but sexual situations are discreet.
PROFANITY -- Quite a bit, but fitting given the people and the stress they often are under.
 
For Which Children?
 
AGES 3-10 -- Older children in this bracket will relate to Ava, but the film is a little too gamey for very young viewers.
AGES 11-13 -- This is a hands-on mother-daughter relationship between two people who totally and wildly love each other. Children will be enticed, and, though parents may disagree, language and sexual situations shouldn't be a problem.
AGES 14 AND UP -- Many girls will be engaged, as will their mothers.
 
Anywhere but Here
 
Susan Sarandon, Natalie Portman, Eileen Ryan, Ray Baker, John Diehl, Shawn Hatosy, Bonnie Bedelia
Directed by Wayne Wang
PG-13 -- 113 minutes
Take "Tumbleweeds," make the mother slightly more fragile and the daughter much more mature, and you have "Anywhere but Here." Ready for a change of men and scene, Adele August (Ms. Sarandon) packs her 14-year-old daughter, Ann (Ms. Portman), in an old Mercedes she can't afford and vacates home in Bay City, Wis., for what she presumes will be a larger, more exciting existence in Beverly Hills, Calif. Out there, or so the narcissistic Adele supposes, she and Ann will suddenly be visited by a rosier reality.
Ann, miserable about leaving home and skeptical of her mother's judgment, has a clearer view. "You're a crazy, unemployed middle-aged schoolteacher with a child to support," she tells her mother after life hasn't proved particularly elevating in Los Angeles. By then the manically impulsive Adele has tired of her job as a speech pathologist and been badly burned by a smirking womanizer she meets at the beach.
Being the more adult of the two, Ann hunkers down over the next couple of years and makes the best of a painful and often chaotic situation by building solid friendships at school and doing well enough academically to get into Brown University with a financial package that is almost adequate to allow her to attend in the fall. Almost. Adele, clinging to her daughter in childish desperation, uses the expense issue to rule out Ann's getting away from her by going East. In the end, though, even Adele tries growing up.
 
VIOLENCE -- None.
SEX -- Adele gushingly tells the long-suffering Ann about her experience in bed with her friend from the beach. Ann undertakes some gentle sexual exploration with a schoolmate, though nothing is explicit.
PROFANITY -- The usual run of profanity, but not excessive.
FOOTNOTE -- It's interesting to watch Ann, who is older and much less dependent on her mother than Ava is in "Tumbleweeds," try to sustain a woman who in many ways is more of a child than she is.
 
For Which Children?
 
AGES 3-10 -- No.
AGES 11-13 -- Ms. Portman makes an appealing, competent heroine, and by this age viewers will be caught up in her problems.
AGES 14 AND UP -- Many older teenagers will also relate to Ms. Portman and the scenario.
 
Liberty Heights
 
Adrien Brody, Bebe Neuwirth, Joe Mantegna, Ben Foster, Justin Chambers, Orlando Jones, Rebekah Johnson
Directed by Barry Levinson
R -- 134 minutes
In another of his Baltimore films, Mr. Levinson goes back to the 50's for a story of growing up Jewish in a time and place that played hob with pat notions of ethnicity. "Get ready, folks, Jews are coming," says someone in a carload of Jewish youths arriving at a high school party full of people fresh from a country club with a sign at the entrance reading "No Jews, dogs or coloreds allowed."
Ben (Mr. Foster), a smart, cool Jewish boy who dresses up like Hitler for Halloween just to see the reaction, and his older brother Van (Mr. Brody) take their chances in a rapidly emerging multicultural society. In one very nice development, and a horrifying one to their parents, Ben begins a chaste but sexually loaded friendship with Sylvia (Ms. Johnson), an equally bright middle-class black girl.
"Just kill me now," says Ada (Ms. Neuwirth), Ben and Van's mother, at news of her sons' interethnic adventures. Their father, Nate (Mr. Mantegna), runs a burlesque house and a numbers business, which provide well for the family until a black drug dealer, Little Melvin (Mr. Jones), hits a bonus bet that wipes Nate out and leads to criminal charges.
But Nate remains ever the gentleman and devoted husband and father. And through these people an era comes delightfully alive.
 
VIOLENCE -- There is a fist fight, and Little Melvin waves a gun around after kidnapping Ben and Sylvia.
SEX -- Some situations, none graphic, many references, and flashes of nudity at the burlesque house.
PROFANITY -- Obscenities fly now and then, but they are never gratuitous.
 
For Which Children?
 
UNDER AGE 10 -- Not a good idea.
AGES 11-13 -- For all the 50's motif, these are characters for any era. Many 90's children will thoroughly enjoy this film, but parents could well object.
AGES 14 AND UP -- This is one R-rated film that should get a clean bill of health.

HEADLINE: New East-West Highway Studied for North Country

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 9

 BODY:
Take a map and trace a line between Watertown and Plattsburgh, across extreme northern New York.
It would show a 170-mile route along the state's geographic and economic fringes, passing through areas where unemployment is high, real estate values and per capita incomes are low, and communities are small and sparsely populated. 
 The region's most reliable industries are its 14 state prisons, but people like Victor Perry look at the territory between Watertown and Plattsburgh and see potential that could be unlocked by construction of a four-lane, limited-access highway.
"It has been something that has been preached and talked about and it has to become a reality if we are to survive," Mr. Perry said.
"It" is the project that has been known as the Rooftop Highway for the nearly two generations in which it has been discussed across the St. Lawrence Valley in New York. The most serious study ever of the idea, financed under the auspices of the Development Authority of the North Country with $1.5 million in federal money, is expected to be completed by late next year.
The study is examining the feasibility of what would be a highway link between Interstate 87 in or near Plattsburgh and the northern end of Interstate 81, just above Watertown.
"If they are sincere about helping the North Country, that is the best way to do it," said Mr. Perry. Business interests say the two primary east-west roadways in northern New York, scenic as they can be, have ill served the industries and the tourism trade across the region. Both of them, U.S. 11, between Watertown and Champlain, and State Route 37, north of U.S. 11 between Watertown and Malone, where it meets U.S. 11, are two-lane roads with many traffic signals.
"We are kind of at the end of the line," said the mayor of Massena, Kenneth MacDonnell, whose village is home to General Motors, Alcoa and Reynolds Aluminum factories. "The state and the country end here."
Representative John McHugh, a Republican from the western portion of the North Country, said the timber and paper industries and agriculture have also suffered without a nearby four-lane highway to ease the movement of goods and supplies.
Representative McHugh, who was chiefly responsible for securing the money in Congress to conduct the study, said the economic benefits of a Rooftop Highway are obvious. "The level of the transportation systems in our part of the world inhibits economic expansion and development," he said.
A bill providing for construction of the highway was passed by the State Legislature in the early 1960's, but was vetoed as too expensive by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. The state later recommended that the roadway be included in the national Interstate highway system, which would have meant most of the cost would be paid with federal funds, but that proposal was rejected by the federal government.
The rule of thumb is that it costs about $8 million per mile to build a four-lane limited access highway. By that measure, a Rooftop Highway would cost more than $1 billion.
The Pataki administration supports studying the feasibility of a Rooftop Highway, said Michael Fleisher, a spokesman for the State Transportation Department.
So does Hillary Rodham Clinton, a likely candidate for the United States Senate. During a forum in Watertown in September, she agreed with local leaders that the North Country has not shared in the prosperity of the nation as a whole and she said the region's road system was one drawback.
"I think transportation is a key," she said.
The route the highway should take, if it is built, is already being debated. If it shadows Route 37, the highway would serve Ogdensburg and Massena but bypass Gouverneur and Potsdam. If it follows Route 11 more closely, the roadway would be 20 miles from Ogdensburg or Massena.
Though the roadway would pass close to the northern boundaries of the state's Adirondack Park, environmentalists have expressed no opposition to the proposal so far. In fact, Neil Woodworth of the Adirondack Mountain Club said the highway could make the western Adirondacks more accessible for hiking and camping and relieve congestion on trails in eastern sections of the park.

SECTION: Section B; Page 17; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Many Homeowners Now Pay Someone to Put Rudolph Up on the Rooftop

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Dec. 9

 BODY:
First, it looked as if all nine reindeer might not fit on the roof. Then the lights on the sleigh blew out, plunging half the roof into darkness.
The Norway spruce in front of the house had grown so tall that it took nearly 4,000 bulbs to light it, and an aerial lift truck had to be called in to wrap strands of lights around the top branches. 
 Clearly, decorating Bill Shaw's house for Christmas is not a job for amateurs. Which is why for the last five years, Mr. Shaw hired professionals to help him put up the outdoor display of lights, sculptures and garlands that has made his house a local attraction during the holiday season.
Mr. Shaw has company. In an effort to create the kind of spectacular effects once reserved for Rockefeller Center, more homeowners are hiring professionals, usually tree care companies that moonlight in Christmas decorations, to install thousands of twinkling lights.
The companies bring in aerial lift trucks, orchard ladders and tree climbers, often working with electrical contractors who dig trenches and run underground wires to the trees and shrubbery.
Tree care professionals said that they began to get requests for professional help about 10 years ago and that the requests have picked up in the last 5 years.
They see several reasons for the increase. The booming economy has allowed homeowners to become more ambitious in their decorating. And as the designs become more elaborate, the displays become more difficult and more dangerous to install.
But more than anything, those in the business credit the trend toward paying for personal services: just as one can pay someone to cater the holiday meal or do the personal shopping, so too can one hire workers to string Christmas lights.
"It seems like lately, the stock market is good and more people are doing it," said Jeff Thrasher with Second Nature Tree and Lawn Care in Stamford, Conn., which has decorated homes in Greenwich, Darien and New Canaan.
"We just did one place completely in a candy cane motif, outlining each tree trunk and branch with bands of red and white lights," Mr. Thrasher said. "The lining of the house is popular, too. If someone has good taste, it can be very stylish."
Not surprisingly, professional displays do not come cheap.
"It's not too difficult to spend $10,000 on decorating a tree, if it's the first time you're doing it," said Daniel Van Starrenburg, president of Savatree in Bedford Hills, N.Y., who did the work on Mr. Shaw's house.
"It's first a question of how passionate you feel and second, how prosperous you feel," Mr. Starrenburg said. "It seems the trend is that people are wanting to do more outrageous and spectacular scenarios."
Costs for professional decorating range dramatically, depending on what kind of equipment and how many hours are required. Some homeowners buy their own lights; others have the tree companies provide the decorations.
Mr. Shaw did his own designing and equipment buying but hired a crew of three men for two days to put everything up. Not only is his entire house outlined with lights but every tree and bush in the front yard is covered. In addition to Santa Claus and the reindeer on the roof, three reindeer and one angel are on the front lawn. The reindeer nod their heads; the angel flaps its wings.
So far this season, Mr. Shaw has bought 128 boxes of replacement lights as well as an additional 23 extension cords. He estimated that he has spent about $7,000 on updating the display, a figure that does not include a generator he had to install, because the power demands would overwhelm his circuit box. His electricity bill during the holiday season? "Don't ask," Mr. Shaw said. "At least triple."
Generally, homeowners decorate evergreen trees with colored lights, while the trend for deciduous trees is to wrap the trunk and each branch with tiny white lights. But aesthetics are not all that is involved: professionals can help with calculations of the wattage required and how many amps each electrical wire can handle.
Since having the lights professionally strung can be expensive, some people have tried to save money by leaving the strands up all year, a practice that tree companies have tried to discourage.
First, arborists say, tight wires can girdle the tree, stopping the flow of sap and damaging growth. The wiring can also be chewed by squirrels, causing electrical shorts. And of course, lights burn out; roughly 40 percent of them have to be replaced each year anyway.
Elaborate decorations are just as vulnerable to accidents as more modest efforts. In other words, if one bulb goes, all of them can go dark.
"That's why you really can't put a lump sum on how much this costs," said Ken Almstead, vice president of Almstead Tree Company in Briarcliff, N.Y., who has worked in Katonah, Scarsdale, New Rochelle and Bronxville.
"Regular outdoor lights aren't great for withstanding winter weather, and let's say we string a great big spruce, one of the strands goes out, we have to come back," Mr. Almstead said. "It's just like the lights on your Christmas tree: when one light goes, everything above it or below it will go, too."
That is what happened last year to Mr. Shaw -- the lights on the Norway spruce had a short and everything had to come down -- but it was not enough to discourage him.
Mr. Shaw, a senior vice president of HRH Construction Corporation in Manhattan, said he started his display small. "I heard Chappaqua was upscale, and I didn't want someone banging on my door," he said.
The display has grown each year and now almost every piece of greenery is lighted. This year, the lawn display is new. Next year, he is hoping to have Santa and his reindeer dangling from a hot air balloon.
Far from complaints, Mr. Shaw said he receives thank-you notes. "It makes people happy and you can't buy that," he said.

HEADLINE: Occupational School to Close After Losing State Tuition Aid

 BODY:
After serving low-income and immigrant students seeking occupational diplomas, the 111-year-old Interboro Institute in Manhattan will shut its doors Friday of next week because of a long-running dispute over whether it should receive state tuition assistance.
The institute, which has been in business since 1888, can no longer pay its bills. It is blaming the State Department of Education for turning off the stream of money. 
 Interboro Institute, with almost a thousand students in its building on West 56th Street, provides entry-level career and occupational education and is authorized by the state to confer the degree of Associate of Occupational Science. The school trains students to be assistants in areas like accounting, business management and paralegal studies.. Many of its students do not have high school degrees and must first complete high school equivalency degrees. Even students with high school degrees often require a program of heavy remedial education.
Affected by the closure will be students like Antyem Mallokandov, who is originally from Russia but now lives in Queens. He is enrolled in Interboro's ophthalmic dispensing program, which teaches students to fill out prescriptions for corrective eyewear.
"I spent two years at Tech," he said, referring to programs he took at New York City Technical College "Now I have to go back there. I thought I was going to finish, now I have to finish again."
Orande Russel, a student originally from Barbados who also lives in Queens, sat looking at the floor and shaking his head over the imminent closing of the school. "I was almost finished. Now I have to start at square one. It just doesn't feel good and I don't know what to do."
Almost all of the students, some of whom are receiving welfare benefits, pay their tuition of roughly $3,400 a year with money from state tuition assistance, and federal assistance, known as Pell grants, aimed at low-income families. If Interboro loses its certification to receive student aid checks, it says, it cannot continue.
Many trade and career schools have been accused over the years of taking government assistance and putting students through their programs who never finish their degrees. Interboro says 15 percent of its students graduate with two-year-degrees, a rate they say is roughly equivalent to other schools serving low-income students.
"This is not some fly-by-night rip- off operation," said Professor Stanley Hoffman who teaches english and composition. "Students who come here have gone on to four-year colleges or gotten jobs."
Interboro's financial problems stretch back at least a decade. An audit of the school by the State Comptroller's Office from 1989 to 1992 found that Interboro violated laws covering the allocation of tuition assistance money and disallowed $4.8 million the school had received. That amount was later reduced to $3.5 million, still money that would have to be paid back to the state.
According to the State Department of Education, there were three major areas of violation. Some of Interboro's students did not live in New York as required. Some students did not take minimum number of courses to be eligible for full-time assistance. And some students had not taken tests from Interboro that were required by the school's admission policy.
In 1996, Interboro began a five-year plan to pay back the state about $800,000 a year plus interest. But in December 1998, the state decided that Interboro was no longer economically viable and should not be eligible to receive state tuition assistance money. It explained that because of Interboro's $1.2 million debt, it was not likely to be eligible to receive Pell grants and so could not go on.
"That took us by surprise," said Rupert A. Jemmott, executive vice president and vice president for academic affairs. "We had no financial problems. We were paying our bills. We were functioning. They withheld funds pending a renegotiation of the payback. Had those funds not been withheld, we would have been fine."
Officials at Interboro said they had been unfairly singled out. "I think there are people in Albany who don't like me and don't like the kinds of students we produce," said Bruce Kalisch, president of Interboro, who has been president since 1987.
Alan Ray, a spokesman for the Department of Education, said the original audit was done completely independently and "the facts are the facts." He dismissed any idea of a vendetta against Mr. Kalisch or the school as "ludicrous."
Interboro has had strained relations before with the Department of Education, whose officials twice tried to shut the school for academic reasons -- concerns over the school's remedial programs and the number of students who had never graduated high school. Those decisions were overturned at the commissioner level.
With the school's closing now imminent, administrators and professors are looking for new schools that will accept Interboro students. But Mr. Kalisch thinks many students will not be accepted elsewhere. Teachers and administrators have been working without pay since December first.
"There is enough blame to go around," said an optics teacher, Gloria Lynch. "I just wish they gave us some money to finish with students already in the pipeline. It's a heartbreaker for so many people."
As she spoke, Ms. Lynch flipped through mementos from students on her desk: a small handmade rug, a hand-carved wooden heart, a letter from Bosnia titled "To one of my favorite teachers."
"It's dismantling my whole life," Ms. Lynch said.

HEADLINE: Social Security Math

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Social Security Advisory Board is right to point to the unrealistic life expectancy rates used by Congress and others when calculating the health of the Social Security trust fund (news article, Dec. 7). But the board ignores a bigger flaw -- unrealistically low economic projections.
The gloomiest Social Security scenarios are based on projections that the economy will slow to recession levels in coming decades. Even short-term predictions are dire. 
 The board sees growth of only 2.15 percent in the coming year. But in a recent report to Congress, groups like the Office of Management and Budget and Data Resources Inc. had estimates of 2.4 percent to 3.4 percent. We should be using more realistic forecasts.
 
ANTHONY D. WEINER
Member of Congress, 9th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Dec. 8, 1999

HEADLINE: William Jackson Dies at 80; Lawyer With Wide Clientele

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
William Eldred Jackson, a New York lawyer with an international clientele that included Nelson A. Rockefeller, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, the King of Morocco and Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 80 and also had a home in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.
The cause was throat cancer, a family spokesman said. He said Mr. Jackson had continued to go to his office until last week. 
 Mr. Jackson came to the law as a personal assistant to his father, Robert H. Jackson, an associate justice of the Supreme Court appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The younger Mr. Jackson, a native of Jamestown, N.Y., was first in his class at St. Albans School in Washington and graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1941 from Yale University, where he was vice chairman of The Yale Daily News. He was an editor of the Harvard Law Review and got his L.L.B. there in 1944.
He then was a lieutenant (j.g.) in the Navy until 1946. He followed Justice Jackson to Germany when his father, on a leave of absence, was America's chief counsel for the prosecution at the Nuremberg trial of major Nazi war criminals. As a staff member, private secretary and law clerk, William Jackson took part in the interrogation of Hermann Goring, Rudolf Hess and Albert Speer. He was co-editor of the eight volumes of trial evidence printed by the American government.
In 1947, he joined the Wall Street law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, specializing in civil litigation, including arbitration, as well as antitrust actions and international legal disputes. He became a partner in 1954 and was a consulting partner at his death.
He was the personal lawyer for Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York in 1974, when President Gerald Ford picked Mr. Rockefeller as his vice president after the Watergate scandal; he counseled Mr. Rockefeller at his confirmation hearings.
Mr. Jackson represented Mrs. Onassis in her negotiations with the Onassis estate after the Greek shipping magnate, Aristotle, her second husband, died in 1975. He also advised Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza, the Swiss industrialist, in the intricate international bargaining before he moved his fabled art collection into its own museum, a stone's throw from the Prado Museum in Madrid.
In the 1970's, Mr. Jackson won two landmark Supreme Court cases for the New York Stock Exchange that established guidelines for class-action cases in the securities industry. He was a past vice chairman of the International Court of Arbitration in the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris.
Mr. Jackson is survived by his wife of 55 years, Nancy Dabney Roosevelt Jackson, a granddaughter of President Theodore Roosevelt; five daughters, Miranda Hook of Fairfield, Conn., Melissa Morgan of Cold Spring Harbor and Melanie Jackson, Melinda Kessler and Marina Jackson, all of Manhattan; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Japan Drops Cornerstone Of Program For Rockets

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 9

 BODY:
In the latest setback for the Japanese space program, the space agency said today that it would abandon its troubledH-2 rocket project, the cornerstone of the program, after a series of costly failures.
The decision will delay the launchings of almost all Japanese satellites for about a year and follows the failed launching last month of the No. 8 H-2 rocket, which plunged into the Pacific shortly after takeoff because of engine trouble. In developing the rocket, Japan sought to free itself from the restrictions that came with relying on the United States for rocket technology and to compete in the commercial satellite-launching market. 
 But the National Space Development Agency said it would immediately halt production of the No. 7 H-2 rocket, which is 90 percent complete at a cost of $160 million. The No. 7 rocket, which despite its designation was the last in the H-2 series, had been scheduled for launching with a communications satellite next year.
The agency said it would focus on the next generation of rocket, H-2A, which the agency said would benefit from past mistakes.
The agency has invested $4.14 billion in the H-2 program, which began in 1986, including $2.7 billion for development and $180 million for each launching.
An aerospace analyst, Fujio Nakano, said the decision to shift focus to the H-2A was a good idea. "With the past H-2 launches," Mr. Nakano said, "we have already accumulated much valuable information that can be used in designing the new rocket model. Considering that this is an investment toward the next-generation rocket technology, 16 billion yen is a small loss."
That total equals $160 million.
The credibility of the space effort was severely damaged on Nov. 15, when the No. 8 H-2 rocket, carrying a government satellite, plunged into the ocean after the first-stage engine stopped firing. That was the second H-2 rocket failure in two years.
The lost rocket and satellite were valued at $340 million. The agency has not determined the cause of the failure.
"While we are still investigating the accident, we decided, considering the cost involved, that we should cancel the No. 7 H-2 and apply the savings and what we learn from the investigation to insuring a successful launching of the H-2A," said a spokesman for the agency, Yasukuki Fukumuro.
Mr. Fukumuro said the agency would save $30 million by devoting its efforts solely to developing the H-2A, which he said has a more advanced engine and more power than its predecessor.
The agency had planned the initial H-2A launching for early next year. But its debut will be delayed for a year to conduct additional ground tests, the agency said. The postponement, along with the cancellation of the No. 7 H-2, will push back the launching of almost every satellite for at least a year.
The agency said it planned to launch the first and second H-2A rockets, which are scheduled to carry a European Space Agency communications satellite and Japanese military satellite, in the summer and winter of 2001.
Mr. Fukumuro said if the initial H-2A launchings were successful, the agency hoped to transfer the technology to the private sector to fulfill the long-term goal of launching commercial satellites. To be competitive, the Japanese plan to offer customers steep discounts on launchings and build a reputation for reliability.
The highly competitive launching industry is dominated by three major players, Boeing's Delta rockets and Lockheed Martin's Atlas rockets, both from the United States, and Ariane rockets made by Arianespace, the European consortium. Russia and China have small parts of the market.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Trying to Put 'Out of Print' Back in Play

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Two of the leading players in the book industry announced separate plans yesterday to invest in new instant printing technology that will resurrect out-of-print titles and lead toward more electronic books.
Barnes & Noble said it had struck an agreement with I.B.M. to provide print-on-demand equipment for its distribution centers, which will allow the No. 1-ranked bookstore chain to quickly convert digital books into conventional print versions one at a time. 
 On the same day, Random House Inc. -- the largest trade book publisher in the United States and a unit of Bertelsmann -- said it was also preparing to invest in state-of-the art equipment for its national distribution center in Westminster, Md., that will begin operation in March or April. But unlike Barnes & Noble, it has not yet struck a deal with any of the major manufacturers of the equipment like Xerox or I.B.M.
Most book buyers may not immediately notice the effect of the equipment, but ultimately such moves mean that the depth and selection of titles will increase because publishers will be able to maintain titles economically in digital form, printing titles out in short runs according to demand.
"I think there are roughly 1.3 million titles considered in print, and some 90,000 books are put out of print each year," said Stephen Riggio, vice chairman of Barnes & Noble. "We think that's a travesty. The technology enables us to declare that the words 'out of print' should be obsolete."
Mr. Riggio said the company expected to start offering a range of services to publishers early next year. It has already been working with a pilot group of five small and large publishers to identify titles, Mr. Riggio added.
Random House is going through the first round of examining its out-of-stock titles, which could be brought back to life in digital form and printed with the new technology, said Erik Engstrom, president and chief operating officer for Random House.
The company has a backlist of more than 20,000 titles, but estimates that there are as many as 50,000 titles that are no longer in stock that could be revived, Mr. Engstrom said.
"Most of this will be invisible to the reader," he added. "The only thing a reader is interested in is whether they can find a book or not. With this equipment, we'll have the ability to print any book in our database whenever we want it. When we have this new printer, we'll also have the ability to turn everything around faster."

HEADLINE: Fritz Fischer, 91; German Historian Blamed Germany for First War

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Fritz Fischer, the German historian who rankled his peers and Germans in general with the thesis that Imperial Germany was squarely responsible for World War I and its consequences, died on Dec. 1 in Hamburg. He was 91.
Dr. Fischer, a Hamburg resident, had been a professor emeritus at the University of Hamburg since 1973. 
 He stirred a hornet's nest in 1961 with the proposition that Germany's naked ambition to spread its political and economic domination across Europe and beyond, to Africa, caused the war. What nettled his critics even more was the moderate language and obvious scholarship with which he made his points.
The controversy initially simmered in Hamburg. Then the news magazine Der Spiegel reviewed his book and capsulized its conclusions in 1964. Heated arguments continued for years, although younger German historians later agreed that many of his inferences from contemporary documents had some merit.
Outside his country, Dr. Fischer became Germany's best-known living historian. The book that had caused such commotion was published in the United States as "Germany's Aims in the First World War" (Norton, 1967). Its title was a neutralized version of the German original "The Grasp for World Power," which gave a clearer idea of the author's judgment.
It challenged the traditional view that Germany, like the other great powers, stumbled into the war, and that there were those on all sides who tried to avert it or halt it before it grew into the catastrophe it became. Some modern British historians have also taken the middle view that there was enough blame to go around and that Britain had its share.
Fritz Fischer was born in Ludwigsstadt in Imperial Germany, the son of a railroad inspector. He graduated from the University of Berlin with a doctorate in theology in 1934 and a doctorate in philosophy in 1937. He taught church history in Berlin until 1939, when he joined the history faculty in Hamburg.
In World War II he served with air force ground personnel and was held prisoner two years at the war's end.
He was the author of several more books on World War I and German history and society. Over the years he was a visiting professor at universities throughout Europe, as well as the University of Notre Dame. He was a honorary member of the British Academy and the American Historical Association.
In 1942 he married Margarete Lauth-Volkmann; there was no immediate word on survivors.

HEADLINE: Victor Perlo, 87, Economist For Communist Party in U.S.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Victor Perlo, a Marxist economist whose career was damaged by accusations during the Red scare of the late 1940's and early 1950's that he spied for the Soviet Union in Washington during World War II, died Dec. 1 at his home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 87.
Mr. Perlo had difficulty finding work after his loyalty was first challenged in 1947 and then in hearings before the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1948 and the Senate Committee on Internal Security in 1953. 
 But he later developed a business as an economic consultant and university lecturer and wrote 13 books. He was known for his analysis of the political economy of American capitalism, comparative economic systems and what he called the economics of racism in the United States.
In one job after the initial accusations, Mr. Perlo worked on the campaign of Henry A. Wallace, the Progressive Party's presidential candidate in 1948.
From the 1960's until his death, Mr. Perlo, who had a master's degree in mathematics from Columbia University, served as the chief economist of the Communist Party in the United States. He was also a board member of the party.
Mr. Perlo, who worked as an economist in government agencies during the Roosevelt and Truman administrations, denied at the Washington hearings that he had spied for the Soviet Union. But like many who were questioned then by Congressional committees, he invoked the Fifth Amendment and refused to provide some answers.
During one hearing in which he sparred with Senator William E. Jenner, the Indiana Republican who led the Internal Security Committee, Mr. Perlo said he did not want to discuss his reasons for invoking his constitutional privilege. But his wife Ellen said last week that her husband had not wanted to begin a line of response that might lead to his being required to testify against others.
At the time of the hearings, Mr. Perlo said in a statement that "the dragging of my name through the mud is part of a big Roman circus."
Mr. Perlo discovered he had a security problem in 1947 when he was denied a passport he needed to become treasurer of the Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees in Europe. He had resigned a post at the Treasury Department and suddenly found himself unemployed. The next year, he was called before the House Un-American Activities Committee on the basis of a 1945 memorandum from a federal agency in which a woman who said she had been a courier between Communist espionage groups named Mr. Perlo as the head of one of the groups.
Mr. Perlo published his first book, "American Imperialism," in 1951; his most recent, "Economics of Racism II" (International Publishers), came three years ago. He taught at the New School and at the College of New Rochelle and lectured at Harvard and other universities.
Besides his wife, Mr. Perlo is survived by a daughter, Kathy, of Dundee, Scotland; two sons, Stanley of Ithaca, N.Y., and Arthur of New Haven; three grandchildren; and a great-granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Unlikely Allies With the United Nations;
For Big Companies, a Strategic Partnership Opens Doors in Developing Countries

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
When Amoco started drilling for oil in Angola a few years ago, Exxon and Chevron had already landed some of the richest oil fields and could easily outbid their smaller rival for others. Lately, though, Amoco has been the successful bidder on several oil tracts.
Why? The company, which is now BP Amoco, realized that the Angolan government, torn by civil war, was ready to favor any company that was also willing to assist with social projects. So in 1997 Amoco offered to spend $800,000 to help local fishermen revive an abandoned fishing port -- and asked the local office of the United Nations Development Program to manage the project. 
 In the last two years, Amoco and the development program have helped repair or replace about a dozen boats, equipped them with a variety of gear, and recruited a local bank to set up a loan program for the fishermen.
"We didn't know anything about fishing, or managing social projects," said Finda Koroma, then Amoco's director for commercial development and now a consultant in Houston. "Companies don't always understand what the U.N.'s development arms can do for them."
They are understanding it more and more. Across the world, huge companies that once shrugged off the United Nations as a worthy, if often ineffectually bureaucratic, do-good agency are now viewing it as a valuable partner. And the United Nations, for a change, is not only welcoming the companies help but seeking it out.
United Nations agencies rarely troll solely for money. "We are not interested in donations, but in relationships that let us tap into their expertise," said John G. Ruggie, assistant secretary general for strategic planning.
For their part, companies know that if they help the United Nations with its pet projects, it will open doors and act as a valuable buffer between them and the governments of countries in which they wish to operate. For computer and health care companies, which along with the oil companies are leading the trend toward collaboration, it is also a chance to introduce their brands to growing markets, while playing up to agencies that routinely buy their products.
All this is a huge change for the United Nations, which a few years ago was so terrified of losing its patina of impartiality that it turned down an offer from Coca-Cola to help would-be entrepreneurs in poor countries sell beverages at sporting events, lest it seem to be favoring Coke over Pepsi. The United Nations still carefully guards its neutral image; it does not promote specific companies. But now it does not turn its back, either. Instead, it solicits help from all of an industry's players.
"If we can set up a nonexclusive arrangement with a company to co-finance a project, why not?" said Mark Malloch Brown, a former World Bank vice president who has run the development program since July. "It's not like we're saying Microsoft gets Botswana, Corel gets Ghana; we're stimulating competition."
It is tempting to link the new corporate camaraderie to the United Nations' much-publicized financial problems, but it would probably have come about anyway. What had been a trickle of private-sector investment in sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, Latin America and other developing economies has become a flood.
In 1990, private sources invested just $43.6 billion in the developing world. In 1997, some $252 billion of private-sector money flowed into developing countries, compared with $77 billion from the World Bank and other public sources.
"If the U.N.'s member countries hadn't gotten past their distaste for foreign investment, we could never have done our own outreach," said Henry Jackelen, director of the development program's private-sector operation. "They realize that the companies are sources of expertise and resources they can't get elsewhere."
Corporate largess to the United Nations is not entirely new, of course. Ted Turner made headlines when he donated $1 billion of stock in 1997. And the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has designated $26 million to help Unicef wipe out tetanus in infants.
But these were philanthropic gifts by individuals whose money was derived from their industrial activities. The new trend is for companies themselves to use United Nations collaboration as a marketing tool, not just a philanthropic one.
"Of course we want to help eradicate neonatal tetanus, but we also want to stimulate the use of nonreusable injection devices, and to build relationships with ministries of health that might buy other products from us as their economies develop," said Gary M. Cohen, president of the medical systems unit of Becton Dickinson & Company. He is working with Unicef -- one of its biggest customers of syringes and other medical devices -- to distribute the company's patented disposable syringes for the same anti-tetanus program the Gates Foundation is supporting.
Nor are the companies confining their giving to their own products and expertise. Many, particularly oil companies, are contributing to United Nations programs on entrepreneurship and human rights, in hopes of promoting stability in countries with civil unrest.
Last year, for example, Chevron, which had been drilling for oil in Kazakhstan for five years, contributed $500,000 toward a business center, run by the United Nations Development Program, that helps Kazakhstanis set up new businesses. Citigroup's Citibank is in on the project, too, helping to run an operation that gives entrepreneurs small loans.
The center, which operates in the same building in the city of Atyrau as Chevron, has already yielded 19 businesses. It helped a local doctor set up a private ambulance service, and a businesswoman rent refrigerators to store and sell ice cream. Now, it is helping locals set up a bowling alley in the region, as well as Atyrau's first supermarket.
"It boils down to our desire to have a stable economic and political environment in which to operate, and to stimulate the local economy," said Philip L. Meek, president of Chevron Munaigas, Chevron's Kazakhstan operation.
Of course, companies could donate products or services without using the United Nations as a go-between. But in many parts of the world, the concept of free enterprise is so new local officials do not know where to begin.
"A bridge to the community was essential in a country that had no real grass-roots civil society before 1989," said Zoltan Valcsicsak, who handles community affairs for Levi Strauss in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Levi Strauss recently funneled $40,000 to the development program to help combat AIDS in Poland, where it has a plant.
Other executives note that United Nations officials understand the sensitivities of governments that do not want to think of themselves as backwards. "The U.N. has been in Russia a lot longer than we have," said John McKeegan, a spokesman for Johnson & Johnson, which recently elicited the development program's help in setting up an educational program for cardiologists in Moscow.
Similarly, Reza Ghaffari, who runs Citibank's offices in Kazakhstan, notes that the development program encouraged local entrepreneurs to take group loans, on the theory that peer pressure would go far in encouraging all members to repay their shares. "We could have just donated the money without bothering to insist on a sustainable initiative," Mr. Ghaffari said, "but this approach will have a greater impact on the community."
And, perhaps the United Nations' most powerful lure of all is that it provides an administrative backbone for projects that companies would just as soon not undertake alone. "Private industry really doesn't have the expertise to run community programs," said Anne Krisitin Sydnes, a vice president of Statoil, the big Norwegian oil company, which hooked up with the development program and Amnesty International last year for a project to train Venezuelan judges on how to deal with human rights issues.
Conversely, the United Nations rarely has the expertise to pull nascent economies into the Internet age. Take the development program's NetAid project, which was kicked off with benefit concerts in New Jersey, London and Geneva on Oct. 9. Unlike Farm Aid and similar fund-raising concerts, NetAid was not a one-shot deal; the development program convinced numerous Internet-related companies that it was to their benefit to help it use the concerts to publicize www.netaid.org, a Web site the development program hopes to parlay into a matchmaking tool for corporations and countries.
Cisco Systems, a major provider of the routers, switches and other equipment that powers the Internet, provided much of the marketing, as well as the technology to enable millions of people to tap into the concerts online. Cisco, in turn, persuaded the accounting and consulting firm KPMG, which it partly owns, to design the Web page. And it persuaded Akamai, a year-old technology company, to contribute its expertise in easing Internet logjams. "It seemed a terrific way to showcase our technology," said an executive at Akamai, which recently went public.
Even so, high-technology involvement is not ending with NetAid. Orientation.com, a New York-based company that runs an advertising-supported network of Internet portals in 20 countries, is providing material for portals that the development program wants to run in an additional 31 countries. "The U.N.D.P. gives us contact with their partners in new countries, and with information that we can use on our other portals," said Tamara Bekefi, a project manager at Orientation .com.
Corel, a software company based in Ottawa, is contributing a suite of business-oriented software for the development program to use in its effort to set up Internet systems in developing countries. Corel's software runs on the Linux operating system, which can be downloaded free from the Internet, and the company is betting that if Web novices get used to Linux now, they are less likely to flock to Windows later. Indeed, Corel has thrown Netscape Navigator, a prime competitor to Microsoft's Internet Explorer, into its package.
"Microsoft is still the clear No. 1, and if we can foster brand loyalty early on, maybe we can level the playing field," said Michael Cowpland, Corel's chief executive.
Other computer companies have similar aims. Rebel.com, a Canadian hardware company that Corel partly owns, believes that computers operated by a free system like Linux are likely to sell well in poorer countries. "Our investment is not under the veil of philanthropy," said Michael Mansfield, president of Rebel.com, which is contributing about $250,000 worth of computers. "It is coming out of our marketing budget."
Such strategic thinking is starting to pervade some United Nations agencies themselves. The Population Fund, which distributes contraceptives in developing countries, is setting up meetings between drug executives and officials in Egypt and India, in hopes of helping the companies overcome high tariffs and other barriers to selling contraceptives there. And the fund expects to set up a Web-based system eventually, one in which governments can buy contraceptives at prices the fund has negotiated.
"We aren't even asking for product donations," said Corrie Shanahan, a spokeswoman for the fund. So why bother? "If the companies sell contraceptives to the middle classes in those countries, it will free up our supply for poor people."
