HEADLINE: U.S. Is Trying To Put Teeth In Inspections Of Iraq Arms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 10

 BODY:
As disagreements between the United States and Russia continue to delay action on a new arms-inspection plan for Iraq, independent disarmament experts are divided over how important it is to try to put in place an airtight monitoring system if the cost is Security Council unity against President Saddam Hussein.
The council today put off a vote on the inspection plan until Monday, at the request of China, which, along with Russia, has reservations. But council members did extend the "oil for food" program in Iraq for six months. 
 "This is really a case where the best is the enemy of the good," said Spurgeon M. Keeny Jr., president of the Arms Control Association, a research organization in Washington that publishes Arms Control Today. "Obviously the best would be to get rid of the Iraqi regime and find every last piece of equipment that accumulated before the gulf war or since. But we can't get international support for that."
Mr. Keeny, a former deputy director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, advises Washington to be flexible where possible to gain consensus, then "claim victory and get on with perfecting the continued inspection regime."
He spoke in an interview today as American and British diplomats spent another day trying to narrow differences with Russia, China and, on some points, France, to avoid a Russian veto of the resolution for a new-weapons monitoring commission for Iraq. Iraq has not had international inspections for a year.
A Russian veto would kill the plan, leaving in place economic sanctions on Iraq that may become increasingly unenforceable. A Russian abstention would advertise council divisions, a boon to Iraq.
The Russians argue that if -- a big if -- Iraq is judged to be cooperating with a new system to be installed by the proposed United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission and the International Atomic Energy Agency within a given period of time or has met a predetermined list of tasks, then sanctions should be suspended while inspection work goes on.
The United States wants the inspectors to list tasks to be accomplished after, not before, they begin work on the ground. In the past, those demands on the Iraqis have included providing documents, allowing interviews with Iraqi officials or opening new sites to inspectors.
The Russians and French complain that the wording in the resolution, introduced formally today by the British, is not clear enough about what the Iraqis are expected to do and is an invitation for Americans to move the finish line at will.
The American representative, Peter Burleigh, disagreed, saying three paragraphs in the resolutions made it "very clear what needs to be done." He called the draft now being considered "an artful and constructive way of dealing with some difference of opinion in the council."
But attempts to juggle wording to prevent a Russian veto worry David Albright, president of the independent Institute for Science and International Security in Washington and a former nuclear inspector in Iraq. He noted as an example that an earlier provision that suggested that experts could be drawn from Unscom, the previous inspection commission, had been stripped from the final draft.
"Taking out that language is certainly a warning," Mr. Albright said. "There are enough questions in the resolution that the next steps are going to be critically important in determining the effectiveness of the inspection regime: 'Who will be the head of the commission? Will Unmovic the inspection team have sufficient experience to conduct inspections? Will their decisions be constantly second-guessed by Security Council members, who will have authority to approve or disapprove the inspectors' work plans?"
Richard Butler, former executive chairman of the inspection team, said the resolution seemed to give the new commission far less independence than he had. "Its head will be supervised by what can only be called a political board," he said.
The College of Commissioners intended to oversee the commission will have the right to review all its policy decisions.
"The mandate seems right," Mr. Butler added. "But the instrument through which it is to be achieved has been made far less independent." aid.
The creation of a singular disarmament commission as a policy tool is an interesting experiment, Ruth Wedgwood, a law professor at Yale said. "When Unscom was founded, it was a brilliantly new form of multidimensional verification," she said. "But the experiment is somewhat spoiled already, because any future target of an Unscom inspection could take heart from Iraq's success in breaking up the Security Council alliance."

HEADLINE: Sisyphus of the Sneaker Makers

BYLINE: BySHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Things looked promising at the Reebok store on Manhattan's Upper West Side last Saturday. Dozens of screaming teenagers stood outside waiting to get in. Inside, younger children scrambled amid the milling adults as music pulsed and members of the Harlem Globetrotters basketball team signed autographs.
All the hoopla surrounded the introduction of Traxtar, a children's shoe with a computer chip to help measure athletic performance. But most of the screaming adolescents were there to see No Authority, a pop music group, and few of the people attending the promotion were wearing Reebok sneakers -- or planning to buy any. 
 The scene highlights the problems facing Reebok International, once the nation's premier sneaker maker and now the laggard in this country's large but stagnant $13.8 billion athletic-footwear industry.
Through the introduction of the Traxtar and a campaign for an updated version of its stalwart Classic sneakers, Reebok is trying yet again to regain cachet with consumers and reverse a decline in market share that has continued for a decade.
The company could use a boost. It has slipped to No. 3 in the world market, steadily losing market share over the decade to Nike, the market leader, and to reinvigorated brands like Adidas (now No. 2 worldwide).
But its strategy is a big gamble, because Reebok is seemingly writing off the huge and important teenage market to distinguish itself from Nike.
While adolescents and young adults make up about 42 percent of the athletic footwear market, they are more likely than their parents to buy several pairs of sneakers and to buy the latest top-of-the-line models, at more than $150 a pair. And their imprimatur can often make or break a brand.
"We're focusing on innovation and luxury," said Paul Fireman, chairman of Reebok, which also makes Reebok brand apparel and accessories as well as Rockport, Polo/Ralph Lauren and Greg Norman footwear and apparel. "Fashion has moved from the hokey-looking products to more streamlined" styles, he added. And Reebok is betting that its Classic styles will strike a chord with fashionable feet of all ages.
As for coolness, "We stopped trying to chase that," said Angel R. Martinez, chief marketing officer of the Reebok division, which accounts for 80 percent of the company's revenue. "We were able to establish footwear as the badge of a lifestyle; that's what we're really going back to," he said, recalling the company's early success as it cashed in on the shift to casual footwear and the aerobics craze of the 1980's.
That success, however, was followed by a string of unsuccessful strategies in the 1990's that were intended to fend off rivals. First, hefty spending on celebrity endorsements failed and Reebok's performance footwear was unpopular. The company refocused on women's shoes in 1992 but lost out to more fashionable competitors. A new technology in 1997 suffered from poor marketing and unattractive styling.
After a decade of missteps, missed opportunities and management shakeups, few analysts are convinced that the company's newest initiatives will pull Reebok out of its slump. What the company needs, they say, is a consistent message.
"The problem with Reebok is that they've gotten very excited about a number of products over the years," but the company's efforts have not always translated into strong sales, said Josie Esquivel of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "They were losing market share during the growth of the industry," Ms. Esquivel added. "They're not perceived as being cool and having their act together."
Last year, Reebok's earnings fell 82 percent, to $23.9 million from $135.1 million in 1997. Sales, which have been declining since 1995, were down 11.5 percent last year, to $3.2 billion. Its profit margin also plunged, down more than 80 percent, to seven-tenths of 1 percent. And the company's shares have lost more than 80 percent of their value in the last three years, closing at $8 yesterday. Its 12 percent share in the world market put it behind Nike, with 33 percent, and Adidas of Germany, with about 16 percent. In the United States, it was still in second place, behind Nike, but its market share has been falling.
And when Nike faltered in 1998, because of Asia's economic slump and as teenagers deemed the styles uncool, Reebok was unable to gain ground, as other competitors, including New Balance, did.
In the first nine months of 1999, sales were $2.28 billion, down 9.6 percent from a year earlier. In September, as part of a restructuring, Reebok laid off 120 employees at its headquarters in Stoughton, Mass., and announced plans to cut an additional 500 jobs around the world -- a total of nearly 10 percent of its work force. Cuts were also made last year.
While industry sales in the United States are forecast to fall slightly this year before rising in 2000, several competitors, including Nike and New Balance, are expected to gain market share. Reebok could end up tied with New Balance Athletic Shoe, with about 8 percent of the United States market, said John Shanley, an analyst with First Security Van Kasper. He estimates that Nike will have about 50 percent, followed by Adidas, with 10 percent.
And just last week, Carl J. Yankowski, who had been president and chief executive of the Reebok division for only 15 months, resigned to return to the technology industry. Mr. Fireman is taking over his duties and few analysts expect Mr. Yankowski's departure to deeply affect Reebok's fortunes. The departure is, however, the latest in a series of recent management changes and another example of the problems Reebok must overcome.
Things were not always so bad.
In 1987, propelled by the women's aerobic fitness craze, Reebok overtook Nike as the largest athletic footwear company in America.
But the companies' positions reversed again in 1989, and in the last few years Reebok has been unable to increase shelf space with retailers. Some styles were deemed unattractive. Analysts complain -- and the company acknowledges -- that Reebok has no uniform message or concise marketing campaign.
Reebok was forced to back away from its efforts to emulate Nike's success through a focus on competitive sports and celebrity endorsements, ending costly contracts with many athletes, including Shaquille O'Neal.
Analysts say that Reebok's DMX performance technology, which puts moving air in the sole for added comfort, was a good one. But while DMX, introduced in 1997, was popular in running shoes, the company could not transfer that success across product lines. Reebok also had difficulty getting professional athletes to switch to their products.
Oversaturation from its focus on mass-market retailers like Sears, Roebuck and J. C. Penney caused Reebok to become victim to heavy discounting. The company also lost credibility with speciality retailers like Foot Locker and among teenagers.
"Kids don't want to shop at a J. C. Penney," said John Horan, publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, an industry newsletter. "And Foot Locker doesn't want that stuff if it's all over the place."
In addition, niche players like Saucony and K-Swiss have hurt Reebok's Classic program with their clean, simple styles at similar prices -- $50 to $80.
But Reebok officials are betting that the Traxtar and new Classic designs will build on the success it has had with products like its Allen Iverson basketball shoe and Polo/ Ralph Lauren lines.
The Traxtar uses a microprocessor and motion detection technology to measure how fast children run and how high and how far they jump. Lights on an oval pod on the tongue of the shoe glow and music is played as performance is measured.
"As we look at the kids' marketplace, it's becoming more interactive," said Matt Feiner, director of children's footwear global product marketing. "We wanted to be the first to bring it into footwear."
Reebok said it would spend about $6 million to market Traxtar in 2000, triple what it is spending on children's shoes this year.
The company hopes the Traxtar, which will sell for around $60 a pair, will be just the beginning of a new line of "smart shoes" for children and adults. Plans are being considered, for example, for a walking shoe with a built-in chip to measure distance and speed.
The new campaign for Classics will begin in early 2000. Reebok plans to position the line as stylish, well made and upscale, with ads in publications like Vogue, In Style and GQ.
The Classics, long known as a simply styled white sneaker, will come in more colors and a modified design, and will be made of nubuck -- a brushed leather -- as well as soft leather. The company hopes the updated styles will encourage sales of Reebok apparel as well as catch the eye of teenagers.
To push the line, Reebok will spend about $15 million on print and billboard ads next year. Company executives say Reebok has never before spent more than $1 million a year on the line.
The company is also planning a new basketball shoe, called Blacktop, and a new fitness shoe for women with DMX technology, later next year.
Wall Street remains unconvinced that Reebok has found a winning path.
Some dismiss the Traxtar as a fad.
And technology, they say, is not what sells sneakers.
"Reebok has this DMX technology, but nobody cares," said Allison Malone, an analyst with Off the Record Research, an investment research company based in San Francisco. "The biggest demographic, these teenagers, they only care about fashion."
"Classics have a following among older ladies," Ms. Malone added. "They're going to have to appeal to a larger base."
Then there's the competition.
Adidas as well as smaller companies like New Balance and K-Swiss have made inroads in the children's and sports performance market.
And earlier this month Nike introduced Nikeid, which the company calls an "interactive, design-a-shoe experience." Customers can use the Internet to order two models of customized sneakers, choosing the shoe color and adding a nametag.
Reebok is a financially strong company with high brand recognition. But if its products do not excite more consumers, analysts warn, it will continue to lose credibility.
"How many lives do they have?" Ms. Esquivel asked. "Winning back is a lot harder than starting off fresh."

HEADLINE: Xerox Says Its Earnings Will Tumble

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation stunned investors yesterday by announcing after the market closed that its fourth-quarter earnings would be about 40 percent lower than analysts had expected.
Shares of Xerox closed at $20.0625, a 14 percent drop, and continued skidding in after-hours trading. 
 The company's chief executive, G. Richard Thoman, blamed the disappointment on a range of problems, including Year 2000 computer fears that have caused customers to suspend capital investments, an internal reorganization that Xerox has struggled with and economic troubles in Brazil.
The combination, he told analysts yesterday, "has surprised us."
More broadly, the announcement by the company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., raises concerns about Xerox's attempt to transform itself from a company making freestanding copiers into one that sells digital printers connected to computer networks.
Doing so requires that Xerox reorganize to focus more on service and outsourcing and that it compete against both longtime rivals like Canon -- which is now doing well -- and new ones like Hewlett-Packard.
So far, analysts said yesterday, the company has failed to accomplish everything at once.
"It obviously seems like there are some very severe problems within the company," said Benjamin A. Reitzes, an analyst at PaineWebber. Over the last year, Xerox's shares have lost more than two-thirds of their value, falling from a high of $63.9375 on May 3.
Yesterday's announcement comes on the heels of a poor third quarter in which Xerox's net profits declined by 11 percent, to $339 million, and analysts lowered their expectations for fourth-quarter earnings to 66 cents a share, from an original high of 92 cents. Mr. Thoman now thinks the company will earn closer to 40 cents a share in the fourth quarter.
In recent months, Mr. Reitzes said, "Every problem seems to have gotten worse."
The trouble is not likely to end with this century, either. "The first quarter won't be a lot better than what we now see," Mr. Thoman said, noting that many of the problems will linger. He added, however, that Xerox's profits should start to recover in the second quarter and continue to do so throughout 2000.
By their very nature, Year 2000 worries will soon end. Many economists believe Brazil will begin to recover as well, and Mr. Thoman said the company's reorganized structure would soon begin to overcome its initial problems.
But analysts seemed unwilling to give Mr. Thoman and his management much benefit of the doubt. During yesterday's conference call, analysts chastised Mr. Thoman for not coming clean about problems sooner, wondered whether the future would hold more unpleasant surprises and complained that he did not talk to Wall Street often enough.
Mr. Thoman took over the top job in April, after leaving I.B.M. in 1997 to become Xerox's heir apparent to Paul A. Allaire, its chairman.
About 20 percent of the earnings shortfall will come from higher-than-expected costs from the company's consolidation of its 36 administrative centers into just 3, Mr. Thoman said. Because Xerox did not dedicate enough people to handling the change, sales representatives -- who are also in the midst of their own shift from covering a geographic area to covering specific industries -- have spent too much time dealing with internal matters.
Xerox is now making "a full-court press" to fix the administrative problems, Mr. Thoman said yesterday.
At the same time, it is trying to shift toward businesses that are growing by at least 10 percent a year, such as the outsourcing of managing documents. Twenty-five percent of Xerox's revenue now comes from such industries; by the end of 2000, the portion should rise to 45 percent, the company said.
Despite the problems, Mr. Thoman said Xerox had little choice but to try such wide-ranging change. "The market is moving quickly," he told analysts. "Customers are not going to wait for us."

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
When all the religions of the world are truly global, some old issues assume new forms.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Globalization: it's a curious contraption of a word, a noun built on a verb, globalize, built on an adjective, global, built on a noun, globe. By now, however, the word not only rolls around rather easily in the mouth; it has also become irreplaceable for discussing the kind of issues that brought demonstrators to the streets in Seattle a week ago. It is also a notion applicable to religion.
The Parliament of the World's Religions, which drew thousands of religious leaders to Cape Town between Dec. 1 and Dec. 8, was a colorful reminder of religious globalization. The original such parliament was held in 1893 in Chicago, in connection with the World's Columbian Exposition. A hundred years later it was repeated, and now its organizers, based in Chicago, plan to make it a perennial event. 
 When the 6,000 participants were not hearing speakers like Nelson Mandela and the Dalai Lama, they were enjoying something like a global religious fair, rushing back and forth to hundreds of workshops and discussions. As in Seattle, there were even a few demonstrators, in this case denouncing the whole affair as satanic and, of all unlikely things, ridden with Zionists. But like the World Trade Organization's meeting, the parliament was only one manifestation of a process that is irreversibly under way.
The world's great faiths have always interacted, of course. They sent missionaries, they borrowed ideas, they adopted rituals. They even absorbed and transformed deities. And they fought wars. Sometimes they imitated one another, sometimes they defined themselves in contrast to one another.
But this usually happened when religions were neighbors geographically, or when a religion expanded through migration or conquest, or when one faith had emerged from another, like Christianity from Judaism or Buddhism from the brahmanism of Northern India, or simply when a few mobile and spiritually inquiring individuals cross-pollinated beliefs.
Just as economic globalization is of a completely different order than traditional overseas commerce, today's religious globalization barely resembles these earlier interactions among faiths.
Today, world religions are truly world religions. Every major faith is everywhere, represented by migrant populations or native converts, its beliefs and sacred texts available, at least in introductory form, to virtually any curious seeker. Pope John Paul II, the Rev. Billy Graham and the Dalai Lama are world figures with followings far beyond their own religious groups.
The very fact that marking the millennium has become a global event is suggestive. Even the most secular celebration cannot entirely erase the religious origins of a calendar that is now implanted in the daily life of historically non-Christian cultures.
But this free flow of religions, like free trade in cotton, computers and currencies, has created its own issues and added new twists to older ones. Many of the issues can be grouped under three headings: turf, tolerance and truth. But in fact they are all interrelated.
Turf is the most ancient of these concerns, the one that endures despite the fact -- and maybe because of the fact -- that barriers to religious alternatives are increasingly harder to maintain. Russian Orthodox leaders protest that Russia is their turf and everyone else is a religious intruder. Roman Catholic leaders often sound much the same way about Latin America. Hindus protest Christian conversions; Islam does the same. Orthodox Judaism claims prior rights in Israel.
Of course, there are opinions within each group challenging this religious equivalent of protectionism. There are vitally important distinctions, moreover, among religious bodies and leaders regarding the lengths to which they will go to protect their turf. There is a growing international lobby against religious persecution. There are advocates of an unrestricted religious marketplace who argue that rigorous competition makes faith stronger, not weaker. And there are also cautionary voices, in the religious sphere as in the economic one, warning that American standards, in this case of church-state separation, cannot be universalized.
Obviously the question of turf is linked to the question of tolerance. In principle, almost everyone favors tolerance. In practice, it can be more difficult to uphold and, sometimes, even to define.
Certainly one of the premises of the Parliament of the World's Religions was that tolerance, if it is to be more than a prolonged truce in religious warfare, requires real respect for one another's traditions, reflected in a willingness to engage in dialogue and cooperate in serving humanity and the environment.
That raises the issue of truth. To some people, genuine respect and tolerance are incompatible with claims that "I have the truth and you don't." To others, the demand that "I abandon my claims to the truth in the name of tolerance" is the very essence of intolerance.
In reality, religious globalization has already dramatically modified the way claims of religious truth are commonly made. Believers today are far less likely than before to deny all the truth in other faiths. The question becomes not true versus false religion, but which faith has the fuller truth, the more adequate grasp on a dimension of reality that will always remain mysterious.
That, of course, still conflicts with the conviction that every religion must be viewed as equally true, and that nothing less can be the basis of genuine respect and tolerance. But to propose that principle as the basis of religious globalization would probably arouse more opposition and outrage than anything the World Trade Organization ever dreamed of.

HEADLINE: TURKEY IS INVITED TO APPLY FOR SEAT IN EUROPEAN UNION

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The European Union today accepted Turkey as a candidate for membership, reversing a thumbs-down vote two years ago, which was based mainly on Turkey's human rights record.
Membership, which is probably many years down the road, would mark the entry of the first Muslim country to the European Union. Turkey, which has long sought closer ties to Europe, is already a member of NATO. 
 The economic and political union also agreed to a plan to bring in more of the formerly Communist nations of Eastern and Central Europe, in the latest step to expand to the borders of Russia.
Alarm over Russian moves in Chechnya colored the summit conference of the 15-nation bloc in Helsinki. The national leaders put out a statement condemning the bombardment of cities in the territory as "totally unacceptable" and threatening to cut assistance to Moscow.
The statement said the European Union would review its common strategy on Russia, apply trade terms more strictly, suspend some provisions of a partnership agreement and shift funds from a technical program to "humanitarian needs" created by the crisis.
Turkey readily welcomed the European offer. "There might be details we find hard to accept," Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit said in Ankara, "but in general the acceptance of our candidate status on equal conditions is a great success for Turkey."
Though Turkey has pursued European validation for years, it balked at some of the terms for its admittance today, and Javier Solana, the union's new foreign policy chief, was sent to Ankara to clarify them. "I'm going there just to explain what has been agreed by the E.U. summit," he said on leaving Helsinki.
To join, Turkey will have to make sweeping political and economic reforms and abolish its death penalty. Its neighbor Greece lately indicated its willingness to reconsider allowing Turkey to join it in the union.
Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen of Finland, current holder of the organization's rotating presidency, expressed hopes for a positive response and said Mr. Ecevit had been invited to the concluding lunch of the summit conference here on Saturday.
Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Malta were the countries gaining preliminary consideration for membership today. They fall into line behind six others already negotiating entry -- Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Poland and Slovenia.
It will be at least three years before the first of them becomes a full member, and it may be decades before all of them are admitted. Under the new plan, the union will expand to 28 member states by 2025, representing a population of 500 million.
While the requirement to improve its human rights record and enact social and political reforms is likely to make Turkey one of the later entrants, today's decision is considered significant for symbolizing a break with a long history of stereotyping of Turks as un-European.
The United States criticized the Europeans for spurning Turkey, a strategically located Muslim NATO ally, at the Euopean Union's summit meeting in Luxembourg in 1997. President Clinton called on the leaders to undo the offense when he visited Greece and Turkey last month.
It appeared that conditions sought by Greece might have given Ankara pause in accepting the invitation. Of particular concern to the Greeks was a provision under consideration saying the two countries should steer their Aegean border disputes to the International Court of Justice.
The overall mood of the conference, once envisioned as a conclusive, forward-looking pre-millennial gathering, was soured by disputes over France's defiance of the European Commission's lifting of the ban on British beef and Britain's objections to a 20 percent withholding tax on offshore investments favored by the other members.
"There has been some tough talk," Prime Minister Lipponen said in a grim news conference this evening. "Our discussions were not at all diplomatic in their language."
Barely mentioned in today's account of the meeting's accomplishments was the approval of the new European rapid reaction force that was once considered a centerpiece of the gathering. A European Security and Defense Initiative calling for such a force was adopted after a brief debate and some minor changes to the program put together by the alliance's principal military powers, Britain and France.
Washington, which at the beginning of the decade expressed interest in Europe's taking on military responsibility for regional conflicts, more recently expressed anxiety at a European force's potential to overlap with and detract from NATO.
Trying to address that concern, but leaving the matter vague, the summit declaration said, "The objective is for the union to have the autonomous capacity to take decisions and, where NATO as a whole is not engaged, to launch and then to conduct E.U.-led military operations in response to international crises."
The 60,000-member crisis response force is to be ready by 2003. The plan also calls for a separate military staff and a permanent political and security committee.
There has been a growing consensus -- especially since the war in Kosovo -- that Europe needs to restructure its military and build up its muscle. But many of the same nations have been cutting their own military outlays.

HEADLINE: Iraq Rules Out a Visit by the Pope; Political Factors Are Cited

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In the first major setback to Pope John Paul II's ambitious travel plans for the millennium, the Vatican said today that Iraq had ruled out a planned papal visit.
The 79-year-old Roman Catholic leader, who has long dreamed of visiting major biblical sites in 2000, had badly wanted to stop in Ur, an ancient city in Iraq believed to be the birthplace of Abraham. 
 But Vatican diplomats were unable to reach an agreement with Iraqi officials over a visit that the pope viewed as a strictly religious pilgrimage, but that was fraught with political overtones for both President Saddam Hussein and the United States, which had lobbied against the visit, fearing that it could lend legitimacy to the Iraqi leader.
Perhaps in the hope that a visit to Ur could yet be resurrected, Vatican officials gave a carefully neutral explanation today of how their diplomacy with Baghdad broke down.
"Iraqi authorities have informed the secretariat of state that the abnormal conditions in which Iraq finds itself due to the embargo and the no-flight zone, as well as the general situation in the region, do not permit a visit by the Holy Father to Ur to be organized properly," the Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said in a statement.
The United Nations imposed the embargo in 1990 after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. American and British planes have patrolled no-flight zones in north and south Iraq since 1991.
Before today's announcement, a senior Vatican official explained privately that the Iraqis appeared preoccupied with the idea that the pope, by asking the United Nations to permit his plane to fly into Iraq, would in some way legitimize the sanctions.
The Vatican official said its envoys in Baghdad had explained that the pope would not ask for permission, but would merely inform the United Nations of his travel plans. But even though the pope has often condemned the sanctions, that argument failed to reassure Iraqi officials.
The Iraqi government may also have feared that during his trip, the pope would preach about human rights, as he does in almost every country he visits. Baghdad gave a strong hint of its concerns last fall, in a letter by Iraqi intellectuals published by the state news agency, which lectured the pope on what he should say during his visit, and expressed reservations about his message to Christians in a predominantly Muslim culture.
Vatican officials let it be known that they were offended by the letter.
American and British official visitors to the Vatican had lobbied against the trip, fearing that a papal meeting with Mr. Hussein would break the isolation imposed on Iraq. But the Vatican, which rejected those overtures as unwarranted interference in its affairs, was ultimately unable to overcome Baghdad's misgivings.
But in Iraq, where preparations for the visit to Ur had already begun,Catholic officials expressed their belief that the trip had only been postponed, not canceled.
Patriarch Raphael I Bidawid of the Chaldean Church told the Vatican's missionary news service, Fides, that concerns about the pope's security had put off the visit.
The pope plans to visit the Holy Land in March, but there are lingering questions about his trip to Nazareth, where the Catholic Church is opposed to the building of a mosque next to the city's main Catholic shrine.

HEADLINE: Deep in the Wilderness, a Growth Industry Is Blooming

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY with BARRY MEIER 

DATELINE: BERYL, Utah, Dec. 7

 BODY:
For parents like Mitchell and Jill Friedman of Great Neck, N.Y., the decision to enroll a child in a wilderness program for troubled teenagers is born of desperation, a last chance to rescue a life endangered by drugs, crime or simply aimlessness. In the Friedmans' case, the outcome was worth the anguish.
"It's wonderful -- I'm crying," Mr. Friedman said today at the graduation of his son, Jeffrey, from the Redcliff Ascent Outdoor Therapy Program. "The last year has been hell. Every day he was out of school, on the streets, somewhere, we were terrified. When we got him here, we finally breathed easier." 
 Jeffrey had just spent 83 days in the desert here in southwestern Utah, in a minimalist world without music, television or cellular phones. Like other wilderness therapy programs, Redcliff tries to strip away bad habits, build character and restore self-esteem by forcing teenagers to fend for themselves and one another through a daily routine of hiking, campfire-building, food preparation and latrine-digging, as well as high school course work. Counselors lead the participants through quiet periods of introspection each day, and psychiatrists and psychologists visit once a week to measure progress.
The satisfaction of people like the Friedmans notwithstanding, wilderness therapy has not been entirely trouble-free. In a widely publicized episode last Saturday, eight Redcliff boys attacked two counselors and fled into the desert. And over the last 10 years, at least four teenagers have died in such programs. Further, some experts question whether the approach provides any long-lasting benefits to wayward youths, contending that the results of "shocking" them with outdoor hardships quickly wear off when they return to their homes and, frequently, renew old habits with old friends.
But the successes have apparently been common enough to make this a growth industry. While the concept of wilderness therapy is hardly new -- the Dallas Salesmanship Club opened one of the first such camps for troubled youth 51 years ago -- it has exploded in recent years. Where there were once just a few scattered operations around the country, there are now hundreds of companies, most of them in Western states.
In large measure, the experts say, the programs' popularity stems from a growing inability of public schools to deal with severe behavioral problems or to identify signs of alienation that lead to drug use or violence. More families are seeking alternative solutions, and the robust national economy has enabled many to afford them. (Redcliff charges as much as $350 a day, and some teenagers stay for two months or more.) State and local courts also use the programs, as an alternative to jail.
No one knows the precise number of such programs, or the industry's rate of success. So many of the programs are new, their services are provided in varied settings, and no scientific survey has ever tried to measure their effectiveness.
But Mark Sklarow, executive director of the Independent Educational Consultants Association, a nonprofit company in Fairfax, Va., that helps families find solutions for their troubled children, said the number of programs had grown to "several hundred," compared with fewer than 25 less than a decade ago.
Typically a camp's population has swollen as well. Mitch Cole, manager of the Redcliff administrative office here, said that as recently as five years ago, only 16 teenagers were enrolled in the program on any given day. Now as many as 64 are participating.
"Working with children at risk is really a growth industry," said Helene Reynolds, an educational consultant in Princeton, N.J., who has recommended wilderness therapy programs, including Redcliff, to her clients. (One of those clients, she said, was the family of a boy involved in the assault on the counselors last Saturday.)
The rapid growth has brought a hodgepodge of oversight. There is no national regulation of the industry, and regulation by the states varies widely. Two industry organizations are engaged in accrediting or monitoring therapeutic wilderness programs for health, safety and program content, but one, the Association of Experiential Education, a trade group in Boulder, Colo., has accredited only 7 of the 165 of its members that offer some form of therapy. And the other, the National Association of Therapeutic Schools and Programs, in Savannah, Ga., which was formed in January, has yet to develop any standards, although it is working with 67 programs in 26 states.
Jerry Wells, executive director of the Koch Crime Institute, a research organization in Topeka, Kan., said that while the outward appearances were different, the underlying philosophy of wilderness programs was the same as that of military-style boot camps.
"The basic premise is that the lack of discipline and structure in their life has led them to bad decisions," Mr. Wells said of the participants. "Therefore, if you provide them with the structure, it will lead them to better decisions."
Mr. Cole, of Redcliff, conceded that wilderness programs were once typically run by people who had more of a military background than experience in therapy work. It was not uncommon, he said, to hear stories of youths' being treated as if they were attending boot camp.
But now, he said, Utah and most other states have strict health and safety regulations against the use of physical force, hazing or food deprivation as a means of discipline. A misbehaving Redcliff teenager who violates the rules by cursing will most likely be punished by having to carry a small rock on the next hike.
"That way, there's a constant reminder of breaking the rule," Mr. Cole said. "It also teaches you that there are consequences to your actions."
Nonetheless, in the last decade four teenagers, three of them in Utah, have died at wilderness camps because of mistreatment or abuse, said Bob MacDougall, who licenses the programs for the Utah Department of Human Services. The last of the Utah deaths occurred in 1994, he added, and all three companies involved in those deaths are now out of business.
Catherine Sutton of Ripon, Calif., whose daughter, Michelle, died nine years ago after a week in a Utah wilderness program called Summit Quest, said counselors had accused Michelle of faking flulike symptoms. Her death was attributed to dehydration.
And after Nicholaus Contreraz, 16, died of a lung infection last year at the Arizona Boys Ranch in Oracle, Ariz., his family won a $1 million settlement of a wrongful-death lawsuit that claimed he had been a victim of physical abuse at the hands of his counselors.
Like many other wilderness programs, Redcliff teaches its lessons of respect, compassion and self-esteem against a tableau of uninterrupted weeks, or even months, of hiking and camping through 580 square miles of rugged desert in southwestern Utah, where nighttime temperatures in winter routinely fall below 10 degrees.
The campers are sent out with only necessities: clothes appropriate for the time of year, sleeping gear and food, which they prepare for themselves and consume with utensils they carve out of tree branches. They dig their own latrines.
A Walkman? A portable radio? Forget it. Not even a wristwatch is allowed.
Rules are strictly enforced, and they include taboos against cursing, sarcasm and any questions about time beyond the present.
Program officials say they have found that the spartan regimen, which stresses teamwork over individualism and provides time for intense personal introspection through individual and group therapy, is the most direct way to save a wayward life.
Mr. Cole said that through follow-up interviews with parents six months after graduation, Redcliff officials estimated their success rate at 70 to 80 percent.
Jeffrey Friedman, who acknowledged that before he entered the program his life in Great Neck had collapsed into daily use of marijuana and indifference toward school, said he now easily recognized the parallel between working with a group in the wild and getting along with his parents and two older sisters.
"I learned a lot more about how things I did affected the group, like they affected my family," he said. "In the group, you have to work together. I realized that at home I was acting selfishly, and it brought down the whole family."
Todd Chavin of Evanston, Ill., also graduated today. His parents, Scott and Judy Chavin, stared at him in near-disbelief when he said, "I don't feel like Todd anymore."
"I've truly changed," he added. "I feel totally different. I'm happy again. I don't want to go home and smoke dope with my friends; I want to move on with my life and become a man."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Orosco Returns to Mets In a Trade for McElroy

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Less than an hour after he arrived on the scene, Steve Phillips struck. The general manager who a year ago brought the Mets Robin Ventura, Armando Benitez and Roger Cedeno pulled off the first trade of baseball's winter meetings today. But Jesse Orosco will not replace the offensive production that John Olerud took to Seattle.
Yes, Jesse Orosco is coming home. The Mets, with whom the 42-year-old relief pitcher began life as a major leaguer, got him back by trading Chuck McElroy to the Baltimore Orioles. But the swap will not rival the one that will send Ken Griffey Jr. closer to home. Wherever that is, whenever that happens. 
 This was an exchange of left-handed relievers who have had better seasons than they had last season. Orosco had a 5.34 earned run average in 65 games and walked 20 batters in 32 innings, but he also struck out 35. McElroy, whom the Mets obtained from Colorado last July 31, had a 5.50 e.r.a. in 56 games, though he was better with the Mets, at 3.38 in 15 appearances.
"It's going to be different," Orosco said in a conference call, commenting on his return to the Mets 12 years after they traded him to Los Angeles. Referring to an interleague game at Shea Stadium, he added: "When I went there two years ago, it was tingling. I was nervous. This will be different. I'll be in a Mets uniform."
Orosco, who gained a career-high 31 saves in a Mets uniform in 1984 and was a postseason hero in 1986, had to approve the trade as a player who has 10 years in the majors, including the last 5 with the same team. He said he approved it because he liked the makeup of the Mets. But he also approved it because he did not want to pitch for the Orioles' new manager, Mike Hargrove, who was Orosco's manager in Cleveland nearly a decade ago.
After Phillips announced the trade, he was asked -- jokingly -- if his work at the meetings was done. "Obviously," he said, laughing, "we have a lot to do. We're going to be very busy here."
Phillips's primary goals are to replace Olerud at first base and to add hitting. While at the five-day meetings, he will talk to agents for several free agents, including first basemen David Segui and David Nilsson and outfielder Greg Vaughn.
Vaughn's agent said Thursday that the Mets were seriously interested in his client, who hit 95 home runs the past two seasons, but that the Mets had not made an offer.
One player the Mets will not acquire is Carlos Delgado. The Toronto Blue Jays signed Delgado, their first baseman, today, giving him $36 million for three years. He had rejected their previous offer of $12 million a year for five years, and they had rejected his request for $38.25 million for three years.
Delgado, who last season hit 44 home runs and drove in 134 runs, accepted less money because the Blue Jays added a provision that will allow him to demand a trade after next season. If he makes such a demand and the Blue Jays do not trade him by the following Feb. 15, he can become a free agent.
The biggest name hovering over the meetings is Griffey. The Mets are among a very few teams that will at least talk with the Seattle Mariners about the possibility of a trade.
"We're going to talk to everybody," Phillips said when asked specifically about his interest in Griffey. "We'll see how we fit with those teams. Seattle is one of those teams."
The Mariners have never told the Mets which of their players they would want, and an executive familiar with the talks between the teams said the Mets had not made an offer for Griffey.
The Cincinnati Reds continue to be considered the team most likely to acquire the superstar center fielder. Jim Bowden, their general manager, is scheduled to meet with Pat Gillick, the Mariners' general manager, on Saturday morning. They have talked many times by telephone the past few weeks.
Some baseball people believe the only thing blocking a trade is Pokey Reese, the Reds' second baseman. The Mariners want him; the Reds do not want to trade him.
"No question you'd love to have the other guy, but I don't want to move Pokey," said Jack McKeon, the Reds' manager, who acknowledged that he had no say in the talks. "Pokey's a great kid. I love him. But I don't have any control over it. They'll do what they think is best for the club."
The Mets acquired Orosco because, Phillips said, he is better at getting left-handers out than John Franco and Dennis Cook, the other two left-handers in their bullpen. "Jesse gives us better balance in the bullpen with situational left-handers," Phillips said.
In the four seasons before 1999, Orosco held left-handed batters to a .166 average. But he was not as effective last season. They hit .270 against him.
There is not much difference economically in the trade. McElroy has two years left on his contract at salaries of $1.35 million and $1.45 million. Orosco will have a $1.1 million salary next season, and the Mets have an option in 2001 for $1.3 million. But the option will become guaranteed if Orosco pitches in 55 games next season. The last time he didn't pitch in that many games in a full season was 1991.
Orosco, who holds the major league record for appearances by a pitcher with 1,090, was asked today how much longer he plans to play. He said his agent and his wife were conspiring to get him to pitch to age 50. "I was laughing at it," he said. "Now it's starting to scare me."

HEADLINE: Where Green Trumps Black and White;
In Harlem's Business Boom, Victors and Victims Come in All Races

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN

 BODY:
First the rent on Desmond Parkin's optometry business on 125th Street in Harlem went "through the roof." Then a Sterling Optical store moved in across the street. Dr. Parkin, 36, had thought he would retire in Harlem. Instead, unable to compete, he decamped for Brooklyn, abandoning his old space to a Starbucks coffee shop.
In the fate of Dr. Parkin, who is black, would seem to be inscribed all of Harlem's worst fears about the remarkable economic development along 125th Street: that small black businesses will be crushed by an avalanche of outside (read white) capital trolling for profit, and by landlords looking to capitalize on it. 
 It is a neat narrative, but not entirely accurate. For the Sterling Optical store is wholly black-owned. A partnership between six young black men and the Abyssinian Development Corporation, a Harlem-based, black-run community development organization, was able to buy the franchise and set up shop with a loan from Bankers Trust and the Local Initiatives Support Corporation.
And that set of facts reflects a larger truth. On the new 125th Street -- essentially the stretch between Fifth Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard -- the victors in business are all races, and so are the victims. While many small black-owned businesses are being imperiled by competition from national retailers and especially by rising rents, one color trumps both black and white in the neighborhood these days, and that is green.
"People are doing business," Barbara Askins, president and chief executive of the 125th Street Business Improvement District, said succinctly.
Just ask Hojae Lee, who had a sale sign in the window of his All Seasons Shoes store recently and a bitter tinge in his voice. His rent, he said, was being more than doubled by his landlord, and that left him no choice but to move.
"We're getting kicked out," Mr. Lee, who is Asian-American, said. "We're here 20 years and we're getting kicked out."
The engine powering much of this ferment is the grandiose structure rapidly rising at the corner of 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. It is Harlem U.S.A., a new shopping center that has lured tenants like Old Navy and Disney who will pay up to $100 a square foot.
Like a metronome, Harlem U.S.A. is setting the street's new pace, and it is a mercilessly fast one. Rents -- particularly those close to the development -- are reaching $75 to $80 a square foot, double what spaces farther east go for, and more than double the top rent on the street five years ago.
"I remember that location being an empty, vacant lot," said Assemblyman Keith Wright, who is the fifth generation of his family to live in Harlem. "To see that large an edifice being built shows progress, shows movement." And, he added, "Any time you have improvements in a neighborhood it's going to increase property values."
As of yet, the center, whose stores will begin opening early next year, has not a single tenant from Harlem. But it, too, defies the easy characterization of black versus white, insider versus outsider. One of the entities poised to profit most heavily from it is a black-run, Harlem-based community development organization, the Harlem Commonwealth Council, which owned the land and co-developed the project.
Community-based or not, such power brokers are not entirely immune to whatever resentment may be bubbling along the street. Rose Rammal, the African-American proprietor of Apollo Express, which sells high-priced labels like Gianfranco Ferre and Dolce & Gabanna, said a black official from the Harlem Commonwealth Council told her she could open a store in Harlem U.S.A. only if she got Fendi, one of her suppliers, to co-sign the lease for her.
"What an insult," she said. "He didn't even search my assets. He just looked at me, black to black. That's crazy."
Harlem Commonwealth Council referred all calls to Drew Greenwald, the developer of Harlem U.S.A. "We're talking to anyone that wants to have space," Mr. Greenwald said, adding that "local tenants are cut a lot more slack than national ones are."
There is no question, however, that the metaphoric bubble swelling over Harlem is largely due to Harlem U.S.A., and it is equally true that the bubble could burst once the center opens. No one knows, for example, whether Harlemites have the disposable income or appetite to make Disney's cash registers sing, or to make the New York Sports Club's treadmills run. No one knows whether the lack of parking for a 275,000-square-foot-mall will deter consumers.
Mr. Wright, who represents central and west Harlem, estimates the median income in his district at $15,000 to $17,000; 40 percent of his constituents receive public assistance. And if the center does not do well, other retailers clamoring for space on the street could pull back.
But until then, landlords, brokers and developers are riding the wave. There is a land rush under way on the street. Some landlords are putting small tenants on month-to-month notice in the hope of trading up to a bigger fish.
Downtown brokers who never paid Harlem mind are suddenly interested, said Eugene Giscombe, whose company owns, manages and leases property on the street. Real estate owners are buying property, any piece of property, without a tenant in sight.
"They're starting to speculate now," Mr. Giscombe said.
There are so many chain stores seeking space on the street that some are looking east of Fifth Avenue. If the demand continues, Mr. Giscombe said, construction will begin on the street, as developers buy and assemble smaller spaces.
"I think it's going to be great for landlords over time," he said.
Whether it will be great for tenants is another story. "Everyone who's been here awhile is sitting on pins and needles," said John Baynes, who has run Theresa Fashions, a small, fusty boutique selling formal wear, for more than 30 years.
For some longtime business owners, the rise of the street may signal the end of the line. William Smith, who has owned Bill's Hardware and Paints at 1 West 125th Street for more than 22 years, said he was already being hurt by the Home Depot in the Bronx. Next year, another Home Depot is scheduled to be built at 125th and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, formerly the site of the Washburn Wire Factory.
"I'm hoping to God I'll be able to sell before then," Mr. Smith, who is African-American, said.
For others, it is the beginning of opportunity. Leon Ellis, a young black entrepreneur, moved his store, Harlem Underground, to Fifth Avenue, just off 125th Street, this year. It has since been doing a business as steady as the embroidery machine whirring away at the front of the store, stitching personalized logos onto T-shirts and hats.
And even some of those who are apprehensive are finding that there are benefits to large competitors: more traffic on the street.
"It means the opportunity for greater customer participation without direct advertisement," said Robert Rencher, the owner of Rencher's Crab Inn, which has been on the street for 10 years.
But what is crushing Mr. Rencher, and many other small businesses, is rent. His is up to $6,800 a month. Some will survive if their landlords do not raise rents as much as they could, of if they renegotiated their leases before rents shot up. Then there is Walter Douglas, of Puppy's, a man whose personality is considerably larger than his tiny store. He has sold clothing to Harlemites for 27 years.
"He supplies Harlem with leathers," often on layaway, said Ms. Askins, of the 125th Street Business Improvement District.
And so Mr. Douglas can afford to welcome Harlem U.S.A., saying, "It's showing people living here that we have the same opportunities as everyone else."
That Mr. Douglas greets every friend who walks by his store, and sizes up every stranger, is a reminder that Harlem still retains the feel of a small town, with 125th Street as its Main Street, on which acquaintances greet each other.
Businesses that fail to try to make a connection with the neighborhood are struggling, Ms. Askins said. "You can't just put something there -- you need to connect with the people," she added.
Old or new, many believe, if few will say on the record, that the loss of middling businesses and bodegas will be no loss for the street. And it may be the rest of Harlem's gain, as smaller businesses fan out to other streets.
But no matter what, change is coming -- as much in the character of the stores as their size. The small stores that served an older, loyal clientele, and embody a different era, are now shoulder to shoulder with stores pursuing a fickle youth market.
Harlem businesses increasingly see urban culture as a possible export. The owners of Dr. Jays, which sells urban street wear, now have three stores on the street, including Harlem N.Y.C., a two-story, 35,000-square-foot store.
Louis Falcon, the manager of Harlem Scheme, a store that sells urban wear to a hip-hop soundtrack, said the store owners came to 125th Street to capitalize on Harlem U.S.A., which is across the street. If you are trying to buy authenticity, their message is, there is nowhere better to buy than Harlem.
Mr. Baynes, the owner of Theresa Fashions, remembers when women on 125th wore gloves and hats, and stores closed on Sundays "It's more like a hip-hop generation street now," he said. "I'm not too pleased with that."

HEADLINE: Clinton Goes 'Home' to Arkansas, Talking Like a Former President

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark., Dec. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton still has more than 13 months left in office, but he was clearly focusing on his future after the White House today as he made a nostalgic homecoming trip to his native state.
Mr. Clinton sounded more like a governor than a president as he spoke to the Greater Little Rock Chamber of Commerce and toured depressed areas of eastern Arkansas, announcing millions of dollars in federal grants to promote economic development, train long-haul truck drivers and improve local health care services. 
 "Let me just take a minute to walk back through memory lane," Mr. Clinton said in a mellow, wistful speech to the chamber of commerce.
The whole day followed that pattern as Mr. Clinton thanked the people he credited with making possible his career in national politics.
"I want to begin by thanking the people of Arkansas, who gave me the chance to serve for a dozen years as governor, without which I could never have become president," he said.
He observed that his days in the White House were winding down, and he emphasized this theme so much that it sounded as if his term would end next month, rather than in January 2001.
Mr. Clinton had little to say about his plans for the remainder of his term. Rather, he boasted of his achievements over the last seven years and described -- in more detail than ever before -- his vision of life after the White House, including his plan to build a presidential library in Little Rock, on a 26-acre site beside the Arkansas River.
Mr. Clinton said the library would not only burnish his record but also attract visitors to Little Rock from all over the world.
"I want this to be a museum, but not a mausoleum," Mr. Clinton said.
He said his presidential archives would be combined with a policy center, where he intends to continue the projects he began as president. He said nothing about the home he and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, bought in Chappaqua, N.Y., or the career she seeks as a United States senator from New York.
Leaders of the chamber of commerce used Mr. Clinton's visit as an occasion to encourage donations to the foundation that is building the library. They said they were trying to raise $125 million.
Mr. Clinton said he would continue his work mediating racial, ethnic, political and religious conflicts after he left the White House.

HEADLINE: No Accord on Island Bombing as Administration and Puerto Rico Point Fingers

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Hopes for settling the dispute over bombing exercises on the island of Vieques appeared to dwindle today, as senior administration officials and the governor of Puerto Rico differed over whether they had actually agreed on the future of a bombing range there and, if so, what exactly they had agreed to.
White House and Pentagon officials complained that the governor had reneged on a promise to endorse President Clinton's proposals, while the governor said the president had announced a plan that did not reflect the actual negotiations with Puerto Rican officials. 
 Mr. Clinton's compromise plan, recommended by Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, rejected an earlier Navy recommendation to continue live-fire exercises on Vieques and accepted a Puerto Rican demand to halt the use of explosives.
The plan also delayed several major decisions on the Navy's future role in Vieques while the Navy and the Puerto Rican governor discussed whether the military could resume exercises in March with ordnance containing no explosives.
As part of the package, the Navy offered the island $40 million in economic revival money to show that it understands it must "repair relations" with the people of Vieques.
But just hours after the deal was announced last week by senior military and civilian Navy Department officials, Gov. Pedro J. Rossello publicly rejected the offer.
Stunned, the Pentagon has now postponed several aspects of the proposal and is discussing moves that could have a serious economic impact on Puerto Rico.
"The White House was surprised by the rejection," a senior administration official said. "We had been led to believe that the governor would endorse this."
Mr. Cohen said he had crafted the compromise with the Navy and Marines in recent weeks and was working under the assumption that the White House had negotiated an agreement with Governor Rossello.
"The White House told us they believed the governor would accept this," Mr. Cohen said in an interview. "So, yes, I was surprised when the governor did not support the agreement."
Through a spokesman, Governor Rossello said that Mr. Cohen misunderstood what had happened.
"It was the other way around," said Alfonso Aguilar, the governor's spokesman. "The president's plan did not reflect what the governor had agreed to. We were surprised and disappointed."
Only President Clinton and several of his senior aides spoke directly to Governor Rossello. Mr. Clinton stepped into the negotiations on Veteran's Day and spoke to the governor at least three times before the proposal was announced last week.
Governor Rossello believed that the president had agreed that the plan would include legally binding commitments that the bombing on the island would end and the Navy would leave, his spokesman said.
Several defense officials said today that they believed the confusion was the fault of politics.
The Vieques issue has brought a rare unity among the people of Puerto Rico, who in turn have put it on the national political agenda. Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is running for senator from New York State, which has a large Puerto Rican population, has sided with Puerto Rico against the Navy. So has Vice President Al Gore, whose presidential campaign co-chairman in Puerto Rico is Governor Rossello.
But the White House said it, too, was chagrined.
"None of us was thrilled about where we ended up on Friday," the senior administration official said.
Governor Rossello will negotiate only with the president and his senior aides in discussions on Vieques, and not with the Navy, his spokesman said today, adding that the governor expected the president to reconsider the plan.
"We are only dealing with the policy makers," Mr. Aguilar said. "The Navy should understand its role in these things. The commander in chief is the policy maker, and the Navy takes orders from President Clinton."
The Navy has postponed sending Rear Adm. Kevin Green to San Juan as the special representative for Vieques, even though the admiral's wife had already arrived there.
And the senior administration official said today that without a "very good sense of whether these talks will go forward in the next several weeks," the military would reconsider its entire relationship with Puerto Rico.
The territory is also home to Roosevelt Roads, one of the Navy's largest bases and one of Puerto Rico's largest employers.
At the same time, Pentagon officials, the White House and the governor said they wanted to continue looking for some way to bring the sides together to resume discussions.
The negotiations are complicated by the presence of hundreds of demonstrators camping on the Vieques firing range who refuse to leave for fear that the Navy will return. The range has been closed since a civilian Puerto Rican guard was killed after Marine jets dropped bombs that unintentionally hit an observation tower last spring.
That death galvanized Puerto Rican complaints against the Navy's use of the 900-acre range on Vieques. The small island has high unemployment; its residents have suffered health problems, including a high incidence of cancer, and the island's coral reef and wildlife have been threatened by the bombing.
For his part, Mr. Cohen said last week's proposal was the best the Pentagon could offer. The loss of Vieques would mean the end of all coordinated live-fire exercises on the east coast for the Navy.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 13, 1999, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about the dispute over military bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques referred incorrectly to Puerto Rico's political status. It is a commonwealth of the United States, not a territory.

HEADLINE: Is There Too Much Venture Capital?

BYLINE: By Charles Ferguson; Charles Ferguson is the author of "High Stakes, No Prisoners: A Winner's Tale of the Internet Wars."

 BODY:
Isubscribe to VentureWire, an e-mail newsletter that summarizes new venture capital investments in Internet companies. An average issue lists about 20 deals, usually adding up to between $100 million and $200 million. What's striking is that VentureWire comes daily -- and yet doesn't catch everything. Driven largely by optimism about the Internet, investment in American technology start-ups will probably reach approximately $50 billion for this year -- about 10 times more than in 1994.
This eagerness to invest in the latest start-up is, of course, another aspect of the same rush of capital that we are seeing when high-technology companies go public. On Thursday, the stock of VA Linux Systems had the biggest first-day gain for any initial public offering in history. This company, which sells computers that run the Linux operating system, faces serious competitors like I.B.M. and Dell, is losing money and will not turn a profit for the foreseeable future. Yet it was valued at almost $10 billion by the end of the day -- a gain of 733 percent. 
 But high-technology start-ups are not just stocks; They are also businesses, and they have to operate. The giddiness about stock prices is obscuring the real needs of companies.
It didn't used to be this way -- in fact, we used to have the opposite problem. Until very recently, the venture capital industry was a small club, verging on a cartel, and the technology sector was for geeks in California, period. Money was tight, particularly during the technology sector recession in the early 1990's.
In 1994, I spent five brutal months raising $4 million for my first company, an early Internet software start-up. At the time, there were maybe a thousand Web sites in the world.
But since the onset of the commercial Internet revolution in 1995, money has flooded into the Internet, with the size of the venture capital industry roughly doubling every year. A very real revolution -- the growth of the Internet -- is being accompanied, and sometimes damaged, by an epidemic of speculation.
Fund-raising has become a buyer's market. Venture capitalists now must compete for deals, despite their vastly increased funds and the large number of Internet companies being started.
In many ways, this is good. It is now much easier for entrepeneurs to raise money. I recently founded my second Internet start-up. This time, I raised over $3 million in the first month.
The Internet has also made business life a lot fairer. You don't have to stay in a big, bureaucratic company anymore; you can join a start-up. You can bypass middlemen and sell directly to the global market. And without a doubt, the Internet wouldn't have come so far so fast if venture funding still behaved as it did a decade ago.
But the fact that virtually any idea -- no matter how dubious -- can obtain money, and that so much money is available, is also causing problems. Competition among Internet companies is increasingly a financial arms race. They must raise huge war chests, give away their products, advertise on television, and pay insanely high salaries -- simply because their competitors do.
The glut of money also has companies -- and the industry as a whole -- growing insanely fast, leading to labor shortages everywhere -- of not only engineers and managers, but graphic designers, accountants, headhunters, telephone system installers.
Fortune seekers, many of them unqualified, flood to the Internet -- both to start companies and to work in them. This leads to sloppy work and some fairly sleazy behavior.
In some respects, the rush and confusion are natural costs of moving forward as a major new technology becomes widely available. Relative to the benefits that the Internet brings, these problems are comparatively minor. But the inherent dangers of a speculative environment will eventually hurt many naive investors -- and perhaps, more importantly, they also make life more difficult for serious entrepeneurs.

HEADLINE: Are You for Real?

BYLINE: By Daniel Johnson; Daniel Johnson is an editorial writer for The Daily Telegraph in London.

 BODY:

THE SOCIAL CONSTRUCTION OF WHAT?
 By Ian Hacking.
 261 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 I AM writing this review in the Reading Room of the London Library. Both are reflections of society. Each concept has a history, an evolving social function. Reviewing books is roughly contemporaneous with the rise of literary and academic periodicals around 1700, though literary criticism is at least as old as Aristotle. Likewise, libraries go back to ancient royal or ecclesiastical collections, but are transformed by the spread of literacy and printing. The purpose of the library of Assurbanipal at Nineveh had little in common with that of Thomas Carlyle's brainchild in St. James's Square, in which I sit, and neither had quite the same uses as virtual libraries in cyberspace.
The library and the book review are social phenomena, but are they "social constructions"? Would it add to our knowledge to be told, say, that many readers of The New York Times Book Review are so busy they often rely on reviews in case they find themselves next to a well-read acquaintance at a dinner party? If that were true, would it "unmask" the review (or the Review) as untrue to its purpose? Is it not the case that people have always read reviews for a variety of reasons, including to learn which books they do not need to read, and to build conversational self-confidence? And is there not more continuity than the notion of social construction suggests? Wouldn't guests at Plato's Symposium have welcomed an Athenian Times Book Review?
"The Social Construction of the Book Review" would be no more zany a title than the A-to-Z of real books in the genre compiled by Ian Hacking in "The Social Construction of What?" Social construction is an all-purpose method of relativizing any object of criticism. Social and natural scientists, no less than philosophers, have a stake in it, especially after the "science wars" of recent years; so, too, do nonacademics, for the rhetoric of social construction has crept into debates about race, feminism and environmentalism and into every kind of political discourse.
Hacking is a Canadian philosopher of science, with important studies of probability and psychology to his name. He is no less at home in Continental philosophy and social theory than in the Anglo-Saxon tradition. His ability to leap with enviable facility from one to the other qualifies him well to bring some order into this intellectual quagmire. "The Social Construction of What?" is a collection of papers, not a systematic treatment, but it hangs together. Hacking starts out by defining the common claims of social constructionists: that X in its present form was not inevitable, that X is bad and that X should be abolished or at least reformed. He looks at how constructionists apply these levels of criticism, ranging from the mere historicizing of gender, race, the economy or the self through an ironical disillusionment to unmasking or revolution. He distinguishes between interactive constructions, such as "women refugees" who create themselves by reacting to their situation, and indifferent or inanimate kinds that are constructed by others, such as scientists.
He argues that the metaphor of social construction suffers from overuse. "Social" is often redundant, while the uses of the metaphor of construction in philosophy by Kant, Bertrand Russell, Rudolf Carnap, Nelson Goodman and Thomas Kuhn, while valid, have little to do with its usage among today's theorists. While earlier philosophers were allies of the natural sciences, modern constructionists set out to subvert them. Thus, Andrew Pickering claims quarks would not have been discovered (he would say constructed) but for contingent factors connected with the political status of high-energy physics. Hacking devotes a chapter to weapons research and finds guilty of "ideological paranoia" those theorists who invalidate its results merely on account of its motives or funding.
When Alan Sokal famously sought to discredit theorists by publishing a spoof article of antiscience in the journal Social Text, he was seeking to reclaim the territory of the left for scientists, whom social constructionists tend to stereotype as navely conservative. Hacking has sympathy with both sides but is uncomfortable with social construction as an explanatory tool.
Since Foucault, madness has been a favorite, if moving, target. Hacking looks at attempts to unmask retardation, autism and schizophrenia as social constructions rather than biological disorders, tracing the conceptual evolution of these pathologies. He concludes that with the help of semantic distinctions formulated long ago by the philosophers Hilary Putnam and Saul Kripke, the debate is probably unnecessary and certainly irrelevant to research into genetic and neurological factors in psychopathology.
In short, if it were to become the dominant hermeneutic method in the world of laboratories and hospitals, social construction might amount to scientific destruction. But how about a case like child abuse? Hacking examines the complex dialectic between reality and concept: definitions of abuse mutate as behavior is modified to accommodate growing public anxiety. Hence our view of the past alters, too: "pedophile" seems inadequate to describe the 15th-century fiend Gilles de Rais, who tortured and murdered children to satisfy his lust; but is it not too pejorative for Lewis Carroll, who did not lay a finger on the little girls he photographed? Medical terms like "battered child syndrome" are created; ramifications for the legal system are endless. Even after Hacking's tour d'horizon, however, we still do not know whether child abuse is usefully described as socially constructed or not.
Hacking concludes with a witty piece about why the Hawaiians killed Captain Cook. This hinges on the question of whether they saw the explorer as a god or merely a chief. Hacking attempts to adjudicate between two anthropological perspectives: that of Marshall Sahlins, who sees the English and Hawaiian versions of events as essentially accurate and compatible, and that of Gananath Obeyesekere, who sees the "apotheosis" of Cook as socially constructed by the English. Sahlins thinks Cook fitted into Hawaiian mythology, while Obeyesekere denies that any colonial peoples saw Europeans as gods. Hacking is a shrewd critic of incoherence, and he finds the ethnographic data inconsistent with Obeyesekere's attribution to the Hawaiians of a "pragmatic rationality" that sounds suspiciously Western. Social construction makes for lively polemics, but does not add much to our knowledge. It is not enough merely to be subversive.
