HEADLINE: The Spike Wasn't Golden

BYLINE: By Robert M. Utley; Robert M. Utley's most recent books are "The Lance and the Shield: The Life and Times of Sitting Bull" and "A Life Wild and Perilous: Mountain Men and Paths to the Pacific."

 BODY:

EMPIRE EXPRESS
 Building the First
 Transcontinental Railroad.
 By David Haward Bain.
 Illustrated. 797 pp. New York:
 Viking. $34.95. 
 ON May 10, 1869, a self-important and somewhat boozy array of frock-coated dignitaries gathered with several hundred rowdy laborers to drive the last spike in the Pacific Railroad. The site was Promontory Summit, Utah (not Promontory Point, 30 miles to the south). The last spike was an ordinary iron spike (not a "golden" spike, which would have been crushed by a sledgehammer's blow). The Central Pacific's Leland Stanford and the Union Pacific's Thomas C. Durant are both said to have swung at the spike and missed, to the great delight of the crowd, but David Haward Bain demolishes this oft-told tale. When the sledgehammers connected, an attached telegraph wire sped the impulse east and west to set off joyous celebration everywhere.
The last spike completed the union of Atlantic and Pacific by rail. The ceremony crowned one of the most dramatic and significant episodes in American history. Passengers and freight could now cross the continent in days instead of months. Settlement, commerce, industry, agriculture and other railroads spread north and south from the twin bands of iron. The Indians' remaining years of freedom dwindled to less than a decade. The United States became a nation not only in cartographic fact but in social, political and economic fact as well.
The building of the Pacific railroad is an epic story, often recounted but never so thoroughly, authoritatively and engagingly as in "Empire Express." The story unfolds along two trajectories, each with its own cast of well-etched characters, each a drama of conflict, adventure, excitement and suspense. The one reverberates through corporate boardrooms, federal and state offices, the cloakrooms of Congress and the courts; the other in the towering Sierra Nevada, the deserts of Utah and Nevada, the rugged canyons of Utah's Wasatch and the Nebraska plains. The Central Pacific raced east, the Union Pacific west, to the meeting that only at the last moment turned out to be Promontory. Bain, the author of "Sitting in Darkness: Americans in the Philippines," traces both trajectories with clarity and engaging narrative, and he is skilled in relating each to the other, for each enormously influenced the other.
No novelist could have created a more vibrant set of characters than those who built the Pacific railroad. The Central Pacific boasted the California-based Big Four -- Leland Stanford, Collis P. Huntington, Mark Hopkins and Charles Crocker. Bain rightly expands this to a Big Five by including the hitherto unappreciated role of Crocker's brother Edwin. Charles bossed the construction gangs. Hopkins kept the books. Huntington played the Washington and New York scene, dispensing lavish sums in cash, stock and bonds to buy the favor of the federal officials and members of Congress on whom federal subsidies and land grants depended. Back home, Edwin Crocker furnished the vital communications link between Huntington in the east and the others in California. Lazy and comfort-loving, Stanford did only what the others pushed him to do.
In contrast to the tight-knit but internally quarrelsome Big Five, the Union Pacific suffered from a sprawling cast of openly warring characters and factions. Many corporate moguls circulated in and out of the railroad's ornate Manhattan headquarters. But the Darth Vader of them all was Thomas C. Durant, unsurpassed master of chicanery, avarice and manipulation of corporate power for personal enrichment. In the field, Grenville Dodge, Jack and Dan Casement and Samuel Reed pushed surveyors, graders and trackers across plains and mountains, but not without the infuriating interference of Durant and his toadies, whose changes of alignment produced more curves and therefore more mileage and therefore more government subsidies.
Even by the loose standards of the 1860's, every ranking official of both railroads could be labeled a crook, as most ultimately were. Bain probes the financial, legal and political skulduggery in all its complexity. He nimbly spins the kaleidoscope of stocks, bonds, securities, first and second mortgages, slush funds and piles of cash. He exposes the artifice of the Credit Mobilier and the Contract and Finance Company, by which the railroad directors let padded construction contracts to themselves. Bain's attempt to untangle the tangle is sometimes bewildering but always fascinating.
Everyone, it seems, got rich, some fabulously rich, while the companies plummeted into debt and finally bankruptcy. High government officials in Washington profited, including the vice president and a string of congressional committee chieftains who found themselves badly embarrassed when the scandal poured forth three years after the celebration at Promontory. Construction suffered, less so on the Central Pacific than the Union Pacific, whose line from Omaha to Promontory was so shoddily built that it had to be almost entirely redone at once. Field supervisors and contractors also found ways to plunder the company coffers. Even Grenville Dodge, who usually emerges as the lone untarnished hero, gets caught with his hand in the till -- not only the Union Pacific's till, but afterward in Indian supply contracts and in building the Texas and Pacific Railway.
More compelling and more readily understood than the corporate swindling is the construction story, an epic matched by few in American history. The Central Pacific's conquest of the California Sierras was a marvel of engineering and labor. The visionary Theodore Judah laid the engineering groundwork, but Samuel Montague and Lewis Clement carried it over (and through) the great granite peaks, across the Donner Pass and down the Truckee Canyon.
The true heroes of the summit crossing, however, were the thousands of docile, obedient, hard-working Chinese laborers Crocker imported from Canton. With primitive equipment, they shaped the grades, raised the trestles, blasted the cuts and tunnels with black powder, shoveled in the fills, laid and spiked the rails and built mile after mile of sheds to guard the line from huge drifts of winter snow and avalanches that could wipe out miles of track. They even lowered themselves down cliffs in wicker baskets, woven on patterns remembered from their homeland, and worked with a volatile new compound called nitroglycerine, without which the great summit tunnel could not have been completed for years. Their graves dotted trackside in mountain and desert, memorials to a people destined for brutal ethnic prejudice in their adopted land.
Pushing west from Omaha, Dodge and Casement, recently Union generals, commanded their Irish workmen, recently Union soldiers, as if still on the battlefield. They were muscular exemplars of labor, but, in contrast to the Chinese, unruly and given to incapacitating binges at the "Hell on Wheels" that leaped west from one end of the track to the next. The Union Pacific faced no such daunting obstacle as the Sierras but had its share of mountain work in the Laramie and Wasatch ranges.
With both sides striving for the maximum in federal subsidies and land grants (as well as markets), surveyors and graders worked far in advance of the end of track. For miles in Utah and Nevada, surveyor stakes and grades ran parallel until a point of union could be agreed and ratified by Congress. Bleak, treeless Promontory Summit was at last fixed, with the Central Pacific to take over the Union Pacific work back down to Ogden, gateway to the Salt Lake Valley.
Today, at the Golden Spike National Historic Site, visitors may view parallel grades, cuts, fills and trestle footings, fruits of the great railroad race that finally ended at Promontory Summit. Ironically, these impressive works, snaking side by side up the rocky eastern face of the Promontory Mountains, were not the product of the legendary Irish and Chinese laborers but of pious Mormons. The church's president, Brigham Young, had arranged for Mormon bishops to mobilize labor gangs and dip into the barrel from which everyone else seemed to be imbibing so freely. Bankrupted by the frenzy of fraud, neither company ever paid the Mormons.
"Empire Express" is well researched, well written, refreshingly revisionist where the sources indicate, illustrated by well-chosen photographs and studded with beautiful topographical maps indispensable to the construction story. The book promises to endure as the standard history of the Pacific railroad.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By Allen D. Boyer 

 BODY:

STIRRINGS IN THE JUG
 Black Politics in the
 Post-Segregation Era.
 By Adolph Reed Jr.
 University of Minnesota,
 cloth, $47.95; paper, $18.95. 
 Forcefully ringing changes on a remark by Ralph Ellison -- that segregation was wrongly seen as "an opaque steel jug with the Negroes inside waiting for some black messiah" -- Adolph Reed Jr. uses these essays to examine where black leadership has failed and where black action may yet succeed. In urban politics, Reed argues, black candidates' need for the white swing vote, combined with the clamor for jobs and growth, inexorably means white leverage over black aspirations; thus Atlanta-based Delta Airlines became a kingmaking force among Atlanta's black elite, and the National Conference of Black Mayors echoed Ronald Reagan's call for ghetto "enterprise zones." Reed, who teaches political science at the New School for Social Research, damns the idea that black Americans "hold a status similar to a protectorate," to be managed by favoring self-appointed spokesmen, and skewers those who have sought white endorsement as "national black leader." Reed rejects the conventional assumption that poor black people are to blame for all their own problems. "I do not want to hear another word about drug or crime," he concludes, "without hearing about decent jobs, adequate housing and egalitarian education in the same breath." Allen D. Boyer

HEADLINE: Food;
All the Cookies

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
Over the years Ethel Carlegren has acquired about 500 Santa Claus figures, some made out of porcelain, others made from wood, wool or clay. She has also collected at least 10 recipes for Swedish Christmas cookies. Still, you will not catch her decorating her Minnesota home anytime before Dec. 13.
"I am Swedish, you see," says Carlegren, 54, who immigrated with her husband, Anders, to Bloomington, a suburb just 10 miles south of downtown Minneapolis, 18 years ago. "First we cook, then we buy presents and finally we decorate." 
 Even though she has reared her two children here, she believes that she has grown more Swedish with each passing year. "Or perhaps just older," she says. "As you get older you begin to appreciate the past." In any case, she has no plans to follow the American custom of decorating right after Thanksgiving and baking the day before Christmas.
Her choice of Dec. 13, on St. Lucia's Day, is actually a compromise to please her daughter, Viktoria. "Ja, my daughter is 15, and she wants the decorations on American time," explains Carlegren, "so I bend a little."
However, it's not clear -- at least to her -- which affects her more: accommodating her adopted home or adapting to changing times. Is it, for instance, the pace of living in modern America that is suddenly propelling her to start baking Christmas cookies the day after Thanksgiving? Or is it because she has a large freezer where she can store her dough? Or is it that there are now high-quality gingerbread kits available in Sweden, where the family spends its summers, and she no longer needs to make her holiday cookie houses from scratch?
Carlegren isn't sure of the answer. "We change in ways we don't notice," she says. And then one day, she realizes, she isn't making Swedish meatballs as often as she used to.
"Some things just slip away," observes Carlegren, the founder of the local chapter of the Swedish Women's Educational Association International, an organization dedicated to preserving the Swedish language and customs. The sum of the changes is simply what is called being Swedish in America.
But around the holidays, subtle shifts seem more dramatic. Carlegren's children, for instance, worry when each of the 500 Santa Claus figures, or tomtar, from their mother's collection is not in the precise spot it occupied last year -and the year before that.
Truth be told, says Carlegren, her kids have never developed much of a taste for Christmas cookies. "The children are so American," she says. "They like salty snacks, not so much sweet cookies." Still, each has his or her favorite. Her daughter prefers gingerbread snaps; her son, Frederik, 25, the saffron buns.
Whatever else changes, the cookies themselves do not. Their flavor always evokes the smell of caramelizing sugar, butter and flour, and the Carlegrens' kitchen forever remains a pathway back to a land that formed these confections long before Viktoria and Frederik were born.
To them, a single unchanged cookie is the one true thing. To their mother, such economy is virtually unfathomable. "I must bake my 10 kinds of cookies and all the saffron breads and buns," she says. "I try to push my children to eat the cookies, but perhaps when they are older, they will have more of a taste for them."
 
Skurna Chokladbrod (Cut Chocolate Cookies)
 
 1 cup butter
 3/4 cup sugar
 1 egg
 2 cups flour
 3 tablespoons unsweetened cocoa powder
 1 teaspoon baking soda
 1 tablespoon vanilla sugar
 1 beaten egg for brushing cookies Pearl sugar for garnish.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Add the egg and mix thoroughly. Sift together the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda and vanilla sugar. Stir the flour mixture into the butter-and-sugar mixture, stirring until the ingredients are just combined.
2. Divide the dough into 6 equal balls and roll each out to a log about 3/4-inch thick. Place the logs, well spaced, on greased sheet pans. Brush each with the beaten egg and sprinkle generously with pearl sugar. Bake until they just begin to darken and crack on top, yet are still soft, 15 to 20 minutes.
3. Remove from the oven and cool slightly. Remove from the sheet pans and place on a cutting board. While the cookies are still warm, use a sharp knife to cut the logs on the bias into 1-inch-wide strips. Cut again on the bias to form small diamonds.
Yield: About 60 cookies.
 
Kalasstanger (Holiday Almond Fingers)
 
 1 cup butter
 1/3 cup sugar
 1 large egg yolk
 Grated zest from half a lemon
 2 cups flour
 1 7-ounce tube almond paste
 1 large egg white
 1 egg, lightly beaten
 1/3 cup sliced almonds.
1. In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg yolk and lemon zest. Stir in the flour until just combined. Gather the dough into a ball, wrap in plastic and refrigerate for at least 1 hour. Grate the almond paste and mix it with the egg white. Refrigerate.
2. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. On a lightly floured surface, roll the chilled dough out until it is very thin (about 1/8inch) and use a sharp knife to cut it into 3-inch squares. Spread the almond-paste mixture over the squares. Roll the squares up as if you were rolling up a carpet. Place the cookies on a greased cookie sheet. Rework the scraps until all the dough is used. Brush each with the beaten egg and sprinkle with almond slices. Bake until the cookies are lightly brown, about 15 minutes. Remove from the hot pan and place on a cool sheet pan.
Yield: About 24 cookies.
 
Spritskransar
(Spritz Cookies)
 
 14 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature
 1/4 cup sugar
 1 egg yolk
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1 1/2 cups flour.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg yolk and salt. Stir in the flour. Transfer the dough to a cookie press or a pastry bag fitted with a large star-shape tube. Pipe out circles of dough that are a little more than an inch in diameter. Bake on greased baking sheets until lightly browned, about 8 to 10 minutes. Cool briefly before transferring to cool sheet pans.
Yield: About 48 cookies.
 
Mormors
Sproda Pepparkakor (Grandmother's Gingerbread Cookies)
 
 2/3 cup dark corn syrup
 1 1/2 cups sugar
 3/4 cup butter
 1 tablespoon ground cinnamon
 1 tablespoon ground ginger
 1 tablespoon ground cloves
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
 4 cups flour
 2/3 cup heavy cream.
1. Place the syrup in a small pan and place over medium heat until it is very hot but not boiling. Place the sugar in a large bowl. Pour the hot syrup over the sugar and beat until the sugar crystals dissolve, about 10 minutes. Beat in the butter, then the cinnamon, ginger, cloves and salt. Sift together the baking soda and 2 cups of the flour and stir it into the dough. Stir in the heavy cream. Add the remaining 2 cups of flour, stirring until just combined. Wrap the dough in plastic and refrigerate for at least a day and up to 1 week.
2. When ready to bake, preheat the oven to 350 degrees. On a lightly floured surface using a floured rolling pin, roll out half the dough to a thickness of 1/8inch. Using cookie cutters, cut the dough out. Use a spatula to transfer the cookies to greased baking sheets. Bake until the edges just barely begin to brown, about 5 to 6 minutes. Cool briefly on the pan and transfer to a cool sheet pan.
Yield: About 100 cookies.
 
Lussekatter Med Saffran
(Lucia Buns With Saffron)
 
 1 cup butter
 1 cup margarine
 1 2/3 cups milk
 1 2-ounce cake of compressed fresh yeast, or 3 1/4-ounce packages dry yeast
1 large egg
 1 1/2 cups sugar
 1 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon ground cardamom
 3/4 teaspoon crushed saffron threads
 6 1/2 cups flour
 1 large egg lightly beaten for brushing Raisins for garnish.
1. Melt the butter and margarine over low heat. Pour in the milk and continue to heat until the milk is warm but not hot. (It should seem to be just about at body temperature.) Transfer to a large bowl and stir in the yeast. Add the egg, sugar, salt, cardamom and saffron. Stir in the flour until a smooth dough forms. Cover with a tea towel and let rise in a warm place until it is doubled in volume, about 60 minutes.
2. Punch the dough down. Divide into 5 equal pieces. Take each piece and roll it out into a snake about a foot long. Cut each snake into 8 equal pieces. Roll each piece again into a smaller snake, about 8 inches long, and form each into an "S" shape with the ends coiled in. Place on a greased sheet pan and continue until all the dough is formed. Cover the sheets with tea towels and let rise until the dough is almost doubled in size, about 40 minutes.
3. When ready to bake, preheat the oven to 475 degrees. Brush each bun with egg and place a raisin in each coiled end. Bake for 5 to 8 minutes, until golden brown. Remove from the pan and cool on a wire rack.
Yield: About 40 buns.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 12-12-99;
Feeding Frenzy

BYLINE: By Michael Pollan; Michael Pollan is a contributing writer for the magazine. He recently received an award from Reuters and the World Conservation Union for "Playing God in the Garden," which appeared here in October 1998.

 BODY:
Gazing nervously across the Atlantic at European outrage over genetically modified food, industry and government leaders have been quick to reach for words like "hysteria" and "madness." How else to explain the uprooting of biotech crops in English fields? Or naked protesters in Rome pelting American cabinet secretaries with genetically engineered ("G.E.") soybeans? It's irrational, surely, to reject out of hand such a shiny new technology, especially one that comes with the seal of approval of American regulators (the vaunted Food and Drug Administration, no less).
Stylistically, too, the European protests seem so old. There they go, those Brits, indulging their Luddite fear of the new, actually taking seriously a prince (a prince!) who declares that this technology lacks the sanction of God. And the French! Hopelessly sentimental, urinating in protest on shipments of high-tech seed and nattering on about "culinary dispossession" as if this were 1968. "Europe seems to be gripped right now by a collective madness," Senator Richard Lugar suggested during a visit to Germany last summer. "And we don't want that to spread to the rest of the world." 
 Since then, of course, the "madness" has spread; witness the events in Seattle. In a global economy, protest moves as easily across borders as products.
In recent months, activists dressed as monarch butterflies have popped up in London, Chicago and Washington (as well as Seattle), reminders of a famous recent study at Cornell that found biotech corn may pose a threat to the beloved insect. A cliche of chaos theory holds that the flutter of a butterfly's wing in, say, Timbuktu, can set off a hurricane half a world away. So it was with these butterflies in Ithaca, who moved the biotech story from the business pages to the front pages. For most Americans, it came as news that there were already some 20 million acres of biotech corn planted in the United States. You mean we're already eating this stuff? And how come nobody thought of doing these tests 20 million acres ago?
The wonder is that it has taken so long for the political debate about G.E. food to reach our shores. One theory about why Europeans got so hysterical so quickly about G.E. food is that they lack a trusted regulator like the F.D.A. protecting their food supply. Sounds rational enough, until you discover that the F.D.A.'s "regulation" of biotech is voluntary; companies decide for themselves whether to submit a new biotech food to the agency for review. In other words, the agency's oversight of biotech food has been based less on law and science than on faith.
Last year, the Center for Food Safety, a public-interest group, sued the F.D.A., charging that its 1992 rules covering biotech food were illegal because the agency had failed to seek public comment or conduct a thorough scientific review. The agency's response was alarming: since we have no regulations concerning biotech food, they can't be illegal. Just last month, seven years after first approving G.E. food, the F.D.A. held its first public hearings about it.
The industry and its regulators evidently didn't think we needed to be informed that our entire food supply was about to be transformed. After all, Americans are by now so far removed from the farm that we know remarkably little -- at least compared with the Europeans -- about the processes by which food finds its way to our plates. Food? That comes from the supermarket. So who was going to notice or care if one more high-tech link was quietly added to a food chain already so long and intricate? We are the people who eat Olestra, after all.
Labeling was rejected out of hand -- too cumbersome and too risky. For who, given the choice, would reach for the spuds with the biotech label?
Right there, in the produce section, lurks the question that goes to the heart of what it means to be rational or hysterical about biotech food. What if I approach the matter as rationally as possible and decide which vegetables to buy based on a strict "cost-benefit analysis"? First, I'll need a little information -- a label (which we may yet get: last month a bill was introduced in Congress calling for the labeling of biotech food). Next, I'll need to know what benefits these novel foods offer. According to the industry that makes them, today's biotech crops (like Round-Up Ready soybeans that resist herbicides, and potatoes and corn that produce their own pesticide) offer plenty of advantages to farmers. They acknowledge, however, that the benefits to consumers are negligible. The food is no cheaper, safer or tastier.
Now add to this calculus what we know about the risks. None to my health have been established, but then, no one's looked very long or hard, either. So: probably safe, but no guarantee. As for risks to the environment, several have already been identified -- the threat to butterflies, the prospect of superweeds and superbugs.
The cost-benefit analysis seems clear: I'd have to be crazy to buy this stuff.
The industry realizes that, in its case, an educated consumer is not its best customer, so lately it has adopted a new tack -- suggesting my produce-aisle calculus is shortsighted and selfish. That's because the real benefits of genetically engineered food will be reaped in the future by hungry people in the third world. Some day, "golden rice" will nourish the malnourished and bananas will be re-engineered to deliver vaccines.
The industry, in other words, is asking consumers to do something it has yet to do itself: Forget rational self-interest, and act on faith. Maybe Monsanto and the others are sincere. So bring on the golden rice! And what will they say about this epiphany in the aisles of my supermarket or on Wall Street? A word leaps to mind: hysterical.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 60; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1006 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 12-12-99: Word & Image;
How to Bust His Trust

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
The judicial finding that Microsoft has attained, enjoyed and abused the power of a monopoly reached me at a fortuitous moment. I instantly knew what punishment fit the crime.
Just a few hours earlier, I had been reading about the tycoon known for "his visionary leadership, his courageous persistence, his capacity to think in strategic terms, but also his lust for domination, his messianic self-righteousness and his contempt for those shortsighted mortals who made the mistake of standing in his way." 
 Bill Gates, the visionary predator? No. John D. Rockefeller Sr., the "Titan" of Ron Chernow's splendid biography. The parallels are uncanny. Also instructive.
Each man seized upon a product that would shrink the earth and define a century. Each employed it to amass incomparable personal wealth. What refined oil did for Rockefeller, processed information has done for Gates. Both brilliantly appropriated the creativity of other folks. Both used that control to gobble up competitors and to crush all challengers. And when finally challenged in court, both shamelessly denied the undeniable evidence of their monopolistic ambitions and predatory conduct.
All this coincidental instruction in the behavior of Microsoft and Standard Oil left me wondering whether Americans would ever learn to overcome the fateful flaw in our free-market system: the very greed that makes us economically creative also repeatedly makes us creatively criminal.
But I was also left full of admiration for Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's quick grasp of the world of Windows and ways of the Web. He mastered the intangibles of Bill Gates's vision much sooner than anyone understood old Rockefeller's devilish designs. And the judge's dense, 200-page indictment of Microsoft was devastating enough to evoke Gates's interest in a deal that might yet rescue him from a lifetime of litigation.
I don't know what either Microsoft or the trustbusters of the Justice Department would deem a proper settlement of the case. But I think Judge Jackson should not close the affair until he can reassert an elementary principle of fair commerce: competition can flourish only if the roads to market are equally available to all competitors.
There's no way to test the market value of a dozen eggs if only one farmer owns a wagon to bring them to town. And if every farmer has a wagon, the market still will not work if one of them collects the tolls for use of the road. For foxy old Rockefeller, the road was a pipeline, then a railroad track, from refinery to port, and he conspired to dictate the tolls for all those roads. Inevitably, he not only paid less than any competitor to ship his own oil; in time, he even commanded a rebate -- called a "drawback" -- from the tolls paid by his rivals.
Decades passed before enough Americans understood how they were being cheated and wrote broad antitrust laws that might protect them against similar betrayals of capitalism. Those are the laws that Judge Jackson now strains to enforce on Bill Gates. But he won't succeed until Microsoft is made to choose between running the wagons and owning the road.
In simpler days, this was sometimes called the "common carrier" rule. If you owned the track, you had to convey everybody's freight fairly. If you owned the wire, you had to connect everybody's phone and carry everybody's message. If you owned a movie house, you had to be available for anybody's films. If you owned a cable, you had to carry all television programs. You could be a common carrier or the creator of something to be carried, but not both.
Simple but also quaint. Technology has a way of overtaking ideology and blurring such distinctions. The cable companies learned to make their own TV shows and to discriminate against rivals. Now the cable owners think they can also become phone companies and the phone companies are angling to send television shows to my computer. And all these wired companies are being challenged by gadgets that send messages and pictures invisibly through the air. What's an egg anymore? Who's a road?
Bill Gates thought his virtual monopoly could never be understood in the old physical terms. And if he had not left a telltale trail of e-mail, the Feds might never have made a plausible case against him. But given the evidence from Gates's own computer, Judge Jackson well understood that Microsoft's imperial triumph had been deliberately and probably illegally engineered.
Gates built Windows, a good road to the information market, and then schemed brilliantly to make it practically the only road that PC owners could navigate. Nearly all wagons -- computer programs -- had to fit on his tracks. Gates's own wagons -- the Microsoft programs -- rode free on his Windows highway, and those of his allies were waved onto low-toll express lanes. Rockefeller rebates redux.
Gates had the market effectively cornered until the Internet produced the prospect of an alternate, Window-less turnpike. Microsoft's long-suffering competitors foresaw a chance of bypassing the personal computer and giving people a much simpler machine that would "borrow" the computing power and programs they periodically need via the Internet.
Belatedly aroused, Gates poured all his monopoly power into blunting that threat. He conspired to destroy rival dreamers, like Netscape, so that his Windows would remain the universal gateway to the Internet. But he was found to have rigged contracts and prices -- while plotting to control the Internet -- and the remaining question is how best to bust his trust.
The remedy, now as in Rockefeller's time, is to make the monopolist choose: Windows or wagons? Gates has already said he wants to keep the road; he wants no deal that deprives him of Windows. Very well; then make him sell off his wagons, his Word and Office programs, and fairly share the Windows specs that competing programmers need to run their wagons on his road.
And then, dear federal trustbusters, please take a look at my cable-TV bills.

PUB-DATE: December 12, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Page 75; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4494 words

HEADLINE: Trickle-Down Civil Rights

BYLINE: By George Packer; George Packer is the author of four books, including "Blood of the Liberals," due out next year from Farrar, Strauss & Giroux.

 BODY:
In early August, some of the country's top business executives made a pilgrimage to Chicago and paid homage to the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The occasion was the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition's annual conference, and before an audience of aspiring black businessmen, a panel that included Sanford Weill of Citigroup, Hugh McCall of Bank of America and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago Bulls and White Sox, swore allegiance to multicultural capitalism.
"It makes money sense," the C.E.O.'s chanted, twice, at Jackson's insistence. He shepherded the participants into a circle of prayer. He told them to hold hands, and they held hands. Harold Levy, Citigroup's director of global compliance, clasped the palm of a black managing director of a New York securities firm named Shawn Baldwin. Jackson prayed for access to capital. 
 "Coke, No. 1 employer in Africa," he murmured. "Archer Daniels Midland, No. 1 in Decatur -- that's in America. There are new, untapped markets."
"Amen," everyone said. And suddenly an energy that was not religious broke loose. Hands released each other to reach into pockets and pull out business cards as the room was given over to a frenzy of networking.
That night at a gala dinner, Janice Mathis, Jackson's chief of staff, watched as the mostly black and decidedly upscale crowd of guests arrived. A woman in a sparkling evening dress hurried over to her, exclaiming, "I love your lip rouge!" Mathis turned to me. "You'll see a lot of folks here," she said, "who wouldn't have anything to do with a civil rights organization."
The executives did not end up in Chicago after a sudden group conversion to the ideals of economic justice. According to Jackson, they were acting out of "enlightened self-interest." The less generous explanation is fear. Jackson can still command a national spotlight when he wants to -- as the mostly white school board in Decatur, Ill., discovered last month when Jackson protested the expulsion of six black students after a brawl at a football game. And in 1996, after racist remarks tape-recorded at a Texaco staff meeting came to light, Jackson put pressure on the company to settle a discrimination suit (for $140 million) and to implement an ambitious affirmative-action plan.
Emboldened, Jackson initiated the Wall Street Project the next year. On the premise that the most entrenched divisions in America are no longer based on race but on wealth, or "access to capital," he began a campaign in which the project buys stock in corporations and lobbies C.E.O.'s to open up jobs, contracts, loans and boardrooms to the "locked out." Before long, some of the largest corporations in America were answering his call for expanded minority hiring and investment in minority-owned companies. Big business, it turns out, has been easier for Jackson to move than the Democratic Party, Southern sheriffs or even the Decatur school board.
Yet the success of the Wall Street project has also raised questions about whether Jackson is offering absolution to corporations that continue to inflate executive pay at the expense of the working poor whom he has long championed.
"Obviously it's a troubling question, and I don't have the answer," says the Rev. Al Sharpton, who came of age politically as Jackson's national youth director. "As one who grew up admiring Jackson, there are some painful things for me to deal with."
Anticipating such criticism, Jackson is at pains to counter it. "There's a scripture: 'Fear not their faces,"' he says when I ask if his proximity to power has compromised his spiritual authority. "Right after we spent four days on Wall Street, we spent eight days in Mississippi. Some people can only be one or the other. They don't have the capacity to reconcile."
Jackson clearly still sees himself as a defender of the downtrodden. His protests over the students' expulsion in Decatur have all the trappings of his own civil rights days: he led marches and ensured his own arrest while demonstrators sang "We Shall Overcome." He compares the town's "power structure" to Selma's and Birmingham's, while at the same time saying that race is not central to the case. He relates the students' experience to the harsh sentencing of juvenile offenders, the underfinancing of schools and a general anger toward America's children. "This is a huge issue we have uncovered here," he says.
Yet not everyone sees it as so huge. Many of the black parents in the community agree with the school board's decision. If anything, the smaller if highly publicized causes that Jackson has embraced -- student discipline, the release of the hostages last spring -- have often served to underscore the limitations of protest politics in our time.
Jackson ran for the presidency a decade ago on a platform of economic populism -- uniting hard-pressed farmers, laid-off and low-wage workers and the urban poor, declaring that "capital does not follow conscience and it needs constraints." There had been nothing like his interracial movement of the disenfranchised since Robert Kennedy's 1968 campaign, maybe since the original Populists in the early 1890's.
But through much of the 1990's Jackson seemed to lose touch with the passions of his earlier campaigns -- trying out a career in television, feuding with and then ministering to Bill Clinton, pondering another presidential run every four years, while his political arm, the Rainbow Coalition, and his Chicago organization, Operation PUSH, declined into irrelevance.
The country seemed to leave Jackson behind: with the Dow Jones soaring, the poor disappearing from view along with the liberal wing of the Democratic Party. When welfare reform, the most drastic revision of social policy in decades, was being debated in 1996, Jackson's voice was strikingly muted.
But with the advent of the Wall Street Project, he has remade himself into the outsider's insider, moving from civil rights advocate and mass leader to power broker. "He could become the black Clark Clifford," says Don Rose, a Chicago political consultant and associate of Jackson's during the 1960's. "He's almost a wise man. He's part of the American establishment. Even Jesse Helms knows that."
Rainbow/PUSH, moribund a few years ago, is now flush with contributions from a long list of corporations, including some targets of Jackson's criticism, and staffed by a new crop of black professionals -- lawyers, journalists, money managers -- bringing a low-key culture clash with the older, mostly female, fanatically dedicated lifers from the years of dashikis and collection boxes. "It used to be more of a movement," says Louise Greene, an elderly volunteer. "It's more corporate now."
If the Wall Street Project lacks the high moral tone of the civil rights movement, it only echoes the noise of a bottom-line society moved more by power and access than by moral appeal. Jackson seems to have reached the shrewd conclusion that Bill Clinton's America is not much swayed by a desire for economic justice, and that government is unlikely to attempt anything on the scale of the movement's gains. And who can blame him for facing these facts?
"There is no position of a mass leader in our society," says Don Rose. "The job has been abolished." In July, at Jackson's urging, Clinton took a tour of poor areas around the country as part of his New Markets Initiative -- the chief antipoverty proposal of his presidency -- calling for $1.6 billion in tax credits and loan guarantees. That's not much more than Bill Gates recently promised for minority scholarships -- indicative of the country's move from public to private philanthropy. "We're on Wall Street," Jackson says, "because that's where the capital is."
To understand Jackson's latest campaign, you have to go back to the last years of the civil rights movement and the last days of Martin Luther King Jr.'s life. Jackson makes a large historical claim for what he is doing today. He calls the fight for access to capital the "fourth stage of the freedom struggle," after emancipation, desegregation and voting rights. And for precedent he often brings up the staff meeting King held on his last birthday, Jan. 15, 1968: a racially diverse group of civil rights veterans and liberal allies gathered in Atlanta to plan what would become King's final battle, the Poor People's Campaign -- an attempt to shift the movement's focus from racial segregation to economic justice.
What Jackson doesn't tell audiences today is that he and King fought bitterly over the Poor People's Campaign. It was an ideological fight, and also a classic Oedipal quarrel between a famous father who expected loyalty to his life's work and an ambitious son who revered him yet wanted to make his own mark. King, middle class and secure in his parents' love, grew up with the luxury of humble virtue. Jackson, born poor and illegitimate, fought his way into the world through sheer force of character and by dint of hard work -- Since I was 6 I was never not working," he says -- reading the newspaper to illiterate neighbors, parking cars outside football games and waiting tables.
One night in early 1965, while studying at the Chicago Theological Seminary, he turned on the television and watched a phalanx of Alabama state policemen assault a column of voting rights marchers in Selma. The next day, Jackson drove south and bulled his way into King's startled inner circle. Soon he dropped out of divinity school and became King's man in Chicago, where he headed Operation Breadbasket and helped take the movement north.
By threatening picket lines and boycotts, Breadbasket forced businesses in the city's black neighborhoods to hire local residents, deposit money in black-owned banks, give contracts to black garbage collectors and exterminators and stock black brands like Mumbo barbecue sauce and Joe Louis milk on supermarket shelves. Within two years, Breadbasket had brought 3,000 jobs to Chicago blacks and swelled the yearly income of South Side residents by $22 million. Black businessmen floated the payroll of King's desperately pinched organization.
Despite this success, mentor and protege were beginning to clash. While King was moving toward democratic socialism, Jackson was moving toward black capitalism. "His experience of the private sector was not substantial," Jackson says of King now. "He believed that the government was more likely to do what it had done before. But I believed we had to build a private-sector body of allies." Here, perhaps, Jackson was the more visionary man.
But just a few days before heading to Memphis for a garbage workers strike, King finally exploded. "If you want to carve out your own niche in society, go ahead," he shouted at Jackson. "But for God's sake, don't bother me!" Jackson had to endure his terrible loss of favor until the last moments of King's life. When King stepped out onto the balcony of the Lorraine Motel, he saw Jackson standing in the parking lot and called out, "Jesse, I want you to come to dinner with me." Then came the crack of gunfire.
Within minutes of the shooting, Jackson had King's blood on his turtleneck, which he wore in public the next day. He and Don Rose quickly sized up Jackson's prospects as King's heir. His death left a great hole that Jackson has spent three decades trying to fill. But with liberalism's long decline since the 1960's, no great dramas have brought his career into focus as Montgomery and Birmingham did King's. Now, at 58, Jackson is returning to his first mission. The Wall Street Project, he told me, is "a matured version of Breadbasket."
When I asked Jackson why he believes that the main struggle is no longer racial but economic, he muttered, "Lemme show you something." He got up from his chair and led me over to the panoramic corner windows of his hotel suite, 32 floors above Chicago. It was 7 a.m., and he had already been up for two hours, reading the papers, conferring with aides in the permanent campaign that is the substance of his days. His eyes were hooded, his voice low and hoarse. Jackson extended his finger north, toward the cluster of skyscrapers shrouded in a charcoal cloud cover.
"That's the Loop," he said. "The price of grain is determined every day in the world down on La Salle Street. That's where the financial capital is." Then Jackson pointed south toward Englewood, an impoverished neighborhood of single-family houses, part of which is in the district his son, Jesse Jackson Jr., represents in Congress.
"Today, the gap is between La Salle Street and Englewood," the senior Jackson said. "Englewood can't miss as an area of awesome potential, but the capital has been cut off." The class gap, he said, "is legal -- and widening. Historically if you say there's a race gap, then we're primed to react because of slavery, because of segregation. But somehow it's almost un-American to speak of a class gap."
Englewood represents one of the Wall Street Project's biggest challenges. Jackson and I would later take a walk through its streets with Mary Flowers, one of the district's state representatives. Half the houses seemed to be abandoned, and a few of the lots were vacant. "Who would loan them something to fix up their house?" Flowers asked in front of an occupied single-family whose porch was caving in. "See the flowerpot? She's trying, absolutely. The little what-nots in the window -- they're doing the best they can, but you think the bank will loan them some money?"
Jackson chimed in. "We have programs to develop other countries," he said. "Englewood is less risky than Indonesia. The government's more stable."
I asked if a bank loan was all that stood between these residents and regeneration.
"It's a hell of a step," Jackson said curtly.
Jackson has a remarkable ability to register the social landscape in its most immediate physical form and absorb it on the run into the framework of his ideas. The first time I met him, we were driving to La Guardia Airport when he suddenly gestured toward Brooklyn and began comparing the Wall Street Project to the Dodgers' signing of Jackie Robinson: "See, the issue never was that there was a talent deficit -- there was an opportunity deficit. Those in charge said that they were directing the major leagues. They were directing the white leagues. It wasn't 'major' till everybody could be in the free market." The analogy seemed quick-witted and apt; I've grown less fond of it since hearing him make it several dozen times.
Jackson seamlessly weaves the set pieces of his speeches into ordinary conversation, and if you spend enough time with him you begin to pick up the rhythm of their approach until, sure enough, thinking aloud suddenly morphs into stock phrasing without the slightest loss of conviction. At one point during the conference, I was trailing Jackson and Bill Bradley down a glass-encased walkway with a spectacular view of Lake Michigan, assuming these two outsize men were talking political turkey. Getting closer, I discovered that Jackson was the only one talking. I picked up the words "fourth stage," but they were enough -- I suspected that I knew by heart the rest of the soliloquy Bradley was hearing.
Having decided not to run, Jackson has thus far withheld his endorsement from both Bradley and Al Gore. In politics as in finance, access to power is creating problems for Jackson. Bradley's proposals on poverty and health care seem more like the ambitious liberalism of Jackson's own presidential campaign. But he has stronger personal ties to the vice president and seems to be leaning toward a Gore endorsement. "Gore's longer relationships with civil rights organizations in the crunch might be the difference," Jackson told me.
As for the president, he and Jackson have had a turbulent relationship ever since 1992, when Clinton strategically distanced himself from the Rainbow Coalition. Recently they've grown closer, though, as Jackson counseled Clinton during the Lewinsky scandal and then joined him on the July New Markets tour. Gene Sperling, the president's economic adviser, says: "I went into the relationship with Jackson with some skepticism. But he's been great -- more reasonable, more practical, more committed than most people you deal with in this town."
Jackson's attitude toward Clinton ranges from political criticism to "pastoral and brotherly" care to a clear-eyed analysis that can sound like self-description. "He wants to be a friend of the wealthy," Jackson says, but adds, "In his heart I think he wants to be seen as an emancipator of the poor."
Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. is more critical than his father of Clinton, Gore and Bradley. He wishes a traditional liberal would enter the presidential race -- a candidate more like the runner-up in the 1988 primaries, Jesse Jackson Sr. The relationship between father and son is strong enough that they don't hesitate to disagree publicly. When Jackson Sr. stood alongside President Clinton in the Englewood section of Chicago in November to tout the New Markets Initiative, Jackson Jr. "listened very carefully for deliverables," he says. "I heard none, and there were none."
Talking about his father's Wall Street Project, the younger Jackson says, "It's a great concept at the level stockbrokers and investment bankers play." But he also offers criticism that keeps his own constituency in mind. "Some minorities are at that level," he says, "but too few of them to affect the Second District of Illinois. It looks like we're helping too few people." Partly to correct this impression, he and his father have written a book, due out in January, called "It's About the Money!" which offers financial advice to families of more limited means.
But in spite of their obvious closeness, any talk of a Jackson transfer of power makes both men bristle. "The Reverend is part of the prophetic tradition," Representative Jackson says. "I am part of the political tradition."
Jesse Jackson Sr. has not lost his passion for those "left behind." He still flies into little towns like Godfrey, Ill., to hearten striking health-care workers whom scarcely anyone else has noticed. He arranges visits between inner-city and suburban Chicago high schools to open students' eyes to the vast inequalities of the "class gap."
In the middle of the Rainbow/PUSH conference he bolted off to address a rally of union janitors who were losing their jobs to outside workers. Within minutes they were on their feet as Jackson exhorted: "Save the workers! Save the families! Keep hope alive!" The words are beyond familiar, but the effect is still genuine.
Jackson's support of minority-owned businesses sometimes gets entangled with his concern about union jobs and wages. There's a contradiction at the heart of his efforts to emphasize class instead of race. "Diversity" has become orthodox thinking in most corporate boardrooms, whereas the need for unions and greater income equality has not -- so the Wall Street Project has ended up addressing the class gap largely through the traditional apparatus of the race gap.
The Rev. Al Sharpton points out that unlike Operation Breadbasket, which had the force of a movement behind it, the Wall Street Project doesn't draw up written covenants with corporations. Rainbow/PUSH surveys companies' hiring practices for minority representation, but the results depend entirely on the pull of a single man, Jackson, with business leaders. Without him, the project would presumably be over.
But the real question is, Who benefits? "Everyone who's left behind," Jackson told me. "If it's just for minorities, then it's open to manipulation." So far, however, the most conspicuous beneficiaries have been a handful of black investment bankers brought in as co-managers and underwriters on some of Wall Street's most lucrative new stock-and-bond issues.
"He gets you into the playing field," Shawn Baldwin, the securities trader from the Rainbow/PUSH conference, told me. "It's a very crowded playing field. He brokers access." Young, intensely driven and adamant that blacks aren't given the chance to prove themselves in the financial world, Baldwin has no interest in Jackson's politics. He often votes Republican and only learned of Jackson's new campaign by reading that Donald Trump had donated Wall Street office space to Rainbow/PUSH. Baldwin described Jackson's role as "almost like a gangster" who calls a meeting to which no one can refuse to come. "After that," he says, "it's up to you."
How these openings for a new generation of black financiers will close the "class gap" is a question that no one except Jackson himself seems able to answer persuasively. The answers I got from others were anecdotal or highly speculative. David Ormes, C.E.O. of Ormes Capital Markets in New York, whose business has tripled since the project began in 1997, told me that he has hired a trader who had been making $50,000 a year selling TV ad time and who would have been overlooked by white firms. Now, Ormes says, "the guy, who made 700 grand, was able to take his kid, put him in a $20,000-a-year private school and hire a Mexican maid." Another recruit has bought a Harlem brownstone and employs local plumbers and carpenters.
In other words, the answer sounds like trickle-down economics -- a phrase that Chee Chee Williams, director of the Wall Street Project, embraced when I floated it. We are all Lafferites now.
The most striking thing about the Wall Street Project is that hardly anyone is against it. A few conservatives call it a quota. A few liberals, like Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, propose far greater levels of government involvement. A few finance experts have questioned whether the investment funds and tax credits can overcome entrenched poverty. A few C.E.O.'s have grumbled privately about the pressure they've come under. But on the whole, Jackson is no longer controversial.
One morning in Chicago, I went to visit Tyrone Galtney, a resident of the Robert Taylor Homes, where 16,000 black Chicagoans are packed into the 16-story high rises in one of the country's worst concentrations of misery. I had met Galtney between events at the Rainbow/PUSH conference, where, in the available three seconds, he was trying to get Jackson's support to resist the demolition of the projects. Hundreds of petitioners write, call or approach Jackson every day; he gave Galtney a name to call. Three weeks later, he hadn't heard back.
"You never see Jesse Jackson coming through here saying, Stop the violence, stop the killing," he complained in his cramped room, surrounded by stereo equipment, computer hardware and piles of papers for the degree he's pursuing in urban planning. "If you can go to Kosovo, Bosnia, why can't you come to the Robert Taylor Homes?"
I began to understand why Belgrade under NATO bombing might be preferable when Galtney gave me a tour of the high rises. His purpose was to show me that "it's totally a normal life" and that the answer was honest management, not demolition. But the smell of urine in the hallways and sewage in the courtyards, the out-of-service elevators, the pitch-black stairwell, the prison-grade steel webbing that encased the buildings, the young drug courier grinning boyishly at us as he played hide-and-seek with plainclothes cops -- an hour and a half into Galtney's tour, his case was in ruins.
When I raised the issue of the Robert Taylor Homes as a tough test case for the Wall Street Project, Jackson pointed out that Deval Patrick, former assistant attorney general for civil rights and now a corporate counsel at the recently diversified Texaco, grew up near there. "What separates these kids from success is opportunity, nothing else," he said.
Don Rose, Jackson's former associate, is perhaps more candid. "There are problems in the black community for which he has no solution," he says. "Drugs, crime, not just unemployment but unemployability -- that's a pretty gritty level to deal on, and no one has any programmatic answer. Jesse doesn't. Trickle-down isn't going to change that. The sociopathy of the ghetto is hard core." Contrasting those problems with the Wall Street Project, Rose says, "I believe they're beyond him, and this is something he can do."
Even in Decatur, Ill., where the problems are not nearly so intractable, Jackson's weeks of demonstrations accomplished little. The school board reduced the students' expulsion from two years to one, but refused to budge further. Jackson is now appealing to the courts.
For all the dollars-and-cents talk of his Wall Street Project, Jackson still needs the language, the imprimatur, of the civil rights movement -- and not only as one of his levers in prying open the doors of power. He needs it also for his own sake. He is still clearly haunted by the memory and example of King, who crops up in conversation every three minutes, as if Jackson isn't entirely comfortable with his own hard-won success and still seeks the posthumous blessing of a man who died fighting for garbage workers. Asked what he reads in his spare time, Jackson answers Niebuhr and Tillich -- King's guiding Christian theologians. Out of grandiosity or goodness or some mix of the two, Jackson can't do anything without placing it in the terms of historical struggle and Biblical morality.
One Friday night after I returned from Chicago, the phone rang. It was Jackson, and he was saying: "There are roads that lead out of Wall Street in different directions. Some of them expand to South Africa. Some lead to Appalachia, the Mississippi Delta. Or to the Hamptons."
I didn't know what he was talking about. But soon his point became clear. It was the beginning of Labor Day weekend, and he had received a number of invitations from C.E.O.'s to spend it at their vacation homes on Long Island. When I asked if he was going, Jackson threw out, almost as an aside, "No, too busy" -- but it was as if he wanted me to know that he was in no one's pocket. He might be on Wall Street but he wasn't of it.
"The project doesn't get away from race," he went on, "because people of color have the double burden of caste and class. You've got sunshine on your side, and over here is shadows and a ceiling. My class is low because of my caste."
He never tires of talking about these things. In all the hours I spent with him there was never any small talk, no interest in personal questions. Suddenly, he had to go -- but before hanging up, there was one more thing he wanted me to know. The new president of Chicago Theological Seminary had pulled his records out of the vault, and a faculty group had decided that he did enough course work in the 1960's to graduate. Next spring, the Rev. Jesse Jackson will finally receive the Master of Divinity degree that he was six months short of earning when Martin Luther King persuaded him to leave the seminary at age 24 and join the movement.
