SECTION: Section 2; Page 41; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2714 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Lessons From a Wagnerian Las Vegas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW GUREWITSCH; Matthew Gurewitsch writes about the arts for The Wall Street Journal and other publications.

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
WHAT news on the Rialto?
Since spring, they've finished construction on the bridge and filled the Grand Canal; a few blocks down, a new Paris has its Opera, Eiffel Tower and Hotel de Ville; and "O" has spoiled me for "The Ring." 
 Greetings from Las Vegas, self-styled Entertainment Capital of the World, where I have lately landed to contemplate new frontiers for opera: opera, for the purposes of this discussion, standing for something greater than itself. Somewhat to the surprise of commentators unattuned to the cyclical rhythms of cultural history, an art form that not so long ago was being written off as a moribund anachronism is experiencing something like a renaissance.
Though critics complain of a repertory in stagnation, every season brings new titles anticipated with genuine excitement, and archaeological work in areas long abandoned (Handel, the French Baroque, early Mozart, bel canto) has expanded our sights quite a bit. At the same time, the ascendancy of the stage director, understood as the visionary in charge of the entire look, feel and meaning of a production, has transformed opera into the paradigm of theater itself. If opera has proved remarkably hospitable to dabblers from the worlds of spoken drama, dance and all manner of visual art, the reason is that everyone wants a piece of the operatic action. All theater, it now seems, aspires to the condition of opera.
"Prima la musica, poi le parole," or vice versa? What comes first? The words or the music? In the contemporary climate, the terms of that hoary debate seem oddly off the mark. On the list of what makes opera the glorious folly it is, spectacle now vies for supremacy with those two. Words are nothing in Las Vegas shows, and the music is at best atmosphere. But the point of this pilgrimage is spectacle, and spectacle is a commodity Las Vegas has always cultivated in spades.
Learning of my destination, some true believers in opera as our grandparents knew it were openly contemptuous. "Better you than me," sniffed one, summing up the general attitude and suppressing a yawn at the thought of the predictable fare awaiting him on his usual circuit of lyric temples. Well, he had made his bed. My own hope was to be jolted awake, my hunch being that opera could do worse than to steal a page or two from the new Vegas.
The new Vegas! In old-time show-biz algebra, of course, spectacle plus Las Vegas equaled girls, girls, girls: flamingos of the floor show asparkle in beads and sequins. Then came the boys from Germany, bearing big white cats and magic tricks. The latest extravaganzas are of a different order: pageants so rich and strange that they refresh our concept of what operatic stagecraft might be, potentially as influential as the ceremonies of Robert Wilson once upon a time (but a lot more fun).
The older shows are still eye-catching in their way, and an opera director might have occasion to lift a page from them now and then. In the interminable Captain Marvel fantasy that is Siegfried and Roy's long-running show at the Mirage, a golden army rattles in lock step, each knight hooked up to four empty suits of armor. Elsewhere, Siegfried meanders among flower-petal maidens like a senior Parsifal, encountering his Klingsor in the form of Roy, who levitates in a ring of fire. The fearless pair also encounters a dragon, Fafner to a heavy-metal T. The package has made a fortune. (The figure one hears is half a billion dollars.)
But the mind's eye of an opera fan adrift in Las Vegas can project opera just about anywhere, free of charge. The exterior of the new Venetian is ready-made for an alfresco "Gioconda" (all we need is the girl). In the maze of Caesar's Palace, a Peter Sellars "Clemenza di Tito" is waiting to happen. For "Idomeneo," cruise down to Mandalay Bay, with its man-made seashore and its six-foot breakers. Glazed eyes in stony faces keep from sight any demons clawing at the heart, yet the card tables at the casinos evoke "The Queen of Spades." The wheel of fortune whirls as in "The Gambler," though without the narcotic hum we hear in Prokofiev.
I came to Las Vegas for the waters. "O," Cirque du Soleil's site-specific aquatic spectacular, its title punning on the French for that most seductive element of the four, occupies a custom-built theater at Bel lagio: a theater unsurpassed in boldness by the Bayreuth Festspielhaus itself. Through the 90's, a string of touring shows established Cirque du Soleil as the brand name for a New Age art of the circus. That its aesthetic might also point new directions for opera might have seemed far-fetched. Now that a show and its showcase have been conceived in a single imaginative act, the kinship to the integrative ideal of opera is plain to see.
Misreading the literature, I understood "O" to take place entirely underwater, behind one wall of a tank specially microperforated so as not to fog up, with unseen respirators and frogmen in place to supply the performers with air.
The frogmen and respirators are there, beneath the surface of a pool 100 feet across. But that surface, rather than the usual stage floor, is what is seen from the house, and what is perforated is sectional platforms that rise and drop undetectably under the water. For dives from the 60-foot tower, the relevant sections sink to their maximum depth of 25 feet. At other times, the whole platform rises clear to stage level, and the cast seems to be skipping on water, until the floor dries and is, temporarily, just a floor.
At the start of the show, 16 pairs of feet sprout straight out of the pool and start dancing upside down. Later, a kaleidoscopic bevy of damsels clamber and balance into pyramid formation on a floating raft, observed by four beach boys who, between plunges, grace the pool's edge like so many Nijinsky fauns.
Water is the sovereign element here, no question, but the others count as well. At ground level, earth, an eerie procession files by, led by the sharp-beaked demon that the Klytemnestra of "Elektra" saw in the watches of the night. In the air, gymnastic phantoms man the ghost of a ship tossing through a tempest fit for "The Flying Dutchman." Most soul-shaking of all are the fires.
Picture this: Over here, a juggler bounds in, tumbling and flying around the ball of fire he swings on a chain. Over there, a hobo settles into his chair, reading his newspaper, unruffled as flame starts to lick at the toe of his shoe, unruffled as it spreads, enveloping the chair, his coat, his hat, his paper. At length he rises, unperturbed, and calmly makes to leave. Ah, but hasn't he forgotten something? Sure enough: the chair. Slowly he turns, collects his property and turns again to vanish, slowly, into the wings. What Tamino has ever done the like?
The curtain is up. In the theater's ample wings, trailing seaweed hair, masked nymphs limber up, as loose-limbed mermen hose off and serene riders mount their airborne steeds. Flashlight in hand, the technical director, Phil Jordan, ex of the Boston Ballet, is conducting a private backstage tour. From the catwalk, we have seen the curtain rip like the veil of the temple, then whisk out of sight. Below stage level, behind plate glass as in an aquarium, we have watched the clockwork choreography of the frogmen, all in black, always in the right place at the right time with air.
For the wet and scantily clad, the temperature is comfortable. A civilian in their midst is finding the air a shade tropical. But who cares? Before my eyes, in flesh and blood, are the Rhinemaidens, the Dutchman's phantoms, the Men in Armor for "The Magic Flute" of my dreams.
"I used to juggle on the street," explains Ray Wold, the blazing hobo, his fires now out. "People walked right by. I said to myself: 'I've got to make them stop. I'll set myself on fire.' " As modest and affable a fellow as you could hope to meet, Mr. Wold wears flame-resistant Kevlar from the crown of his bowler to the tips of his shoes, but nothing to shield his face. This act is his very own "Nessun dorma."
MYSTERE," Cirque du Soleil's first Las Vegas creation, is still running strong in a custom-built theater of its own at Treasure Island. In the fashion of so much contemporary theater, it is "nonlinear," but a series of images showing the transformation of grub to butterfly sustains a clear arc of continuity. Sometimes obviously, sometimes elliptically, the acts and imagery develop a pervasive theme of growth and transformation. A design motif of bulging oval bellies, like pregnancies affecting the male as well as the female may please viewers with a stronger taste than mine for the grotesque.
But there are sequences that would shine in any setting: the crystal-clear, stop-and-go group acrobatics on the ring of vertical, "Chinese" poles, or the thunderous ritual pounding of the Japanese drum, suspended in midair. Most wondrous of all -- and in a metaphoric sense, the most musical -- are Marco and Paulo Lo rador, brothers from Portugal. Their slow-motion hand-balancing routine (a dream of flight so intimate that it feels almost too private to watch), unfolds like the dialogue for violin and cello in the White Swan adagio of Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake," which, as it happens, the composer recycled from the love duet of his abandoned opera "Undine."
Of perhaps more concrete interest to the visiting opera impresario, "Mystere" features bungee aerialists, whose volleys would adorn any number of operas of the exotic and supernatural, from Monteverdi, Cavalli, Lully, Rameau, Handel, Haydn and Gluck through Meyerbeer and Verdi to the fables of Rimsky-Korsakov, Prokofiev's "Love of Three Oranges" and Henze's neglected "Konig Hirsch."
In fact, the latest "Ring des Nibelungen" at the Lyric Opera of Chicago used lip-synching bungee Rhinemaidens, who got their moves from Debra Brown, Cirque du Soleil's resident choreographer. ("Die Walkure" had silent doubles, too: spear-brandishing Valkyries who bounded and somersaulted through the air from hidden trampolines.) Ms. Brown has also worked on the premiere productions of operas at the Metropolitan ("The Ghosts of Versailles") and the Canadian Opera Company ("The Golden Ass"), experiences she treasures. Still, she wonders how far the unfamiliar medium will allow her to go.
"I find myself in opera because of work I've done in circus," she says. "But coming from circus, where there's no fourth wall, I'd like to bring the action closer to the public, and I'm not sure that's appropriate.
"Opera is the most prestigious of the arts. Circus is born on the streets. That affects how they're delivered, the relationships inside the creation. There's a whole different rhythm at the heart of it all. Circus has no unions. People work for hours on end. Their skills are honed on the street. They develop an exceptional sense of timing. If they didn't grab your attention, they would die. Their art is what puts food on their table."
But the differences may not be so profound after all. Opera, however lofty it grows, has roots in popular entertainment, too, and a singer has to grab your attention no less than a juggler. Cirque du Soleil, as it has evolved, is no closer to the street (and no farther) than La Scala. The question is, can the Cirque aesthetic, fusing material of humble origin into a process akin to opera at its most lavish, ever contribute more to opera than fetching accents?
A simplistic answer is no. Cirque du Soleil's shows develop as self-standing artistic creations, generated through the synergy of its director, Franco Dragone, and his production team, on one hand, and the specific talents of the available performers, on the other. The usual business of an opera house, in contrast, is to stage the sort of pre-existing work we like, these days, to call a "text."
Now factor in the economics. The theater at Bellagio was built -- with a proscenium stage and theater-style seating in place of the cramped cocktail tables and banquettes of Vegas tradition -- at a cost of $70 million; producing "O" came to another $22 million: figures to strike terror in any impresario's heart. And running costs?
"Still to be determined," answers Pavel Brun, an alumnus of the Russian Theater Academy with credentials in pantomime, choreography, Soviet jazz-rock and the aerial high bar, and the artistic director of Cirque du Soleil's two Vegas shows. "There's no prior experience in theater history for a long-running aquatic show," Mr. Brun explains. "We can get comparison figures from related areas like bridge construction, cruise ships, military operations." He warns against focusing on the green stuff.
"We can do a black-and-white show with sawdust, and it might impress you just as much as this one," he declares. "I'm very far from believing that a humongous budget can surmount artistic problems. Our touring show 'Quidam' cost only $2 million Canadian, which would be about $1.5 million American. That's nothing, moneywise, but it had so many things to say."
For the moment, in any case, the bottom line for "O" remains elusive. Fortunately, Steve Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts, has deep pockets. His was the entrepreneurial panache that initiated the Cirque du Soleil shows as exclusive and, he hopes, permanent Vegas fixtures. As for the income stream, tickets to "Mystere," in a 1,500-seat theater, go for $70 a pop; for "O," with 1,800 seats, the prices are $90 and $100. Each show does 476 performances a year, and most sell out. Thus, box-office receipts from "O" must total some $80 million a year, and Mr. Wynn's license to print money should be coming through any day now.
Again I ask, would a production anything like "O" be possible in an opera house? Maybe the answer will be less simplistic this time.
"You ask if it would be possible to apply Cirque's style, techniques and technology in the opera house," Mr. Brun shoots back. "Definitely. I can't wait to see it happen. Are there plans? I wish."
Mr. Brun reminds me that Cirque du Soleil is, after all, still in the business of putting on a circus. The elements it integrates are the ones that have been filling tents big and small for centuries. What is different is the framework -- and the purpose.
"Modern opera and the modern circus have the same problem," he says. "Ballet, too. Technique becomes the star of the show, the target of performance. That's wrong. Technique should be a language.
"We see wonderful singers, but their technique is overwhelming. We don't see a character, because the whole concentration is on the voice. It's the same with a trick at the circus. The ringmaster comes in and announces, 'Now we'll show you the quadruple somersault.' So what? For that I can go to the Olympics."
What is the most valuable lesson Cirque du Soleil might teach the opera crowd? "That production means much more than nice costumes, a nice set, a nice budget," Mr. Brun answers. "The job of the director is to develop a vocabulary that goes for everybody, from the diva down to the last chorus girl. It can't be done quickly. The job is to create superior individuals. If the 15th girl on the right is picking her nose, she's the one you see."
COULD the Cirque team make this happen in an opera house? Could an opera house do the job on its own?
"Without me, they can do nothing," Mr. Brun says, like other ex-Soviets keeping a straight face when striking the peremptory note.
But he exaggerates. Over the centuries, excellence in operatic production has broken forth from time to time. Even today, it is not unknown. Living witnesses can testify to the power -- total, on the right occasions -- of Wieland Wagner, Giorgio Strehler, Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, John Dexter (especially in collaboration with David Hockney), Gotz Friedrich, Harry Kupfer, Peter Sellars, Herbert Wernicke, Liliana Cavani, Luc Bondy, Nicholas Hytner, Dieter Dorn, Graham Vick.
Like Lord Elgin in Athens or Napoleon in Egypt, an opera producer on the loose in Nevada may catch the itch to plunder. Take all you can afford that will serve your purposes, say I. But most of all, look past the surface. Take fire, not window dressing. Let vision guide you. Shun hollow effect. Return to first principles. The gauntlet is down. Las Vegas has raised the bar.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1418 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Managing Risk at a Tainted Former Factory Site

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
FOR more than four decades Rowe International churned out vending machines from its 328,697-square-foot complex on Troy Hills Road in Hanover Township. When it closed in 1995 there were competing visions for the future of the 34-acre environmentally tainted site.
The Morris County township wanted to see it recycled for housing. So three years ago Hanover rezoned the land for 49 single-family detached homes compatible with those that had sprung up over the years around the old plant. Since the site was to be redeveloped for housing, state environmental laws would require that it be cleaned to the highest standard. 
 But the owner wanted to sell the property for an industrial re-use, which would require a less stringent cleanup. And Rowe International, which had started that cleanup, sued the township over the rezoning.
The result, after two years of negotiations, is unusual. LandBank, an environmental remediation and development firm based in Lakewood, Colo., acquired the site from Rowe last September for an undisclosed price, with the condition that Rowe drop its lawsuit. LandBank also assumed the risks of completing the cleanup of the property according to state standards for residential re-use.
At the same time, LandBank has a deal in place with Sterling Properties of Livingston, under which the housing developer will buy the site for an agreed upon price once the cleanup, which LandBank expects to take two years, has been completed.
Joseph Forgione, a Sterling principal, said most of the homes in the $50 million subdivision would be on quarter-acre lots, adding that they would be 2,400 to 2,800 square feet in size and cost an average of $400,000, the county average for new homes.
The resolution of the conflicting visions not only addresses the cost of the cleanup, but also offers protection from lawsuits if unknown contaminants are found -- issues that historically have daunted buyers and sellers of polluted sites. LandBank has obtained $16.65 million in insurance policies from United National Insurance Company, of Balla Cynwyd, Pa., to cover cost overruns and protect, in perpetuity, Rowe and Sterling Properties -- as well as Whippany Ventures I, the entity LandBank created to acquire the site. Future liability for the site and surrounding properties is limited to known contaminants associated with the plant.
LandBank's parent -- the IT Group, a publicly traded environmental engineering and services firm in Monroeville, Pa. -- has also supplied a guaranty to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, which oversees such cleanups, that the former Rowe site will be cleaned to state standards.
All parties involved are pleased with the resolution of the problem, calling it an example of recycling so-called brownfields as available sites for development dwindle.
"We're seeing more adaptive re-uses as a result of the state's change from a manufacturing to a service economy and of a strong residential market," said David J. Schoner, a vice president at Coldwell Banker, the residential real estate firm based in Parsippany.
He added that the activity was not surprising in eastern Morris County, where available land is scarce, because its access to job centers and major roadways continues to draw home buyers and, in turn, developers.
Mr. Forgione said that was among the reasons his company got involved with the Rowe property, which he said was among the last sizable tracts left open to development in the 10-square-mile township. "To develop such sites requires creative solutions," he said.
Efforts by the state and municipalities like Hanover are also helping to return polluted sites to productive re-use. In Hanover, "the secret is to make the economics work" on such sites as Rowe's, which are remnants of the community's past as a factory and mill town, said Sal Iannaccone, a township committeeman and Hanover's director of planning. With the Rowe site, he said, "we rezoned it to a density that provided enough building lots" so recycling could make economic sense.
Mr. Iannaccone said the township had used, or will use, the same formula for other brownfields in its borders, including a 77-acre site on Eden Lane that once housed the Whippany Paper Board factory, which has been rezoned for office use. The current owner is advancing plans to turn it into a three-building, 750,000-square-foot office complex.
EFFORTS to recycle former industrial sites got a helping hand nearly two years ago when the state enacted the Brownfields and Contaminated Site Redemption Act. The measure provides for reimbursing developers up to 75 percent of the cost of the completed cleanup -- if, among other things, the redevelopment would generate tax revenue exceeding the cost of the cleanup. It also protects purchasers from private lawsuits related to past contamination problems and carries an assurance that the state will not sue once the site is cleaned according to its standards.
The state's efforts have helped facilitate the re-use of the 10,000 contaminated sites in New Jersey, down from about 20,000 in 1985, according to the Site Remediation Program, which is under the jurisdiction of the state's Department of Environmental Protection. Of the remaining sites, 1,130 are brownfields, which the state defines as tainted industrial or commercial sites.
In the case of the Hanover deal, Alphonse J. Inserra, a case manager at the Site Remediation Program, said that "a large company that has the financing is taking on the cleanup project and will be able to do it quickly and make a profit."
Kyle R. Cascioli, director of real estate acquisitions at LandBank, said his company would clean the Rowe site to state standards without state subsidies, adding that his concern was involved with over a dozen such deals across the country.
For such deals to work, he said, they must include a site with intrinsic real estate value, a firm to competitively clean it and an insurance policy to make the seller and buyer of the land and its developer "comfortable that the risks have been removed." All those factors are in place in the Hanover deal, he said.
Mr. Cascioli said his company estimated the total cost of the Hanover project at $4.3 million to $4.5 million, including the cost to acquire, insure and clean the site, with the cleanup alone costing $1.65 million.
In addition to protecting the parties from environmental liabilities, one of the three insurance policies LandBank obtained will cover an additional $1.65 million in unexpected costs that could arise if unknown pollutants are found.
The company will recapture the overall cost of the project when it sells the cleaned property to Sterling. Mr. Forgione, the Sterling principal, would only say that his company has contracted to buy the site for more than $4 million, noting that the assurance against liability was key to the transaction.
Richard J. Conway Jr., a Morristown-based environmental lawyer who represents Rowe International, agreed.
"It's fair to say Rowe is pleased with the transaction," he said. "LandBank has a contract to clean the site and Rowe will no longer have to worry about the New Jersey facility."
Once LandBank's parent guaranteed the cleanup, the state returned the $2 million bond Rowe posted for the remediation, which Rowe and LandBank will share. Though Mr. Cascioli would not disclose how the money is to be divided, he said Rowe, which has moved to Grand Rapids, Mich., would be compensated for the land and LandBank would be able to make a profit for taking on the cleanup risk.
LandBank began the cleanup immediately after it took title to the site in September. The work involves removing asbestos from the old plant and then demolishing it and cleaning the contaminants on the site and in the groundwater, including metals such as chrome and chlorinated solvents left behind by the manufacturing operations.
Mr. Forgione said Sterling had secured county approval for the housing project, adding that it would seek approval from the Hanover Township Planning Board this month. He said he expected to start construction on the project, called Forest Hill Estates, late next summer.
As planned, the brick and stucco homes, designed by Thomas Brennan, an architect based in Plano, Tex., will have three or four bedrooms and such features as two-car garages and full basements. He said they would be built on 28 of the 34 acres of the site; the rest will be left as open space.

HEADLINE: Groups Challenge New H.I.V. Testing Law

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS

 BODY:
A LAW that took effect in Connecticut on Oct. 1 requiring that newborns be tested for H.I.V. if their mothers refuse to be tested during pregnancy or delivery is being challenged by health providers, women's groups and civil libertarians.
Opponents charged that the law is an invasion of privacy and will cause women to flee prenatal care. Supporters said it will help identify babies, and mothers, who test positive for H.I.V., enabling both to receive care. 
 The Connecticut law requires that pregnant women be counseled about the value of testing and the opportunities for treatment, but says they can still decline testing. If they do, according to the law, the babies must then be tested, as they are now tested at birth for eight other diseases.
Connecticut was the second state to pass such as law. New York passed it with similar controversy in 1996.
"Everyone agrees that testing the pregnant woman is much better than testing the baby," said Nettie Mayersohn, a an assemblywoman from New York City who was the moving force behind the New York law. "But some women don't access prenatal care, and some mothers are in denial and don't want to be tested. We have to make sure babies are identified and get into treatment."
All babies born to H.I.V.-positive mothers will test H.I.V.-positive at birth, so testing the baby is a way of testing the mother. Public health studies show that with no treatment, 25 percent of these babies will remain H.I.V.-positive, while the rest will convert to negative in about a year, when the baby develops its own immune systems and clears its mother's antibodies.
The federal Centers for Disease Control has recommended universal testing of pregnant women, but not mandatory testing.
The new law has been challenged by the Connecticut Hospital Association, which filed a lawsuit in October to overturn it. The group represents all 31 acute care hospitals in the state. The association is challenging the constitutionality of the statute based on a woman's right to privacy. The lawsuit is expected to go to trial next year in federal district court in New Haven.
Jennifer Jackson, a lawyer representing the association in the lawsuit, said, "We fully support efforts to increase H.I.V. testing in pregnant women, but we're very concerned that this law creates an atmosphere of mandated testing that may interfere with the patient-provider relationship and will discourage women from seeking health care. The law is contrary to long-standing hospital and physician policies and practices."
The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, representing women's, public health and AIDS groups, as well as some individual doctors, said it expects to file a friend of the court brief in the spring.
"When we fought this bill in the state legislature," said Joseph Grabarz, the executive director of the state Civil Liberties Union, "we brought 36 public health experts who testified that this law would be counter-productive in fighting pediatric AIDS."
Mr. Grabarz, as well as several other opponents, focus on the "fleeing care" effect they believe the law will have on women who are at high risk, or perceived to be at high risk, for contracting H.I.V., "particularly if there is a language difference or a socio-economic difference," he said, between the care giver and the pregnant woman.
But Sen. Toni Harp, Democrat of New Haven and chief sponsor of the law, said most women in high-risk groups, such as prostitutes and intravenous-drug users, are already being offered H.I.V. testing. "The women we worry about most are those who are married to I.V.-drug users or to men with multiple sex partners," she said, who may not be aware of their partners' activities that put them at risk. Many of these women's doctors are in private practice.
"This is a way to get people to understand that H.I.V. is not a disease of specific groups, but that it can affect people across the spectrum," Senator Harp said.
She also noted that the issue is very politically charged. "Some people in the AIDS advocacy community oppose the law publicly, but have told me privately that they think it's the right thing to do," she said.
Senator Harp said State Department of Public Health statistics show that 95 percent of women take the test when it's offered, but that too often care givers decide their patients are not at risk for AIDS and so don't offer testing.
A study conducted in New York state between August 1995 and January 1997 of almost a thousand H.I.V.-exposed babies was published last year by the New England Journal of Medicine. It showed that the transmission rate for babies born to women treated with the anti-viral drug AZT during pregnancy was 6.1 percent; when the mother was treated during delivery, the transmission rate was 10 percent; when treatment of the baby began during the first 48 hours of life, the rate was 9.3 percent; and when begun at three days or older, the rate was 18.4 percent.
"There's absolutely no evidence that women are fleeing treatment" because of the law, said Ms. Mayersohn, the New York assemblywoman. "Opponents said women would give birth in the streets of New York because they'd be afraid of getting tested if they went to a hospital."
But the law has actually had the reverse effect, she said.
"Women know their babies are going to be tested, so more mothers are agreeing to be tested prenatally," she said.
Opponents said the mandatory approach is an attack on pregnant women's autonomy.
"The law reduces the power of mothers to decide," said Michael Merson, dean of the Yale School of Epidemiology and Public Health and former head of the United Nations Global Program on AIDS.
Dr. Merson said that before the law passed, only a handful of H.I.V.-positive babies had been identified in Connecticut in the past few years, largely because so many H.I.V.-positive pregnant women are treated with AZT.
"Are there more babies we don't know about? That's the issue," he said. "We did not have evidence that there were a lot of H.I.V.-infected babies. Why don't we create regulations for getting the health care system to work better to test women? That shows respect for women and allows them to control their lives."
Under the Connecticut law, babies whose mothers were not tested are screened at birth for H.I.V. The results are available within 48 hours, but the screen can produce false positives. The results of a confirmatory test are not available for at least a week more.
That can lead to agonizing choices for women whose babies test positive. Mothers of these babies are told not to breast feed, because breast milk also contains the virus and can be passed to the baby. If a confirmatory test is negative, by then it's too late to start breast feeding.
Several opponents of the law also said they were concerned about giving AZT to newborns who may turn out to be H.I.V.-negative, because the medication, while effective in preventing AIDS, could harm the baby. However, there is no evidence that AZT has harmed babies who have been treated, although some doctors are concerned about possible long-term effects.
One pregnant woman who recently was offered the test, and took it, said she thought the law was a good idea. Maribel Friend of Madison has a 17-month old daughter, but she said she was not offered the test by her doctor during her first pregnancy.
She preferred taking the test as soon as possible rather than waiting until her baby was born. "With an illness like this," she said, "the earlier you find out, the better the baby's chances.
"If it had come back positive I would have said, 'Why me?' " she said. "But it could happen to anyone. You could have a partner who is cheating on you. I think people are scared to find out if anything is wrong with them, so making it mandatory is good. You want to do the best thing for your child."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Median House Prices Soar to Record Levels

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
WHEN Gary and Diana Fernbach started looking for a house, they first searched in Port Washington, attracted by its good school district and proximity to family. Since the mid-80's, they had been living in a co-op in the same community.
But they had no luck. "The worst house in town," said Mr. Fernbach, "was priced at $300,000." 
 So Mr. Fernbach, a computer administrator for a food service company in Melville, and his wife, a teacher-supervisor in a Glen Cove nursery school, did some research. They discovered that Plainview, a 20-minute drive from Port Washington, had equally good schools but far more reasonable house prices.
The four-bedroom Cape Cod into which they moved in September cost them $252,000. A four-bedroom house in Port Washington would have cost at least $100,000 more, Mr. Fernbach said.
"It was frustrating that we couldn't stay in the town we wanted, so we made a compromise," he said. "But it worked out for us because now we are very happy."
Making compromises has become a solution for many buyers in Long Island's strong housing market, where prices recently reached their highest dollar levels ever.
Sales figures obtained by the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island from its roughly 1,000 member offices show that for the month of October the median closing price of a house in Nassau County was $230,000, a $30,000 increase over October 1998. In Suffolk County, the median closing price in October was $165,000 compared with $150,000 12 months earlier.
And those figures don't tell the entire story. Because of the strong market, brokers say, increasing numbers of sellers ask brokers not to put their houses on multiple listing to avoid unnecessary heavy traffic. Sales of those exclusive listings are not always reported to the Multiple Listing Service.
Also not reported by the M.L.S. are sales by owners, co-op sales and sales by brokers who are not part of the M.L.S. system. But, said Sal L. Prividera Jr., spokesman for the New York State Association of Realtors, "We feel our realtors cover 80 to 85 percent of the market."
Carolyn Weber, vice president of ReMax of New York, which has 15 offices in Nassau and Suffolk, said sales by her agents show an overall 18.8 percent increase in prices over the 12-month period ended last October. "It boggles my mind what people are paying for properties," she said, "but we have a very affluent society around here."
"Buyer confidence" is driving the housing market, said Joseph E. Mottola, chief executive of the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island and the Long Island Board of Realtors. "The unemployment rate here is very low, the cost of our energy is less than it used to be, and you still have favorable interest rates," he said.
People who need a house may be shocked by what sellers are asking, said Teresa Angelino, a broker with ReMax's Roslyn office. "They start out with a limit in mind, but when they realize that prices may continue to go up they go the extra mile," she said.
Also driving prices up is lack of inventory. "We're in a very unique market because there is practically no product," said Jane Salamon, a partner in the Sterling Properties brokerage in Roslyn. "If a house comes on the market that is priced even within the top side of reason, it sells right away."
Even the recent rise in the national average interest for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages -- from 7.32 to 7.67 percent in six months ended Dec. 6 -- has had very little effect on the market, brokers say. Many people are taking profits out of the stock market and investing them in real estate, said Pat Masone, manager of the Prudential Long Island Realty office in Huntington. "We have people buying $2 million homes for all cash," she said.
In Jericho, which has two highly rated school districts, prices in better neighborhoods have gone up "dramatically," said Linda Petralia, manager of ERA Gatewood in Syosset. For example, she said, a four-bedroom split-level sold in July 1998 for $350,000. Last March, she continued, a similar house next door sold for $450,000.
But first-time buyers like Madelyn and John McGrane, who recently signed a contract to purchase a $238,000 three-bedroom ranch in East Northport through ReMax's Huntington office, say that waiting for the market to soften and for prices to ease also has its frustrations.
"The problem with waiting is that you wind up paying out rent when you could be owning something," said Mrs. McGrane. "I also think that houses in our price range will continue to go up because there is a housing shortage. Very little is being built for under $500,000 and how many people can afford that."
LIKE many buyers in today's market, the McGranes, who had been house hunting for six months, made an immediate offer when they saw the house they liked.
"We decided to buy in a matter of minutes," Mrs. McGrane said, "because our experience had been that houses were on the market a day or two and then they were gone."
Kathy Betz-Behette and Joe Behette also made an offer on their house as soon as they saw it. "At one point, I threw my hands up," said Mrs. Betz-Behette, describing her experiences as a home buyer. "For every house there seemed to be 50 buyers."
After searching for 18 months, she said, they found just what they wanted, a three-bedroom colonial in Williston Park.
"We liked it, the price was right, and we were not going to walk out of this home without purchasing it," Mrs. Betz-Behette said, explaining why she and her husband immediately offered the owners their $265,000 asking price.
After they made their offer, other people offered the owners $20,000 more, but fortunately for them the sellers stuck to the deal, she said.
"It used to be people would look at a house and say, 'I'll go home and think about it,' " said Toby Klingsberg, an associate broker with the Jan Kalman agency in Woodmere. "Now, if they come across something that meets their needs they jump on it."
And that leaves some sellers on the other side of the fence, faced with finding a house in a seller's market.
John Ficara and his wife, Robin, placed their four-bedroom split level in Jericho on the market at the end of August because they wanted a bigger house on a quieter street. They found a buyer two weeks later.
"I heard the market was good, but I didn't expect it to be that good," Mr. Ficara said. He declined to specify the selling price other than to say it was in the high $300,000 range. The closing will take place in January.
Fortunately, he added, he and his wife own a rental house, which they will now use temporarily until they find another.
"We've already started looking and prices are really high, " said Mr. Ficara, who is a certified public accountant. "We are hoping that the market will slow down so that we can buy on a dip."
After selling their home in Syosset two weeks after placing it on the market, Steven Sklover, a dress manufacturer, and his wife, Joan, a secretary for a cable news station, found themselves in a bidding war for a house they wanted to purchase in Williston Park. The found a four-bedroom colonial.
The seller wanted $300,000, and they made a $275,000 offer, Mr. Sklover said. But with other buyers also interested and bidding against them, they wound up paying $296,000.
Although many houses sell quickly, "buyers are very shrewd and compare properties, so if a house is overpriced, it will sit there and not sell," said Camille Pisciotto, owner of Great Neck Realty Better Homes and Gardens in Great Neck.
But the concept of what is overpriced is open to question as the market catches up with what might have been an inflated price a year ago.
For example, a four-bedroom house in Great Neck that might have sold for $350,000 a year ago now is priced at $435,000, according to Ms. Pisciotto.
The same holds true for co-op apartments in Great Neck, said Liza DiMarco, who handles co-op sales for Ms. Pisciotto. One-bedroom apartments now typically fetch $90,000 compared with $70,000 at the beginning of 1999, she said, and two-bedroom units, which are the most in demand, have risen to $325,000 from $225,000 over the same time period.
Ray Manzoni, who owns an agency that bears his name in Mount Sinai, said that prices in his area of Suffolk have increased 15 percent to 20 percent over the last year. He said he advises sellers who are in no rush to sell to price their houses at slightly more than market value and then be prepared to come down on the price. "If you can sell your house in a day, it means you're selling it too cheaply," he said.
While those selling tactics could put even greater pressure on prices, some observers predict that a leveling will occur next year as the amount of inventory increases. "I think the market will continue to do well in the year 2000," said Mr. Mottola of the Multiple Listing Service. "But as prices go up and as interest rates rise, the balance between supply and demand will begin to moderate."
Some brokers are already seeing faint signs of change. Evelyn Atanas, owner of a Williston Park real estate agency that bears her name, said she had already noticed a slight drop in the number of callers. "There are still people looking, but somehow I don't feel that excitement that was there a few months ago," she said. "Prices have escalated to such a point that a lot of people are beginning to say, 'Let me wait.' "

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Rockefeller University's Campus Bridge Over East 63rd Street;
An Engineering and Legal Feat

BYLINE: By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
Don't let its lyre-like simplicity mislead you.
New York's newest bridge, linking the north and south ends of the Rockefeller University campus across the barrier of East 63rd Street, is a complex feat of engineering -- both structurally and legally. 
 Its signature feature is an 87-foot-high, white, V-shaped steel tower on the north side of the street, between York Avenue and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. Cradled within the crook of the V is a cantilevered pedestrian deck and utility conduit, stayed by five pairs of diagonal steel cables. The cables are tied down on the north end of the bridge and threaded through the tower, extending as far as 94 feet, almost all the way across 63rd Street.
And it is the cables that one notices on approaching the bridge from the west. "The first premise was that the bridge had to be light," said Wendy Evans Joseph, the architect who designed the structure, in collaboration with Matthys P. Levy of Weidlinger Associates, an engineering concern.
The asymmetry of the bridge reduces its profile in the streetscape. "As you come upon it," Ms. Joseph said, "you see the cables -- not the tower."
The $2 million bridge will not open until early next year. But its origins can be traced to a 1973 agreement under which Rockefeller University, a biomedical research center, along with the New York Hospital and the Hospital for Special Surgery were permitted to build over the F.D.R. Drive. Rockefeller was also given the right to build over 63rd Street, through air space that was officially demapped and conveyed to the university, said its lawyer, Robert S. Cook Jr. of De Forest & Duer.
That was not the only air space involved. The new bridge also crosses an easement that the university granted to the city for an earlier pedestrian bridge along 63rd Street -- perpendicular to the new span -- that the public uses to get to the East River esplanade. "So the university had to take back a piece" of that easement, Mr. Cook said.
The new bridge will serve researchers and faculty members living in Scholars Residence and Faculty House, many of whose children attend the university's preschool center on the main campus. The towers are separated from the campus by 63rd Street, a particularly daunting crossing because it also serves as a ramp to and from the F.D.R. Drive.
The Scholars Residence was designed with a wall that could be knocked out to accommodate a bridge. But there seemed to be no economical way of supporting a span on the south end. So the bridge project was stymied until 1996, when the subject came up in a dinner conversation between Ms. Joseph and Torsten N. Wiesel, who was then president of the university. The architect asked if she might try to find a solution. Rather than designing a bridge supported at both ends, she proposed a span that would be cantilevered over the street.
Adding further complexity to the geometry of the bridge, the utility conduit branches off at the north end from the pedestrian deck, which runs into the Benjamin and Irma G. Weiss Research Building, straight through the cafeteria and past the elevator bank, ending at a curved staircase in the lobby.
The plaza in front of Weiss is also being rebuilt, to designs by Thomas Balsley Associates, working with Ms. Joseph, to create a greater sense of openness and transition to the south end of campus.
"The apartment buildings felt quite isolated," said George B. Candler, the director of planning and construction at Rockefeller University. "This, for the first time, links 400 families and gives them the sense of being part of the community." DAVID W. DUNLAP

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Legislators Approve Measure To Cover Infertility Treatment

BYLINE: By WENDY GINSBERG

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
State senators met for a voting session on Monday and the Assembly held a voting session on Thursday. Here are some highlights.
 
INFERTILITY -- Health insurers would be required to provide coverage for the treatment of infertility under a bill passed in the Senate. 
 The bill would require health care providers who insure more than 50 people to pay for services that would detect infertility and also help pay for procedures such as in vitro fertilization. A woman under 35 who has been unsuccessfully trying to become pregnant for two years would be eligible for the treatment. A woman age 35 or older would have to try to become pregnant for one year before she could receive treatment. Other medical conditions that cause infertility would also be covered under the bill.
Senator Robert J. Martin, a Republican from Morris Plains who is the bill's sponsor, said other states including Massachusetts and Minnesota had passed similar measures dealing with infertility, which he said inflicted "extraordinary physical and mental strain."
But Fred Hillmann, a spokesman for Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield, said the cost of health insurance could rise up to 3 percent if the bill is passed, an increase that he said would make insurance unaffordable for an estimated 30,000 people.
The bill now goes to the Assembly.
 
TROOPERS' LEGAL BILLS -- State troopers who are cleared of wrongdoing in a criminal lawsuit resulting from actions while at work would receive back pay and have their legal fees reimbursed under a bill passed in the Senate.
The bill would be retroactive and could cover the legal fees for the troopers John Hogan and James Kenna if they are acquitted of attempted murder and aggravated assault charges connected with an April 1998 shooting on the New Jersey Turnpike.
The bill would give troopers the same legal protections granted to other police officers in the state, said Assemblyman Neil M. Cohen, a Democrat from Elizabeth, who sponsored the bill. Currently, troopers are given representation in civil cases, but have to pay for their own defense against criminal charges.
Supporters of the bill cite the cases of two troopers who were denied back pay for time when they were suspended from duty -- in one case for more than a year -- though they were acquitted of charges. The bill now awaits approval from the governor.
 
DOMESTIC VIOLENCE -- Victims of domestic violence who are fired because they miss too many work days as a result of court proceedings would be eligible for unemployment benefits under a bill passed in the Senate.
Under the bill, people who can prove they were battered or abused would also receive worker's compensation for days they missed because they feared their abuser would find them at their workplace.
Sandy J. Clark, associate director of the Coalition for Battered Women, said the bill was necessary because a victim can become a "sitting duck" for a batterer who knows where and when the victim will be at work. She said the bill would give domestic violence victims the economic independence needed to escape their abuser.
Victims who are eligible for benefits would be subject to the same restrictions as other unemployment recipients.
The bill now goes to the Assembly.
 
PARKING TICKETS -- Motorists would be excused from paying fines for parking tickets that are more than three years old under a bill passed in the Senate.
The bill, which now heads to the Assembly, requires that a motorist be cleared of charges if the town's court system fails to provide notice of the violation by issuing a warrant for arrest or ordering suspension of a driver's license.
The bill's sponsor, Assemblyman Alan M. Augustine, a Republican from New Providence, said three years was ample time for a municipality to inform a driver of a violation.

SAFE NEEDLES -- Hospitals and other health care centers would be required to use safer needles under a bill passed by the Assembly.
The bill was prompted by estimates from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that more than 1 million accidental needle sticks occur in the country each year. Bernard W. Gerard, Jr., vice president of Health Professionals and Allied Employees, estimates that 18,000 to 30,000 needlestick injuries occur each year in New Jersey. The accidental stickings can lead to hepatitis B infections or HIV.
Rick Abrams, the president of the New Jersey Association of Health Care Facilities, said he did not oppose the bill, but has some fears about the cost of implementing it.
The bill now heads to the Senate for a vote.

Lorraine Predham and David Keir

Lorraine Marie Predham, a State Department official, and David Sherwood Keir, a lawyer, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Woman's National Democratic Club.

His father, who retired as a senior economist at the American Council of Life Insurance, a trade association in Washington, is an assistant to the Federal Reserve Governors.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
What If Officials Got a Raise And Nobody Complained?

BYLINE: By David Halbfinger; David Halbfinger reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Lawmakers here are about to give themselves a 40 percent raise, and hardly anybody seems to care.
To a new arrival from across the Hudson, it was unthinkable at first. From afar, or from the car while driving through, New Jerseyans seemed much more knowledgeable about state politics than New Yorkers, and always livid about something -- screaming over the radio or forming human chains, jealously guarding their wallets and threatening to throw the bums out at the slightest sign of government waste. 
 Not now.
Even members of the Legislature seem a little surprised at the silence. A year ago, fearing a scathing reaction from the public, they appointed a commission to give the idea of a pay increase close scrutiny, and to give themselves a shred of political cover. Conveniently, it took until after the Assembly election in November for the seven-member panel to meet for the first time, though it took just eight and a half hours spread over five days to do its entire job, recommending a jump in pay from $35,000 to $49,000 for lawmakers, the first increase since 1990.
But when the commission finally held its one and only public hearing on Dec. 1, just three people showed up to argue against a raise for lawmakers and for the governor, judges and other officials whose salaries were examined. The state's leading taxpayer groups all stayed away.
James DiEleuterio, the president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, who headed the commission, said the paucity of opposition was telling. "Don't you think that would indicate that everyone accepts the idea that people need to be paid a reasonable salary?" he said.
Certainly, a decade is a long time for anyone to go without a raise. And the proposed increases would not take effect, at the earliest, until 2002, after the next legislative election.
It is a bit of a stretch, though, to mistake the vacuum for a broad public consensus. John F. Sheridan, director of New Jersey Citizens for Tax Reform, said his group remained "adamantly opposed" to a pay raise, but didn't see the sense in saying so formally. "Why waste our time?" he said. "It's a done deal."
Yet Mr. Sheridan, who vowed to fight the re-election of anyone who votes to fatten his or her own paycheck, admitted in the next breath that his threats might not be all that meaningful.
"It depends on our fund-raising," he said. "The economy's killing everybody. When people are fat and happy, it's hard to get money. When they're scared because government's reaching into their wallet for what little they have, it's pretty easy."
Still, one has to wonder whether the commission's recommendations would have come out the same -- the lone taxpayer advocate on the panel, Sam Perelli, was essentially ignored -- had Mr. Sheridan or someone from a similar group chosen to make even a symbolic stand.
The minutes of the Dec. 3 session, for example, reflect a short discussion of legislators' pay. "The New Jersey legislature works harder than other state legislatures," the stenographer typed. "Positions are really full-time."
Mr. DiEleuterio noted that a Rutgers professor found that the average New Jersey lawmaker puts in a 35-hour week. "That's certainly starting to push the limit in terms of what should be considered a part-time job," he said.
For many lawmakers, it is a full-time job. But not for all. And neither the Rutgers professor, Alan Rosenthal, nor the commission itself paid any attention at all to how much some legislators earn in the other full-time jobs they manage to hold down at the same time.
Around 10 percent of the 120 members of the Legislature are employed in other government jobs, whether at the county or local level or in schools. And then there are the dual officeholders, among them the Assembly's minority leader, Joseph V. Doria, who is also mayor of Bayonne; Assemblyman Raul Garcia, the mayor of Union City; and Senator Nicholas J. Sacco, the mayor of North Bergen, who also is principal of a public elementary school in his hometown.
Then there is Sharpe James, of Newark, who now earns more than the president of the United States. As mayor of New Jersey's largest city, he is paid $168,000. With his pay as a state senator from the 29th district, his gross yearly earnings hit $203,000. Mr. James, of course, proposed a ban on dual officeholding as soon as he won a special election to his Senate seat. There haven't been any takers so far.
For now, the commission's recommendations seem likely to pass in a hurry, although Governor Whitman has expressed some reservations about raising the pay of members of the Casino Control Commission more than 50 percent, from $90,000 to $141,000.
"People are fat and happy," said Mr. Sheridan of Citizens for Tax Reform. "They're thinking about Y2K, and the Christmas holidays. Nobody's paying attention. When the bills come due, and they will, there's going to be a mighty angry electorate out there."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Spoonful of Sugar For Microsoft's Bitter Pill

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
A Spoonful of Sugar
For Microsoft's Bitter Pill
HERE was a second round of secrecy-cloaked settlement talks between Microsoft and the Government last week in Chicago. The only sure thing about these meetings, presided over by Richard A. Posner, a Federal appeals court judge, is that they are hardly social gatherings; there is no love lost, and a common ground for compromise will not be easy to find.
Microsoft will not voluntarily agree to the harsher sanctions being considered by the Justice Department and 19 states -- a breakup of the company or forced licensing of the programming code for Windows -- unless Judge Posner proves to be a sorcerer instead of a mediator. And the government will not accept a sin-no-more solution in which Microsoft signs a settlement that prohibits certain kinds of conduct or contracts. 
 Is there any sensible middle ground? That remains to be seen.
Hal R. Varian, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, has an intriguing proposal. Mr. Varian is a leading "new economy" academic who studies the workings of high-technology markets. He was co-author of a widely praised 1998 book, "Information Rules," with his Berkeley colleague Carl Shapiro, who was the Justice Department's chief antitrust economist in 1995 and 1996 and is now advising the states on remedies in the Microsoft case.
In a settlement or in court-ordered remedies, Mr. Varian says, it is a foregone conclusion that Microsoft will be swallowing some strong medicine, considering Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's blunt findings last month that the company was a monopolist whose tactics had thwarted competition and hurt consumers.
Mr. Varian says two measures will be "an absolute minimum." The first is to make Microsoft publish prices it charges personal-computer makers for its Windows operating system and to open up its marketing contracts with PC makers, Internet service providers and others. Mr. Varian says such pricing and contract "transparency," monitored by a third-party watchdog, would inhibit Microsoft from using price and other incentives to reward companies that gave its products favored treatment and punish those that did not -- a key allegation in the antitrust suit.
THE second minimal step, according to Mr. Varian, would be to require Microsoft to publish Windows application program interfaces and explain how they work. These interfaces, known as A.P.I.'s, are the software hooks that enable other companies' programs, from word processors to games, to run properly on Windows computers. Some software developers contend that Microsoft has "hidden A.P.I.'s" in Windows that give a leg up to its own applications business and favored partners. Microsoft dismisses that assertion as the equivalent of an urban legend. Other developers say the real problem is that the A.P.I. documentation from Microsoft is often misleading or erroneous.
Both steps would help achieve the government's main policy goal in the antitrust case: to limit Microsoft's ability in new markets to use Windows monopoly power to its advantage, from server software to e-commerce. "But the real issue is what you do beyond documented A.P.I.'s and transparent contracts," Mr. Varian said.
His next step is his innovative contribution to the Microsoft debate. Mr. Varian recommends compulsory licensing of Windows at a deep discount after a set period. Say the license price for Windows 98 is $55 a copy. After two or three years, the price would drop by perhaps $30. The timing and discount could be negotiated in a settlement or determined by a court.
Throughout the case, Microsoft has said that it is simply fighting for the right to innovate and add whatever it wants to its operating system. "This plan would really give them an incentive to innovate, because in two or three years the existing version of Windows is going to get a lot cheaper," Mr. Varian explained.
Today, new versions of Windows face competition of sorts from the old versions, but Microsoft makes sure that PC makers have every incentive to upgrade at the pace that suits Microsoft. Under the Varian option, however, manufacturers like Dell Computer, Gateway and Compaq could offer both and permit consumers to choose the older, cheaper version if they preferred.
The economic incentives for Microsoft might also change, so that bundling ever more features into a bloated operating system stops making sense. Instead, it might see greater overall profits in making Windows a leaner, faster, more reliable core operating system and in marketing new features like voice-recognition software as a separate product.
The Varian solution is not simple, since it requires a form of policing and regulation. But there are only complex answers to the Microsoft problem. Mr. Varian's mirrors the logic of patents and copyrights: the inventor is rewarded with exclusive rights for a while, but the duration is limited to avoid the social losses from monopolization.
"With this, the software passes into the compulsory licensing phase, not into the public domain," Mr. Varian said. "But the result is the same. You would get a temporary monopoly in the intellectual property that provides a balancing of private incentives and the public good."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
Business District Hangs Its Hopes on a New Manager

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
A decade ago, much of the Lower East Side was dilapidated and dangerous. Storefronts were boarded up and drugs were rampant. But in the last few years, the neighborhood has turned its gritty reality into a virtue, attracting the young and chic to its bars, restaurants, stores and avant-garde theaters.
Matthew Bauer, the former executive director of the Lower East Side Business Improvement District, is often credited as the engine behind the best of those changes. 
 "I think Matthew was the first person to really organize a very disparate group of merchants," said Susan Vaughn, the chairwoman of Community Board 3. "He brought a lot of positive publicity for the area."
But Mr. Bauer left three months ago to become president of the Madison Avenue Business Improvement District. The Lower East Side district has hired Andrew Flamm, 31, a former marketing manager with the city's Economic Development Corporation, to fill his shoes.
"Andrew's background was eclectic," said Howard Slonim, the business district president. "He had an economic background and a business development background, and also experience in relating to merchants. He was a natural fit for the position."
Mr. Flamm, who started work last month, said he had been getting to know the merchants. He said they told him that they wanted continued foot traffic and a more physically attractive area for shoppers.
If the past is any indication, he will have his hands full trying to accommodate the conflicting needs of the traditional Lower East Side businesses, the newer merchants, bars and restaurants, and the neighborhood's residents.
"I don't know anything about the new guy," said David Troutman, a community organizer, but he said that in the past, the district had "pushed aside the wishes of some of the smaller businesses, and certainly the wishes of some of the residents." One continuing problem, he said, is that the neighborhood has too many noisy bars.
"We want some community planning," said Clayton Patterson, a longtime resident. "We want to see greengrocers. We want to see things that benefit the community at large, not just people who don't live here, and rent out their property for the maximum amount of money."
Mr. Flamm said, "My goals are much the same as his." He added that one long-term plan is to work with the Essex Street Market to create a low-cost business incubator for high-quality food vendors. Other plans include finishing projects started by his predecessor, such as decorating the medians on Delancey and Allen Streets, installing bishop's-crook light fixtures and planting more trees. HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Cola Makers Leave Their Bottlers Flat

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
COCA-COLA, the soft drink, is based on a closely guarded secret formula. But the arithmetic that results when Coca-Cola, the company, decides to squeeze more profit from its complex relationships with its bottlers was laid bare last week.
On Friday, shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises, in which Coca-Cola holds a 39 percent stake, closed at $18.375, less than half their 52-week high of $37.50. The share price of Coca-Cola Consolidated, the No. 2 Coke bottler in the United States, closed at $49.75, down 13.5 percent for the year. 
 This had already been a bad year for the bottling stocks, but it became worse last month. That was when an executive of Coca-Cola Enterprises disclosed that Coca-Cola was raising the price it charges for concentrate -- the powder or syrup that is mixed with water and carbon dioxide to become soft drinks -- by 7 percent, twice the usual rate. The move was seen as Coke's attempt to capture some of the profit that the bottlers were anticipating from a price increase they initiated earlier this year at the wholesale level.
For Summerfield Johnston Jr., the chairman and second-largest shareholder of Coca-Cola Enterprises, a result has been this: In early June, his 28.6 million shares were worth about $1.07 billion; the value of that stake has been whittled down to about $525 million.
"I would say he's not a happy camper on this whole thing," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. The unhappiness of bottlers like Mr. Johnston -- whose opinions carry some weight at Coca-Cola -- may have been a factor in the departure of M. Douglas Ivester, Coca-Cola's chief executive. Mr. Ivester stunned investors last week with the news that he was stepping down in April.
The concentrate price increase was imitated over at Pepsi-Cola a short time later. And for the Pepsi system, it has been the same story: shares in Pepsi Bottling, the company spun off from PepsiCo earlier this year, are now at $16, after trading as high as $25.25 in July. And the Whitman Corporation, another major Pepsi bottler, now trades at $13.125, down 48 percent for the year.
The stock prices of the concentrate companies, however, have fared better. Coca-Cola closed on Friday at $63.25, down just 5.6 percent for the year, while PepsiCo closed at $36.9375, down 9.6 percent.
Does all this mean that investors should avoid bottling stocks? Not necessarily, say some money managers and analysts.
"The upside isn't limited if you are a long-term value player," said Scott Black, the president of Delphi Management, which is among the top five stakeholders in Coca-Cola Consolidated and has a stake in Pepsi Bottling. "You're getting exclusive territorial franchises, a business that generates lots of cash, and very low multiples." With cash flow growth of 10 percent or so in good times, the stocks are attractive.
Mr. Goldman said he thought all the bottling stocks had been oversold. He has 12-month price targets of $40 on Coca-Cola Enterprises, $31 on Pepsi Bottling and $16 on Whitman.
A spokesman for Pepsi Bottling, which announced the Pepsi-Cola concentrate price increase last month, said the timing was right as long as PepsiCo made marketing-support payments to the bottler. "Consumers have to want what we make, sell and deliver," said the spokesman, Larry Jabbonsky.
The relationship between the concentrate companies and their bottlers has been a concern on Wall Street. Many investors want to see a more equitable distribution of profits between the two sides; historically, more of the profit has accrued to the concentrate makers, whose margins are extremely high. Returns on invested capital have also been far higher for the concentrate companies than for the bottlers.
STILL, there seems to be some confusion, said Paul Rissman, a senior vice president at Alliance Capital Management, who recently added to stakes in Coca-Cola Enterprises and Pepsi Bottling, both of which he calls "incredibly cheap."
"If the concentrate companies were to intend to rob some of the profits from the bottlers, they'd just be cutting off their noses," he said. "We think they know that. We think they are trying to reach agreements with the bottlers where they can both make money."
Companies like Coca-Cola have urged ever-higher volume from their bottlers, and stand to benefit from increased concentrate sales. But there has been a big cost to bottlers around the world, said Andrew J. Conway, an analyst for Morgan Stanley.
In a note to investors published last week, Mr. Conway assessed Mr. Ivester's contributions and generally gave him high marks. However, he said volume growth targets of 7 to 8 percent -- which Mr. Ivester's successor, Douglas N. Daft, said he planned to pursue -- had a distinct downside.
"Mr. Ivester's targets have led to an unprecedented rate of bottler investment in plants, trucks, machinery and coolers," Mr. Conway wrote. "Given the global economic slowdown, this rate of investment was well ahead of the volume curve that has emerged. In turn, this has left many global bottlers with subpar returns on invested capital."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Sleepy Steps For Japan After a Long Hibernation

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
WHEN Commodore Perry parked his big black ships at the mouth of what is now Tokyo Bay nearly 150 years ago and demanded entry, Japan was still a feudal society.
At the moment, Japan appears to be tentatively emerging from a more modern version of the Dark Ages, an economic recession that has lasted for most of the decade. More important, the rigidity that has been the hallmark of its postwar economic structure appears to be cracking. 
 Politicians are talking about doing things that have been going on elsewhere for years: privatization, deregulation, restructuring, promoting competition.
Foreign direct investment, never very popular in Japan, is rising. The banking system is being reformed. And some big companies that used to guarantee lifetime employment are announcing layoffs.
Such developments have not gone unnoticed: the Topix stock index is up nearly 50 percent this year.
P. Nicholas Edwards, a managing director and head of the Warburg Pincus Japan Growth fund, talked about the Japan that seems to be emerging from the rubble. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Numbers released in Tokyo last week suggest that after two periods of very modest expansion, Japan's economy contracted a bit in the third quarter. After being so weak for so long, are conditions still that fragile?
 
A. The numbers were badly reported in the U.S. The headline number was worse than expected, although that was largely due to the fact that prices as measured by the gross domestic product deflator fell more than they had in the second quarter. In real terms, the economy grew at just under a 1 percent annual rate, up from 0.6 percent in the previous quarter.
Over the next 18 months, the economy won't show tremendous growth. It will grind through that period with growth of somewhere between 0.5 percent and 1 percent. Two years down the road, the economy should really accelerate.
 
Q. What about the Japanese consumer, who unlike his Western counterparts would rather save money instead of spend it?
 
A. The consumer is feeling more buoyant than he was, but that is a relative judgment, because he was very depressed a year ago.
Computer sales are up 57 percent year-over-year, and last month car registrations turned positive for the first time in 32 months. Consumers don't feel ebullient, but they do feel a bit better and there is a constructive view going forward.
 
Q. That is not exactly the sort of economic outlook that should excite investors. Yet the stock market is doing better. Why?
 
A. The story about Japan and the stock market -- and it has been a tremendous year if you were in the right areas -- is about Japan feeling its way to the creation of the new economy which surrounds the Internet and telecommunications and restructuring. Some companies are working very hard and are very focused on improving value for shareholders. Others are less focused.
 
Q. Which companies best symbolize this new Japan?
 
A. I refer to them as the Three Musketeers -- Softbank, NTT Mobile Communications Network and Hikari Tsushin. Those companies symbolize the growth in the telecommunications and Internet sector in Japan.
 
Q. Any other companies that come to mind?
 
A. Sony and Fujitsu have done well. But it is really a sector thing. A number, including telecommunications, electronics, specialty retailers and securities brokers, have done well. The rest have underperformed. Fifteen of the 33 groups of stocks in Japan are down for the year. Steel, mining, foods,
warehousing are all the boring old sectors.
 
Q. What is your 2000 market forecast?
 
A. The outlook is not quite as good, but the basic premises of the thesis remain sound: by continuing to invest selectively in the winners one should continue to do quite well.
 
Q. In the depths of the Asian crisis, it was commonly held that the rest of Asia couldn't recover without a vigorous Japan. Things don't seem to be panning out quite that way.
 
A. The fact that the economy has gone from negative to positive growth, and that the currency is stronger, has been positive for the region. It may be a while before Japan becomes an engine again, but Asia looks quite good because Japan looks better.
 
Q. Japan is a very traditional society with entrenched elites. What are the chances the forces that represent those elites, and the old economy, will prevail over those who represent the new economy?
 
A. There is validity in the fact that there are forces of conservatism in the country. But there is zero chance the old will win out over the new.
Culture is irrelevant. If you compare Great Britain of the 1950's through the early 1970's to today, it is apples and oranges. At the moment, Japan is probably halfway through its transformation.
