HEADLINE: The World;
Syria Grabs A Moment To Bargain

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: BEIRUT

 BODY:
AMERICANS have never quite figured out Hafez al-Assad. Most see him as a kind of tyrant, even a terrorist -- a leader who supports extremists abroad and suppresses opponents at home. As rendered on those oversized Soviet-style posters, he can look the part of a dinosaur, a relic from a pre-global, pre-millennial, pre-New Middle East past.
There is truth to that image; Mr. Assad has a record of ruthlessness, though most of it dates from more than a decade ago. But he has also ruled with finesse, willing to forgive some foes when the reward is stability. 
 Until he took power in a 1969 coup, Syria was fractious; under Mr. Assad, that problem was solved by imposing iron rule rather than democracy; still, that brought the gift of stability.
Little wonder, then, that Mr. Assad has long been seen as the Arab neighbor with whom Israel most wants to make peace. The reason has only a little to do with Syria's military strength, which is now faded, and almost everything to do with Mr. Assad himself. More than any of his Arab counterparts, he is seen as a man who understands both power and survival. And he has a record of keeping what few bargains he has struck with Israel. So he is viewed as someone who, if he made a deal, would make one that sticks.
In addition, he has a great deal to say about what happens in Lebanon, which ended its civil war in the 1980's only by turning to Syria as a power broker and inviting in its army. Lebanon remains a base for guerrilla attacks on Israel, which keeps control of a tense buffer zone that is the scene of frequent bloodshed.
That is why, for more than a decade, one of the biggest questions in the Middle East has been when Mr. Assad might see advantage in aggressively seeking a deal. With the surprise announcement last week that he was ready to send his foreign minister to Washington to meet with Israel's prime minister, a new question looms: Might this really be the moment?
There is good reason to think so, and not just because of the small shift in his stance that opened the way toward peace talks when Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright visited Damascus early in the week.
Behind that shift lies a broader sense not only of new opportunity, but of urgency.
Until early this year, Mr. Assad had always carried himself as if time did not matter. He had prided himself on his refusal to compromise; to win peace, Israel would have to withdraw from every inch of the Golan Heights. In recent months, his government had gone further, saying that even to restart talks, Israel would have to publicly commit itself to borders that existed before the 1967 war, something Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, would not do.
But Mr. Assad is 69 now and clearly ill. Since early this year, he has seemed preoccupied by a need to cement the position of his son, Bashar, 34, as his heir apparent, and his decision to return to the talks without such a public Israeli commitment suggests a further recognition that it would be foolhardy to wait too long.
Perhaps Mr. Assad feels peace with Israel would guarantee his place in history. But perhaps more important, it could transform Syria's domestic environment to his son's advantage. The younger Mr. Assad is a staff colonel but has little military experience and lacks the confidence of the former Baath Party bosses and long-serving generals. His strength is his close ties with Syria's business community. So it seems logical that a Syria at peace, with an eye on prosperity rather than security, would be a far easier place in which to establish himself in power.
To Syrian ears, another clock has begun to tick more loudly than ever -- the one marking progress toward a final Israeli-Palestinian peace. With the Israelis and Palestinians now pledging to wind up their final peace talks by late next year, President Assad does not want to find himself shut completely out of the circle of peace -- including decisions to be made on the fate of Palestinian refugees, more than 500,000 of whom now live in Syria or Lebanon.
The winding down of President Clinton's last term is yet another ticking clock, this one measuring how long the White House might be willing to put pressure on Israel to cement Mr. Clinton's own legacy.
Mr. Assad, of course, has been here before. The talks in Washington are to begin "at the point where they left off" nearly four years ago, when Israel walked out after Islamic militants launched a bus-bombing campaign in Israel, soon to be followed by an all-out conflict in southern Lebanon between Israeli forces and the Syrian-backed Hezbollah guerrillas.
That history shows how easily peace can be sidetracked by violence. But this time, as Mr. Assad clearly recognizes, changes in the Middle East have presented Syria with better opportunities -- particularly in Lebanon -- to untangle itself from its conflicts.
As one price for peace, Israel has made clear its demand that Syria rein in Hezbollah, the Lebanese guerrillas whose attacks on Israeli forces and towns have been used by Damascus to put pressure on Israel. But doing that is not like turning off a tap.
ARMED by Iran and fueled by Iranian-inspired ardor, the guerrillas are subject only to indirect Syrian control. Four years ago, a Syrian attempt to shut them down almost surely would have been met with open rebellion from some, at least. But this is not the Lebanon of four years ago, in part because Iran, too, has changed. The Revolutionary Guards who once trained militants in the art of terror in Lebanon's lawless Bekaa Valley have long since departed. And since Mohammed Khatami assumed Iran's presidency in 1997, he has been trying to put an end to Iran's isolation, even though he still faces opposition on that score from very powerful conservatives. That power struggle in Tehran presumably gives Mr. Assad some room to maneuver if he wants to curb the militants.
Last summer, Mr. Assad's government warned Palestinian militants based in Syria that if peace were to come, it would be time to find a new line of work. Through Bashar Assad, Syria later sent the same message to Hezbollah. Among diplomats in Lebanon, the betting is that if peace were to come soon, the message would be heeded.
Of course, even if the new road leads to peace, the path is unlikely to be straight. Syria and Israel have been enemies for 50 years, and much distrust still lies between them. Many skeptics in Israel and the United States think Mr. Assad's opening was just a sucker bid, intended to lure Israel into a big concession or, perhaps, to persuade the United States to end sanctions.
Mr. Assad's associates say he frowns on the theatrics that have come to be associated with Middle East peacemaking. Still, simply by dispatching Farouk al-Shara, his foreign minister and closest adviser, to Washington this week, Mr. Assad knows that he is sending a new signal; never before has so a high-ranking a Syrian official held direct talks with an Israeli delegation. If Mr. Assad himself joins any talks, diplomats here guess, it will not be until the final moments, when a deal is ready to be signed. But for the first time in memory, the diplomats say, that prospect now seems more real than fanciful.

HEADLINE: In the Workplace, Who's Taking From Whom?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Big Theft, Small Theft: Is There a Difference?" (The Right Thing, Nov. 21), in which Jeffrey L. Seglin discussed the ethical issues surrounding employees' thefts from companies -- and whether the taking of company property is justified, for example, if the company has stolen the employee's personal time:
I think the column was correct in calling for flexibility and reasonable discretion in dealing with such issues, but it provided no specific guidance. 
 That, of course, is the basic problem with flexibility: when we don't have some agreed-upon ideas on where to draw the lines, many people will go too far.
One helpful standard might be this: Does a given behavior increase or decrease the total resources available to everyone?
For example, if I make a phone call from my desk to make a dental appointment, it takes about a minute. If I wait until my break and go downstairs and use a pay phone, it takes about 10 minutes, costs a quarter and makes it hard to write the appointment on my calendar.
The inefficiencies that would be required to strictly devote every working second to one's work make no sense -- there would be fewer hours for useful activities.
On the other hand, when employees devote large chunks of job time to personal business or schmoozing, it is hard not to believe that everyone is made worse off. The biggest costs in most businesses are for labor. An employer with inefficient workers is simply not going to produce enough revenues to afford high wages.
 
DAVID BURRESS
Lawrence, Kan., Nov. 22
 
The writer is a research economist at the University of Kansas.

HEADLINE: Critical Shortage of Lawyers for Poor Seen

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE

 BODY:
A shortage of lawyers willing to represent New York City's poor is reaching "crisis proportions" and creating "chaotic, delay-ridden" courts, the state's chief administrative judge is warning.
In Criminal Court, the lack of lawyers has forced dozens of defendants to spend six months to a year in jail awaiting trial, largely because no court-appointed lawyers have been available. One defendant has spent more than two years awaiting trial, court officials said. 
 "We're at a real turning point in terms of being able to find adequate defense representation to keep the system going," said the judge, Jonathan Lippman.
In Family Court, where the appointed lawyers represent poor parents in foster care disputes and custody cases, up to 50 parents are sent home each week because no lawyer is available, court officials said.
In a rare show of unanimity, judges, prosecutors, defense lawyers and the Giuliani administration agree that the court-appointed defense system needs a drastic overhaul.
The heart of the problem is a long-troubled, $52 million program that has soared in size and importance as a result of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to reduce the influence of the Legal Aid Society, the city's largest criminal defense organization for the poor, which has a staff of salaried lawyers. The program, the Assigned Counsel Plan, was created in 1965 to match private defense lawyers with indigent defendants in murder cases and a few other cases the Legal Aid Society could not handle.
In the wake of the mayor's successful breaking of a 1994 strike by Legal Aid lawyers and a surge in quality-of-life arrests, the number of poor people represented by the program has surged to more than 80,000 a year. Self-employed lawyers now handle about half of the criminal cases in the system, and the remainder is split among the Legal Aid Society and other nonprofit groups. The assigned-counsel program now handles more criminal cases than the Legal Aid Society.
But the program, which has long been dogged by accusations of shoddy work and overbilling, is providing its lowest-quality legal representation in decades, according to criminal justice officials. Experienced lawyers are leaving the program, complaining that caseloads are soaring and fees have not been increased in 13 years. And budding lawyers are failing to enroll in the program because of its low pay and a declining interest in public service work, law professors said.
The number of lawyers actively participating in the program in Criminal Court has plummeted from roughly 1,000 a decade ago to less than 500 today.
"We are unable to keep many of our most highly qualified and most experienced lawyers," said Harvey Fishbein, a lawyer who heads the program's screening committee in Manhattan and the Bronx. "And the attorneys that remain on the panel are overwhelmed by the number of cases."
The state court system, prosecutors' association, bar association, attorney general and City Hall support a $70 million proposal by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye to overhaul the program by doubling the lawyers' fees.
But Judge Kaye's proposal, which was unveiled in June, has received tepid support in Albany. John McArdle, a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, said Mr. Bruno opposed the plan because of financing concerns.
Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said they had not taken positions on the proposal. Legal experts and participants in the program said that because it serves criminal defendants, the poor and members of minorities, winning support is difficult.
Judges, prosecutors and participants agree that the program's inability to attract lawyers stems from its low pay. Lawyers are paid $25 to $40 an hour for their work with indigent clients, one of the lowest rates in the country. Federal court-appointed work pays nearly twice as much -- $75 an hour -- and private defense lawyers can earn from $150 to $500 an hour. A few lawyers who devote their practices to such cases are forced to work out of their homes.
Lawyers with successful private practices who take only a few court-appointed cases warn that the low fees invite incompetence and fraud. "No competent criminal defense lawyer zealously representing his clients can make a living on those rates," said Ronald Kuby, a Manhattan defense lawyer. "So you either cut corners, do huge volume or inflate your hours."
Chester Mirsky, a professor at New York University Law School, said higher fees might not be enough to attract more lawyers to the program. He said the defense system for indigents needs to be revamped and new ways must be found to attract young lawyers.
Anthony Ricco, a court-appointed Manhattan defense lawyer whom judges and administrators describe as the kind of experienced trial lawyer the program needs to retain, said the low fees have forced him to shift the bulk of his court-appointed work to federal cases. "I can't survive economically on the rates," Mr. Ricco said. "They are horrendous."
Morale among the lawyers who remain in the program is at rock bottom. "You truly have to be crazy to do this," said Susan Tipograph, a Manhattan lawyer who has worked in the program since 1977 and helps administer it. "You get abused by judges and you get abused by clients because they think you must be a bad lawyer because you're doing this kind of work."
The lack of lawyers interested in the program results in cases like that of Jeffrey Martinez, a Bronx man who has spent two years and three months waiting in jail for his trial on murder charges. Patrick Watts, Mr. Martinez's court-appointed lawyer, said the case was initially handled by another court-appointed lawyer, who became ill. He added that he had been too busy defending other indigent clients to bring Mr. Martinez's case to trial.
Low-level cases generated by the mayor's crackdown on quality-of-life crimes contribute to the problem. Swamped court-appointed lawyers sometimes fail to appear when their clients are in court. The no-shows delay a resolution of the case and clog the system, judges said.
In the Manhattan Family Court building, where distraught and weeping parents are a grim fixture, clients complained that overworked lawyers were unable to pay serious attention to their cases. Margaret Pacheco, a 45-year-old Manhattan woman on methadone whose 4-year-old son, Frankie, was placed in foster care last year, broke into tears on Friday when describing her efforts to win back custody of her son.
"They try, but there is so much pressure on them," she said, referring to her lawyers. "We can't afford to get a real lawyer, so we end up losing out."
New state regulations that require some children to be put up for adoption within a year of being placed in foster care will exacerbate the problem, court officials and lawyers say.
Edwina Richardson, a court-appointed lawyer from Brooklyn who works in Family Court, concurred. "You're dealing with the fundamental right of being able to raise your children," she said. "When there is a delay in talking to an attorney or there is a delay in even getting an attorney in that type of case, parents are justifiably upset."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Rising Above Obstacles With Custom-Made Help

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL

 BODY:
Mary L. Robinson cannot remember when she and her husband split up. It might have been before she was hit by the white sedan. It might have been after. The two events had nothing to do with each other, except one meant the end of suffering, and the other marked its beginning.
Ms. Robinson, who is now 48, says she was abused for a decade by her second husband, who assaulted her and so demoralized her that she tried to take her own life three times. Her only respite was work, she said. Although she had not finished high school, she proudly held down a job as a receptionist and word processor at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. 
 But in 1990, as she was crossing a street in Crown Heights, the Brooklyn neighborhood where she lived, a car ran a red light and hit Ms. Robinson, who rolled onto the hood of the car, her spine fractured.
While she was recovering, she received government assistance that allowed her to continue caring for her two children, then 6 and 7. The physical loss was devastating, Ms. Robinson said, but it was the psychological blow that took the greatest toll.
"I went, like, down," she said. "I lost confidence in myself, and I didn't want to be around people or have anyone around me, even my family. I didn't want to leave the house. I just wanted to be alone."
Ms. Robinson knew she wanted to get off welfare, but she did not know how.
She had once signed up for workfare, but her first assignment was removing garbage from the side of highways. Not only was she unsettled by the cars roaring by, which reminded her of her accident, but the arduous labor also made her back pain flare up. She did not even last a day.
It is a new initiative of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, that will help Ms. Robinson find a job she can succeed in. The program, Pride 2000, which started in July, serves 1,000 to 1,200 disabled welfare recipients from Brooklyn each year.
Two days a week at the program, Ms. Robinson gets computer training and attends classes to prepare for the G.E.D., the General Educational Development Test. She gets hands-on work experience as a receptionist three days a week. While completing Pride 2000, which the agency calls work-based education, Ms. Robinson is also offered counseling and workshops in building self-esteem.
Wayman M. Young, director of Pride 2000, said: "Many of the people in the program have not worked before, and those who have usually have disabilities or medical conditions which prevent them from working at their former occupations. So, you need to create an atmosphere that is conducive to their making a slow transition back to the workplace."
Mr. Young said the program focuses on each client, because many of the welfare recipients have a particular set of barriers to employment.
"We do individual service plans, because one size does not fit all," he said. "It requires a customized fitting, so to speak, and a customized growth of that fitting."
In addition to the Brooklyn Bureau's efforts, there are various other programs among the charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund to assist welfare recipients and other people who have had trouble entering the work force -- whether because of disability, language difficulties or lack of educational skills.
Many people served by job programs supported by the Neediest Cases Fund need this kind of personal attention, experts say.
Since federal and state welfare agencies began revamping programs to move recipients from welfare to work, many families have been able to enter the nation's work force, through a combination of job training, motivational workshops and the added incentive of looming time limits for receiving benefits under the 1996 welfare legislation.
But many people still on public assistance face severe obstacles to employment, said Barry Van Lare, executive director of the Welfare Information Network, a nonprofit national clearinghouse based in Washington.
At the time of the 1996 legislation, Mr. Van Lare said, it was estimated that about a third of people receiving assistance would be able to get off the rolls with minimal support from the public sector. Another third were considered more difficult cases, he said, and the others were categorized as people with severe impediments to finding work. As the more employable segment of welfare recipients moved off the rolls, those in the "severe impediments" category became a much more significant portion of the whole. Sheila R. Zedlewski, director of the Income and Benefits Policy Center at the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan nonprofit group in Washington, said they make up 40 percent to 50 percent of current recipients.
Mr. Van Lare said: "What we're all observing is that lots of people who have barriers are able to get to work, but there are still lots of people who have multiple barriers who can't get off the rolls. Of those who don't succeed early on, many are going to require more intensive and extensive services."
It took a certain amount of hand-holding to help Ms. Robinson get back on her feet. Even as she tells her story, her eyes dart across the room to Juana Tellado, her case manager, who has guided her through classes, work and some of the painful memories that haunt her.
"If she can talk about her life and her whole experience, that's an important part of change," Ms. Tellado said. "If she's willing to open herself and say, 'I was hurting myself when someone else was hurting me,' to me that's an indication that you're building self-esteem."
 
Language
For Many Immigrants, The Biggest Hurdle
For Dianna P., 43, a single mother who lives in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, the biggest hurdle from welfare to work was the English language. When Dianna (who does not want to use her full name because she does not want people to know that she was receiving welfare) immigrated to the United States from Odessa, Ukraine, a year ago, she received $277 a month, and six weeks' worth of classes in English as a second language from the refugee support program of the New York Association for New Americans, a nonprofit agency for immigrants. But she did not become proficient enough to navigate the job market.
Everywhere she applied for work, she said, the answer was, "We'll call you."
"I was ready for this situation," she said through a translator. "I understood I was a new person for this country, and I tried not to be disappointed." But it was discouraging nonetheless.
Although Dianna had been a bookkeeper in Odessa, the best job she could find with her limited English skills was cleaning houses and caring for the elderly. When her refugee support ran out, she went on welfare for seven months, receiving $468, plus food stamps, each month to care for herself and her son, who is now 15.
Then one day a few months ago, she saw an advertisement in a Brooklyn newspaper about a job opportunity for recent Russian immigrants at MetCouncil Employment Services, a program of the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation of New York, a charity supported by the Neediest Cases Fund. The employment program serves recent immigrants, victims of domestic abuse and former welfare recipients.
When Swiss banks admitted earlier this year that they had helped the Nazis hoard money and property stolen from Jews during World War II, the MetCouncil created a program to help Holocaust survivors file compensation claims with the banks. The organization was hiring people who could help the survivors -- many of whom are elderly and do not speak English -- manage complicated paperwork and legal issues so they could apply for some of the $1.25 billion in settlement funds.
Dianna went to MetCouncil and got a job fielding calls from Russian-speaking Holocaust survivors, answering complex questions about application guidelines. But the organization did more than just set her up with employment. While working 20 hours a week, she was also offered English-language instruction four hours every weeknight through the agency. She now makes enough money to support herself and her son without welfare.
The coordinating council serves at least 1,200 Russian-speaking clients every year at nine sites in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens, said Sandra Greenstein, director of employment and training programs for the MetCouncil. Limited English skills can become more than just a practical obstacle to finding employment, Ms. Greenstein said, because when recent immigrants cannot communicate effectively, they feel dependent on the services, like welfare, that they know they can count on.
"For the person who doesn't speak the language and is from another country, they're so frightened anyway it's so hard to tell them, 'Don't worry, we'll help you out when you don't have benefits,' " she explained. "Just think, you don't even have the ability to defend yourself in your own language. It's like having a gag in your mouth."
She said most of her Russian-speaking clients preferred to find jobs outside their community because they wanted to assimilate as quickly as possible. But some use their native language skills while they learning English.
"They just have to get a job first," Ms. Greenstein said. "And yet they are very career-minded, so we'll continue to help them as they get off welfare."
For her part, Dianna is happy to continue working within the Russian community, and pleased to have switched careers from bookkeeping to social work.
"Here, I can improve my English and at the same time, I can work with Russian people and help them out," she said. "That's the most important thing."
Although Dianna had found a job, her money troubles were not quite over. Jackie Ebron, director of crisis intervention services for the coordinating council, said Dianna got stuck in a Catch-22 of the welfare system. Her food stamps and most of her other entitlements were cut off before she got her first paycheck. She feared that she would lose her apartment and be unable to feed her son in the intervening month -- or months, who could be sure?
Dianna had no source of income for a month and a half, but she was too ashamed, Ms. Ebron said, to ask for help. Ultimately, Ms. Ebron, noticing Dianna's distress, asked what was wrong. Dianna explained her situation. That was when the coordinating council used money from the Neediest Cases Fund to keep Dianna and her son afloat. The fund provided a month's rent, money for medicine, food, clothes and other basic needs. It also gave the family a food voucher and a food package so that Dianna could return home every day knowing she and her son could make it to payday.
With that help, Dianna has been able to remain in the work force, doing what she loves. "If I hadn't come here, I don't know what I would do," she said on Wednesday. "But I'm glad I met these people here, because I must work. I must do it for my son."
 
Education
Lack of the Basics Keeps People on Rolls
What prevents most welfare recipients from leaving the public assistance rolls is a lack of basic education, said Julie Strawn, senior policy analyst at the Center for Law and Social Policy, a nonprofit research and advocacy organization based in Washington. According to a recent study of current welfare recipients by the Urban Institute, 41 percent do not have a high school degree or equivalent, and 43 percent have no work experience or have not worked in more than three years.
Michael Dykes, 33, was receiving Supplemental Security Income, a form of federal public assistance for the disabled, ever since he could remember. His disability is not physical; he has so much trouble reading that he is categorized as learning disabled. Mr. Dykes, who grew up in Pittsburgh and moved to the Bronx three years ago, had to repeat three years of school and then dropped out of high school at age 20, when the school's principal told him he would never graduate, he said.
For several years, he worked for a private garbage-hauling company, then for two supermarkets, and finally as a bouncer and security guard. But, he said, by the time he was 22, he was unemployed. "I lost all those jobs," he said. "Some closed; some went out of business; others, I don't know."
At 24 he was living with his mother and began drinking heavily and using cocaine. When his addictions led him to steal from her, she turned him out, and he soon landed in jail. When he got out, he had nowhere to turn but the Salvation Army, where he now shares a room with two other men. Although he managed to conquer his addiction on his own, he said, he still could not find a job.
He turned to Exodus House of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, which runs a job-training program for the homeless, former prisoners and victims of domestic violence, among others. Three months ago, Catholic Charities also began a new job training program, the Millennium Career Opportunities Project, which provides 30 people with practical job-seeking skills, like resume preparation, practice interviews and computer training.
Exodus House also has an education outreach program, a series of workshops that lasts 12 weeks and includes classes on setting priorities and achieving personal goals. Clients are matched with mentors who help them deal with the problems that have kept them out of the work force in the past. And as part of a self-esteem building program, at the end of the 12 weeks, clients must tell their life stories to a group of their peers.
Exodus House also offers a literacy program, G.E.D. training, individual tutoring, a job-readiness program and classes in English as a second language. There is also a job retention program, guiding clients through precarious job issues and offering strategies for managing conflict in the workplace.
Mr. Dykes joined Exodus House last year, completed a job readiness program and then joined the education outreach program this fall. Alison H. Kelsick, the director of Exodus House, said it was hard to find him a job because he could not read or write. Mr. Dykes said he is learning how to read, and hopes to earn an equivalency diploma. The hardest part of the program, he said, was writing his life story for the final presentation.
"It was stuff I didn't want to bring up," he said. "But I got some stuff that was really hurting off my chest. Like my brother dying, and losing a lot of people I care about."
On Tuesday night, Mr. Dykes waited nervously outside the chapel on the Fordham University campus at West 60th Street before "Speakers Night," in which several Exodus House clients shared some of their most difficult life stories. Mr. Dykes will tell his own story at another ceremony, but that night he was introducing another participant. He knew what he had to say, but he swallowed his words as he talked about the mentor who had helped him figure out how to get his teeth fixed, and how to think about the future.
"This is about telling your story and accomplishing your goals," he said, glancing inside the chapel. "One of mine is to go back to school and bring up my reading and try to move myself forward. Before, I never used to have goals for myself. Or if I did, I never met them. Now I feel I can."
Mr. Dykes still has a long path ahead of him before he will find permanent, stable employment. But he has overcome one of the first barriers to getting there, he said -- his own fear.
Like Mr. Dykes, many welfare recipients who have severe practical barriers to employment face another challenge that can be just as daunting: they lack confidence that once they get a job they will be able to keep it. Most say their greatest fear is escaping welfare only to find that they cannot make ends meet without it, and having to reapply for benefits.
For some people, like Dianna, the Neediest Cases Funds came at a critical time, when she needed an extra boost to get across the income gulf between the welfare system and the workplace. For others, like Mr. Dykes and Ms. Robinson, the important contribution the Neediest Cases Fund makes is helping to support programs that will accompany them on the entire journey from public assistance, through job preparation and into stable employment, and, if needed, beyond. In most cases, it is this assurance that makes leaving the rolls possible at all.
Ms. Robinson, who has wrestled with her feelings of inadequacy, said joining the work force has made a tremendous difference, and not just for her pocketbook.
"Oh, I love it here," she said last week of the Brooklyn Bureau's welfare-to-work program, Pride 2000. "It seemed like before this program I wasn't going anywhere. I just kept going down and down. Now I'm coming up. It's slowly, but I'm definitely coming up."

HEADLINE: Gore Begins National Effort to Get Black Vote

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Invoking the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his own Southern roots, Vice President Al Gore came to a historic black section of Atlanta today to begin a nationalwide effort to encourage African-Americans to turn out for him at the polls, both in the primaries and next November.
"The other side is counting on blowing the roof off all of the election finance and breaking all the records and lining up all of the special interests," Mr. Gore declared in a speech rife with biblical cadences after entering to the throbbing beat of "Love Train," which is fast becoming his campaign theme song. 
 "Well, I can tell you that here in the South," he said, "we have the capacity to blow the roof off voter registration and turnout and grass-roots enthusiasm."
In contrast to his failed 1988 presidential bid, when he campaigned as a candidate of the South, Mr. Gore rarely mentions the South this time around, presenting himself as a national candidate. But he talked today of the special bond that Southern whites have with blacks.
"We, especially those of us here in the South, are intensely proud of what we have done together," he said, lauding "those who took the blows, shed blood that was redemptive for our nation."
The Gore campaign considers the black vote crucial to the vice president's ability to stave off former Senator Bill Bradley, especially with several Southern states holding primaries in March.
Donna Brazile, the Gore campaign manager, said blacks usually make up more than a fourth of the turnout in Democratic primaries in the South. Most surveys show Mr. Gore with a substantial lead among African-Americans over Mr. Bradley, who has made his own efforts to attract black voters. The goal, Gore advisers said, will be to get them to the polls.
Mr. Gore has been courting black voters for years, but today his campaign began a nationwide push.
With simultaneous events in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Des Moines, the campaign announced the support of nearly 3,000 African-Americans, most of whom have already endorsed him. They included elected officials and members of the clergy as well as the singer Aretha Franklin and the comedian Bill Cosby and athletes like Shaquille O'Neal and Carl Lewis.
Mr. Gore chose to kick off his campaign for the black vote in Atlanta, where the black community's roots run deep and because Georgia is the first Southern state to vote in a primary, on March 7.
The timing of today's events reflected the quickly advancing primary schedule and the fact that the candidates are in the process of fielding delegates in several Northern states with significant black populations, including New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Illinois.
Mr. Gore spoke this morning in the small auditorium of the Atlanta Life Insurance building on Auburn Avenue, just up the street from the Ebenezer Baptist Church, where Dr. King preached and is buried. The life insurance company was started by a former slave, Alonzo Herndon, in 1905 and became a cornerstone of black businesses in the area.
Mr. Gore was praised by a succession of black politicians, who cited his support for affirmative action, his father's support for civil rights and, mostly, the Clinton administration's record in reducing crime, reducing black unemployment, helping more blacks attend college and appointing a record number of blacks to jobs in the administration.
Mr. Gore's supporters today included Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia. Mr. Lewis reminded the audience that the Georgia primary fell on the 35th anniversary of the civil rights march in Alabama from Selma to Montgomery, a coincidence that the Gore campaign intends to exploit.
"Some of our sisters and brothers died for the right to vote," Mr. Lewis told the audience. "On March 7, we will go to the polls and we will vote like we never, ever voted before, and then in November 2000 we will come back to the polls and vote again."
Mr. Gore told the crowd: "I make you this pledge. Together, with your enthusiasm, your ideas and your commitment, we're going to win this nomination."
"The next president is going to appoint three to four justices of the Supreme Court," Mr. Gore said. "What would Thurgood Marshall have thought if he took his historic cases to a Supreme Court that was stacked with ideological right wingers predisposed to say no?"
He added: "Anyone who says affirmative action is no longer needed because we've reached the promised land has confused the wilderness with Canaan."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: CHARITY FOR POOR LAGS BEHIND NEED

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
As incomes of the better-off Americans rise in this age of prosperity, with the stock market and corporate profits booming, charities report that both individuals and companies are donating less to organizations that support the homeless, the young and the hungry than they did in leaner times.
Leading charitable organizations like the Salvation Army and United Way say that as a result, they are struggling with a surging demand for their aid, and that the private donations they collect are falling far short of the need. 
 "What is so stunning to me is that people in America have this image of prosperity and everybody benefits," said Deborah Leff, president of America's Second Harvest in Chicago, which oversees a network of 189 community food banks nationwide that distribute nearly $400 million in donated food to 26 million people.
Ms. Leff said contributions to Second Harvest's $10 million annual budget have been rising but by nowhere near enough to meet the demand. "I think people just aren't aware of the need," she said. "They think of hunger as a distended stomach in some developing country. That's starvation, not hunger."
Tom Jones, director of development and national spokesman for the Salvation Army, the nation's biggest charity, said, "In this era of prosperity, need continues to skyrocket, especially in the major cities." Giving to the Salvation Army is up in some cities and down in others but nowhere does it meet the need, Mr. Jones said.
"I continue to hear from places like Memphis and Houston of how many more people are coming to ask for help in paying their rent or utility bills," he said. "The army is facing not only more need but a more complex kind of need," in serving more and more families than single adults.
Paul Clolery, editor of NonProfit Times, a newspaper for executives of nonprofit groups,said, "Demand for services is through the roof."
The travails of the nation's purest charities -- those, unlike colleges, museums, hospitals and churches, that serve the indigent exclusively -- clash with evidence of a slowly falling poverty rate, rising incomes, and the overhaul of the welfare system three years ago that has coaxed many recipients into jobs. The charities say that with their mostly low-wage jobs, many former recipients earn less than they collected in welfare checks along with food stamps, health care and subsidized housing.
Meanwhile, better-off Americans who might help are spending and borrowing more than ever and reaching record levels of bankruptcy and debt, so they have less to save and to give. "One would have expected that at a certain level of prosperity, people might reach a certain limit of their consumption," said Julian Wolpert, a professor at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton who specializes in tracking philanthropy. "But we're not getting that."
In some ways, the nation has never looked so bountiful. William H. Gates 3rd, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, and his wife, Melinda, have created a foundation that dwarfs even those of the Rockefellers and Fords, and by the end of this year, Harvard University will have amassed more than $2.3 billion in a single capital fund drive. Giving USA, which monitors philanthropic giving, reports a prosperity-driven surge in giving to a record $175 billion last year, up nearly 11 percent from 1997.
But about 90 percent of the money goes to religious organizations, some of which operate services for the poor, and to other organizations that cater mostly to the rich and the middle class like the opera, ballet, museums and universities. "They add nicely to our quality of life," Mr. Wolpert said of these organizations, "but they are also the kinds of things that we ourselves use."
No one keeps track of contributions to programs the poor use. But Giving USA reports that contributions for human services, including most forms of traditional charity and some that are not, represented 9.2 percent of all giving last year, a decline from 13.9 percent in 1970.
And by a variety of measures, people are also giving less to all forms of philanthropy. The Independent Sector, a coalition of philanthropic organizations, says households donated 2.1 percent of their incomes last year, compared with 2.5 percent a decade ago, and that the number of those making any contributions fell to 70.1 percent last year from 75.1 percent in 1989. After inflation, the organization reports, a family's average gift to human service organizations fell to $250 last year from $271 four years ago.
Animals get more sympathy than children, said Joyce Strom, president and chief executive of the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in Boston. "If there's an animal abused," she said, "people will flock to the cause and raise money on the spot."
Ms. Strom's organization, which serves 100,000 children a year, must struggle with curbs in government support of its services and the costs and difficulties of raising money from the public.
State payments for the society's services to children amount to $24 million of its annual budget of $30 million. While salaries and other costs rise, the state has frozen the payments of support, some for as long as 12 years. "So in going after private donations, Ms. Strom said, "I have to raise money just to fill the hole I'm in, and it's really, really tough to raise money."
As a result, Ms. Strom said, "We have to turn people away all the time. People who are reported for child abuse and neglect but who are screened out because their cases are not serious enough."
Some analysts are unsympathetic with the travails of low-budget agencies that serve the poor. "It's their mission to complain," said Paul G. Schervish, director of Boston College's Social Welfare Research Institute, who sees the nation entering a golden age of philanthropy, with the baby-boom generation leaving tens of trillions of dollars to their estates and charities.
"What's happening is these groups are facing competition," Mr. Schervish said. "It doesn't mean people are giving any less." Part of their contributions to organizations like Harvard and Boston College is used to educate the poor, he said.
Michael Petit, a director of the Child Welfare League of America and former commissioner for human services for the state of Maine, said: "There is a large gap between what these families require to be whole and what is available to them. The early, front-end investment in children is not occurring at a sufficient scale to make a difference."
Such charities' accounts of the gap in their resources and needs vary only in the details. At the United Way, said Tony De Cristofaro, a spokesman, "over the last 10 years, we have had increases virtually every year in contributions." But he said the share that donors designate for health and humans "is flat at best or declining."
Other charities describe similar gaps in needs and resources. The Capital Area Food Bank dispatches almost two million tons of food a month to 780 food pantries and church kitchens that feed 200,000 people a month.
"In 1988, we were seeing one out of five children" in the Washington area, said Linda Brantley, the food bank's president and chief executive. "Then five years down the road, it was one out of four. Now we are seeing one out of three."
Julie Platek, vice president for fund development for Associated Catholic Charities of Houston, has noticed that supporters now give for buildings and endowments more readily than for services.
The organization just completed a successful drive for $11 million, mostly for a new central program building. But raising money for emergency services -- disaster relief, food, shelter and clothing -- is much harder. In part because of the change in the welfare system, "we had a 40 percent increase in the numbers of people served through emergency assistance from 1996 to 1998," Ms. Platek said.
Philanthropic contributions by corporations, typically about one percent of their profits and about five percent of all giving nationally, have been declining more than those from individuals, many charities report. This has put a strain on the National Urban League in New York, whose affiliates provide education and job training to minority clients.
With mergers and plant closings, said Milton Little, executive vice president and chief operating officer, "this has been an extremely difficult year for us."
Charity executives say it is hard to determine why Americans do not share more of their prosperity with the poor. They speculate that in moving to gated communities in the suburbs, people who rally to help hurricane victims seen on television do not see the need around the corner. Herman Ewing, president of the Urban League of Memphis, said prosperity, for all its appeal, can undermine the sharing and the bonds of neighbors and communities and gives people a lot to protect.
"The result of prosperity is isolation, arrogance and in-your-face," Mr. Ewing said. "This among people who were once interdependent in terms of basic survival needs. The idea that you're looking out for me for food and I'm looking out for you for this or that is all by the boards."
Gail Ober, executive director of the Children's Aid Society of Pennsylvania, said: "I'm concerned that we are not a kinder society. Child welfare agencies serve the most at-risk families. I'm not sure there's a value attached to having some responsibility for those families."
Elizabeth Boris, director of the Center on Nonprofits and Philanthropy at the Urban Institute, said, "We're not as generous as we could be." But it may be because many of the newly rich have not turned their attention to charity. "This may be a lag," Ms. Boris said. "Maybe the whole generation of folks making money are not yet a part of the network of people who give."

HEADLINE: Homeless in America: A Statistical Profile

 BODY:
No one knows precisely how many Americans are homeless. But with homelessness reemerging as a political issue, federal officials released a report last week that is a comprehensive analysis of homeless people served by shelters, soup kitchens and other programs. The snapshot by the Department of Housing and Urban Development was based on surveys and interviews in 1995 and 1996 of adults who used these services. Officials estimated that 470,000 were sheltered on an average night in February 1996, which was about one quarter of those who were homeless at any time during the year.

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
Two's a Challenge, But Seven's a Crowd

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
For months, the morning line on next year's Senate race in Pennsylvania has been that the Republican incumbent, Rick Santorum, should be one of the easiest targets for Democrats in their battle to recapture the Senate. He is a conservative in a state that typically elects moderates, his 1994 margin of victory was a flimsy two points and he has since struggled to raise his poll numbers. 
 In fact, Democrats think Mr. Santorum is so vulnerable that no fewer than seven -- so far -- are competing for the right to take him on.
And that's turning out to be a problem.
For Democrats.
Last weekend, when the Democratic State Committee gathered in Harrisburg, six of the contenders showed up to work the corridors and caucuses in search of support. That struck many committee members as perhaps too much of a good thing and they have since begun to push the thought that perhaps it would be better, politically, if some candidates dropped out, lest the party end up badly battering itself in a divisive, money-devouring primary next spring.
Not one of the seven contenders is widely known throughout the state, and some face serious campaign money problems. The one with the best chance to be nominated and go on to beat Senator Santorum, many Democratic leaders think, is Representative Ron Klink, who hails from the Pittsburgh area.
The most visible of the other candidates, all from the Philadelphia area, are Tom Foley, a former state labor commissioner, Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky and Peter Kostmayer, former members of Congress, and Allyson Y. Schwartz, a state senator.
As Mr. Klink's supporters see it, in a nomination fight he would have his base area in western Pennsylvania mostly to himself whereas his main competitors would be scrapping for -- and splintering -- the vote in their base area in eastern Pennsylvania.
As the fall contest nominee, the Klink supporters go on, Mr. Klink, who tends to vote liberal on economic issues and conservative on social issues, would be ideally positioned not only to go for the state's big centrist vote but also to steal some of Senator Santorum's conservative base.
An analyst, Charles E. Cook Jr., wrote recently in the Cook Political Report that if that reasoning was correct, then "the question is, who is running second and third in the primary field and how long will it take before the field becomes more manageable?"
"Santorum is vulnerable," Mr. Cook said. "But Democrats have a long way to go before they can take advantage of that vulnerability."

HEADLINE: At Bush's Ear, A Supply-SiderWith a Heart

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LAWRENCE B. LINDSEY, the former Federal Reserve governor who is now George W. Bush's chief economic adviser, sees himself as a mere technician, helping to turn the presidential candidate's vision into nuts-and-bolts programs.
"Governor Bush has a very clear idea of where he wants to take the country," Mr. Lindsey said the other evening, winding down after a hectic week of helping him make his first big economic policy speech of the campaign. "We're there to provide suggestions on the best way to accomplish the policy." 
 Mr. Lindsey, an affable, 45-year-old Harvard-trained economist who worked in the White House during both the Reagan and Bush administrations, has been around politics long enough to know when to defer to the boss.
But Mr. Lindsey clearly has substantial influence in honing the campaign's message and putting flesh on the Texas governor's "compassionate conservatism" theme. Equally important, he provides policy gravitas to a candidate who constantly confronts whispers that he is a lightweight.
In the year and a half since they first met and began discussing economic policy, Mr. Lindsey has covered a lot of ground with Mr. Bush, from international finance and trade to Social Security and the Federal Reserve. But on no subject has he had a more direct influence than on tax cuts, the centerpiece of any Republican platform. While by all accounts the $483 billion tax-cutting proposal that Mr. Bush unveiled this month was shaped by the candidate's own philosophy, its details and presentation carried Mr. Lindsey's stamp.
Mr. Lindsey, for example, does not see a clear case for reducing the tax rate on long-term capital gains below the current 20 percent, at least not at the expense of reducing marginal income tax rates, but he is much keener on eliminating the inheritance tax on large estates. The Bush plan bucked supply-side orthodoxy by skipping a capital-gains tax cut, but it included a phaseout of the estate tax.
And while a strong believer in lower income tax rates, Mr. Lindsey is not a fan of the single-rate flat tax advocated by other Republicans including Steve Forbes, whose candidacy is dogging Mr. Bush from the right. Mr. Bush's plan keeps the progressive income tax system intact.
Mr. Lindsey has warned for several years that the economy may soon turn downward, and Mr. Bush presented his tax plan in part as insurance against a recession.
"It's very clear when you look at the Bush tax plan that it has Larry Lindsey's fingerprints all over it," said Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy studies at the Cato Institute, a conservative research group.
With elections often turning on pocketbook issues, an economic plan is as much a part of a presidential campaign as the stump speech or the fund-raiser. And as the presidential race moves toward the first primaries, economists and other policy experts are building economic platforms for each of the candidates, motivated variously by principle and ideology, the lure of power and the media spotlight, and the promise of a big job if the outcome is right.
ON the Democratic side, Vice President Al Gore, eager to distance himself from Washington and President Clinton on many issues, is making a conspicuous exception for the administration's economic record. He is relying more for advice and policy prescriptions on insiders like Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy adviser, than on the outside economists in his camp, like Alan Blinder, the Princeton economist and former Fed vice chairman.
Bill Bradley, the former New Jersey senator whose campaign cultivates an image of plain-speaking insurgency and who keeps his own counsel on most policy matters, announced last week that he had two establishment heavyweights in his camp: Paul Volcker, the former Fed chairman, and Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist.
Among the Republican candidates, Mr. Forbes has a whole stable of supply-side economists, headed by Lawrence Kudlow, a former Reagan administration economist now with Wertheim Schroder, an investment firm. Senator John McCain of Arizona has no formal economic team but relies on an informal network of contacts from his two decades in Washington and his chairmanship of the Commerce Committee.
But needing to educate himself about a host of complex topics -- and eager to tweak traditional Republican thinking on some economic policy issues -- Mr. Bush has assembled a larger and more prominent roster of economic advisers than any of his rivals. In addition to Mr. Lindsey, the 10-member team includes Michael J. Boskin, who was chief White House economist under President Bush and is now at Stanford University's Hoover Institution; Martin S. Feldstein, the Harvard economist who is head of the National Bureau of Economic Research; John F. Cogan, who was a budget aide to President Reagan; and John B. Taylor, an expert on monetary policy. Mr. Cogan and Mr. Taylor are also at Stanford.
Developing Mr. Bush's proposals is a role that in some ways seems tailor-made for Mr. Lindsey -- and enlisting him is good politics for Mr. Bush. Mr. Lindsey made his name in Washington during the 1980's with an academic defense of tax cuts as a spur to economic growth. That endeared him to the Republican Party's supply-side wing, a group that felt betrayed by President Bush and harbors suspicions about Governor Bush's commitment to reducing taxes.
Yet even as he has advocated conservative orthodoxy on reducing marginal income tax rates, Mr. Lindsey has challenged it by urging his party to do more to fight poverty and to provide low-income people with better access to housing. At the Federal Reserve, where officials often seem cloistered in their offices, Mr. Lindsey was known for trooping through subsidized housing projects and warning bankers to make sure that race and barriers to obtaining credit did not discourage homeownership. "You could see in Larry's approach some of the precursors to compassionate conservatism, whatever that means," said Mr. Blinder, who served at the Fed with Mr. Lindsey.
To a presidential candidate trying to woo his party's conservative base while seeking to redefine its ideology to appeal to moderates, Mr. Lindsey's credentials as a supply-sider with a heart fit perfectly. "They were simpatico from the get-go," said Al Hubbard, a longtime friend of Mr. Bush who worked with Mr. Lindsey at the White House and introduced the two last year.
Yet in other ways, Mr. Lindsey is an odd choice as a top aide to any presidential candidate, especially the congenitally upbeat Mr. Bush. Mr. Lindsey is renowned for his bearish views on the stock market and his consistent predictions that the strong economy is on the verge of a painful downturn, positions that raise questions about his skills as a forecaster.
Eighteen months ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average was at 8,500, he said publicly that stock prices were overvalued and that he had sold all his equity holdings so he could sleep better at night. The Dow closed on Friday at 11,224.70.
And with the current business expansion just months from becoming the longest in the nation's history, Mr. Lindsey warned recently that a downturn in the business cycle was near.
Under the glare of media attention as the campaign has heated up, Mr. Lindsey has moderated his views -- but just a bit.
"I have a lot of faith about the long-term strength of the economy and in the positive changes that have happened over the last 20 years in reducing taxes and regulation," Mr. Lindsey said. "But I don't think we've repealed the business cycle, and I think that financial markets are probably more optimistic than they should be about the course of the business cycle from here on out."
In many ways, Mr. Lindsey has always been outspoken, at least by Washington standards. Four years ago, while still at the Fed and making $123,000 a year, Mr. Lindsey was turned down for a charge card by Toys "R" Us. Eager to make a point about the fallibility of credit reports, Mr. Lindsey went public with his experience.
It turned out that his credit report showed many inquiries about his financial history, in part because he was refinancing a loan at the time. The inquiries raised a red flag, which Toys "R" Us and the bank issuing its credit cards did not check further.
The episode had a happy ending. Mr. Lindsey said that nearly all big credit card issuers came to him at the Fed to say they would adopt a new approach: People rejected for credit by a software program would get a second look by a human being to see if there were mitigating circumstances.
"The problem I had was that we're increasingly using computers to make consumer credit decisions and taking human decision-making out of the process," Mr. Lindsey said.
BORN in Peekskill, N.Y., the son of public school teachers, Mr. Lindsey grew up intending to become a lawyer, and with far more liberal views than he holds now. While at Bowdoin College in Maine, he got early exposure to supply and demand by starting a hot-dog stand, and exposure to politics as a volunteer for George McGovern, the 1972 Democratic presidential nominee. As his interest in policy grew, he moved decidedly to the right.
"The lesson we learned from the Great Society and the 1970's is that those objectives of a better life for everyone are fine, but big government is not going to be the one to provide it," he said. "The question we have is what can we conservatives do, we who believe in the power of the individual and the market, to solve the problems that liberalism has failed to solve."
Part of Mr. Lindsey's answer is on display in Mr. Bush's tax plan. Acting on Mr. Bush's order that the proposal address the ways in which high marginal tax rates hurt taxpayers at all income levels, Mr. Lindsey and the rest of the economic team spent months debating not just how much to reduce rates for the wealthy and the upper middle class, but also how to aid the working poor.
People earning $20,000 to $25,000 a year can face some of the highest marginal tax rates in the system. At those income levels, many people begin losing the benefits of the earned income tax credit, which helps people whose incomes are below or just above the poverty line. Seeing that quirk as a barrier to entry to the middle class, Mr. Lindsey and his colleagues settled on a plan that reduces the lowest rate to 10 percent and doubles the per-child credit to $1,000.
"One of the strengths of the Bush plan -- which has many weaknesses -- is its effort to reduce the high marginal tax rates paid by the working poor," Mr. Blinder said. "Among supply-side conservatives there is typically remarkably little concern with the plight of the poor in general and with the very high marginal tax rates paid by the poor."
Having spent nearly all of his professional career in Washington, including five years as a Fed governor ending in early 1997, Mr. Lindsey said he originally intended to remain neutral during the Republican primaries, in part because he had ties to a number of candidates, including Lamar Alexander and Dan Quayle. Then Mr. Hubbard introduced him to Mr. Bush. After traveling to Austin for three long sessions with the governor last year, Mr. Lindsey jumped when Mr. Bush asked him to join his team.
"Having the right president is important, and I think I found the right guy," Mr. Lindsey said. "He's a natural leader. He's got good instincts. He absorbs things quickly and he's comfortable with himself."
Mr. Lindsey helped pull together the other members of the team, many of whom worked in the White House during the 1980's and have strongly held positions of their own. He has helped to brief Mr. Bush on a variety of subjects and to prepare him for debates. And he is working with the rest of the team on detailed proposals for topics like overhauling Social Security and improving access to health care.
The group met irregularly for much of the last year, starting even before Mr. Bush announced he would run. The members have gathered in Austin, in Washington and once at Mr. Boskin's home in California; they hold regular conference calls. Technically the group is managed by Mr. Hubbard, not Mr. Lindsey, so that Mr. Lindsey is free to advocate positions, rather than play the role of honest broker among competing views. And there have been some disagreements. As the tax plan was completed, for example, the 10 members were evenly divided over whether the top income tax rate should be reduced to 30 percent or 33 percent from 39.6 percent. Mr. Bush ultimately decided on 33 percent.
"It's a very collegial group that's worked well together," Mr. Hubbard said. "That doesn't mean there haven't been disagreements, but for the most part they haven't been about what's best for the economy. They've been about what works best on the political side, and ultimately that's the governor's call."
WITH the tax plan out of the way, Mr. Lindsey -- who is working for the campaign as a volunteer -- is again spending more time at what he calls his day jobs. Those are a chair at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group, where he is working on a book about housing, and his consulting firm, Economic Strategies Inc., whose clients are financial institutions and large corporations in the United States, Asia and Europe.
He seems likely, though, to be back in the thick of politics in coming months if Mr. Bush goes ahead with an approach, backed by Mr. Lindsey, to use much of the projected federal budget surplus to finance a partial privatization of Social Security. And should Mr. Bush be elected president, Mr. Lindsey and his colleagues on the economic team would no doubt have plum jobs available to them -- from Treasury secretary on down.
"We haven't talked about it and we shouldn't," Mr. Lindsey said of post-election daydreams. "My wife and I have said, 'Let's do this through the election and see what happens.' But by all means I'd like to have only one job after the election."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: December 19, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about Lawrence B. Lindsey, chief economic adviser in the presidential campaign of George W. Bush, referred incorrectly to a disagreement among members of Mr. Bush's economic team in recommending a reduction in the top federal income tax rate. The team was divided between two main options for reducing the rate -- to 30 percent or 35 percent, not 30 or 33; in his plan, Mr. Bush decided on 33.

Chart: "Sorting Out the Candidates"
The leading presidential candidates in both parties are setting out positions on economic policy issues. There are big differences among the candidates as well as between the parties.
 
REPUBLICANS
 
GEORGE W. BUSH
 
BUDGET: Supports using the Social Security surplus to revamp the retirement system and using non-Social Security surplus mostly for tax cuts.
 
TAXES: Wants a $483 billion, five-year tax cut that would gradually reduce all income tax rates, double the child credit to $1,000, reduce the marriage penalty and phase out the tax on large estates.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY: Generally supports individual investment accounts within Social Security.
 
FEDERAL RESERVE: Advisers support reappointment of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
 
TRADE: Supports free trade and China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
 
JOHN McCAIN
 
BUDGET: Skeptical about projected surpluses. Advocates caution in using them to cut taxes. Would divide budget surplus among Social Security, tax relief, Medicare and some debt reduction.
 
TAXES: Would expand the lowest, 15 percent income tax bracket up to $70,000, to cover most middle-class taxpayers. Would reduce the marriage penalty and the estate tax.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY: Would use surpluses to help pay Social Security benefits and would create individual investment accounts within the system.
 
FEDERAL RESERVE: Strong supporter of Mr. Greenspan.
 
TRADE: Supports free trade and China's entry into the W.T.O. if it meets the group's standards.
 
STEVE FORBES
 
BUDGET: Would continue caps on spending and eliminate cabinet agencies to reduce government. Wants a constitutional amendment requiring a supermajority in Congress to raise taxes.
 
TAXES: Wants to replace the progressive income tax system with a 17 percent flat tax on all income above certain levels ($36,000 for a family of four); would eliminate capital gains and estate taxes.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY: Would create individual investment accounts within Social Security, financed out of payroll taxes. Would place no restrictions on retirement age.
 
FEDERAL RESERVE: Critical of Mr. Greenspan; suggests Jack Kemp as a possible replacement.
 
TRADE: Supports free trade. Says Taiwan should be brought into the W.T.O. before China.
 
DEMOCRATS
 
AL GORE
 
BUDGET: Supports using Social Security surplus to reduce the national debt; will avoid both big spending proposals and large tax cuts.
 
TAXES: Open to a modest tax cut, perhaps $250 billion to $300 billion over 10 years, for low- and moderate-income people or for specific purposes like reducing the marriage penalty or promoting education savings.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY: Would preserve current system perhaps with some investment of reserves in the stock market.
 
FEDERAL RESERVE: Strong supporter of Mr. Greenspan.
 
TRADE: Supports free trade, but needs votes from unions that oppose China's entry into the W.T.O.
 
BILL BRADLEY

HEADLINE: Panama Trouble: Who Hands Canal Over?

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
At the beginning of the century, President Theodore Roosevelt not only drove home the importance of the Panama Canal to America's becoming a great power, he also felt so strongly about it that he drove a steam shovel that helped dig the engineering marvel of his age.
Now, as the century ends, another president, Bill Clinton, is having trouble finding a United States official to give it away, a problem that more than anything reflects how the canal has receded in importance -- militarily, economically and, above all, politically. 
 Even as the administration describes the moment of the handover as a signal one in relations with Latin America, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she would not go, apparently because she preferred to be in Washington for Middle East peace talks. The American delegation will instead be led by Jimmy Carter, who was president in 1978 when the Senate decided, with only one vote to spare, to approve the treaties giving away the canal, which cost the United States $352 million and 5,609 lives to build.
The Panamanians had hoped that the handover ceremony would be more prestigious. President Mireya Moscoso came to Washington in October to ask Mr. Clinton to go this Tuesday to the Miraflores Locks for the ceremony that will symbolically transfer power over the canal. Mr. Clinton was noncommittal.
The State Department recommended that the president go. The National Security Council sent him a memorandum that described the ceremonies but did not say whether he should attend. Officials there would not say what was the recommendation of the president's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger.
"I know he wanted to go," Thomas F. McLarty 3rd, formerly the president's top Latin American adviser, said on Friday. "I think he felt it was a historic occasion."
Mr. Clinton has never told the Panamanians or the American public why he has decided not to attend. White House aides have offered a variety of explanations, from the need to work on the budget, to the difficulty of laying on yet another foreign trip, to his desire to let Mr. Carter take the leading role -- an explanation suggesting a Clinton affection for Mr. Carter previously unknown.
Aside from Dr. Albright, with whom Mr. Berger argued over her decision to stay away, another obvious fill-in for Mr. Clinton is Vice President Al Gore. But, in a presidential campaign in which Mr. Gore clearly wants to take no chances at all, he never volunteered, knowing that among the costs of the approval of the canal treaties in 1978 and 1980 were the seats of about a dozen Democratic senators. Nor did the White House, his staff insisted, ever ask him to go.
By the weekend, the White House was still scrambling to fill the delegation. While Rodney Slater, secretary of transportation, and William Daley, secretary of commerce, were included in the delegation, the State Department said its highest-ranking official would be Peter Romero, the acting assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs.
But if the administration was having trouble stirring up much enthusiasm for the handover, critics were also failing to stir up much outrage over what at this stage is a done deal.
That was not always the case. In 1976, while President Gerald R. Ford was negotiating a pact, he was challenged in the Republican primaries by Ronald Reagan, who made the canal issue a rallying cry, saying: "We built it. We paid for it. It's ours and we're going to keep it."
Another California Republican, Senator S. I. Hayakawa, displayed a sense of the history of American involvement in Panama's secession from Colombia when he said, "we stole it fair and square."
The fight in the Senate in 1978 was bitter, and today's arguments are pallid in comparison. Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader from Mississippi, and Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a California Republican, have been complaining that Hutchison-Whampoa, a company based in Hong Kong, has contracts for container ports at both ends of the canal -- an implication that the canal could become a foothold for Chinese meddling, or worse, in the Western Hemisphere.
Mr. Lott has called its presence "a critical national security issue." Mr. Rohrabacher said the problem was even worse: "Mainland Chinese criminal Triad gangs -- some of whom have ties to Chinese intelligence agencies -- are active throughout Panama, in partnership with the Russian mafia, the Cuban intelligence service and South American cartels in conducting drug and weapons smuggling."
Robert Pastor, a professor of political science at Emory University who worked on the treaties under President Carter, scoffed at such complaints, saying Hutchison-Whampoa runs large port operations around the world
But Mr. Pastor also criticized Mr. Clinton, saying the president's absence from the handover ceremony was a mistake.
This was the moment, he said, to define American leadership for the 21st century, for "the transformation of the 20th century is symbolized by the evolution of our role in Panama, from insisting on a quasi-colonial presence to defend the canal at the beginning of the century to recognizing that the best way to defend the canal in the new century is by a partnership with Panama."

A map on Dec. 12 with an article about the turnover of the Panama Canal by the United States showed the boundary of the former Canal Zone incorrectly. It did not encompass the city of Colon.

HEADLINE: Loose Cannon

BYLINE: By Aaron L. Friedberg; Aaron L. Friedberg, the director of the Research Program in International Security at Princeton University, is the author of the forthcoming "In the Shadow of the Garrison State."

 BODY:

THE END OF
 NORTH KOREA
 By Nicholas Eberstadt.
 191 pp. Washington:
 The AEI Press.
 Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $14.95. 
 The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is a bizarre and frightening new kind of political life form: it is less a nation-state than a shakedown state. Unable to feed its people, incapable of directing the economy to make anything that can be sold on world markets and unwilling to risk reforms that might weaken its grip on power, the country's ruling clique subsists on the earnings from a calculated policy of extortion. By threatening to build and test nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, the North Korean government has succeeded in extracting substantial quantities of assistance from the international community, in particular from the United States, Japan and the genuinely democratic Republic of Korea to the south. North Korea exports terror and imports foreign aid. In his careful, incisive and important new book, "The End of North Korea," Nicholas Eberstadt, a visiting scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, explains how this unwholesome exchange began and makes the case for bringing it to a close.
The splitting of the Korean peninsula, like the division of Germany, was a product of the early cold war. From its inception in 1948, the Soviet-backed government in Pyongyang proclaimed its highest goal to be the reunification of all Korea under Communist rule. When it failed to achieve its aims by invading South Korea in 1950, it embarked on a huge arms buildup and waited for another opportunity to strike. The moment never came.
By the late 1970's, South Korea was beginning to boom. Meanwhile, the North Korean economy was staggering under the combined burdens of a bloated military budget and a grossly inefficient system of central government planning. Since the fall of its Soviet patron, North Korea has been locked in a death spiral of declining production, shriveling trade and deepening famine. (By some estimates, as many as two million to three million of its 22 million people may have starved to death in recent years.) Only outside assistance, obtained through threats to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and periodic launchings of increasingly long-range ballistic missiles, has staved off a total, terminal collapse.
The governments of the countries keeping North Korea on life support see little alternative to continuing to do so. Some have even convinced themselves that if they can only coax North Korea into greater economic openness, they will be able to pave the way for a genuine reconciliation between North and South. Eberstadt makes quick work of such fantasies. All schemes for expanded commercial contact and peaceful political change turn on the assumption that Pyongyang can somehow be persuaded to loosen up. But North Korea's dictator, Kim Jong Il, who insists on the title "Dear Leader," has repeatedly made clear that he regards even the slightest act of relaxation as tantamount to suicide.
Eberstadt argues persuasively that prolonging North Korea's life may actually increase the costs and the dangers of its inevitable demise. With every passing day, the developmental gap between the two Koreas grows, and with it the difficulty of merging them into a single, prosperous society. Given time, North Korea will also be able to build more and better terror weapons.
What is to be done? On this question Eberstadt is disappointingly vague. Apart from urging policy makers to abandon their current obsession with short-term stability, he does not have many concrete suggestions. Cutting North Korea off from all outside assistance might hasten its fall, but it would also risk triggering war or desperate acts of large-scale terrorism. Until they have convinced themselves that they can deal with these dangers, the United States and its friends will probably continue to pay the Dear Leader the tribute he demands, while hoping that somehow, someday, he will simply go away. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Pataki's Health Plan

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is disappointing that Gov. George E. Pataki proposes to make health coverage affordable only to the unemployed (news article, Dec. 9). Surely Mr. Pataki doesn't want New Yorkers to give up their jobs to get health coverage when three of four of the 2.4 million uninsured adults in New York are working. 
 While Mr. Pataki says he is concerned that employers will drop coverage if the state helps pay, he overlooks the fact that the uninsured are working for employers who don't provide coverage now. Many other states have expanded coverage to the uninsured. New York has made health coverage affordable to children in working families; uninsured adults deserve the same.
 
RICHARD KIRSCH
Albany, Dec. 9, 1999
 
The writer is executive director of Citizen Action of New York.
