HEADLINE: Caught in a U.S. Civil War

BYLINE: By Norbert Walter; Norbert Walter is chief economist for Deutsche Bank.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
In the eyes of most outsiders, the United States, with its dynamic companies and strong lead in high technology, is the prime beneficiary of globalization. And yet, in the wake of the disastrous World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle, it is effectively presenting itself as one of globalization's most aggrieved victims.
No wonder, then, that many abroad see the United States as a nation divided against itself. It dominates the world economy with its strong economic performance, but at the same time feels deeply insecure about participating in the global economic system. 
 In my view, this confusing attitude is to a large extent due to one phenomenon: Quite a few Americans are currently determined to make globalization the catch-all phrase for issues that primarily warrant debate within the United States: American wage inequality and the accessibility of American workers to benefits.
American labor unions and their allies opposing globalization argue that free trade is costing American workers their well-paying manufacturing jobs with generous benefits, and thus contributes to growing wage inequality. But the entire set of worker issues has much deeper roots than globalization.
To prove this, you just have to look to Europe. While we have our fair share of problems to deal with, sharp income disparities are not among them, despite globalization. Moreover the same corporations often give their employees higher wages and better benefits in Europe than in the United States.
The American political system has chosen great flexibility in the labor market and comparatively little government intervention in the economy. These choices work well for many Americans but leave others behind. And all of the issues they raise have been around since long before globalization dominated the scene.
That is why people outside the United States worry now that, for many Americans, the rest of the world simply provides a convenient stage on which to carry out an internal debate. The W.T.O. -- with its power over the entire world economy -- is not the right forum for dealing with what essentially are domestic American problems. Wage inequality in the United States will hardly be resolved by imposing labor standards on developing countries and enforcing them with sanctions, as President Clinton has suggested.
Observers who are not part of the internal American debate should be forgiven for their irritation at being dragged into this family quarrel. Viewed from abroad, the rather unexpected American attack on the global trading system appears particularly strange. The current system and its institutions -- like the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the W.T.O. -- were created largely by American design.
Now that most countries around the world are, at least to some degree, embracing the American-inspired free-market model that drives them, it is bewildering to see significant forces inside the United States trying to distance themselves from it.
Of course, the root of the conflict is in domestic American politics. Some analysts have begun to compare the trade policy of the United States to its conduct of the Kosovo conflict, with losses to be avoided at almost any cost. This leads to a surreal negotiating strategy: unless American politicians can ensure that globalization makes every last American a complete victor and satisfies every American concern, it is an unacceptable proposition for the United States.
This is disconcerting.
Historically, most successful trading regimes have relied on at least one country that is strong enough -- and, above all, willing -- to enforce the rules and, if needed, make some concessions to keep the process moving. In the 50 years since the end of World War II, the United States has done a tremendous job of filling this role.
Americans will be quick to point out that others, especially the Europeans and the Japanese, must share the burdens of economic leadership. But political realists also have to consider that Europe and Japan are in the midst of the painful transformation that the United States economy underwent in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
The United States economy is strong and continues to grow. The United States has it in its power not to shun its global responsibilities. At a minimum, other countries, facing their own adjustment costs from continued change in the world trading system, will not agree to the American demand that no American be disadvantaged by global trade.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Local Signals May Be Costly For Satellite TV Providers

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Talk about putting your money where your lobbyists' mouths are.
For years, the nation's big satellite television companies, DirecTV and EchoStar Communications, have wailed and railed in Washington for the right to include local broadcasters in their services. Two weeks ago, they finally got it. 
 Now comes the really hard work.
Between them, DirecTV, with about eight million subscribers, and EchoStar, with about three million, may have to spend as much as $1 billion to deliver local stations, including local affiliates of the four big broadcast networks, to dozens of markets nationwide.
Even so, not every satellite subscriber will get local stations; there may not be enough satellite capacity -- or economic motive -- to rebroadcast hundreds of local television stations and there probably never will be. And in the case of EchoStar, even in areas where the local service will be offered, many of its customers will require new, slightly larger satellite dishes to pick up the rebroadcast local signals.
But such are the tradeoffs in the confluence of technology, politics and finance that has characterized the development of the satellite television business.
Until two weeks ago, the satellite operators were forbidden by law to transmit local channels -- including ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC affiliates -- to most customers. The rationale for the restriction was that the national satellite services might harm local broadcasters by, say, beaming a New York City station into Des Moines.
But for years, the satellite companies howled that the local restriction hurt them and consumers by keeping satellite television from providing full competition to local cable television monopolies.
"We realized a while ago that it was, in our opinion, very important if we were going to be effective competitors to cable that we have the ability to offer local programming on fair terms," said David K. Moskowitz, the EchoStar senior vice president who oversees the company's local broadcasting initiative.
So when President Clinton signed the Satellite Television Home Viewers Act, which lifted the restriction, on Nov. 29 as part of a spending bill, the satellite companies largely hailed the development as opening the final door to competition with the cable monopolies.
"This is a big fix," said Eddy W. Hartenstein, president of DirecTV, which is part of General Motors' Hughes Electronics subsidiary. "The last remaining barrier why people haven't gotten the service is they say, 'Can I get my local channels?' "
But for the satellite companies, the potentially lucrative opportunities of carrying local broadcast signals will come at considerable cost. DirecTV and EchoStar have already begun transmitting local signals to big markets, including New York and Los Angeles, and want to expand their offerings to dozens more markets by the end of the year. But as the carriers roll out their local offerings across the nation, the capacity of their existing satellites will be sorely tested.
Moreover, the Federal Communications Commission has yet to write the rules for implementing the new law. A big open question is how many local stations within a market the satellite company will be obliged to carry. While both DirecTV and EchoStar say they want to offer the four major commercial broadcast network affiliates, they argue that they should not be compelled to rebroadcast the dozen or more less-watched stations in some big metropolitan areas.
For both consumers and the satellite carriers themselves, the wrinkles in offering local stations are largely a product of how satellites are deployed and managed.
Some 22,300 miles above the equator, there are three orbital slots authorized for direct-broadcast satellites. At that altitude, a satellite positioned at 101, 110 or 119 degrees west longitude can serve all 48 contiguous states.
At each of the three direct-broadcast satellite slots, there are 32 available frequencies. And on each frequency, current video compression technology allows the satellite companies to transmit up to 10 standard television channels.
By the legacies and luck of F.C.C. licensing, DirecTV controls all 32 frequencies at the 101-degree slot, an additional 3 at 110 degrees and another 11 at 119 degrees. EchoStar, meanwhile, controls no frequencies at 101 degrees, 29 at 110 and 21 at 119.
That means EchoStar, with 50 frequency slots, has more total capacity than does DirecTV, with 46 frequency slots. The big catch, however, is that standard satellite dish antennas can receive signals from only one slot at a time. Almost all DirecTV subscribers have their dishes pointed at the 101-degree position, where DirecTV controls all 32 frequencies Almost all EchoStar subscribers aim at the 119-degree slot, where EchoStar has 21 frequencies.
The difference has major implications for the ways the companies will introduce local programming and for the steps users will or will not have to take to view it.
Because DirecTV controls all 32 frequencies at the 101-degree slot, most DirecTV subscribers can theoretically receive up to 320 channels. DirecTV, however, now generally offers its customers a maximum of about 225 channels.
DirecTV intends to use the unused channel capacity at 101 degrees to beam down local broadcast signals. By the end of next month, it plans to use its available channels to offer the four major local broadcast affiliates to each of 20 to 25 markets, or about half of the nation's TV households.
But it is an inefficient process, since everyDirecTV dish antenna in the country will be catching signals of all of those 80 to 100 local affiliates. By scrambling and selectively unscrambling the signals, DirecTV will enable subscribers in any one local market to view only the local broadcasters from their home market.
And yet, DirecTV subscribers in those 20 to 25 markets will not need to recalibrate their dishes or buy new ones. That is why DirecTV appears excited about the prospects of convincing its existing customers to pay an additional $5.99 a month to receive local programming as part of their satellite service. If even 20 percent of DirecTV's existing eight million customers sign up, that means about $115 million in additional annual revenue for the company.
EchoStar, however, finds itself in a somewhat more difficult position. Since almost all EchoStar subscribers' dishes point to 119 degrees, where EchoStar controls only 21 frequencies, EchoStar will not be able to deliver many, if any, new local channels to subscribers using their existing dishes.
And so, EchoStar intends to beam local channels mostly from satellites in the 110 degree slot, which EchoStar obtained rights to only last summer in a deal with the News Corporation and MCI Worldcom. Receiving those signals, however, will require most EchoStar customers to either add a second dish or replace their existing dishes with a new model that can capture signals from two orbital slots at once.
That is why EchoStar does not talk so much about offering local channels to existing customers but is promoting the new local services to attract new customers.
"Most of our existing customers have found ways to satisfy themselves without the network channels from our service," Mr. Moskowitz said. "But there is an enormous population that has not yet pulled the plug on cable because of the absence of local on satellite. And that's what's so neat about this; it gives new customers that reason."
Whatever their competitive positions now, though, both DirecTV and EchoStar face the same regulatory uncertainty as the F.C.C. writes the rules to put the new satellite television law into effect.
The problem for the satellite companies is that they want to offer only the four big-network affiliates -- and maybe a few other popular stations -- in each local market. But the F.C.C. is expected to rule that entering a given market obligates carriers to retransmit every broadcast station in that market.
Cable television systems are under a similar obligation, which is known as the must-carry rule and which is meant to prevent smaller stations from discrimination.
The satellite companies say the requirement, which is expected to take force in 2002, will require them to offer local service in fewer markets than they might otherwise because it will quickly consume too much of their satellites' channel capacity.
"Must-carry is a terrible thing, and I just don't understand the logic of it," said Mr. Moskowitz, the EchoStar executive.
Last week, DirecTV announced that it would buy and launch a new satellite to help meet its must-carry obligations. Unlike the company's traditional satellites, which beam signals to the entire nation, the company's new so-called spot-beam satellite is expected to make more efficient use of the companies' frequencies, allowing them to be reused in different markets for rebroadcasting local television channels.
With communications satellites generally costing $250 million each, EchoStar and its chairman, Charles W. Ergen, have not yet committed to launching a new spot-beam satellite.
Even without launching additional satellites, the companies could end up spending hundreds of millions of dollars on the various other on-the-ground systems that will be required to transmit local channels to dozens of markets, analysts said.
But in the satellite industry's continuing battle against cable television, local stations may be the final weapon, one too valuable to turn down.
"We're in a growth business," Mr. Hartenstein said. "We're creating value from a business perspective, and we're creating a great alternative to cable, especially with this last local offering."

Chart: "The Challenge of Providing Local Television by Satellites"
For DirecTV, a new law that lets satellite television companies rebroadcast the signals of local television stations is a costly opportunity. The diagrams below, greatly simplified, show DirecTV's near-term and long-term approaches to providing local broadcast coverage in some of the nation's largest metropolitan areas.
 
THE NEXT TWO YEARS
 
HOW IT WORKS -- DirecTV's existing fleet of satellites is capable of transmitting about 320 channels, using beams that cover the entire nation. To provide local-broadcast coverage, channels intended for only one local market are scrambled so that customers elsewhere cannot view them. Using this technique to deliver four local-broadcast channels in each of 25 markets will consume 100 of the satellite system's television channels.
ADVANTAGES -- The company can use existing satellites to offer four local channels in some areas immediately and expects to reach about 25 major markets by the end of January.
DISADVANTAGES -- Inefficient. It will limit DirecTV's ability to offer other types of programming, and households outside the largest markets will not get local rebroadcast service.
 
BEGINNING 2002
 
HOW IT WILL WORK -- A new satellite that DirecTV plans to put in service by 2002 will be designed to break up beams into spots aimed at selected metropolitan areas. This will allow different channels to be sent to each area.
ADVANTAGES -- Much more efficient. The company will be able to offer more channels in each market and expand the service to smaller markets. It will also free the national channels, allowing for many more programming options from DirecTV's other, full-beam satellites.
DISADVANTAGES -- The company will have to spend about $200 million to build, launch and operate the spot-beam satellite. And households in most rural areas will still not be included in the local rebroadcast service. (Source: DirecTV)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: World Trade Group Picking Up the Pieces From Seattle

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Struggling to recover from the trade conference in Seattle that collapsed in failure nine days ago, the World Trade Organization plans a special meeting this Friday to decide how to proceed.
A spokesman for the 135-nation group that makes the rules for international commerce said that the main purpose of the meeting of its general council would be to regain momentum for resolving some disputes that had foiled the ministerial conference in Seattle, leaving delegates dispirited and angry. 
 The conference had been intended as a forum for delegates to agree on an agenda for lowering some of the remaining barriers to freer world trade, through negotiations to take place during the next few years.
Thousands of protesters disrupted the conference in scenes reminiscent of late 1960's mass action against American involvement in the Vietnam War. They denounced the W.T.O. as a secretive, probusiness group that ignores environmental protection and labor rights in the name of corporate profits.
Protesters blocked access to the conference sites on the first day and some rampaged through downtown Seattle; more than 500 were arrested by riot police officers, who have been accused of responding with violent tactics of their own.
The conference ended after delegates could not even agree on whether to discuss issues that have divided them, most notably agricultural subsidies and labor rights in developing countries.
In the week since W.T.O. delegates have returned to their Geneva headquarters, many remain shocked by the events in Seattle. Some staff members at the ordinarily quiet building that houses the organization say they have been barraged by hate mail and virus-laced e-mail.
"There is certainly a feeling of disappointment," said Tunisia's envoy, Kamel Morjane, in a comment typical of the negotiators who have returned.
While most envoys refrained from finger-pointing in public, there was no hesitance to do so in Brussels, where the European Union trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, attributed the breakdown in Seattle to American presidential-campaign politics, and said he doubted that a new round of negotiations could get under way until after the election next November.
The W.T.O.'s director general, Mike Moore, sounding a rare hopeful note, said he wanted to get going with efforts to open a new round of trade talks. "The longer we delay launching the negotiations," he said, "the more the poorest among us lose."
Others have expressed pessimism whether the organization can even decide what should happen next.
"There is a confusion here," said Mexico's envoy, Alejandro de la Pena. "It is not at all clear how we are going to follow up.
"But we all know this is not the end. It's not like this is the first time we have found ourselves in a situation like this," he said, alluding to the suspension of negotiations during the previous Uruguay trade round in 1988 and 1990.

HEADLINE: Y2K PULSE;
Concern Over Year 2000Remains Low in Surveys

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
With the days winding down until the year 2000, each new survey or poll seems to add to the evidence that Americans are confident computer glitches will not have much impact on their lives.
The National Federation of Independent Businesses, the leading trade association for small companies, reported recently that many members who had said last spring that they would take steps to prepare for computer problems this fall had now decided not to bother. And a survey for the National Association of Manufacturers found that 93 percent of members expected the year 2000 to have almost no impact on their companies and only 4 percent foresaw significant disruptions of any part of the economy. 
 "What's news in this survey is what we're not seeing," said Jerry Jasinowski, the manufacturing group's president, in announcing the results last Friday. "There's no last-minute panic and little stockpiling of inventory."
The manufacturers' sample was small -- just 100 out of its 14,000 members -- but the economist who did the survey, Edward Yardeni of Deutsche Bank, said the results were in line with answers to the same questions by a much larger group of similar companies about two weeks earlier. (The data from these surveys, and previous samplings, is at www.peoplepolls.com). The levels of concern rise only when certain sectors, like health care, are isolated, Mr. Yardeni said.
The air of normalcy is being reinforced by surveys that are actually thinly disguised advertising. Blockbuster Video recently reported that more than 22 percent of those it polled planned to celebrate the arrival of the Year 2000 by renting a movie and staying home. London International Group, maker of Durex condoms, reported that among 16- to 21-year-olds worldwide, nearly half intend -- or at least hope -- that the big night would include activities requiring its products.
It all adds up to a challenging climate for many Year 2000 entrepreneurs, particularly those who anticipated that disruptions and public concern would be in full swing by now.
Consider the book world. "The Millennium Bug" by Michael S. Hyatt, probably the best seller so far among Year 2000 books, is hanging strong, relatively speaking, in the No. 820 spot on Amazon's hardcover sales list. But "Time Bomb 2000" the onetime hot-seller by Edward Yourdon, a well-known software expert, and his daughter, Jennifer, was down to No. 12,322 over all in the rankings. And "Crisis Investing for the Year 2000" by L. Jay Kuo and Edward M. Dua, was 86,808th.
Meanwhile, Jan Nickerson, who claims to have created the only Year 2000 board game, has just started a two-for-one sale ($34 including shipping at www. Y2KConnections.com).
Those trying to sell their wares are increasingly competing with others who make many of the same points more succinctly for free. The Utne Reader recently began offering free copies of its Y2K Citizen's Action Guide to any group that wants at least 50 or more (contact mitra@utne.com). "Awakening: the Upside of Y2K," a collection of essays on community and personal preparedness edited by Judy Laddon, Larry Shook and Tom Atlee, costs $7 at Amazon.com; but Ms. Laddon will give 50 or more copies for free to anyone who pays shipping costs (JGLaddon@aol.com).
And last week, Global Action Plan, a nonprofit environmental group in Woodstock, N.Y., announced plans to distribute 125,000 preparedness brochures to community groups in 16 states, all financed by the Nathan Cummings Foundation. (The brochure can be downloaded free at www.GlobalActionPlan.org). 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

RCN Planning to Acquire Small Local Phone Carrier
Expanding its communications footprint from the East Coast to the Midwest, RCN has agreed to acquire the 21st Century Telecom Group, a small local communications carrier based in Chicago, for about $260 million in stock, executives close to the talks said. The deal is expected to be announced today.
 RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., and so far operating mainly in the corridor between Boston and Washington, is the biggest company competing against the regional Bell companies for residential customers. Page C8.

With the days winding down until the new year, each new survey or poll seems to add to the evidence that Americans are confident Year 2000 computer glitches will not have much effect on their lives. A Century of Powerful Advertising
Madison Avenue did not assume its familiar form until this century -- when mass-produced, name-brand products began to be promoted through mass media. So in the spirit of summing up a century, it only makes sense to designate the 100 most powerful corporate and product brands of the 20th century, which must include McDonald's, and predict which brands will be powerful in the 21st century. Company by company, executives reported at a media conference that the cyclical business was thriving. And they also said that revenues from their Internet properties were growing exponentially. HEADLINE: Telecommunications Powerhouse;
Goldman Sachs Rules as Industry Is Transformed in Europe

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
For a brief period last month, it seemed that the Goldman Sachs Group might become a victim of its own international success.
Mannesmann, the German telecommunications giant, had filed a conflict-of-interest suit in London, arguing that Goldman should be barred from advising the British wireless company Vodafone AirTouch. On what grounds? Because Goldman had advised an investor in Orange of Britain, a wireless company Mannesmann itself wanted. 
 But the court called the suit hopeless, refusing to censure Goldman for having too many of a good thing -- clients. In the end, the episode underscored what investment bankers had known all along: Goldman Sachs had become a dominant force in the redrawing of Europe's telecommunications map.
Chalk it up to the appetites of acquisition-hungry Europeans eager to expand their network empires -- and to Goldman's years of positioning itself to direct and underwrite that action.
This year, Goldman has been an adviser on $239 billion of telecommunications mergers in Europe. That represents an almost fourfold increase over 1998, according to Thompson Financial Securities Data, and enough to propel it from No. 11 to No. 1 on the list of bankers in European telecommunications mergers. Not only is Goldman the lead adviser for the voracious Vodafone, Britain's largest wireless concern, but it acts as counsel to other giants, most notably Deutsche Telekom, which Goldman took public in 1996.
This rise to prominence has come at the expense of European investment bankers like Lazard Freres & Company and Schroders, Britain's largest independent investment bank. They have not only fallen behind Goldman on their own turf but know that its most formidable opponent in the region is another American firm, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company.
But the European bankers face more than bad luck. In a year when American-style corporate takeovers are overrunning the traditions of economic nationalism in Europe -- a few years ago, a hostile bid by a British company for a German telecommunications company would have been unthinkable -- the contestants need the American banks that know best how to play the game.
"They've outmuscled all of us because of their single-minded focus on winning," an investment banker at a European firm said of Goldman. To illustrate his point, he began humming the theme song from "The A Team," a 1980's television show about a group of rebels who brandished weapons to defeat their enemies. "Goldman's like the A Team. They're a real shoot-'em-up group."
Goldman began its march into Europe more than a decade ago when, anticipating a wave of privatization in telecommunications, the firm began calling on government agencies to help them sell stakes in state-owned telephone concerns. Scott Mead, a Cambridge-educated American, was one of the core team to set up shop in 1988 in London, where he is now co-head of Goldman's global communications, media and entertainment group. His counterpart is another American, Robert S. Harrison, a longtime Goldman partner who teamed up with Mr. Mead early this year and is based in New York.
One of the group's first deals was a public offering by Telefonica S.A., Spain's biggest telecommunications company, in the late 80's. Other stock underwriting assignments followed, including one by Britain's Cable and Wireless in 1989 and another by TeleDanmark of Denmark in 1994.
But Goldman's big break came when it was picked by the German government to sell a $13 billion stake in Deutsche Telekom in a stock offering in 1996. The assignment became the cornerstone of Goldman's campaign to court top-tier European telecommunications players. "It was the franchising of our German office," Mr. Mead said. "People could see the German government had faith in us and this was a good thing."
Wooing Deutsche Telekom required a protracted courtship. Goldman bankers from both London and Frankfurt had approached the German company in 1990 about the prospects of a sale. They held regular strategy sessions with executives along with several smaller meetings, Mr. Mead recalled. Top executives from New York made regular visits and in 1994, a Goldman associate began working from an office in Deutsche Telekom headquarters.
Its established relationships with European telephone companies helped Goldman to pounce as new businesses like wireless communications and Internet access have spun out of the telephone industry.
"The Goldman strategy is if it was owned by the government, take it private," said Howard Anderson, chairman of the Yankee Group, a telecommunications research firm. "If it is private, take it public. Then merge it. They are a transaction machine."
Consider the case of Spain's Terra Networks S.A., a provider of Internet access and content in Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries, which Goldman took public last month and whose market value reached $13.9 billion as of last Friday. Terra Networks is a unit of Goldman's oldest European telecom client, Telefonica.
Goldman's European base has also enabled the firm to enhance client relationships in the United States. In 1998, for instance, Goldman advised the Ameritech Corporation, the Chicago-based telephone company, on its purchase of a 34.4 percent stake in another Goldman client, Denmark's state-owned TeleDanmark, for $3.1 billion. That deal led to Goldman's advising Ameritech on its sale earlier this year to SBC Communications Inc., Mr. Mead said.
This year, however, if any company has put Goldman on the map in Europe it has been Vodafone AirTouch. Few people in the United States had even heard of the company until last January, when it defeated Bell Atlantic in a bidding contest to buy AirTouch Communications, one of the largest American cellular phone companies, for $77 billion. And then, as if to show there were no hard feelings, Vodafone followed up in the summer with the announcement of an $80 billion cellular joint venture -- with Bell Atlantic.
Vodafone executives knew Goldman as far back as 1988, when the firm helped with the spinoff of Vodafone from Racal Electronics, a military-electronics company. In the early going, Goldman did not conduct much business for Vodafone because the telecommunications company was not actively pursuing deals, said Christopher Gent, Vodafone's chief executive. In fact, Goldman nearly lost the account altogether when it played lead banker for the 1996 initial stock offering of a Vodafone competitor, Orange, without conferring with Vodafone.
To make amends, Mr. Gent said, Goldman's chief executive at the time, Jon S. Corzine, called him personally to apologize. "We came to an understanding early on of what was expected of them," Mr. Gent recalled. "I expected them to commit to us."
It was not long before Mr. Mead began to call on Mr. Gent personally.
The two men hit it off, and Mr. Gent recalls a strategy meeting in 1997 where they came up with the notion that telecommunications companies like Vodafone would either "hunt or be hunted." To survive in a global market, Mr. Gent said, "we had to do it by transactions, not by being stealth."
Goldman leaped into action, dispatching teams from both Europe and the United States to begin working up a strategy with Vodafone, resulting in the AirTouch and Bell Atlantic forays and the ongoing effort to take control of Mannesmann.
But even Mr. Gent is mindful of the risk Goldman has taken by choosing to represent his company in the Mannesmann battle. Germany is one of its most lucrative markets, and if the strategy backfires, the Goldman name will surely lose some luster there. "It was a huge decision for them to back us in Germany because they are so strong there," Mr. Gent said. "It could hurt them. I'm sure there was a lot of discussion at Goldman about this."
Last January, Mr. Harrison, a longtime Goldman partner and friend of Mr. Mead's since their university days in Britain in the late 1970's, joined him at Mr. Mead's invitation to co-head the communications, media and entertainment group. Through the spring, over several dinners in Manhattan at Provence in SoHo and other French bistros, and through frequent trips between New York and London, the two mapped out their group's strategy for adapting to a fast-changing telecommunications world.
First, the Mr. Mead and Mr. Harrison decided that Goldman's 175 telecommunications bankers worldwide should focus on two types of concerns: "super league" telecommunications companies, of which they say there are some 60 worldwide, including the likes of Vodafone and Deutsche Telekom; as well as emerging telecom companies. "We are looking for the next Global Crossing, huge users of capital that require high-yield financing," Mr. Harrison said, alluding to an upstart telecommunications company that Goldman and others have advised, which is investing in undersea cables for Internet use. "Right now it is a question of finding them."
And it is a question of whether Goldman can service them. Goldman has always been strong in merger advice and taking companies public. But high-yield finance -- debt financing with sufficient risk that investors demand a higher interest rate -- has never been Goldman's forte. Hoping to change that, Goldman recently hired David Solomon, a noted Wall Street rainmaker and former co-head of investment banking at Bear, Stearns, to help lead its newly expanded global high-yield banking business.
Steve Galbraith, an investment banking and brokerage analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, is one of many in the industry who are closely watching Goldman's high-yield effort. "It is the only part of their arsenal they are missing," Mr. Galbraith said. "It will be interesting to see if this strategy works out."
And in a nod to the colliding worlds of technology, telecommunications and media, Goldman's global communication group has set up a joint venture with its technology team to represent Internet companies and telecommunications equipment makers. It is not unusual for technology and telecommunications bankers to cross paths, but until now they have typically called on clients separately in order to protect lucrative fiefs.
If Goldman's approach is successful, other investment banks might be tempted to follow suit. If not, Goldman may find its bankers divided by turf battles that could leave the firm vulnerable to competitors all too happy to swoop in and steal business.
"Their vision is: fortune favors the bold," Mr. Anderson, the Yankee Group chairman, said of Goldman's success in Europe. "We'll see how well they apply it to their own business in the coming years."

HEADLINE: Experts Say NASA Is on Course, Despite Setbacks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Lean, mean and ready to do things differently, Daniel S. Goldin came to the office of NASA administrator seven years ago as a crusader eager to shake up an agency adrift in failure and mediocrity. His mantra was "faster, cheaper, better."
No more behemoths that cost many billions of dollars apiece would be built to explore outer space. Instead, he vowed to tap American ingenuity to build swarms of small but powerful spacecraft that would probe the heavens, sending back a nearly constant stream of new information. Today, about $100 billion later, the revolution that Mr. Goldin engineered is in a crisis. It has suffered its worst blows yet with the loss in recent months of a pair of Mars craft -- an orbiter and a lander with two innovative surface probes the size of cantaloupes. 
 Still, there is surprising agreement among NASA officials and leaders in space exploration that despite its troubles, the agency is on course.
Mr. Goldin, 59, the longest continuously serving head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is zealous, even as he appoints panels to investigate the current problems. He says he is chastened by failure but unbowed in his tenets.
"We got set back," he said of the Mars failures. "But we'll pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off, and we're going to rock this world. The revolution continues."
He said his initiatives have not only produced dozens of successes in space exploration -- discovering new worlds and probing many others, from the Moon to the galactic maternity wards where stars are born -- but also saved taxpayers at least $40 billion.
A half-dozen space leaders seemed to echo Mr. Goldin's judgment.
In interviews, they said his revolution is basically sound, if shaken. Plans for the Mars program, shattered by disaster, are in flux. But no expert foresaw big changes in the principles of "faster, cheaper, better," nor a need for more than relatively minor adjustments in what some call Captain Dan's star trek.
Some analysts said the voyage is just beginning to pick up speed and big economies and advances lie ahead.
"We fell into cutting too many corners," said John C. Beckman, head of the systems division at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, which designed the recently lost spacecraft. "But the basic process is not broken. There's still a lot to be gained from increasing our efficiency. I really do believe that we've barely scratched the surface in terms of what's possible."
Claude R. Canizares, chairman of the space studies board at the National Academy of Sciences and director of the Center for Space Research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, agreed, saying that on balance the revolution's troubles were worth the benefits.
"It's possible that the pendulum has swung too far," he said. "But you can argue that, given the realities of human nature, this was bound to happen and it's not wholly a bad thing. It helps you define the limits. Hopefully we can learn from that in terms of best practices, rather than learning as in a tribunal."
John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, was the most critical, saying penny pinching had pushed many teams to the breaking point.
"There's a balance between science return, acceptance of risk and cost reduction," he said. "Those have gotten out of balance, with too much emphasis on cost reduction. But the idea of doing missions more rapidly and at lower cost certainly is still valid. The issue is how rapidly and how much cost reduction."
The general upbeat appraisal for "faster, cheaper, better" is all the more remarkable given a rash of failures that began in 1997 and reached a crescendo in past weeks:.
*Two Earth-observing craft, Lewis and Clark, failed in orbit in 1997 and production in 1998, victims of instrument problems, testing delays, rising costs and control-system flaws.
*In December 1998, the Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous spacecraft missed its meeting with Eros, a potato-shaped rock 25 miles long. It is to try again next year.
*The telescope on the Wide-Field Infrared Explorer satellite lost its protective cover shortly after launching last March, letting coolant escape into space and ruining the astronomy mission.
*In September, a mix-up between English and metric units in navigation data sent the Mars Climate Orbiter off course and probably plummeting into Mars in fiery death.
*This month, the Mars Polar Lander, a traditional probe with retrorockets as well as two small hitchhikers meant to smash into the planet at 400 miles per hour and survive to send back data, fell silent as it neared touchdown.
After the latest failures, NASA promised a "major rethinking" of the strategy for the Mars program, which could include a two-year delay in the next landing effort, planned for launching in 2001.
Despite the ominous cast of recent events, more than one analyst noted that there had been many more successes than failures. Winners include spacecraft that have studied the Moon, the Sun, an asteroid, the Earth's magnetosphere, interstellar clouds, interplanetary dust and distant stars and new kinds of engines for advanced spacecraft.
The Mars Pathfinder mission in 1997 became a global sensation as its plucky little robot, Sojourner, rolled across the Martian soil, analyzing rocks and sending back stunning photographs.
Howard E. McCurdy, a space historian at American University who is working on a book about the Goldin revolution, noted that the total cost of 16 small missions was about the same as the Cassini spacecraft, a $3.3 billion colossus of the old school now on its way to Saturn.
"That's why it's so attractive," he said of the revolution. "You can do 16 missions for price of one."
"Yeah," he added, "you lose maybe 20 percent but you're still ahead."
The NASA program that is hard to shrink dramatically for safety reasons, he said, is that of human spaceflight, including the nation's fleet of space shuttles and the international space station taking shape in orbit.
Their costs, Dr. McCurdy said, dwarf those of the satellites and probes and account for roughly half the NASA budget, which this year is $13.6 billion.
Joseph A. Burns, a planetary scientist at Cornell University, said the Goldin revolution had considerable merit but was failing to come to grips with future big-ticket exploratory goals that were hard to do fast and cheap. Examples he cited were "a serious search" for life on Mars and a major voyage to the outer solar system, where icy planets and comets hold clues of creation.
"A lot of people would still like to do that," he said of a trek to the dark fringes of the Sun's realm.
Mr. Goldin said his agenda was expanding, not contracting, and that by design it could continue to embrace risk and failure.
If NASA has 10 winners out of 10 tries, he said, "we have mediocre goals." Conversely, he added, if two or three ambitious tries fail while seven or eight succeed, that "would be unbelievable success."
Revolution is difficult but rewarding, he said. Most important, "it goes on."

HEADLINE: Candidates Go to Florida, Eyes on the Primary Prize

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 12

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, the Democratic candidates for president, opened a spirited competition for Florida voters this weekend, delivering dueling speeches before the state Democratic convention that, in gentlemanly language, sharply contrasted their records, styles and visions for the country.
In a forceful speech before 2,000 party stalwarts today, Mr. Bradley suggested that the vice president would "shrink back" and "tinker around the edges," while his own "bold" ideas would rekindle the spirit of three Democratic icons: Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Robert F. Kennedy. 
 "I say, 'Now is not the time to settle,' " Mr. Bradley said, testing a new refrain in his 35-minute address. "I'm not prepared to settle for anything less than making access to health care affordable to all Americans. I'm not prepared to settle for anything short of registering and licensing all handguns in this country. I'm not prepared to settle for anything less than bringing all children out of poverty in this country."
"Democrats," he concluded, "do not settle."
On Saturday, Mr. Gore delivered a 45-minute speech in which he toned down his usual sledgehammer attacks on Mr. Bradley, apparently out of respect for the health of the former senator, who had gone to a California hospital on Friday suffering from a bout of irregular heart beats.
But without naming his opponent, Mr. Gore suggested to his audience that Mr. Bradley's positions on Social Security, education, the budget and Medicare, the government health care program for the elderly, were out of sync with traditional Democratic values.
"I voted against those Reagan-Bush budget cuts," Mr. Gore said, omitting his usual criticism of Mr. Bradley for supporting them in 1981. "I fought against the Newt Gingrich Republican Congress," he added, invoking questions about Mr. Bradley's party loyalty for retiring from the Senate in 1996 after Mr. Gingrich became speaker of the House.
In another implicit jab at Mr. Bradley, Mr. Gore said, "I have never been afraid to take on the big pharmaceutical companies," a reference to Mr. Bradley's repeated Senate votes for measures supported by the pharmaceutical industry. New Jersey, the state Mr. Bradley represented in the Senate, is home to many of the nation's largest drug companies, several of which contributed heavily to Mr. Bradley's Senate campaigns.
Mr. Bradley's irregular heart beats, atrial fibrillation, a chronic condition for which he takes daily medication, forced him to cancel several West Coast events on Friday and Saturday. But his doctors, who say the condition is not serious, said the palpitations stopped spontaneously on Friday, without treatment.
Mr. Bradley looked relaxed and energetic today. His aides said he would maintain a busy campaign schedule this week.
The appearance of the two candidates in Florida, the fourth-largest state, underscored the potential importance of its primary, which falls on March 14, one week after the primaries in California, New York, Ohio and several other states. Both men will have to campaign selectively in March, and this weekend's convention indicated that they will focus on Florida.
For the Gore camp, Florida, along with other Southern states, offers an important opportunity to knock Mr. Bradley back if he does well on March 7. The vice president, who is from Tennessee, is viewed as the front-runner here and across the South. He has locked up endorsements from Attorney General Bob Butterworth and other top Democratic officials in Florida, and from the state's largest unions, including its 442,000-member A.F.L.-C.I.O.
But officials of the Bradley campaign say they can compete with Mr. Gore in Florida more effectively than in other Southern states, largely because of its many transplanted New York and New Jersey residents. In addition to representing New Jersey in the Senate for 18 years, Mr. Bradley played basketball for the New York Knicks for 10 years.
In wooing Florida voters now, the two candidates also reflect a growing concern among many Democrats that the eventual Democratic nominee may have trouble winning here next November because Florida's Governor, Jeb Bush, is the brother of the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
President Clinton won the state in 1996, but several polls have shown George W. Bush leading both Democrats here.
"Their coming here sends a signal that Florida is still viable for the Democrats," said Charles Whitehead, the chairman of the state Democratic Party.
Mr. Whitehead said he thought Mr. Bradley faced "an uphill battle" in Florida. But he said he thought the former senator was gaining support, adding: "I would guess that 75 percent of Bradley's supporters in the room today were committed to Gore before the convention. He was very well received today."
Mr. Gore's chief message here was to Florida's legions of retired people, reassuring them that he would stand fast on protecting Social Security and Medicare, programs he has said Mr. Bradley would do little to defend and might even undermine.
Mr. Gore also traded unabashedly on his partnership with President Clinton, who remains popular in Florida and who spoke warmly of Mr. Gore to the conventioneers earlier on Saturday. Mr. Gore reminded the audience of the economic boom of the Clinton years and of Florida's support for the re-election of the Clinton-Gore ticket in 1996.
"Bill Clinton and I came in and, with Democratic votes alone, we changed the policy of our country, and we reordered the priorities," Mr. Gore said. "This kind of progress is not something that we should just casually toss aside."
Mr. Bradley gave his usual stump speech today, but spiced it with a stronger assertion than usual of his support for Social Security, Medicaid, Medicare and civil rights protections.
"Is there anybody who questions our belief in Social Security, civil rights, Medicare?" he asked. "That's why I find it so dismaying that one Democrat can attack another on these issues. On issues that are articles of faith for our party. If we are united on anything, we have to be united on these issues."
Both candidates made strong appeals to black voters, voicing their support for affirmative action, which has become a hot topic here. Opponents of the policy are trying to place an initiative on the ballot that would end the use of racial preferences by the state government and public universities.
Both candidates said they supported giving a visa to the father of Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old Cuban boy who was rescued off the Florida coast while escaping to the United States aboard a boat last month. The boy's mother died on the trip, and he has become the focus of a battle between his father, who says he wants him returned to Cuba, and Cuban-Americans in Florida who want him to remain here.

HEADLINE: 10-Year-Old Jetliner Remains a Work in Progress

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
Sitting on huge steel jacks in a maintenance hangar here, the big, gray Boeing 737, tail No. N-1383, was in for some serious work.
A floor beam under the aft galley was rusting; the steel tracks that guide the wing flaps were wearing out, and engineers suspected that the cargo doors were developing hidden cracks. The plane's maintenance report over the past month formed a computer printout about 15 feet long, and the Federal Aviation Administration had demanded that United Airlines, the plane's operator, install a better flight data recorder and a firefighting system in the cargo holds, among other changes, in response to airplane crashes. In all, the plane needed about 50 changes, plus extensive routine maintenance. 
 The situation seemed to prove the adage that a plane is a collection of spare parts flying in close formation. But Frederick L. Mohr, managing director of United Airlines' maintenance center here, called N-1383 a "pretty good airplane."
Passenger jets like N-1383 usually get close public scrutiny only after fatal accidents. At that point, every broken part they ever flew with, every flaw that was waiting to be corrected, every malady that any plane of that type ever experienced, takes on an ominous aura.
But the everyday reality for planes like N-1383, which is based at United's San Francisco hub and makes short flights around California, is far different. With hundreds of thousands of parts, multiple redundant systems, elaborate monitoring systems and a strict maintenance regimen, the plane is almost always available, able to safely carry 126 passengers in coach and 8 in first class and even safely sustain a variety of part failures in flight.
The plane almost always needs work, however. Today was "Day 3 of 19," as described by Robert K. Corriveau, the team leader for the hangar section where 215 mechanics were stripping pieces off the plane, reminiscent of insects on the carcass of a giant bird.
In its 10-year lifetime, in 30,166 hours of flight, the plane has never had an engine fail or have to be shut down in flight, and if it is average among United's fleet -- the airline's engines are more reliable than most others -- it will not have that problem for years to come. In 20,080 flights, it has never had to return to an airport or divert on the way to a destination because of a mechanical problem.
The airline has had to report to the Federal Aviation Administration about problems involving N-1383 on three occasions, all relatively minor incidents involving lights that were not working correctly. One involved floor lighting for emergency escapes, another the light on an emergency exit slide, and the third an indicator light that flickered instead of correctly showing whether the plane's wing slats were retracted in flight. The pilot had to look out of a window of the passenger cabin to see that the slats were functioning properly.
But the history of airline crashes is, in a way, carved into the hardware of this airplane. For example in May 1996, a ValuJet DC-9 took off with improperly packed hazardous cargo that caught fire, causing the plane to crash. On this visit, N-1383 was having smoke detectors and fire suppression systems installed in its forward and aft cargo holds.
The inspection itself is partly a result of the roof peeling away in flight on an Aloha Airlines 737 in April 1988. (The plane landed safely.) Some of the flaws found are not easily detected. A worker examined the floor beam, for example, with a mirror only a little bigger than the one a dentist might use.
Other changes come from other crashes.
In September 1994, a USAir 737 crashed near Pittsburgh, and solving the mystery of the cause took more than three years, partly because its flight data recorder had been an early model; on this visit, N-1383 was getting an updated version.
The new flight data recorder is a good example of the difference between minimum requirements and what United considers good maintenance. The original flight data recorder captured 16 categories of information; the F.A.A., after much debate, is requiring 22, but the one United is installing will capture 36.
The aircraft is also getting a computer, the "enhanced ground proximity warning system," that compares the plane's course to an electronic map and warns against flying too low.
That is a result of the 1995 crash of an American Airlines plane in Columbia. And the plane is getting a new weather radar that can detect windshear, the sudden shift from a headwind to a tailwind.
Forty of the 50 changes in the maintenance visit are voluntary, most of them recommended by Boeing, with others the idea of United.
From a bolt on a landing gear that tends to crack because of corrosion, causing delays, to unreliable seals on a refrigerator in the galley, the list of changes goes on and on.
But these are only the changes made in heavy maintenance. The service report over the last month is a secession of burned-out light bulbs or other small problems. The plane has six wheels, and has had four tire replacements in the last month. One tire was replaced twice.
Over and over, maintenance officials say that safety is their top priority. But it was clear that many of the changes would be reliability problems long before they would be safety problems.
The engineering staff evaluates a constant flow of service problems from the field, and "service bulletins" from Boeing recommending changes as well as the manufacturers of the engines and other components. On a plane like the 737, the service bulletins can reach 1,000 a year. Airlines like United will take action on most of the recommendations. The aviation agency will focus on a handful and make them mandatory.
United's aim is to complete action on the suggestions in the safety-related bulletins long before the agency mandates them, which can take years. Sometimes this backfires.
For example, after the National Transportation Safety Board said that the USAir crash in Pittsburgh showed a problem with the hydraulic unit in the rudder, United replaced the unit in its 737's before the agency finished drafting its rule to require the change. In the end, though, the agency mandated one test more than United had accomplished, and the airline had to take the hydraulic units off the plane a second time and put them to the additional test. "We went out and tried to lead the industry, but then they came out with another test," said Gregory Borsari, United's manager of engineering for 737's.
Each change leads to a raft of other changes. Anything that adds five pounds or more to the plane's weight goes into a database used to recalculate its center of gravity, for example. (And planes, like people, tend to get heavier as they age.) And any new system, like the fire detection and suppression system, means a new maintenance schedule.
For N-1383, which United bought new from Boeing in March 1990, this was heavy maintenance visit No. 2, the second time it has been torn apart and rebuilt. The process will include 20,148 hours of mechanics' labor, including 3,000 for modifications ordered by the aviation agency, recommended by Boeing or simply desired by United's 200 engineers, at a total labor cost of $420,000. Materials will cost another $342,000.
That is relatively cheap. By heavy maintenance visit No. 7, when the plane will be more than 30 years old, N-1383 will require 38,000 hours of labor, and the visit will cost about $3 million, not counting modifications that have not yet been devised.
The escalating cost of heavy maintenance may be what determines how long the plane can economically be flown, said Mr. Mohr, the United official. After that it will be scrapped or sold to a third-world airline "that doesn't have the same standards."

HEADLINE: Iowa Pivotal for Forbes's Battle to Counter Bush

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
In a convention hall filled with farm families from every corner of Iowa, Steve Forbes recently came face to face with George W. Bush and was treated to a vision of his coming task in Iowa's caucuses next month.
Wherever Mr. Bush went, cameras and flashes heralded his way, and teenage girls squealed with delight to be near him. A sea of John Deere-green baseball hats labeled "Bush Farm Team" bobbed on farmers' heads as they surged forward for autographs and a closer look at Mr. Bush, the governor of Texas and the front-runner in the race for the Republican presidential nomination. 
 In another corner at the Farm Bureau's annual meeting was Mr. Forbes, the multimillionaire magazine publisher, with only a meager crowd around him as he earnestly extolled the money-saving virtues of his flat tax plan.
At one point, when Kara Holtkamp of West Point, Iowa, put one of the Bush hats in Mr. Forbes's hands for an autograph, he gamely quipped: "Bush will let you wear the green. I'll let you keep the green."
Even though Mr. Bush's long shadow falls over the Forbes campaign here, it is in Iowa, Forbes campaign strategists say, that they feel they have the best chance of halting Mr. Bush's march toward his party's nomination, and establishing Mr. Forbes as a viable alternative.
To that end, the Forbes campaign is making Iowa its top priority. Veteran political strategists, with years of experience in local politics, are on Mr. Forbes's payroll. Television advertisements that cost about $60,000 a week are filling the Iowa airwaves. Grass-roots organizations have been set up in every county and most of the state's precincts, complete with county farm chairmen, anti-abortion captains and an assortment of other volunteer leaders to round up Forbes supporters.
Sophisticated direct mail and phone bank campaigns are under way, stressing how Mr. Forbes's tax program will help farmers. And the candidate himself has been hopping from one crossroads town to another in a campaign bus that blares John Philip Sousa marches, and wooing local voters with a first-class offering of food and drink.
The Forbes campaign here sees itself as part of a one-two punch to halt the front-runner: Mr. Forbes solidly challenging Mr. Bush in Iowa and Senator John McCain of Arizona closing in on Mr. Bush in New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primaries, to be held on Feb. 1, one week after the Iowa caucuses.
While no one -- even those in the Forbes camp -- expects Mr. Forbes to win in Iowa, they are hoping to keep Mr. Bush's lead here as slim as possible. Mr. McCain has avoided Iowa and is concentrating on New Hampshire, where he and Mr. Bush are neck and neck in the polls and Mr. Forbes remains a distant third.
"McCain is banking on us in Iowa to hold Bush down," said William Dal Col, the Forbes campaign manager. "And we're banking on him in New Hampshire."
John Maxwell, the campaign's top pollster, said: "Our Iowa strategy is to show Forbes as a viable candidate and pierce the veneer of inevitability of Bush. No one has ever gotten the Republican nomination doing poorly both in Iowa and New Hampshire. We're posing a serious threat to Bush in Iowa and McCain is in New Hampshire. Bush cannot take a double hit."
Forbes strategists are banking that their candidate's conservative economic message -- reducing taxes and shrinking the government -- will resonate with Iowa Republicans. But they are also hoping to score big with a socially conservative message of family values and opposition to abortion, much as Pat Robertson, the religious broadcaster, did when he placed second in the caucuses in 1988, behind then-Senator Bob Dole of neighboring Kansas, and as Patrick J. Buchanan did when he finished a strong second in 1996, behind Mr. Dole.
"Forbes is trying to emerge as a religious conservative alternative to Bush," said Dennis Goldford, head of the department of politics at Drake University. "In the Republican caucuses, something like 40 percent of the voters can be social conservatives, and Forbes has decided to bend that way. He has no illusion he could beat Bush. But if he could soften him in Iowa and McCain can deliver a punch, then people might start looking for someone else."
To this end, the Forbes campaign has put the former head of the Iowa Christian Coalition, Stephen Scheffler, on its Iowa payroll, and Mr. Scheffler has lined up an array of Iowa anti-abortion leaders telling social conservatives that Mr. Forbes is a more viable candidate than Gary L. Bauer, who is also seeking votes from religious conservatives.
Audiotapes of Mr. Forbes's anti-abortion speech at the National Christian Coalition convention are being sent to social conservatives, along with a number of position papers and a brochure called the "Baby Mailer" by local staff members because of the photograph on the cover of this anti-abortion pamphlet.
"I'm convinced Forbes is a guy who can go the long haul, has a message that is consistent and he's a winnable candidate," said Mr. Scheffler. "Social conservatives are convinced that he is for real and won't get squishy with his pro-family agenda when he gets elected."
In spending, organization and advertising, Mr. Forbes is going toe to toe with Mr. Bush, just as he did in last August's Iowa straw poll, when Mr. Forbes and Mr. Bush spent from $800,000 to $1 million each. Mr. Bush came in first, with 31 percent of the nonbinding vote, and Mr. Forbes finished second with 20 percent. The Forbes campaign would not say how much Mr. Forbes, who is dipping into his $440 million fortune to pay for his candidacy, has budgeted for the Iowa caucuses.
Unlike in a typical election that is settled at the ballot box, victory in the Iowa caucuses often comes to the candidate with the superior organization -- one that can deliver supporters to 2,142 local precincts for several hours of political debate with their neighbors on a cold night in January.
"You've got to go out and get real people," said Mr. Dal Col, the Forbes campaign manager. "You've got to grab them and get them to go out on a night that can be 20 to 30 degrees below zero, have them fight for their candidates and then take a vote."
Steve Grubbs, a Forbes campaign employee and former chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, added, "It's not like you have one big battle; you have 2,000 little ones."
Usually, about 100,000 Republicans -- roughly 20 percent of the total in the state -- show up at the caucuses. In a multicandidate field like the current one, the candidate who can get about 40,000 of those can win. In 1996, Mr. Dole won with 33,000 votes against Mr. Buchanan, Lamar Alexander, the former governor of Tennessee, and Mr. Forbes. Not only is the number of votes needed to win relatively small, but victory is entirely symbolic -- they are not binding on any Iowa delegate to the Republican National Convention.
How Mr. Forbes is approaching his campaign in Iowa is markedly different from his 1996 campaign, when he came in at the last minute with a series of negative television advertisements attacking Mr. Dole and had virtually no ground organization; Mr. Forbes ended up placing fourth. In addition, his reputation here was tarnished by the viciousness of his attacks on Mr. Dole, which only succeeded in damaging Mr. Dole's image nationally and labeling Mr. Forbes as a spoiler in his own party.
This time, the Forbes campaign here says, it has learned from those mistakes. "In 1996 we threw some ads up on the air, but we didn't have a ground game," Mr. Grubbs said. "This time we have a ground organization second to none to compete with Bush."
Mr. Forbes's broadcasting campaign consists of three television advertisements promoting his own views and making subtle digs at Mr. Bush, who has been criticized for his inexperience, especially in foreign affairs. One commercial shows Mr. Forbes with Ronald Reagan, highlights the candidate's "three decades of experience" and "vast knowledge" as publisher of the "foremost business magazine in the world," and maintains that Mr. Forbes's tenure at Radio Free Europe "helped play a role in the fall of Communism."
But will this all work? Iowa's five-term former Republican governor, Terry Branstad, who is a Bush supporter, said that while he believed that Mr. Bush had "a broader base and wider public support," Mr. Forbes was doing "much better" than in 1996: "He's got his bus tours, he's got his money, he's hired people who know how to run an organization and he's spending the time here."
Still, it is clear that Mr. Forbes has his work cut out for him.
"Forbes seems mean-spirited," said Joshua Bronsink, a Des Moines business consultant who attended a recent Chamber of Commerce luncheon here where Mr. Bush talked about his tax plan. "And I'm against a lot of what he says socially. Forbes is not electable, although I do think he will do well in Iowa. But, for me, he's always tearing people down and he's never been elected to anything before. That's why I'm for Bush."
Similar concerns were expressed at the Farm Bureau meeting. "I'm afraid people are tired of Forbes from last time around," said Don Wolhford, a Franklin County farmer. "People don't think he's electable, and they see Bush as a fresh face."

HEADLINE: Candidates Eager to Negotiate Cyberspace and Cyberissues

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
"Yours," Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah admonished Gov. George W. Bush of Texas during the first of the Republican presidential debates earlier this month, "is not user friendly."
As political zingers go, it might have been a bit lame. But that Mr. Hatch would use precious air time to criticize an opponent's Web site as "pretty tough to use" is only one indication of how the presidential candidates are confronting the Internet and technology generally, both as substantive issues and pervasive cultural forces. 
 They are raising money over the Internet. They are raising money from people who have grown rich from the Internet. They are debating how best to nurture the potential of the Internet while shielding children from pornography and consumers from potential misuse of data about them. And in the early stages of the first Internet-era national election, they are eager to let voters know they are as comfortable with a mouse as the next guy.
"The pace of candidate education is nearly as rapid as the pace of technological development," said Representative Christopher Cox of California, a Republican who is one of the few true techies in Congress.
Vice President Al Gore long ago dropped his paternity claim to the Internet. But Mr. Gore, who can sometimes be spotted with a Palm Pilot clipped to his belt, dropped into the CyberStop Cafe in Washington last week and with reporters and photographers watching sent an e-mail message to Bill Bradley, his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, questioning his opponent's stand on Medicare.
Mr. Bradley has held electronic town hall meetings. And the Republican candidates have gone back and forth about technology issues regularly during their debates.
"In not very many years, politics has moved from a lot of smoke-filled rooms and ward bosses giving out turkeys to constituents to dueling e-mails," said Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, a Democrat with a strong interest in technology issues. "This is an extraordinary transformation in politics. To reach the swing, independent voters who are going to decide about the 2000 elections you've got to talk about these issues."
The most politically charged of the issues may be whether and how to apply sales taxes to electronic commerce, and it is shaping up as a test of the candidates' views on the Internet in the economy and society.
Most governors and many local government officials are worried that as business migrates from Main Street and the mall to Amazon.com and Ebay, state governments will face a fiscal crisis, since online retailers for the most part are not required to collect sales taxes, the primary revenue source for states.
But in Washington, there is support in both parties for making the Internet a permanently tax-free shopping zone. A government commission studying the matter seems headed toward a deadlock.
The issue is particularly tricky for Mr. Bush, who is trying to establish his antitax credentials but shares the concerns of other governors that revenue losses from a shift to tax-free Internet shopping could leave states in a bind and hurt traditional retailers. Mr. Bush favors extending a moratorium against Internet taxes while the issue gets further study.
Mr. Bush's unwillingness to come out definitively against Internet sales taxes is being exploited by his rivals, who are suggesting obliquely that Mr. Bush is soft on taxes and maybe a bit of a Luddite to boot.
"The Internet should not be taxed," Senator John McCain of Arizona said. He extolled the Internet as "the greatest thing that's happened to the world," and compared its impact to a combination of the printing press and the industrial revolution.
"The governors are incredibly short-sighted when they want to tax this baby in its cradle," Mr. McCain said.
Mr. Hatch said it was "far overblown to think that the fact that people buy over the Internet is going to reduce Main Street U.S.A."
But the politics of technology can be complicated. Despite his message to Washington to "keep the government's mitts off" the industry, Mr. Hatch has been a supporter of the federal antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation. He has been raising campaign funds from executives at some of Microsoft's rivals.
Steve Forbes, by contrast, says the Microsoft case is a waste of time and money, because the pace of change in the software business will render moot any court judgment.
The scramble to raise money from technology companies almost guarantees that candidates will continue to pay attention to the issues on the industry's mind.
Mr. Bush had raised $1.73 million from people affiliated with technology and communications companies through Oct. 15, while Mr. Gore had raised $1.54 million from them, Mr. Bradley $770,000 and Mr. McCain $500,000.
But the candidates seem fascinated and intrigued by the technology's potential to affect the world, not just dot-com companies.
Defending his support for bringing China into the World Trade Organization, Mr. Bush cited the Web's potential to communicate democratic values even in the face of opposition from a repressive regime.
"Imagine if the Internet took hold in China," Mr. Bush said. "Imagine how freedom would spread."
