HEADLINE: Translating S.U.V. Into European;
Re-engineering The Old World

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec.13

 BODY:
A typical ad for a Hyundai Galloper reads like a zoology text: "Strong and Savage, Lives in Cities."
Hyundai Motor and other automakers have introduced such ads to persuade Europeans to buy an unlikely animal, a native of North America that has been bred successfully in East Asia and is now spreading to the narrow lanes and congested cities of Western Europe: the sport utility vehicle. 
 Astronomical gas prices and a tradition of compact cars would seem to make most of Europe less hospitable than the United States to sport utilities. Yet Europeans -- to the delight of auto industry executives but to the dismay of environmentalists and traffic planners -- are taking to the vehicles in a big way, moving up from their midget Fiat Cinquecentos and Renault Twingos.
To be sure, many of the models sold in Europe, sometimes modified versions of their trans-Atlantic kin, are smaller and more fuel-efficient than the behemoths found on American roads. But some larger models are also attracting buyers.
After several years of relative stability, European sales of the high-riding sport utilities surged 26 percent last year, four times the rate of the overall passenger vehicle market, to 464,400. This year, they are expected to grow another 21 percent, to roughly 564,200, again four times the pace of the overall market.
Still, that number represents only about 3.7 percent of the total number of new passenger vehicles registered, far lower than in the United States, where last year sport utilities made up 16 percent of the market. The growth in Europe last year and this year was fueled by the introduction of new models like the Land Rover Freelander, the new Honda HR-V and the General Motors Corporation's updated Frontera from its Opel division, all smaller than the standard sport utility and hence better attuned to European roads. And with virtually every major manufacturer preparing an entry or already selling one, Europe's flirtation with sport utilities is expected to continue.
"There is still latent demand in Western Europe for this thing," said Nigel Griffith, an analyst at Standard & Poor's DRI in London. "There are still cowboys out there."
Last year, General Motors replaced its old Frontera, which was essentially an Isuzu Rodeo for the European market, and sold 25,000 of the new model. This year, it expects to sell 37,000 Fronteras, which are built at a factory in Britain. In just the first eight months of this year, Honda Motor sold more than 17,000 HR-V's, its new sporty, two-door hatchback similar to the CR-V in the United States, lifting its total European sales of sport utility vehicles to more than 41,000 -- almost as many as it sold in Europe in all of last year. And Land Rover, part of the BMW-owned Rover Group, sold more than 40,000 Freelanders last year, the model's first year.
Encouraged by such successes, Fiat Auto announced this summer that it would invest $122 million in a joint venture with Mitsubishi Motors to build a sport utility at a factory outside Turin, Italy. Renault of France says that early next year it will introduce a utility, its first since bowing out of Jeep 12 years ago when it sold its controlling stake in American Motors to Chrysler. And Ford Motor is planning a downsized sport utility vehicle next year that will be more fuel efficient than the Explorer, its smallest model now, in part to meet the mounting European competition.
Then there are the offerings for the more pampered European motorists. The Mercedes-Benz unit of DaimlerChrysler had such success in Europe with its M-class utility, which is assembled in Alabama mainly for the North American market, that it started production of the M-class in July at a factory in Graz, Austria. In Italy, Mitsubishi is manufacturing the Pajero Pinin, an upscale model that it developed with the Italian design house Pininfarina. BMW has decided to introduce a European version of its new luxury X5, which goes on sale in the United States in December.
To outdo them all, Volkswagen plans to trot out its first two sport utilities by 2002. One, a midprice Volkswagen, will be built at a factory in Slovakia, while a more expensive version that is part of a joint venture with Porsche will be assembled at the same factory, then outfitted with a fancy Porsche interior and a more powerful engine at a factory Porsche is building in Leipzig, Germany.
Because European roads are smaller than those in the United States and gas prices are higher, automakers have bred a miniature species of sport utilities for Europe. Honda's new two-door HR-V, for instance, at 13 feet 6 inches, is 28 inches shorter than the Ford Explorer.
Utilities imported from the United States are trimmed to meet European tastes and requirements. Chrysler, which imports the Wrangler and the Cherokee from the United States, and assembles the Grand Cherokee at the factory in Austria where Mercedes makes the M-class, builds different seats and a stiffer suspension into its European cars and installs wipers and lights that conform to European standards.
Because of high gas prices (in Italy, for example, unleaded gas can cost more than $4.50 a gallon), many sport utility vehicles in Europe have diesel engines, since diesel fuel is cheaper. And most European utilities have four-cylinder engines, which use less gas than the V6 or big V8 engines in comparable American models.
In the United States, the sport utility was dreamed up by American automakers as essentially a pickup truck with a roof over the bed and extra rows of seats, and then successfully copied by Japanese manufacturers. In Europe, by contrast, it was first popularized by the Japanese -- who created the market by introducing smaller, more economical utilities they had designed for congested Asian cities -- and then copied by other automakers.
"The Japanese created the market from scratch," said Daniel T. Jones, a professor of auto industry management at the Cardiff University business school in Wales. "And everyone piled in behind the Japanese."
European automakers like the S.U.V. for the same reason their American counterparts do: fat cars make fat profits. Yet the growing competition in Europe, as more and more models flood the market, has depressed profit margins below those in the United States. Moreover, small production runs, usually of 30,000 to 40,000 vehicles, prevent the economies of scale that benefit manufacturers in the United States, where runs are often five to six times that size.
To keep costs down, Professor Jones said, the Europeans often share development costs with partners and borrow equipment from existing models. Thus, the platform for Renault's new sport utility will be adapted from its highly successful Scenic line of cars. The mechanical equipment for Fiat's new entry will come from Mitsubishi.
Even so, the automakers charge far higher prices in Europe for the same models they sell in the United States. A Chrysler Grand Cherokee, for instance, sells for up to 300,000 francs in France, or more than $46,000, compared with about $35,000 in the United States. The manufacturers explain the difference by citing transportation costs, European taxes and the expense of outfitting the cars to meet European standards. European consumers do not seem discouraged from buying.
Indeed, so many luxury automakers are rushing into the market that a new category of high-priced, high-performance sport utility vehicle is emerging -- populated with the likes of BMW's X5, Mercedes-Benz's M-class and Porsche's planned offering -- that is blurring the very definition of a utility. Thomas Zauber, a BMW spokesman in Munich, emphasized that "we don't say sport utility vehicle, we say sport activity vehicle, as opposed to off-road varieties." BMW, he said, believes that "the market is beginning to differentiate, and we believe it's going to grow in Europe."
Increasingly, Mr. Griffith of DRI said, "the market is about a statement of self-image, what people want to project to other people, and not just about moving from point A to point B."
Whatever you call the vehicles, more and more Europeans are buying them, and for much the same reasons as their Americans counterparts.
"You've got maximum safety, even if going off road to pick mushrooms," said Mario Roccabella, who drives a Suzuki Vitara, a small utility. Indeed, Mr. Roccabella, a 48-year-old auto salesman in Rome, got so hooked on his own vehicle several years ago that he began selling several brands, including Land Rovers, Mitsubishis and Subarus, and now organizes rallies for S.U.V. owners. Even in labyrinthine Rome, he said, sport utilities abound, offering greater vision because of their height, and a relatively smooth ride "even though the streets are made of Swiss cheese."
Environmental objections to the vehicles have not yet arisen, and some countries, like Italy -- now one of the hottest markets -- have even abolished taxes they once levied on off-road vehicles to discourage their spread, under pressure from automakers as well as constituents.
Some automakers and environmentalists cite the relatively low market share of sport utility vehicles, their smaller size in Europe and greater fuel efficiency as reasons an environmental debate has not erupted in Europe.
Still, some European motorists are already griping about sport utility drivers who hog the road in extremely congested cities.
"I don't like it very much the way they look down at you from so high up," said Ann-Henri Le Gouvello, 55, who owns a soup company in Rambouillet, France, and who uses a four-door Mercedes-Benz 300GE -- hardly a subcompact -- to drive to Paris or go hunting near his Rambouillet home. He sniffed at what he deemed pretentious city dwellers in their showy all-wheel drive vehicles, saying, "They use them to drive only in the city, and they never leave the road with them."
And despite fears that too many of the vehicles are on the drawing board, the automakers are accelerating their plans, pointing not only to growth in Europe but the potential for export.
Dave Reuter, a spokesman for Ford Europe, said its new, smaller model was designed for North America, Europe and Asia. Volkswagen expects to sell some of its new Volkswagen and Porsche utilities abroad; roughly half the 20,000 Porsches it will build will be sold in the United States.
"They never would have done it just for Europe," Mr. Griffith of Standard & Poor's said.

HEADLINE: Xerox Shares Shake Off Friday's Jitters

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
As shares of the Xerox Corporation regained a modicum of what they lost late Friday, a market truism was reaffirmed yesterday: investors are simply contrarians these days.
Right after the market closed on Friday, Xerox dropped a bombshell, warning that fourth-quarter earnings, which it had already said in October would be poor, would be even worse than that. Xerox's shares continued to fall in after-hours trading after closing at $20.0625, down 14 percent. 
 Yesterday, analysts flooded First Call/Thomson Financial with downgrades. They reduced their estimates for Xerox's fourth-quarter earnings to 40 cents from 66 cents, and they lowered their estimates for next year's earnings to $1.91 from $2.29.
"They went from estimating a 3 percent rise in earnings next year to a 3 percent decline," said Charles L. Hill, director of research at First Call. "Clearly, the analysts see some long-lasting problems at Xerox."
Yet neither Xerox nor investors were acting as though the company was in serious trouble yesterday. Conventional wisdom normally dictates that a company fight an upstart competitor by dropping prices. Although Xerox has been steadily losing market share to Canon, which has introduced many new digital products this year, Xerox announced price increases yesterday of 3 percent to 5 percent on some of its highest-end and lowest-end digital products.
"These are products where we can still sell everything we build, and that makes a price increase sustainable," said Jeffrey J. Simek, a Xerox spokesman.
Investors, despite their reaction late Friday, had calmed down by yesterday. Instead of plunging further in response to the analysts' downgrades, Xerox's shares rose $1.0625, to $21.125.
"Xerox has a tremendous customer base, and those customers will give them time to get their act together before they switch to competitors," said Hadley Reynolds, director of research for the Delphi Group, a document processing industry consulting firm in Boston.
It was unclear yesterday whether investors were simply bargain hunting or whether they agree with Mr. Reynolds rosy prognosis. If it is the latter, it is based more on hope than on tangible signs of improvement.
Many of Xerox's problems are beyond its control, of course. Brazil, once Xerox's hottest growth market, has serious economic trouble. And the strong dollar has damped the numbers Xerox can report from still-healthy sales in Europe.
But it is in the United States that Xerox is suffering the most. It still derives 75 percent of sales from slow, low-margin copiers whose markets grow less than 10 percent a year. Sales remain disappointing for Xerox's most profitable product line, the high-speed copiers used by publishing houses for print-on-demand applications and by corporations in their central copier operations.
Xerox attributes the shortfall to jitters over potential Year 2000 computer problems. But if that were the case, both the company and analysts would be predicting a big bounce from pent-up demand during the second quarter of 2000. No one is making such predictions.
Nor does Year 2000 seem to be an industrywide problem. Canon USA, which is emerging as Xerox's hottest competitor for high-speed digital copiers, insists its sales continue to boom. To be fair, Canon does not yet offer the kind of superexpensive high-speed copiers that Xerox says were the hardest hit by Year 2000 problems. But, the company intends to offer its first 110 page-a-minute digital copier in January, which means it will be approaching potential customers just as their Year 2000 fears are abating.
"If companies really are holding back on purchases because of Y2K, then we're going to have one real blowout first quarter," said Timothy Andree, a Canon vice president. Six months ago, Canon was ranked fourth in the copier industry, behind Xerox, Ricoh and Sharp. Now, many analysts say Canon may well end the year as No. 1.
"The hottest products win the day, and Canon's products are the hottest right now," said Benjamin A. Reitzes, an analyst at PaineWebber.
Xerox's sales people are in poor shape to fight back. They are grappling with a reorganization, effective in January, that makes them responsible for specific industries and companies, not geographic territories. On top of that, Xerox recently cut its administrative staff, figuring that it could easily consolidate 36 administrative centers into three.
The result was chaos. Billing errors and uncollected receivables skyrocketed, and sales people spent their time placating angry customers instead of cultivating new ones.
"They've bungled this entire restructuring at a time when there are just too many copier companies chasing too little business," Mr. Reitzes said.
Still, Xerox has not lost all its fans. Gibboney Huske, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, is sticking with her buy recommendation on Xerox stock. In fact, she predicts the share price will hit $41 within the next 18 months.
"Xerox is still a good buy from the perspective of risk-return," she said. "Granted, in the last month you've seen all the risk and none of the return, but ultimately these are short-term issues that will be resolved."
Mr. Simek said that Xerox already had a senior management task force working on "more than 25 countermeasures to help us heal more quickly and sustain earnings growth." For now, Mr. Simek offers no details, other than to say the countermeasures range from generating demand to reducing costs. He promised greater detail on Jan. 25, when Xerox will announce its fourth-quarter earnings.

HEADLINE: Race, Class and Now Money Fueling Rent-to-Own Battle

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In many poor communities, rent-to-own furniture outlets often stir the same mixed emotions as utility companies: both businesses provide necessities, but their steep prices often breed resentment.
So it is little wonder that the industry's annual efforts to win favorable legislation from the New Jersey Legislature often involve the inflammatory issues of race and class. This year's battle, over a bill that would exempt rent-to-own businesses from the state's laws limiting interest rates on lending, has also been fueled by big money. And as lawmakers rush to finish their business before the end of the legislative session on Jan. 10, it has become one of Trenton's most bitterly contested issues. 
 Rent-to-own advocates, who say their high prices are necessary because they provide a costly service for a market no other businesses will enter, have given tens of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions in the last two years and spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on lobbying. They hired three of Trenton's most powerful lobbying firms to sway legislators.
Rent-to-own dealers also set off a split in the state's National Association for the Advancement of Colored People by hiring its former public affairs director to lobby for the bill.
After a squabble among civil rights leaders and heated debates between members of the Black and Latino Caucus, opponents of the bill managed today to prevent the measure from coming up for a vote. But supporters of the bill say they may mount one last charge to push the measure through both the Assembly and the State Senate on the day of the final voting session, so the battle may not be over.
Industry officials say the New Jersey proposal, which is similar to New York State's law, is actually a consumer protection measure because it would mandate that rent-to-own dealers disclose the total cost of an item on every price tag. The bill would allow customers to use their rent-to-own records as a credit reference, but would forbid the companies to file negative credit reports against those who failed to pay.
But consumer advocates oppose the bill because it would shield rent-to-own dealers from lawsuits by making it legal for them to charge up to 200 percent of the retail price of a piece of furniture before customers would gain ownership. In the past three years, the industry has lost or settled several costly class-action suits charging violations of the state's consumer fraud laws, and in one case a Passaic County judge criticized the shops for charging "unconscionably" high rates.
Consumer groups have asked to limit the purchase price on rent-to-own items to 130 percent. Advocacy groups say that in poor neighborhoods, where many residents do not have the financial wherewithal to get credit cards, there is little choice but to patronize rent-to-own shops. Curtis Fisher, executive director of New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, said his organization's survey found that rent-to-own businesses charged annual interest rates of 125 percent for a 14-cubic-foot refrigerator, and as high as 200 percent.
"The practice of charging too much for a piece of merchandise isn't capitalism," said Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg, a Bergen County Democrat. "It's loan sharking."
In the past, those arguments helped opponents of rent-to-own legislation prevail over their better-financed, better-organized foes. But during this legislative session, which began in January 1998, rent-to-own businesses have given more than $40,000 to political candidates from both parties, state records show.
The industry also spent more than $80,000 on lobbying firms in 1997 and $220,000 in 1998, a study by the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group shows.
The most controversial move in the industry's campaign was the decision to hire Walter Fields, the former N.A.A.C.P. political action director. He helped win the endorsement of the Black Ministers' Council of New Jersey and its director, the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, New Jersey's most prominent civil rights leader.
Late last week, Mr. Fields also used his influence within the State N.A.A.C.P. to persuade the group's newly elected director to issue a letter dropping the group's longstanding opposition to the bill. But at the group's quarterly meeting last weekend, N.A.A.C.P. members overruled their director and voted to renew their opposition to the bill. Some members also criticized Mr. Fields for working for an industry that is mistrusted in many black neighborhoods. "It's unfortunate that people have to racialize this," said Mr. Fields, who is black. "And it's just wrong for people to think that every black person should have a preprogrammed position on this issue."
By today, the N.A.A.C.P.'s actions persuaded Craig Stanley, one of the Democratic co-sponsors, to withdraw his support for the bill unless certain amendments were added. Assemblyman Joseph Charles, director of the Black and Latino Caucus, said that a heated discussion among his members also swayed two Democrats who had briefly considered supporting the bill.
Republican sponsors of the bill, who needed three Democratic votes, suddenly found they had none, and were forced to withdraw it. But Dale Florio, an industry lobbyist, said the fight had not ended. "Until the session ends, there's always a possibility," he said. "So if you're asking if we've given up, the answer is no."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Path to Untold Riches Branches Off Wall Street
For the first time since Wall Street became the surest professional path to riches during the frenzied 1980's, those with the biggest paydays are not investment bankers but former investment bankers. 
 One-time masters of the universe say banking has become prosaic, with the heavy demands no longer producing unrivaled rewards. Many are leaving to join online start-ups, technology companies and venture capital firms -- the pillars of the new economy. Page A1.
 
Computer Consultant to Buy USWeb
Whittman-Hart, a computer consulting company, said that it had agreed to acquire USWeb/CKS, a company specializing in Internet design and marketing strategy, in a stock swap valued at about $5.87 billion. The two companies said they would create the largest Internet professional-services concern in the world. But Wall Street reacted negatively to the deal, sending the stock of both companies plummeting. Shares of Whittman-Hart closed at $54.50, down $24.5625, or 31 percent. Shares in USWeb also fell, closing at $43.8125, down $7.0625, or 13.9 percent. C2.
 
Nasdaq Sets 7th Record This Month
Technology stocks continued to power ahead, pulling the Nasdaq composite index to its seventh record this month. The Nasdaq composite climbed 37.93 points, or just more than 1 percent, to 3,658.17. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 32.11 points, or 0.3 percent, to 11,192.59, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also slipped, but by a more modest 1.82 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,415.22. C13.
 
Bond prices fell on expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates early next year. The yield of the 30-year issue rose to 6.20 percent from 6.16 percent. C13.
 
Despite Warning, Xerox Shares Rise
Despite Xerox's announcement on Friday that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations and subsequent downgrades by analysts, neither Xerox nor investors were acting as though the company was in serious trouble. Shares rose $1.0625, to $21.125. C2.
 
G.M. May Help Pay Nazi Victims
The German subsidiary of General Motors said that it would probably contribute to a fund to compensate forced laborers during the Nazi era, a move that could make the carmaker the first American company to accept responsibility for those abuses. A3.
 
NTL Continues Cable Buying Spree
NTL, a six-year-old telecommunications company based in New York that operates mainly in Britain, expanded its foothold on the Continent with a $3.7 billion agreement to buy Cablecom Group, Switzerland's leading cable television operator. NTL's chief executive, Barclay Knapp, has pursued a strategy that combines bundling telephone service, cable television and Internet access into a single service much as AT&T has sought to do. C4.
 
ING Withdraws French Bank Bid
Shares in Credit Commercial de France surged 5 percent after ING Groep, the biggest Dutch financial services group, first made and then withdrew a $10 billion takeover bid. Analysts said they expected ING to continue to pursue the bank. C4.
 
Hundreds Protest Altered Food
As the Food and Drug Administration held the last of its three public hearings on bio-engineered food, hundreds of protesters staged what organizers said was the largest rally ever in the United States against the use of genetic engineering in food. A25.

HEADLINE: Security Council Backs Off Again on Vote on Inspections for Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Security Council backed away today from a vote that had been planned on a new arms-inspection system for Iraq. Diplomats said foreign ministers of the five permanent council members were continuing to confer by telephone in hope of broadening support for the resolution.
The vote to create a new disarmament commission for Iraq and a new program for the Iraqis to follow that would lead to a suspension of nine years of sanctions had been tentatively planned for Friday, then Saturday and then today. Action is now possible on Tuesday. But that is also not certain. 
 Diplomats seemed in the dark about exactly what was being discussed at a higher level, because it was fairly clear that of the five veto-bearing permanent members of the 15-member council, Britain and the United States would vote for the measure and that Russia and China were widely thought likely to abstain. Some diplomats said the delay was intended to give more time to efforts to persuade Russia to vote yes.
France, which appeared last week ready to support the resolution, seems to be moving toward abstention, diplomats said.
Iraq has put pressure on Russia and France, traditional business partners, to stop the move toward new inspections, and France's hesitation may reflect its desire not to leave itself exposed in Iraq by breaking ranks with Russia. The French have talked the most in recent weeks about holding out for the broadest consensus. Its representative here, Alain Dejammet, said France had proposed changes in the resolution to help the Russians support it.
The Iraqis argue that they have met all the requirements for a lifting of economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations after the invasion of Kuwait in 1990 and would agree to international monitoring only after the embargo had vanished. The resolution before the council would lift the limit on Iraqi oil sales immediately and make import procedures easier. But it would also keep controls on how Iraq spends its money until it had met certain requirements to be framed by a new inspection team.
Russia says that this is too vague a goal line for Iraq and would like to have tasks spelled out in advance. Under a resolution after the gulf war in 1991, Iraq was required to destroy all its weapons of mass destruction and the means to make new ones. Much of its arsenal was eliminated. But questions remain about biological weapons, which Iraq at first denied having, and nuclear programs, which inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency found to be more advanced than they had expected. Fears that both those programs have continued run high among disarmament experts.
Today, there were reports that Iraqi was refusing to issue visas for inspectors from the atomic energy agency to make a routine visit, required by agreements on nuclear nonproliferation that predate the gulf war.
Some Arab diplomats, watching the yearlong effort to try to replace an inspection system that ended with British and American air strikes against Iraq last December, question whether the United States really wants effective monitoring in Iraq, which would make independent American military action more complicated, or whether Washington is backing the new plan in the full knowledge that Iraq would block it, providing a pretext for additional bombings.
Iraqi rejection of the plan would allow sanctions against Iraq to remain indefinitely or until Arab nations and more distant friends of Iraq are prepared to begin breaking the embargo. The Clinton administration appears willing to gamble that the embargo will hold, at least in the near future, while it pursues its plan to strengthen an Iraqi exile opposition in the hope of toppling President Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: The Union Faction That Keeps Talking Strike

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
Like many such rabble-rousing efforts, it began as a newsletter, in this case named "Hell on Wheels." Fifteen years ago its leaders waged what they now unabashedly call "propaganda campaigns" to topple their union leadership. For years, slowly and methodically, they stoked the discontent of the city's 33,000 transit workers over wages, benefits and other contract provisions, like the use of welfare recipients to do work done by union members.
That dissident band of transit workers, now called the New Directions Caucus, is wielding unusual influence over contract talks, pressing the union leadership to strike rather than accept an unsatisfactory contract. Indeed, if they have long been a thorn on the side of Willie James, the president of Local 100 of the Transit Workers Union, they have lately emerged as the force that could add bite to Mr. James's bark. 
 Yesterday, the quiet-spoken leader of the caucus, Tim Schermerhorn, 44, told reporters that union members ought to vote to strike at a membership meeting today if the contract package is not substantially better than management's last public offer. He said that he had not seen the latest details of the talks, but that at a time of economic boom in the city, a satisfactory package would have to include wage increases significantly above the cost of living, and a reversal of management's new disciplinary system and the policy allowing welfare recipients to take union jobs. The dissidents have 22 of the 46 votes on the union's executive board, which must authorize any strike by a simple majority vote; that voting bloc, along with some swing votes, could make or break any deal.
"If we don't get a contract that is just, if we don't get a contract that represents some advancement for members of the union, we should walk," Mr. Schermerhorn said at a news conference yesterday outside the Grand Hyatt Hotel, where negotiations continued between officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the union. "If we can't win a good contract now, we won't win ever. The economy is a primary consideration."
How many members they can persuade to vote to strike remains unclear. But the caucus does seem to have considerable support. These days, New Directions slogans can be frequently seen on transit workers' lapel pins and scrawled on the sides of subway tunnels. The mayor has even singled out New Directions in his most caustic remarks against union agitators. In the last elections, Mr. Schermerhorn, a subway motorman, narrowly lost to Mr. James.
Clearly, this is New Directions' moment, partly because this contract dispute could shift the balance of power within Local 100. Also at stake is the tenor of union-management relations for years to come. It would serve the transportation authority well to make an attractive contract offer to Mr. James. Otherwise, during the next round of talks, the authority could face far more militant union representatives, led by the New Directions crew, on the other side of the bargaining table.
Today, New Directions leaders stand to gain or lose considerably. If Mr. James delivers a promising contract package at the membership meeting today at the Manhattan Center, New Directions leaders can claim credit for holding his feet to the fire. If he does not, they can argue that he sold them out.
By contrast, if they force the union into an unsuccessful strike, Mr. Schermerhorn is likely to share the blame along with Mr. James.
"On the one hand, they've positioned themselves as militant advocates of a very good contract," observed Joshua Freeman, a history professor at Queens College. On the other hand, he said, they're not leading the negotiations. "They have responsibility without authority, and that's a pretty tough position to be in."
For his part, Mr. James has described Mr. Schermerhorn as "a publicity seeker" bent on torpedoing any progress made in contract talks.
Nor did Mr. Schermerhorn have many words of praise for Mr. James.
"Willie is coming off to the public as militant," he said with a laugh yesterday. "The ranks of Local 100 don't see him that way. They see him as a union official under pressure, and we have to keep the pressure on."
The transit workers union has had a radical thread throughout its history. And it is that legacy, particularly the militancy of the union under its longtime president and founder, Michael Quill, that Mr. Schermerhorn and the New Directions cadre are trying to invoke. "The real powers that be in the city -- business -- is planning an orgy of profit-making," he said, referring to holiday shopping and the tourism season. "They're not going to rake it in if the trains aren't running."
Mr. Schermerhorn was 9 when his father, a car maintainer, took him to the 1966 union meeting at which his father voted to strike. "The thing I was impressed with most was the power of these meetings, how the strength and self-confidence of people would infect each other," he recalled in an interview yesterday.
In his last 17 years on the job, Mr. Schermerhorn said, that strength and self-confidence are what he has sought to engender in his co-workers through New Directions.
"Whatever we get is because a strike threat was made real," Mr. Schermerhorn argued.
So will there be a strike starting tomorrow?
"I think the strike is possible, but not likely," he said, "because I think our union officials will do everything possible to prevent one."

HEADLINE: Mayan Carving to Be Returned to Guatemala

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
A 2,000-year-old Mayan stone carving that police detectives discovered in a Brooklyn garage last month will soon be shipped back to Guatemala, where it is believed to have been plundered from a ruin, the Guatemalan consul general in New York said yesterday.
The consul, Fabiola Fuentes, said that the authorities in her country consider the carving -- a 500-pound oblong stone depicting a jaguar clutching a man -- to be priceless. Ms. Fuentes said she expected the carving to be shipped in the coming weeks to the National Museum of Anthropology and History in Guatemala City, where specialists will try to determine from which ruins the object was looted. 
 The carving, which may date back as far as 150 B.C., was found on Nov. 12 packed in a crate in a garage on Pitkin Avenue in East New York after the police received an anonymous tip. Detective Ruben Santiago of the Major Case Squad said that investigators determined that the landlord and tenants of the house knew nothing about the carving, and that no arrests were made. Detective Santiago said the theft might have been committed by a ring trafficking in stolen artifacts. "There is a problem with things being smuggled," he said. "This is not the only piece."
Ms. Fuentes said that after detectives notified her about the discovery, she sent photographs of the carving to the Ministry of Cultural Affairs in Guatemala. Although archaeologists there could not determine the artifact's precise origin, Ms. Fuentes said, they said features on the stone were very similar to other Mayan carvings found in the Guatemalan highlands.
"It is very clear that the piece is from Guatemala," Ms. Fuentes said. "They have experts, and they determined that the piece comes from Guatemala. They know with precision the characteristics of the monuments of Guatemala."
Experts familiar with Mayan artifacts say the theft was no surprise. Despite international treaties barring the export of ancient artifacts, the sale of stolen carvings and pottery from countries in Central America where the Mayans flourished has been a problem for more than 30 years.
"Most of the valuable ones have been carved up and taken away already," said Ian Graham, an archaeologist at the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology at Harvard University. In August, Mr. Graham alerted the authorities that a 1,000-year-old artifact being offered for sale by an American collector had been stolen from Guatemala years before.
For the Guatemalan authorities, putting a stop to the looting is difficult in large part because many of the richest sites are heavily forested and hard to patrol. Ms. Fuentes also said that Guatemalan officials believed the thieves worked for powerful criminal rings, possibly tied to drug smugglers.
"It's hard to establish how much we lose because there are so many small pieces taken, instruments and pottery and even monuments, like the big one that we lost," Ms. Fuentes said. "It's hard to imagine, but these people have so much logistical and economic power in order to move these pieces from the country."

LENGTH: 2094 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: Where Next, Bronx Bombers?;
Steinbrenner Keeps Saying He May Leave. He Hasn't. The Clock Ticks.

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
For the last five years, George Steinbrenner has repeatedly promised that he will soon announce where he wants the Yankees to play when the lease at Yankee Stadium runs out in 2002.
Sometimes he has said he will disclose his choice by opening day, and sometimes he has said an announcement will come at season's end. In 1997, he said he would decide whether to stay in the Bronx or to move to Manhattan or New Jersey after that year's mayoral election. The following year, he said a decision would come after the race for governor. 
But as Steinbrenner weighs his options, much of the rest of New York has come to the conclusion that he is really down to only two: staying in the Bronx in a renovated Yankee Stadium or in a new ballpark.
"The rationale for leaving the Bronx has been eliminated," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "Now the question is, how do you stay in the Bronx and keep George happy?"
The possibility of building a new ballpark for the team on Manhattan's West Side has all but evaporated, as has the chance, at least for now, of shifting the team to New Jersey, many politicians, urban scholars and New York City and State officials say.
Steinbrenner, who is 69 years old, has spent much of the decade publicly bemoaning what he says are the high rate of crime in the Bronx, inadequate parking and nightmarish traffic around Yankee Stadium, and the failure of Yankee fans to turn out in sufficient numbers for home games.
But more than 3.2 million people attended games at Yankee Stadium last season, a record for the team that has won more world championships than any other. And Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls the site on the West Side that has long been considered a potential future home for the Yankees, has said unequivocally that he wants the team to remain in the Bronx.
Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development arm, said the season attendance figures may prove decisive for Steinbrenner. "George saw the fans come out in large numbers, and all indications are that he will stay in the Bronx," he said.
Vincent Tese offered his long-term perspective, predicting that the Yankees will move to Macombs Dam Park, the city park beside Yankee Stadium, where a new ballpark might rise. Tese was chairman of the state development corporation in 1993 when Mario M. Cuomo, then the governor, first suggested the West Side to Steinbrenner. "He's tried to get into Manhattan for years," Tese said, "but that's out."
Not even Steinbrenner's most ardent ally -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- talks any longer about what had once been a pet idea: building a $1 billion enclosed stadium for the Yankees above a railroad yard on the West Side, between 30th and 33rd Streets and 10th and 12th Avenues.
Without publicly acknowledging that the Manhattan alternative was dead, the mayor demonstrated his own sense of how far the political pendulum had swung when he proposed last January to use the site for a new football stadium to lure the Jets back from New Jersey. He never mentioned any baseball use of the site when he made the surprise football proposal in his annual State of the City address.
Any lingering doubts about the mayor's intentions were erased during the early morning of Oct. 28, when he stood with Steinbrenner in the Yankees' clubhouse at the Stadium, basking in the glow of their 25th World Series victory.
"This place becomes even more hallowed ground," said the mayor, a lifelong Yankee fan. "You think about all the baseball history made in this place. It means this location becomes even more important."
Asked whether that meant the Yankees would stay put, Giuliani said, "I think they will."
 
A Bird in Hand Takes Wing
In recent months, Steinbrenner's spokesman had said the Yankees' future would be decided once the team's merger with the Nets was completed. That occurred two weeks ago. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, declined requests for an interview, but through the spokesman he insisted that all options remained open.
The new stadium saga has spanned 12 years, time enough for Steinbrenner to hire seven managers, return from a banishment from baseball, nearly sell 70 percent of the team to Cablevision, beg the forgiveness of Yogi Berra for firing him as his manager in 1985, play postgame traffic cop to investigate jam-ups near the stadium, resuscitate Darryl Strawberry's career and win three World Series in four years.
Late in 1987, Steinbrenner and the Koch Administration announced a lease deal that would have kept the team in Yankee Stadium, which the city owns, until 2032, in return for new parking garages, luxury boxes, a Metro North station and other improvements. Nearly a year later, the agreement fell apart.
"We talked to him several times and he was ready to make a deal," said Robert Esnard, a deputy mayor under Edward I. Koch. "Then he didn't want to. He's a tough businessman."
The task of satisfying Steinbrenner and keeping the Yankees shifted from Koch to Mayor David N. Dinkins to Giuliani, upon his election in 1993, and Giuliani embraced the rail yard idea shortly after a consultant's study in 1996.
If Giuliani and Steinbrenner had hoped to make an effective case to build a revenue-rich Yankee ballpark on the West Side, that time is probably past, said several former and current city and state officials.
It was quickly branded a billion-dollar white elephant. Critics argued that a Midtown stadium would produce traffic gridlock, pollute the air and create insurmountable parking problems.
The idea was embraced and deemed easy to finance by Giuliani, even before he had fully consulted with city and state officials -- or even with Steinbrenner himself. The mayor, who said his personal preference was for the Yankees to remain in the Bronx, promoted the West Side as a way of keeping Steinbrenner from taking the team out of New York City altogether.
While the notion of a Yankee Stadium in Manhattan originated with Gov. Cuomo, his successor, Pataki, wants the Yankees to stay in the Bronx; the governor controls the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the rail yards.
The stadium issue turned into a political minefield last year when the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who was running for governor, tried to place a referendum on the November ballot that would have kept the city from spending money for a new stadium anywhere but in the Bronx. Aware that polls showed Vallone's referendum would be approved overwhelmingly, the mayor blocked Vallone by placing minor revisions to the City Charter on the ballot, knocking off the stadium referendum.
Steinbrenner stepped into the fray. "If you single me out," Steinbrenner warned Vallone, "you sure as hell are going to lose me."
Many elected officials say now that Steinbrenner and the mayor failed to build broad public support for the West Side plan. "I told Steinbrenner that the West Side had no chance if it's discussed in a political context," said Cuomo, who bemoans the idea's fate. "We should have spent a year developing answers to every legitimate question, then go to the public and discuss it issue by issue."
Vallone is obviously delighted with the outcome. "The cockamamie idea to go to Manhattan is dead," he said.
It is by no means clear when or how the Yankees' long-range plans will be resolved. Steinbrenner rarely talks in public about his intentions, and even the mayor is not saying much these days. Giuliani's spokeswoman declined several requests to answer questions about the stadium.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey has pledged neither to raid New York for the Yankees nor to spend tax dollars to build a new baseball stadium.
In turn, Steinbrenner does not seem very interested in New Jersey. A year ago, Whitman said she would submit a stadium plan if an advisory panel created by Steinbrenner asked for one. No request was ever made, said Pete McDonough, a spokesman for Whitman.
The Yankees recently merged with the New Jersey Nets, and Steinbrenner's new partners, who include Raymond Chambers and Lewis Katz, are planning to build a new basketball arena in Newark with state support. It is hard to measure what influence, if any, the Nets' owners will have on the stadium decision. They have deep roots in New Jersey, but they are also committed to helping inner cities, so they might frown upon the Yankees' leaving the Bronx.
Howard Rubenstein, Steinbrenner's spokesman, insists that all options are still being weighed and says Steinbrenner is also awaiting a $3 million city-financed study on the Bronx and Manhattan sites. "We're still looking at the West Side," Rubenstein said. "It has many pluses."
 
Politics and Timing All in the Calculus
Many city and state officials suspect that Steinbrenner intends to wait everyone out to obtain the best possible deal for his team. But the risk for Steinbrenner is that he might miss his moment; some current and former government officials think he already has.
Right now, Steinbrenner is more focused on negotiating a new cable television deal for the Yankees, which would succeed a $486 million contract with the MSG Network that spans 12 years and expires after next season, according to a business associate. "He's been saying, 'This TV thing has to get done,' " the associate said.
Steinbrenner could further delay choosing his stadium site -- and perhaps try to build support for the West Side -- by exercising the first of two five-year options to extend his current Yankee Stadium lease, from 2003 to 2007.
"That's what I expect to happen," Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said. "It doesn't achieve anything in the long term, and everyone knows it would be a dive. It just buys time for the Yankees and the city."
But time may not be on Steinbrenner's side. He might have only one more year to conclude a long-term deal with Giuliani, a cheerleader who often wears the familiar blue Yankee cap and jacket. Giuliani is expected to run for the United States Senate, and if victorious he would leave as mayor in January 2001.
"The mayor's decision to seek higher office means the stadium is no longer on the front burner," said Moss of N.Y.U. "His term is expiring before the Yankees' lease. The options have been taken from the Yankees."
Completing an expensive deal during a Senate race to keep the Yankees in the Bronx could carry political risks for Giuliani, political analysts said. But there might be some political advantage, too, because of the large Hispanic population in the Bronx, said Norman Adler, a political consultant.
If Steinbrenner defers his decision beyond the Senate election, he may lose his best chance at getting the largest possible subsidy from the city. The next mayor is very likely to be a Democrat; the field includes Ferrer, Public Advocate Mark Green and City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, among others. The successor to Giuliani, a Republican, is unlikely to be as generous with the Yankees.
"If he makes a deal with Giuliani, it will be for more than with the next mayor," former Mayor Koch said.
And there is a third risk to Steinbrenner's biding his time: the city's economy cannot stay robust forever, and a recession could turn munificent public financing for a stadium into an unaffordable luxury.
Steinbrenner's delays have slowed the Mets' plans to build a new ballpark next to Shea Stadium. The team unveiled a design for a $500 million stadium in April 1998.
But the Mets' deal has not advanced very far. "Nothing has prevented Rudy from making a deal with the Mets first," said City Councilman Walter McCaffrey, a Queens Democrat. "It might have given the city leverage with George Steinbrenner."
Fred Wilpon, co-owner of the Mets, said there had been talks with the city about financing his stadium. "But I can't answer why a deal hasn't been done," he said.
Of course, making a deal with the Yankees means offering one. According to people inside and outside government who have watched the Giuliani-Steinbrenner dance, the mayor would make an offer if only he knew what Steinbrenner really wanted.
Even Steinbrenner's friends are unsure why he has not decided. Some speculate that he has been hesitating because he does not want to be remembered as the traitor who took the Yankees out of the Bronx; others assume that by not deciding, he somehow keeps his options open.
"Once, I thought he knew what he wanted," said a friend. "Now I don't."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Official Foresees Less Debt Reliance

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Japanese finance minister said today that he expected the government to begin trying to gradually wean the country's shaky economy away from its reliance on public borrowing, a practice that has made Japan one of the biggest debtor nations.
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's comments, made in an interview here, suggested that the government was keenly aware that its relentless borrowing was increasingly calling into question its fiscal responsibility, a criticism that Japan had made of the United States in years past. 
 Mr. Miyazawa is one of the nation's most powerful and best-known politicians, and his comments about government spending came against the backdrop of mild economic improvement in Japan after its worst recession since the end of World War II. The remarks may be a sign that the government is beginning to have faith that the economy's long-term prospects are improving.
Until now, officials have been wary of publicly describing the signs of life in the economy over the last year as a recovery. They have also given little indication when Japan would stop borrowing heavily to inject money into the economy, much of it to build public works projects ranging from extra tunnels and airport runways to a new Tokyo subway. Such spending has increasingly been criticized as extravagant, wasteful and unlikely to keep the economy going once the money runs out.
Mr. Miyazawa said that he had discussed the matter of a gradual, measured return to fiscal restraint with Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi on the phone this morning, and that the prime minister seemed eager to find a way to reassure the public that he was concerned about Japan's increasing indebtedness and would work to correct it as the economy regains momentum.
"Mr. Obuchi wondered how could he say it without giving up the appearance of the fight against recession," Mr. Miyazawa said. "There is some anxiety about that."
How widespread the prime minister's concerns are among the political elite here is unclear. Shizuka Kamei, chief policy official of the governing Liberal Democratic Party and leader of one of its largest factions, is an outspoken advocate of government spending to prop up the economy. Moreover, few politicians are likely to endorse any meaningful reduction in public spending before Parliament elections, which must be called by September.
Nonetheless, the Japanese deficit, already the highest in the industrial world, is expected to reach 10.7 percent of the gross domestic product by the end of this fiscal year, on March 31, 2000. The United States, by contrast, is running a surplus estimated at 1.9 percent of its gross domestic product, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based group of rich nations.
The reversal of fortunes between the two countries is embarrassing for Japan, which criticized the United States several times in the 1980's over its budget deficit.
Mr. Miyazawa's remarks came as business executives here indicated somewhat more conviction about a recovery. A widely watched business survey by the Bank of Japan, released today, showed that corporate sentiment improved in the third quarter to its best level in two years. Still, the survey -- known as the tankan -- contained some mixed signals, notably evidence that large businesses were cutting capital spending even more than they had predicted in the second quarter. Such cutbacks reflect corporate caution about the strength of the recovery.
In a separate report suggesting that the recovery remained tenuous, the finance ministry said Japan's trade surplus fell for the ninth consecutive month, largely because of the strength of the yen. This has made Japan's products more expensive abroad, hurting the profits of major exporters ranging from Sony and Honda to Kikkoman, the world's largest producer of soy sauce.
Parliament recently approved the government's ninth expensive attempt to prod the recalcitrant economy into action -- a package of public spending, loan guarantees, tax breaks and other measures worth $171 billion if local government spending and lending are included.
That, coupled with the news that for the first time since World War II, the government will have to finance more than half of its budget through bond issues, has raised public sensitivity to the country's increasing fiscal imbalance, which has swelled total public debt to more than $5.4 trillion.
Magazines and talk shows here have been debating the value of all the spending, as well.
Mr. Miyazawa said he thought that tax receipts would start to rise, perhaps as soon as next year, after declining in five of the last six years.
"Tax revenues in the next fiscal year may go up," he said, "reflecting some improvement in the business situation as a result of the restructuring that many companies have undertaken."
The ministry's tax bureau is substantially less optimistic, though. The government's efforts to overhaul the tax system will in the short term actually reduce what it takes in.
And even though the economy has improved, corporations and individuals show little sign of increased financial well-being. Last fiscal year, corporate Japan collectively lost money for the first time since the government began gathering data on companies' performance in 1960, according to data compiled by Mikuni & Company, the country's only independent credit-rating agency.
And Mr. Miyazawa himself, one of the few voices of fiscal restraint in the top echelons of government, noted today that consumer sentiment remained uneasy. "In some ways," he said, "the anxiety is more intense now than it was at the bottom."

HEADLINE: AutoNation To Close Stores And Cut Jobs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In an admission of serious difficulties, AutoNation Inc. announced today that it was closing most of its used car superstores immediately and laying off their 1,800 employees, while taking a one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $430 million to $490 million.
AutoNation, which has grown in just three years from a garbage disposal company to the nation's largest seller of new and used cars, also said that it would suspend further purchases of new car dealerships and concentrate instead on reducing costs at existing dealerships. 
 The company, which had hired some of the brightest consultants in the auto industry at premium salaries, has begun eliminating 225 of the 600 jobs at its corporate headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and plans to cut pay and advertising at poorly performing dealerships, said Michael J. Jackson, AutoNation's chief executive.
Because of high corporate overhead and losses at the used car superstores, AutoNation's fourth-quarter earnings will also fall considerably short of analysts' expectations, he said. In a bid to mollify Wall Street and auto dealers who sold their family businesses to the company for stock, AutoNation also announced tonight that it would buy back another $500 million of stock, in addition to the $1.2 billion worth of shares that it had already repurchased.
The company made its announcements after the close of the stock market. In after-hours trading, AutoNation's stock fell to $8.50. It had fallen 93.75 cents, to $9 at the close of regular trading. The stock had already lost more than three-quarters of its value since a peak two years ago.
Today's events were the latest in a series of setbacks at AutoNation for H. Wayne Huizenga, the company's chairman. Mr. Huizenga made his reputation by consolidating the garbage hauling and video rental industries, creating two corporate giants, Waste Management and Blockbuster. But auto retailing has proved much more difficult.
AutoNation entered the auto business by setting up used car superstores on a far grander and more lavish scale than anything the industry had ever seen. The parking lots had 1,000 or more used cars. The showrooms had computer kiosks with information on every car in the lot. The prices were prominently placed on every car, with no negotiations allowed. And there were dozens of young, college-educated sales people who worked for salaries, instead of the commissions that had long given used car salesmen an incentive for aggressive sales techniques.
But rival used car sales businesses responded by undercutting AutoNation's fixed prices. One morning two years ago, shortly after AutoNation's used car superstore in Coconut Grove, Fla., had opened for business, a well-dressed woman stood at a kiosk and furiously scribbled down prices. Asked what she was doing, she replied that she was going to take the prices to another dealership to get a better deal.
Mr. Jackson, who joined AutoNation in October after running the North American operations of Mercedes-Benz, said that the used car superstores were high-cost operations with no chance of ever generating profits proportionate to their risk. Even if AutoNation had been willing to invest heavily, devote a lot of management time and wait for years, he said, "the cost structure in those stores would still have been very high, leading to marginal operations."
AutoNation has 37 used car superstores now, but 8 of them have already become the used car portions of its new car dealerships. The company now plans to combine six more with new car dealerships and close the remaining used car superstores on Tuesday.
AutoNation's annual sales are now close to $20 billion, and the closing of the superstores will only pare that by $1 billion, Mr. Jackson said. AutoNation had previously announced that it would combine its three car rental companies -- Alamo Rent-A-Car Inc., National Car Rental System Inc. and CarTemps USA -- and spin them off as a separate company, the Auto Rental Corporation. AutoNation said today that the spinoff would be completed in January.
But the core of AutoNation's business remains: 409 new car dealerships in 19 states. They make AutoNation several times the size of any other chain of dealerships in the country. Mr. Jackson said that these operations remained strong, but that their profitability had been eroded by high costs from the company's corporate bureaucracy.
Administrative costs from levels of management above the store level were running at an annual rate of $240 million by this autumn, up 71 percent from a year earlier, Mr. Jackson said. Those costs will only be $140 million next year, he said, adding that he expected that the company's dealerships would be able to save another $30 million next year by not having to deal with so many officials and initiatives from the corporation's headquarters.
While AutoNation's new car dealerships have benefited from the industry's soaring sales this year, the used car superstores suffered from the rebates and other incentives that automakers have used this year to push sales. AutoNation specializes in late-model used cars in good condition, but the customers for such cars tend to be people who can also afford new cars.
As the price of new cars has leveled off -- and fallen sharply after allowing for inflation and improvements in car features and reliability -- prices for late-model used cars have begun falling. That hurt the used car superstores, which faced a choice of cutting prices or letting cars sit unsold.
"This was the wrong time and place to be trying to survive on late-model cars," said Chris Denove, the director of consulting services at J. D. Power and Associates.

HEADLINE: The Art of Giving, in Good Times

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Dec. 12 front-page article "Charity for Poor Lags Behind Need" might lead one to believe that as Americans have gotten wealthier they have gotten stingier. 
 But there is an explanation for reports by several large charities that donations have decreased, despite economic prosperity.
Americans are moving away from giving to traditional corporate-like charities toward giving in more personal ways to local, innovative and grass-roots charitable efforts. This kind of giving has several advantages. Giving to a charity that is more like a well-run small business than a large conglomerate makes it easier for the giver to know where the money is going. Moreover, giving to a grass-roots charity means that donors can come to know the people who run the charity and the effect the charity has on those it serves.
 
GABRIELLE KURLANDER
New York, Dec. 13, 1999
 
The writer is president of All Stars Project, a nonprofit group that produces theater in poor communities.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Wall St. Is Flush With Cash But Also Green With Envy

BYLINE: This article was reported by Joseph Kahn, Laura M. Holson and Patrick McGeehan and was written by Mr. Kahn. 

 BODY:
Even by the inflated standards of high finance, Wall Street is overflowing with holiday cheer this year. Investment banks have set aside $13 billion to pay bonuses, 20 percent more than last year, with pay packages above $10 million no longer a rarity.
Yet among Wall Streeters the mood has changed. One industry veteran bemoaned the "opportunity cost" of remaining a financier in the Internet age. Others are leaving to join online start-ups, technology companies and venture capital firms, the pillars of the new economy, where they sometimes take home more than their old bosses from Day 1 -- and, they say, have more fun. 
 For the first time since Wall Street became the surest professional path to riches during the frenzied 1980's, those with the biggest paydays are former investment bankers.
Like Timothy Weller. He is the talk of the Street, but mostly because he no longer works there. Last summer, Mr. Weller, 34, left Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, where he was a middle-ranking analyst tracking the telecommunications business, to join Akamai Technologies, which provides networking services for the Internet.
Akamai, based in Cambridge, Mass., enticed him to sign on as chief financial officer by selling him 1.05 million shares, valued then at $2.63 million, and even lent him the money to buy them. Gratification was quick: when Akamai went public in October, its stock soared from $26 to $230. Mr. Weller's stake is now worth $240 million.
But that could change if the share price falls. And companies often place restrictions on when shares can be cashed in.
Few bankers will reap such gains, but many are still taking their chances on the Internet. One-time masters of the universe say banking has become prosaic, with the heavy demands no longer producing unrivaled rewards. Bankers now ogle online entrepreneurs the way lawyers and accountants once envied Wall Streeters.
"It used to be that investment bankers were at the cutting edge," said Mark Long, who as a banker for Credit Suisse First Boston helped some of America's hottest Internet companies go public. "Today, bankers are just hired guns."
During a trip last summer to promote the Internet start-up Intraware to potential investors, Mr. Long, 32, accepted his client's offer to become a vice president, joining shortly before it went public.
If Intraware does well, Mr. Long stands to earn considerably more than he did as a banker, thanks to stock options. But that is only one reason he left. "You get tired of sleeping 45 minutes a night," he said, "to sell someone else's business."
With profits for financial firms and bonuses for bankers at all-time highs, there is certainly no looming crisis on Wall Street. Even those who leave banking often do so with trepidation, fearing that inflated Internet stocks could come crashing down.
The Internet's impact has been more psychological than financial. The pressure to earn Internet windfalls shows up in little ways, as with the rising stock analyst who says he has lost bidding wars for Upper East Side apartments and adds, only half in jest, that $10 million does not buy much of a condo these days.
The online lure is also enhanced by ex-bankers who have changed careers seamlessly. Jeff Bezos worked on Wall Street until he founded Amazon.com, and that trend keeps gathering steam. Mr. Bezos, now many times a billionaire, hired a number of other former bankers and made them Internet retailers. Analysts and deal makers involved in technology, telecommunications and the Internet readily change hats and become financial officers or strategic planners at start-ups, often bringing along former colleagues.
Some defectors compete directly with their old firms. At least three new online investment banks and several Internet stock and bond trading companies, all planning to use the Internet to steal business from traditional investment banks, are led by people who learned the business from the inside.
Robert Lessin, chief executive of Wit Capital, an online investment bank, and formerly a top officer at Salomon Smith Barney, has poached a long list of bankers from Salomon, Merrill Lynch and other firms.
"It's like I'm a banker but I get to wear casual clothes," said Kate Cornish, 28, who left Salomon for Wit a few months ago.
Especially susceptible are those three to five years out of business school -- on the cusp of devoting a career to a firm, but young enough to start fresh.
"They say, 'I want to be a multimillionaire by the time I'm 30, but if I stay at Morgan Stanley, it may take me until I'm 50,' " said Joseph Perella, Morgan's head of investment banking. Americans, he added, want "instant gratification."
In reaction, Morgan Stanley has started offering stock to some newly hired bankers. BancBoston Robertson Stephens, a leading technology banking firm, has lost 10 bankers to Internet clients this year. The firm recently took 300 employees to a weekend retreat to help build esprit de corps and to aid retention, though firm officials said it was not a response to this year's attrition.
Investment bank recruiters once acted like bouncers, accepting only the best. Goldman Sachs still finds plenty of eager applicants, says Peter Kiernan, a senior partner who oversees hiring from business schools, but now, he said, "if you expect to back up a truck and load the top 10 people in a class, you're going to be disappointed."
Business school graduates think entrepreneurial jobs are the wave of the future, he said. He now tries to convince people that they can be entrepreneurs within an investment bank, which can be a tough sell. "One thing you don't do is try to sell against the Net," he said.
Not long ago, Wall Street did not have to try so hard. With the rapid growth of stocks and bonds and the explosion of mergers, securities firms were seen as controlling the levers of America's economy. Investment banking, offering top dollar, consistently ranked as the No. 1 or No. 2 career choice for top business graduates.
Popular culture followed the money. "Wall Street," the movie, and "Bonfire of the Vanities," the novel, created a stereotype of shark-like bankers and traders. In the early 1990's, investment banks were seen as the engines of globalization, financing road projects in China and privatizing phone companies in Brazil. While corporate America merged and consolidated, bankers raked in record fees.
But the Internet, like an electronic black hole, has stolen all the gravity. Securities firms seem to have less to do with creating Internet companies than they did with arranging restructurings or sending capital abroad. And through the Silicon Valley looking glass, Wall Street egos can appear almost humble.
Scott McNealy, chief executive of Sun Microsystems, wrote an Op-Ed article in The New York Times last summer extolling the value that entrepreneurs create in the economy and belittling the "nonjobs" of bankers. In "The New New Thing," Michael Lewis, who a decade ago chronicled Wall Street hubris in "Liar's Poker," portrays today's financiers as desperate grovelers who shovel money at Internet entrepreneurs in hopes of profiting from their creative instincts.
Investors seem no different. They have pumped up the stocks of Internet-friendly finance companies so much that a recent survey of the wealthiest people in finance, compiled by Institutional Investor magazine, found that the richest financiers often double as Internet entrepreneurs.
Charles Schwab, the founder, chairman and chief executive of the No. 1-ranked Internet broker, has seen his Schwab stock holdings soar to almost $5.8 billion, making him the second wealthiest person in finance after Warren E. Buffett. J. Joe Ricketts, chairman and co-chief executive of Ameritrade, the No. 7 Internet broker, has stockholdings of almost $2 billion, eclipsing the combined stockholdings of the leaders of Morgan Stanley, Merrill and Goldman.
Until recently, headhunters rarely tried to lure bankers away from Wall Street. But dot-com fever has changed that. When Priceline.com decided in June to go after an investment banker to fill a senior post at a unit it expected to take public shortly, it asked Cynthia Remec, an executive recruiter, to round up candidates the same day and set up interviews the next. Ms. Remec frantically phoned 20 bankers to fill this tall order. Within hours, to her surprise, she found 15 eager to hop the train to Stamford, Conn., Priceline's headquarters, for an interview. Priceline hired one of them, Anne Maffei, a former banker at J. P. Morgan, as a senior executive at Webhouse.com, its grocery-shopping affiliate.
Bankers and analysts on the front lines of the new economy sometimes make especially easy pickings. Though the work hours of Internet entrepreneurs are legendary, many bankers say the life compares favorably with the burden of arranging public offerings and mergers.
"You feel like lead oar in 'Ben Hur,' " said Bill Burnham, a top analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston who left to join Softbank Capital, an Internet-focused venture fund. "No one works harder than a tech banker or has less control over his life."
The lure of stock options is also potent. Thomas Casey, 47, left as co-head of global telecommunications and media at Merrill Lynch to head corporate development, among other things, at Global Crossing, a new company that is building a fiber optic network for Internet traffic.
At first, the move was a roll of the dice. He left behind a hefty pay package -- $3 million to $5 million a year at his level. When he started at Global Crossing, he took a huge pay cut. But he got options on 2 million shares when the stock was valued at $2 a share. Those options are now valued at nearly $90 million.
"On Wall Street, you are not going to be so rich that your children and grandchildren would never have to work again," Mr. Casey said. "But you have that opportunity if you go to a start-up."
Mr. Casey said money was only one motivation. "Ultimately, I wanted to be in a position where I participated directly in creating something substantial," he said.
Today, some Wall Street firms are responding aggressively. Nearly all the big ones have taken stakes in online trading companies, including virtual stock-trading forums known as electronic communications networks. Most now allow clients to buy and sell securities on the Internet. Several analysts predict that Wall Street's willingness to compete online will slow the growth of purely online rivals -- and perhaps stem the outflow of seasoned bankers.
But John Hewitt, a longtime Goldman vice president who helped execute that firm's efforts to modernize its technology, still sees the biggest securities firms as being stuck in another era. He recently left Goldman to become president of Knight/Trimark, which has used technology and low fees to lure stock-trading business.
Mr. Hewitt, 48, said he long expected to retire as a Goldman employee. But the more he learned about the Internet, he said, the more it gnawed at him -- to the point that he raised his hand for the Knight/Trimark job during a business dinner with Ken Pasternak, the chief executive.
"All the Wall Street firms, Goldman included, have become so successful that they have a vested interest in the status quo," Mr. Hewitt said. "The more I thought about it, the more I felt I had to go somewhere that had a sense of speed and that wasn't afraid of the future."
