HEADLINE: Bush Tangles With McCain Over Campaign Financing

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In the most spirited Republican debate so far, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona sparred over Mr. McCain's advocacy of overhauling the nation's campaign finance laws, with Mr. Bush declining Mr. McCain's offer that the two take a joint pledge against accepting so-called soft money, largely unregulated corporate contributions.
Mr. McCain, who has emerged as the most potent challenger to Mr. Bush for the Republican presidential nomination, told Mr. Bush that special interests were controlling the federal government and that, "You and I can stop that tonight." 
 "We can commit, as nominees of the party, that we'll have nothing to do with soft money," Mr. McCain said
Mr. Bush answered that such a repudiation of soft money would amount to "unilateral disarmament" by giving an advantage to Democrats, who benefit from donations from labor unions.
Without soft money, Mr. Bush said, "Our Republican Party and conservative values don't have a chance."
The exchange underscored Mr. McCain's efforts to portray himself as an insurgent outsider and as the only candidate willing to speak often unpopular truths, an image that he further burnished tonight by denouncing federal ethanol subsidies in a state that cherishes them and challenging Mr. Bush and other candidates to defend the program.
The discussions of campaign finance laws and ethanol subsidies were just two of instances tonight in which Mr. Bush's challengers -- in particular, Mr. McCain and Gary L. Bauer -- sought to put him on the defensive or pin him down in uncomfortable ways.
Mr. Bush's lackluster performances in two forums earlier this month had come under intense scrutiny and criticism, with even some Republican officials expressing disappointment in the impression he had made. Tonight, a few of his opponents clearly smelled blood.
But Mr. Bush responded to their attacks, direct and indirect, with a more assertive demeanor and a more confident manner than he had exhibited in previous debates. He also mounted his own offensives, saying that the tax cut he has proposed provides economic relief for some low-income people and noting that Mr. McCain's plan does not.
Like Mr. McCain, Mr. Bauer tried to coax Mr. Bush into a vow: a promise that if Mr. Bush became the Republican nominee, he would choose a running mate who opposed legal abortion.
Mr. Bauer mentioned the New Jersey governor, Christine Todd Whitman, who supports abortion rights, as someone whom Mr. Bush should assure Americans would not be chosen as the vice presidential candidate.
But Mr. Bush, an easy smile on his face, essentially chided Mr. Bauer for focusing on a narrow issue, saying that the most important criteria for a vice president was that the person be able to ascend to the presidency if necessary, be loyal and share his conservative views.
At other times, the rules that were supposed to govern the debate, which took place in the Des Moines Civic Center, failed to rein in candidates who seemed more eager than ever to challenge and comment on each other's answers, producing some pungent and occasionally funny dialogue as the discussion ranged from gun control and health care to the vanishing of the family farms and America's trading relationship with China.
Mr. Bauer and Mr. Bush in particular quarreled over that last topic, with Mr. Bauer challenging Mr. Bush's support of China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Bauer said that if he became president, "I will stop allowing China to play us for suckers."
"They dump their goods here," Mr. Bauer said, "and Iowa farmers are selling less to China now than they did 10 years ago."
Mr. Bush defended his position, saying that China's place in the trade organization would help change that, because they would feel more beholden and compelled to comply with reciprocal trade laws.
"Opening up Chinese markets is good for Iowa farmers," Mr. Bush said in a defiant voice.
"They haven't kept their agreements for 20 years," Mr. Bauer shot back.
But Mr. Bush and Mr. Bauer found agreement on something else: both of them cited Jesus Christ when the candidates were asked to name their favorite philosopher-thinkers.
Mr. Bush said simply, "Christ, because he changed my heart."
John Bachman, an anchor for WHO-TV in Des Moines, the sponsor of the debate, seemed surprised by the brief response and said, "I think the viewer would like to know more on how he's changed your heart."
To that, Mr. Bush said, "Well, if they don't know, it's going to be hard to explain. When you turn your heart and your life over to Christ, when you accept Christ as the savior, it changes your heart. It changes your life. And that's what happened to me."
Moments later, Mr. Bauer offered a fuller response in which he quoted scripture. "Christ," Mr. Bauer added, "taught all of us about our obligations to each other, to the unborn child, to those living in poverty, the need for us to be together regardless of the color of our skin."
The candidates began mixing it up when Mr. McCain was asked about his push to reduce pork barrel spending, and, unprompted, brought up his opposition to federal subsidies for ethanol, a corn-based fuel.
Support for ethanol subsidies is a litmus test for candidates in Iowa, but Mr. McCain, apparently seeking to bolster his case that he is willing to oppose special interests, flatly said he would cut the program.
"I'm here to tell you the things you don't want to hear as well as the things you do, and one of them is ethanol," said Mr. McCain, who has adopted an unusual, possibly risky strategy of ignoring Iowa so that he can devote more time to other states with early contests, particularly New Hampshire, Arizona and South Carolina. Mr. McCain is making the most of his maverick image and plans a joint appearance with Bill Bradley, one of the Democratic presidential candidates, on Thursday to discuss campaign finance reform.
Mr. Bush unflinchingly explained his support for ethanol. "It's good for our air," he said. "It also reduces our dependency on foreign oil."
"Who knows?" Mr. Bush added. "Maybe someday we'll be driving automobiles with 100 percent corn product. And guess what? We can grow it right here in Iowa."
Steve Forbes, the publisher, who is hoping that a strong second-place finish to Mr. Bush in Iowa will add velocity to his candidacy, said that the federal government has to do much more research in general to find uses for agricultural products.
And Alan Keyes, often a voice of conservative moralism in these forums, rued the dwindling number of family farms not as an economic reality but as a cultural one, saying that some of the country's most enduring, bedrock values are tied to agricultural life.
Once again, the event was something of a showcase for Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a long-shot candidate who has carved a niche as the droll jester.
Mr. Hatch drew one of the most rousing responses of the evening after Mr. Forbes said of Democratic proposals, "That usually means hold your wallet."
Mr. Hatch turned to Mr. Forbes and interjected, "Steve, I couldn't even lift your wallet is all I can say."
Tonight's debate, which was moderated by Mr. Bachman and Tom Brokaw of NBC News, was the third in only 11 days to feature all six candidates for the party's nomination, and it was the first to take place in Iowa, a pivotal state whose precinct caucus on Jan. 24 is the opening contest of the primary season. The first primary, in New Hampshire, comes eight days later.
Mr. Bush appears to be on much sturdier ground in Iowa than in New Hampshire, where Mr. McCain has pulled ahead of him in recent polls.
The two previous Republican forums -- in Manchester, N.H., on Dec. 3, and in Phoenix on Dec. 6 -- were strikingly cordial affairs with the six candidates speaking to and about one another in relatively restrained, respectful terms.
But Mr. Bush's opponents, still trailing him in national polls, made subtle and sometimes indirect efforts on those occasions to chip into that lead by portraying him as someone without the requisite experience, seriousness or intellectual maturity to lead the country.
After the second of those debates, political analysts and journalists placed a microscope over everything from the downward slant of Mr. Bush's lips, which seen by some as a smirk, to his seeming adherence to a practiced script.
Tonight, he may have reassured some supporters and quieted some critics. While the corners of his mouth still turned downward at times, he seemed less cautious.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
FENTON, RICHARD LEWIS

 BODY:
FENTON-Richard Lewis. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Richard Lewis Fenton, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who love him be comforted. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary
FENTON-Richard L. United States Diplomat and Financier. Richard L. Fenton, a prominent New York real estate executive and former United States Foreign Service officer, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a short illness. He was 55 years old. After graduating with Highest Honors in Government from New York University in 1966, Mr. Fenton pursued graduate studies at the London School of Economics followed by a year at Cornell Law School. In 1968 he enrolled in the Foreign Service Institute of the United States Department of State where he completed requirements to become a Foreign Service Officer. In 1972, he became the youngest person in the history of the United States Foreign Service to receive the title of Consul. Over a 10 year Foreign Service career he held diplomatic posts in the Dominican Republic, Italy, Canada and Washington, D.C. During his Washington, D.C. posting, he founded Afco Properties, a real estate investment firm which acquired and renovated historic residential properties in Georgetown. Upon taking a leave of absence from the diplomatic service in the late 1970's, he joined his brother's commercial real estate firm, Peter R. Friedman, Ltd. He worked closely with his brother, Peter. Fluent in French, German, Italian and Spanish, Richard and partner, Harry Seherr-Thoss, developed a high profile group of international clientele. An avid sportsman, Mr. Fenton was a Lifemember of the Corviglia Ski Club in St. Moritz, Switzerland whre he was a regular competitive ski racer. He also excelled in windsurfing, mountain biking and mountain trekking. In May, as a member of the Explorers Club, Mr. Fenton completed an 18 day trek and flag expedition into the remote Upper Dolpo region of Nepal near the Tibetan border. Mr. Fenton is survived by his mother, Belle Friedman, his brother, Peter and two daughters, Alexis and Filippa. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, December 15, 10AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York. Contributions in his memory to The Weizmann Institute of Science and The Explorer's Club.
FENTON-Richard. The Board of Directors of 936 Fifth Avenue Corporation offers its condolences to the family of Richard Fenton. Mr. Fenton was a neighbor and valued member of the Board of Directors of 936 Fifth Avenue. His contribution through the years to the building's operations and success were numerous and will be missed. Board of Directors, 936 Fifth Avenue Corporation

RESNICK, PEARL

 BODY:
RESNICK-Pearl. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends, mourn the passing of one of our most beloved leaders, who played an important role in our development, Pearl Resnick. Together with her late husband, Jack, she was a longtime patron of the University. After his passing, she continued her involvement not only as a benefactress, but also as a member of both the Global Board of Trustees and the American Board of Trustees. Her interest in every program of the University's mission was tremendous. She loved the traditional dimension of the University and was especially concerned with the personal welfare of faculty and students, particularly those who had emigrated from Russia. Indeed, she established the Jack and Pearl Resnick Institute for the Absorbtion and Retraining of Russian Immigrant Scientists, and subsequently built the permanent home of the Resnick Institute. Beyond the actual programs, her warm and loving personality evoked enormous respect from all who had the privilege to know her. She was truly love incarnate. To her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren she was a loving and devoted matriarch whose love was characteristic of her person and all that she did. With this love, she inspired her family to carry on with her same spirit of matchless generosity for every worthy cause, Jewish, American and humanitarian. There can be no doubt that she will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Aharon Dahan, Chairman, Global Board of Trustees Charles Dimston, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Melvin Stein, President, American Friends of Bar-Ilan University Gen. (Ret.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University
RESNICK-Pearl. The DOROT community is stricken by the passing of Pearl Resnick, a remarkable woman whose clear-eyed, warmhearted support of major medical, communal, educational and arts organizations improved the lives of thousands. Pearl was the source of a tradition of communal involvement that has flowed like a shining stream from generation to generation in her family. As a generous DOROT supporter and sponsor of our Thanksgiving Banquet for the elderly, Pearl created an annual highlight that truly gave our elders reason to give thanks, and an experience to cherish throughout the year. Her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren carry on her tradition through their leadership as members of the DOROT Board, service on planning committees, fundraising efforts, and hands-on participation in our Package Deliveries. Pearl was the designated recipient of DOROT's Rose Sommer Generations Award, which she would have received at DOROT's Gala in May 2000 as part of a salute to the Katz-Resnick family, "Four Generations Helping Generations". We are devastated that the award will have to be presented posthumously. Our hearts go out to Pearl's children: Marilyn and Stanley, Burton and Judith, and Ira and Paula; her grandchildren: Neil and Amy, Bruce and Bonnie, Roni and Stuart, Scott, John and Susie, Peter, Daniel, Benjamin, Joshua, Jordana; her great-grandchildren: Jaclyn, David, Nicole, Brian, and Stephanie; and her extended family upon the loss of this vivacious and inspiring woman. May they find solace in their personal memories, in her legacy of tzedka and chesed which flourishes in them, and in the knowledge that her name will forever be a blessing. Vivian Fenster Ehrlich, Executive Director Anne E. Heyman, President Renee Adler Ascher, Board Chair
RESNICK-Pearl. The Yeshiva University family is profoundly grieved by the passing of a dear friend, a distinguished humanitarian, and a communal leader who was the matriarch of a family that has long played a leadership role at YU and its Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Widely beloved for her sterling character and inspiring personality, she was a YU Trustee, AECOM Overseer, and Benefactor with her late husband, Jack Resnick, a longtime AECOM Overseer. In 1989, the University conferred upon her an honorary doctor of humane letters degree, noting her "staunch dedication and tireless efforts on behalf of this University." For their endowment of a range of vital programs at AECOM, Mr. and Mrs. Resnick were honored in 1990 with the naming of the College's Jack and Pearl Resnick Campus. HEADLINE: Wages vs. Warrants

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
In the months leading up to the current contract showdown, the president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union maneuvered to turn the dispute into one focusing on economic justice for New York City's subway and bus workers.
In every speech, in every interview, the union president, Willie James, sought to win public sympathy and throw management on the defensive by talking about how his hard-working members had made major concessions in their last contract and had not shared in the city's economic boom. 
 But last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani jumped into the fray and in a mere few minutes transformed the terms of the dispute from economic justice to law and order, reminding the union that a transit strike would be illegal and would cripple the city.
Mr. Giuliani also reminded union leaders and members that he would seek maximum punishment against the union for breaking the law. With his threats, many labor experts say, the mayor has single-handedly reduced the chances of a strike by forcing Mr. James and his union's members to think twice about a walkout and its consequences.
Mr. Giuliani has transformed the dispute in another way -- it is no longer so much a fight between Mr. James and an anonymous bureaucracy, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Rather, it has become a mano a mano dispute between the mayor and Mr. James, and many labor experts say that Mr. Giuliani inevitably has the upper hand because he has on his side the state Taylor Law, which bars strikes by public employees.
But the mayor's tough stance has complicated matters by pushing Mr. James into a corner, and some labor experts said that could backfire. The union leader, who eked out a narrow election victory last year, cannot let himself be seen as knuckling under to the mayor because he would lose credibility with his members.
"The way the mayor has taken a fairly bellicose stand toward labor-management relations," said William Kornblum, a labor expert at City University Graduate Center, "can lead unions to up their demands, mobilize people and get them to prepare for a strike."
However much Mr. Giuliani and Mr. James might want to deny it, the dispute is a big political test for both of them.
A transit strike that creates havoc for millions of New Yorkers could embarrass the mayor and, at a time he is preparing for a race for United States Senate, undercut his reputation for competence even though he does not control the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency that is controlled by the governor. A calamitous strike could weaken the mayor the way the 1969 blizzard and the troubles plowing the streets badly undermined Mayor John V. Lindsay.
Some labor experts say the mayor has pressured the transit workers to scale back their wage demands on the theory that if they win hefty increases, he will be under pressure to be just as generous with the city's nearly 300,000 unionized workers who are scheduled to negotiate contracts next year.
For Mr. James, the stakes are high because if he does not deliver at the bargaining table, his members can easily vote him out in union elections scheduled for next year.
His need to show his mettle, labor experts say, helps explain why Mr. James has talked so tough and has repeatedly threatened a strike. While an illegal strike can result in victory and can make a union leader a defiant hero, it is a high-risk strategy that can result in jail, huge fines and a crushed union.
On one hand, the 12-day transit strike of 1966 turned the union's leader, Michael J. Quill, into just such a hero, even though, or perhaps because, he was sent to jail. On the other hand, the union fared far worse in the 11-day strike of 1980 because it was fined $1.25 million and its treasury was all but wiped out.
Mr. Giuliani has done his best to convince Mr. James and his union that if they strike, the results will be like those in 1980, not 1966. The mayor has implied that if they walk out on his watch, they will be walking the plank.
Even some frequent critics of the mayor, like Ester R. Fuchs, director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy, say his strategy seems to be working.
"I think the mayor is doing the only thing he knows how to do -- he is not somebody who uses honey or sugar to get what he wants," she said. "He thinks that punishment and retribution are the way to push people back in line. His hard-line strategy may work in the end because the transit workers can't afford the kind of fines the court will impose."
When Mr. Giuliani was asked his views of the transit dispute last Wednesday, he said he should not get involved because the dispute was between the union and the M.T.A. But by Friday, he had changed course and resumed his normally tough persona, perhaps recognizing that he might be blamed for a disastrous strike even though he does not control the M.T.A., although its executive directive, Marc V. Shaw, had been his budget director.
So the mayor attacked both sides for not negotiating around the clock, suggesting that they, not he, would be to blame for any strike.
Sounding like an angry Norse god, he also threatened to rain thunder and brimstone down upon the union if its members walked out. He threatened to get a court injunction, he warned the union that it could face millions of dollars in fines, and he told members they could lose two days' pay for every day on strike.
Ever since the mayor threatened to lower the boom, Mr. James has sounded more optimistic about a settlement. But he has also remained defiant toward the mayor, calling his interference counterproductive.
"I'm not scared of the Taylor Law," Mr. James said. "I'm not going to allow anything the mayor says intimidate this union or myself to accept a substandard contract that's not worthy of my members' consideration."

 CORRECTION:
A news article and a news analysis article yesterday about negotiations between the Transport Workers Union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York misspelled the given name of the authority's executive director in some copies. He is Marc V. Shaw, not Mark.

HEADLINE: MY JOB;
I Write Copy for a Web Start-up

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE SHAW 

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, I abandoned the sinking ship of newspaper journalism and hopped aboard a pirate vessel, the Internet. Instead of writing news for a venerable newspaper, I'm now providing content for a Silicon Alley start-up founded by two 20-somethings.
My fellow reporters and I often grumbled about the long hours, low pay and humdrum assignments at the Philadelphia daily where we toiled on the suburban beat. Yet, when I told them where I was going and added that, yes, at the tender age of 27, I'd be receiving stock options, I saw sellout in their eyes. 
 Sellout? Maybe. But in journalism, you have to work your way up the ladder for years. After all, your bosses have worked their way up the ladder. So, you put in time at newspapers in states like Iowa and Louisiana, and then maybe you have a shot at a staff job on a newspaper in New York or San Francisco.
In the new economy, if you're smart and confident, you don't have to wait in line. You can be whatever you want to be. There are no ladders and no pigeonholes.
My new bosses at InfoRocket, an online information-auction company where users pay other users for answers to their questions, seemed excited about my arrival. Experiment with the copy, they told me. We trust you.
So I admit it: I was probably rubbing it in when I told my newspaper friends that InfoRocket's co-founder, Matt Cassin, 24, was wearing shorts during my interview. And that irreverent employees had scrawled site models and quotes like "Revolt Against Time" in black ink on the office's white walls. (I later learned this was because the walls were to be torn down.)
But it wasn't just the casual atmosphere that struck me; what bowled me over was the sheer energy of the place. People were coming and going, banging away furiously at the keyboards, shouting across rooms. At one point, Teo Montoya, 25, the other co-founder, stumbled into the room unshaven and disheveled. He had been up all night writing code, but that didn't stop him from sitting down with me for an hour to talk about everything from my favorite movies to the "new information paradigms."
I hate to say it, but the hectic pace made me wonder if this Internet start-up didn't resemble a newsroom back in the heyday of newspapers. I belonged here, I told myself.
I didn't have a computer or a desk for the first three days, and it took even longer to get a telephone. But on my first day the company ordered pizza and my 13 colleagues and I sat around the conference table. "O.K., team," said Matt. "How is everything going? Do we need to discuss anything?"
We really didn't, but we did anyway. I was forced to reveal my most embarrassing moment. (Losing my bathing suit while water-skiing, if you must know.)
Now, I'm hard at work planning the e-mail newsletter I'll eventually be writing for our users. "I have lots of ideas," I say. "We'll take 'em," my colleagues reply.

HEADLINE: Spreading Harlem's Boom To a Neglected Boulevard

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
If 125th Street is Harlem's Cinderella, emerging from the ashes to a kind of nobility, Frederick Douglass Boulevard, the lean corridor that stretches north through the neighborhood from Central Park West, is her warted stepsister, abandoned in the ruins.
The boulevard is pockmarked with vacant lots, abandoned buildings and other unsightly signs of blight. The Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, has called it an embarrassment to the city, especially as the rest of Harlem undergoes an economic rebirth that she and others have referred to as its second renaissance. 
 On Friday, Ms. Fields unveiled a plan for the redevelopment of the boulevard from 110th to 135th Streets, announcing that she would commit $2.5 million from her capital budget during the next three years to support development activities along the corridor. The proposal identified 16 sites, mostly on city-owned land, along the boulevard as prime spots for residential and retail development, and suggested specific uses for each one.
While much of the capital financing was pledged to provide money only where necessary for residential construction and was not otherwise specifically earmarked, the proposal identified three city-owned vacant lots that Ms. Fields's office is moving to develop within two years, with cooperation from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
Her office has designated an additional $1.05 million for the renovation of Frederick Douglass Circle at the northwest corner of Central Park, along with other streetscape improvements along the corridor.
"Frederick Douglass Boulevard is the central north-south corridor in the community," Ms. Fields told about 150 community leaders, corporate investors and real estate developers at a conference she convened at the State Office Building on 125th Street. "It is the backbone of Harlem. Its redevelopment will send a powerful message that the second Harlem renaissance has deep and permanent roots in the community."
The proposal was the result of a study commissioned by Ms. Fields from the Urban Technical Assistance Project of the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation.
In general, it envisions Frederick Douglass Boulevard as a residential corridor where older buildings would be renovated, new low-rise apartment buildings would be built on now-vacant lots, and street-level storefronts would be used for small businesses.
Ms. Fields did not say how much it would cost to finance the proposal and said she could not provide an estimate. Her spokeswoman, Lisa V. Daglian, said no elements of the plan were final.
"What they are is potential projects," Ms. Daglian said. "They are sites we consider, based on the study, to be prime development opportunities." Ms. Fields said the plan would succeed only if there was an effective partnership between the public and private sectors.
Ms. Fields's presentation on Friday, essentially a pep talk to encourage investors to join in the revitalization of Frederick Douglass Boulevard, seemed to have drawn interest from developers, although some thought her remarks focused too heavily on corporate investment in the neighborhood.
"We all know the stock market is very fickle, and I don't think we can depend on our corporate partners if the stock market crashes," said Thomas Lopez-Pierre, a managing member of the Kierra Trenee Pierre Partners, an Upper Manhattan business that owns and manages franchise restaurants. "We need to stand on a foundation of community ownership. Otherwise Harlem will be left to burn in the aftermath of a market crash."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
An upbeat government report and some sour industry notes on the future of global aviation.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. Edwin McDowell's e-mail is emcdowell@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
SEVERAL days before the start of an international aviation conference in Chicago early this month, the United States Transportation Department released an upbeat report about the future of aviation and the success of the various Open Skies agreements.
Those agreements between nations permit unrestricted air service by airlines of each country to, from and beyond the other's territory, with no limit on the number of flights, the type of aircraft and the prices they can charge. The United States has agreements with 38 countries worldwide. 
 The Transportation Department found that from 1996 to 1998, on routes connecting interior cities in both the United States and foreign countries, fares fell an average of 17.5 percent where Open Skies was in effect. In markets without Open Skies agreements, the average decrease was 3.5 percent. The department also noted that the global impact of air transport would approach $2 trillion in 2010, almost double that of 1994, and directly and indirectly would account for more than 30 million jobs, 6 million more than in 1994.
But the "Beyond Open Skies" conference in Chicago heard a less upbeat view of the future of aviation from James Goodwin, the chief executive of UAL's United Airlines, the nation's biggest carrier. Declaring global aviation at a crisis point, he said there was not enough runway space, terminals or parking space to accommodate the millions of arrivals and departures and the one billion passengers projected to fly on United States airlines by 2012, up from 680 million passengers this year. And he laid most of the responsibility at the door of the nation's air traffic control system.
This is not the first such industry warning. Earlier this year, Carol Hallet, president of the Air Transport Association, made similar predictions, contending that the air traffic control system was inadequate to handle the current 21,000 daily flights, much less the billion passengers expected within the next dozen years. In addition, the magazine Aviation Week and Space Technology primarily cited the United States government for the growing air travel crisis, a crisis in which "passenger safety could be severely compromised."
But it is rare to hear such forebodings by an airline executive at a conference intended to celebrate the growth and economic importance of the aviation industry. Nevertheless, Mr. Goodwin warned that if something is not done soon, air traffic delays would triple in 10 years, costing passengers both time and money.
 
A Matter of Service
Today is the deadline for the airline industry to put into effect its improved customer service provisions. These include giving passengers notification of cancellations, delays and diversions; replying within 60 days of receiving written complaints, and advising of the lowest fare available for each flight.
But individual airlines have gone beyond that, pledging to notify passengers by phone (instead of at the airport) of flight cancellations when known at least two hours before departure (Delta Air Lines), promising not to keep passengers aboard delayed planes for more than an hour (Northwest Airlines) and establishing a consumer advisory board to give advice about the airline's performance (U S Airways).
U S Airways yesterday vowed to allow passengers to cancel purchased tickets within 24 hours without penalty and promised to make prompt refunds. Two days ago, Continental Airlines said that a so-called Service Planning Center would be installed at each of its hub airports in Newark, Houston and Cleveland to rebook passengers on alternate flights, make hotel reservations and generally assist fliers.
But judging from reaction on the Internet and in trade publications in recent weeks, the flying public is taking a decidedly wait-and-see attitude.
 
Passenger Rights
Passenger rights are spelled out on a Web site recently introduced by the National Business Travel Association (www.BizTraveler.org). There are also some 2,000 travel tips, including how and where to file a travel complaint, warnings about regions to avoid because of safety or weather threats, what to do when bumped or delayed, how to travel with a laptop computer or with children, and what safety precautions to take in hotels.
Those tips were collected from more than 1,400 of the association's corporate travel managers, and although intended for business travelers, they should prove equally helpful for all travelers. The Web site's passenger complaint form will allow the association to monitor the actual level of service being delivered in the travel industry, seek a remedy if possible, and, in the case of air travel, compile a report from the responses and forward it to the appropriate regulatory body.

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1128 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS INTO ACTION;
It's Not the Product That's Different, It's the Process

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS; This column about management issues appears every other week. Fred Andrews's e-mail address is frandrew@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MARSHALL McLUHAN wrote 35 years ago that the medium is the message, a puzzling perception that turned out to be profound. Today, a great many business thinkers, in one way or another, seem to be saying something similar: In the new economy, the process is the product.
Set aside the electronic gadgetry. Are the other things we buy -- the cars we drive, the shoes we wear, the trips we take -- all that different from what they were when the other George Bush was president? 
 Not really. The shirts and skirts and jackets we wear today are pretty much the same as the ones that hung in our closet a decade ago. But the ways they are produced -- all the steps from textile plant to doorstep delivery -- have been overhauled, in a forced infusion of information technology. In the 1990's, the apparel industry saved its skin by bringing off a process revolution all but invisible to the consumer.
Something similarly invisible is taking shape now with the Internet. Who could possibly escape the squall of dot-com retailing this season? But largely out of sight, the Internet is also devising the institutions that will enable businesses to deal with one another in radically different ways.
Corporate America seems to have concluded that the train -- the Internet Express -- is leaving the station. The foundations of a new business order are being laid right now. And unless companies respond in kind, they will wither like towns on the Great Plains that failed to attract the early rail lines.
Richard R. Roscitt, the new president of AT&T's huge Business Services arm, made his reputation building complex Internet-based networks for corporate giants. He thought he saw the makings of a business revolution in the Internet several years ago, but he is astounded at how quickly it came. "You would have to have had a crystal ball," he marveled in an interview last week.
The commanding heights of business have come alive to the power of networking as a pervasive way of doing business, Mr. Roscitt said. Established giants are shifting critical functions to the Internet, at least to their roped-off corner of it. Merrill Lynch has embraced online trading, Citibank sends trillions of dollars a day across the Net. The Internet is pumping "the lifeblood of the organization," Mr. Roscitt said. "The stakes are much higher."
The chronic weakness among automakers has been a development process that moves at a turtle's pace. Now AT&T is building an Internet network for General Motors that will enable G.M. to bring cars to market more quickly. The five-year, $350 million project will link G.M. design centers, factory floors and dealerships the world over and allow them to perform continuously as though they were side by side.
In "Blown to Bits" (Harvard Business School Press, 1999), Philip Evans and Thomas S. Wurster, partners at the Boston Consulting Group, argue that communication via the Internet has become so cheap and so powerful -- and still no end in sight -- that it will shatter today's business order. They predict it will force every business in America to pick apart the processes that lie behind its products and consider putting the chain back together in novel ways.
It has always been costly to convey thorough, reliable, timely, rich information. That reality protected those who could afford to play. On the Internet, the cost will all but dry up. And once pure information is cut loose from the expensive physical means of delivering it, whether a printing plant and a fleet of trucks or a dedicated network of mainframe computers, the value of all those old arrangements comes into question.
In the new economy, information will substitute for goods. Branch Rickey once remarked that luck was the residue of design. Mr. Evans and Mr. Wurster write that "inventory is merely the physical correlate of deficient information." Not nearly as epigrammatic, but it is a powerful thought: The more known about what customers want, the less the need to tie up money in expensive (and perishable) stock. The process replaces the product.
Exactly that notion about inventory drove the remaking of the American garment trade. Apparel makers, under searing pressure from retailers like Wal-Mart, used computer links and the sharing of sales and production data to create a discipline of speedy response. They successfully met the simultaneous demands of "lean retailing" for both lower inventories and a much greater variety of goods, at lower prices and in smaller, more frequent deliveries.
The story of how information technology enabled the American garment industry to triumph over low-cost competition overseas is told in "A Stitch in Time" (Oxford University Press, 1999) by Frederick H. Abernathy, John T. Dunlop, Janice H. Hammond and David Weil.
Laser technology permitted the key innovation: the bar code, which tracks demand at the cash register and the status of goods at every earlier stage. That system in turn required computers and software to monitor thousands of prices and millions of items.
But the industry also had to abandon old thinking and invent a new way for handling goods, the bustling hub known as the modern distribution center. "A distribution center," the authors of "A Stitch in Time" remark dryly, "is the antithesis of a warehouse." Goods sit in a warehouse; they speed through a distribution center on conveyor belts, racing from supply trucks at inbound bays to delivery trucks at outbound.
And yet nothing would flow until everything fit. The industry had to hammer out common standards at every juncture, from the bar-coding itself to labels on shipping cartons to uniform price tags and garment hangers.
That history came before the Internet, but the pattern is instructive. The new order will require not only lasers and computers but also, like lean retailing, fresh thinking about old processes and new arrangements of bricks and mortar. The apparel rebirth relied on expensive computer systems tying giant retailers more tightly to selected suppliers. By contrast, the Internet will be open and cheap, accessible to a host of new and smaller suppliers.
Uniform standards, essential in every era, now define the day. The Internet itself consists of agreements to communicate in a certain way. New protocols are being added industry by industry. With every added layer, the Internet connects new realms and thousands of new participants. Mr. Evans and Mr. Wurster of Boston Consulting say that in many ways this standard setting is more profound than the dazzling technology. Mr. Roscitt of AT&T says it is the only way to fly.
"Internet protocol is what everyone's going to jump on," Mr. Roscitt said. "No one in their right mind would build anything not based on that."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Accentuating the Negative, 30-Year Yield Rises to 6.30%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury yields rose sharply yesterday as investors chose to ignore November's moderate consumer price data and instead focused on stronger-than-expected retail sales.
The Federal Reserve has said it will raise interest rates again if there is evidence of continuing strong growth, even if the inflation rate remains tame. For that reason, Treasuries had their biggest decline in months yesterday as investors grew concerned that the central bank would indeed raise rates to try to brake the economy's growth. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 11/32, to 97 21/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, increased to 6.30 percent from 6.20 percent on Monday.
The surge in the yield of the long bond was the largest since August, as buyers moved to the sidelines amid concern that strong holiday retail sales would bolster fourth-quarter growth and help build inflationary pressure, increasing the odds that the Fed would soon raise rates.
"Clues of budding wage pressures and potential labor strife are beginning to build," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "and with gas prices at the pump continuing to rise amid surging economic growth, the specter of rising inflationary expectations down the pike is very likely to translate into higher bond yields."
Mr. Fine said these concerns had not gone unnoticed by the Fed. While the central bank is expected to leave short-term rates alone at its next policy meeting on Dec. 21 to avoid rocking the boat during the Year 2000 transition period, he said, another increase is expected during the first quarter unless there is evidence of a slackening economy.
In addition, long-term interest rates could come under pressure as the year unfolds, and could weaken stock prices.
Treasuries fell yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November. Combined with upward revisions in previous months and reports of busy Christmas shopping nationwide, the report suggested that consumer spending remained extremely strong.
Also leading the bond selloff were investors' liquidating their long positions before the end of the year. Although such selling was relatively small in size, such volume allowed it to cause large swings in prices, traders said.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist for Nesbitt Burns Securities, said early reports suggested no let-up in personal spending in December. "The trend in consumer spending remains too hot for the bond market's liking," she said. "Retailers have entered the critical Christmas shopping season with considerable momentum."
"The bottom line," Ms. Cooper added, "is that on balance, the pervasive strength in retail sales outweighs the good news on the C.P.I. for bonds, but the mix of a strong consumer and still-tame inflation is positive for stocks."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH, KAREN W. ARENSON and EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:

Teachers Retain Paterson for Talks
The United Federation of Teachers has retained BASIL A. PATERSON, a former state senator and deputy mayor, and his law firm, Meyer Suozzi English & Klein, to handle the contract negotiations with New York City. 
In talks for the current contract, RANDI WEINGARTEN, the union's president now but its general counsel then, was lead negotiator. Ms. Weingarten said she wanted to bring in a labor lawyer for the next round, in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to seek a merit pay plan and the teachers are expected to demand increases for their 140,000 members to bring their incomes closer to those of their suburban counterparts. Mr. Paterson has negotiated on behalf of other city unions.
 Ms. Weingarten says she is planning to present a contract proposal early next year. The current contract expires next November.
 
Honoring a Man for All Semesters
Talk about longevity. Columbia University honored MICHAEL I. SOVERN last week for his 50 years at the university, including 6 as a student, 9 as a law school dean, and 13 as the university's president. (He played hooky for two years after his law school graduation, in 1955, when he taught law at the University of Minnesota.)
The crowd of about 500 that gathered at the Plaza Hotel to celebrate his tenure included former professors, students and colleagues, as well as representatives of groups where he was chairman or president, like the Shubert Foundation, the American Academy in Rome and the Japan Society. Even with those diversions, Mr. Sovern, 68, can't seem to tear himself away from Columbia. He is back in the classroom, teaching legal methods to entering law students. According to the celebration's program notes, Mr. Sovern threatens to remain as long as he can "lurch to the lectern."
 
Going From Collegiate to Concord
JACOB A. DRESDEN, who has been headmaster of the Collegiate School, the private academy on the Upper West Side, since 1991, will become the head of the Concord Academy in Massachusetts July 1. His departure was announced in October. Mr. Dresden, 56, will replace Thomas E. Wilcox, who is leaving Concord after 19 years to form a national program to teach science and technology to inner-city students.
Mr. Dresden's wife, PATRICIA MARKLE DRESDEN, will leave her post as head of the lower school at Marymount School, the Roman Catholic girls school on Fifth Avenue opposite the Metropolitan Museum, to move to Boston as well. Mrs. Dresden said she intended to remain in education, but had not settled on a new position.
 
New York State 3rd in Teacher Pay
New York State ranked third, behind Connecticut and New Jersey, in a recent salary survey conducted by the the American Federation of Teachers based on the 1997-98 school year. The state's average was $48,712. Connecticut's was $51,727; New Jersey's was $50,284. The national average teacher salary was $39,347 annually. New York ranked second to Alaska in beginning teacher salary, which was $30,204 in New York.
The federation's president, SANDRA FELDMAN, said that in a boom economy, teacher salaries were falling behind those of other professions. ABBY GOODNOUGH, KAREN W. ARENSON and EDWARD WYATT

HEADLINE: Help E-Commerce Grow

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Nov. 30 letter about the policies of the World Trade Organization and positions taken by Microsoft stated that the W.T.O. seeks to "make Internet commerce tax-free." In fact, the W.T.O. has only a moratorium on tariffs for transmissions over the Internet. But it has taken no position on taxes, like sales or value-added taxes, relating to online purchases. 
 Microsoft is one of many companies supporting this policy and urging extension of the tariff moratorium, because we believe that this results in lower prices for consumers, helps e-commerce grow and avoids discrimination against suppliers in international trade. It's important to note that the W.T.O.'s position does not alter individual countries' internal tax structures and certainly does not make Internet commerce "tax free."
 
BRAD SMITH
General Counsel, Worldwide Sales
and Support, Microsoft
Redmond, Wash., Dec. 6, 1999

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Closes Lower on Worries Over Long-Term Interest Rate

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, hobbled by a drop in the technology sector and a jump in long-term interest rates on news that shoppers went on a big spending spree last month.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 32.42 points, or 0.29 percent, to 11,160.17. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 12.05 points, or 0.85 percent, to 1,403.17. 
 The Nasdaq composite index plunged 86.51 points, or 2.36 percent, to 3,571.66 after racking up 23 record closes in 31 trading sessions.
"The Nasdaq is at long last starting to go down," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
"You could attribute it to profit taking set in motion by very sharp declines in the bond market as there is a growing concern that the economy remains too strong," he said.
Internet stocks, which helped push the Nasdaq to a series of record highs over the last four weeks, fell sharply.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond plunged 1 11/32, to 97 21/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.30 percent from 6.20 percent on Monday on worries that the Federal Reserve may have to raise interest rates again to slow the economy's growth.
In another sign of a speeding economy, the government reported retail stores perked up in November, beating forecasts, as shoppers hit stores after the Thanksgiving Day holiday in the traditional run-up to Christmas.
The Commerce Department said total sales soared 0.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $255.8 billion -- nearly twice the 0.5 percent increase forecast by Wall Street economists -- after a gain of 0.3 percent in October.
The jump in bond interest rates rattled financial stocks.
Among the Dow components, American Express was off 6 to to 160 1/2, and J. P. Morgan & Company was off 3 5/16 at 131 1/4. Citigroup was down 1 13/13 at 53 1/2.
The Labor Department reported that inflation was still subdued, with the Consumer Price Index up only 0.1 percent in November. Excluding food and energy, the index rose 0.2 percent.
Among Internet stocks, America Online was off 5 3/8 at 88 7/16 and Amazon.com slid 6 7/8, to 95 5/8.
Semiconductor stocks fell after Solectron, a custom electronics maker, slumped 9 1/8, to 82 5/8, on disappointing quarterly results.
Analysts said a shortage of components had hurt Solectron, and fear about the shortage dragged down chip makers.
Among them, Intel, a Dow component, was off 1 1/4 at 72 13/16 and Texas Instruments Inc. was off 9 5/16 at 96 5/8.
Microsoft rose 2 1/16, to 98 11/16, on speculation that there was a settlement of the government's antitrust suit against the company. Microsoft said the rumors were "unfounded."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Treasury Secretary Offers A New Vision for the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The Clinton administration, which has defended the International Monetary Fund against vocal critics at home and abroad for many years, has proposed that the fund redefine its mission, become less secretive and end some lending programs -- changes that critics have long demanded.
The proposed changes, the most thorough rethinking of the I.M.F.'s role in the world since the financial instability of the early 1970's, would limit its core mission to making emergency loans to countries that face short-term currency crises. In recent years, the I.M.F. has assumed a broader role in advising and lending to poor and developing countries, but has been widely criticized as ineffectual in administering some longer-term programs. 
 Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, speaking at the London Business School today ahead of a Berlin meeting of both advanced and developing economies, said the monetary fund should phase out long-term lending and cede some of its aid to developing countries to its sister agency, the World Bank. The fund should also be quicker to step aside when a country has ready access to private capital, Mr. Summers said.
"To say that the I.M.F. is indispensable is not to say that we can be satisfied with the one we have now," Mr. Summers said in a speech outlining the proposals. "Going forward, the I.M.F. needs to be more limited in its financial involvement with countries."
The blueprint for change is intended to serve as a mandate for a new managing director of the fund. Michel Camdessus, the current managing director, announced his resignation before the end of his term and will leave the I.M.F. in February. Choosing a new managing director, a post that has customarily been held by a European, will be an informal topic of discussion at the meeting in Berlin beginning on Thursday, American officials said.
The administration's plan appears to be a response to a growing chorus of critics of the fund, including economists and members of Congress, who have said that the I.M.F. could have done more to detect, prevent and contain the emerging-markets financial crisis that began in mid-1997. Though the crisis has passed without the worst fears of the I.M.F.'s critics having been realized, its lending programs to a few countries, most notably Russia, were widely considered to be failures.
Some members of Congress have tied their support for a highly promoted Clinton administration goal -- forgiving the debt of some of the poorest countries -- to an overhaul of the I.M.F. Others have called for changes similar to those Mr. Summers outlined today. Representative H. James Saxton, Republican of New Jersey, who monitors the fund, said that its long-term lending programs are conducive to corruption in poor countries and should be stopped.
In proposing the changes, Mr. Summers rejected calls for turning back the clock on the I.M.F. to a time when its mission was solely to help countries shore up foreign-exchange reserves, a measure taken to protect a currency from declining too sharply in value. The Treasury secretary said the fund should still provide some long-term credit and guidance to poor countries. He also said that the fund deserves praise for how it handled the financial crises of the last several years, even in Russia.
But he nonetheless prescribed a thorough revamping. Most notably, he said the fund should phase out low-interest-rate financing, forcing most countries to raise money from private sources at prevailing interest rates. If that were carried out in full, it would affect dozens of the fund's lending programs around the world. Some programs, like the one for the Philippines, have run as long as 25 years.
Mr. Summers also said the fund should become more open to the public, by publishing its annual budget, for example. And, he said, the fund should compel member countries to disclose many kinds of financial data they now provide on the condition that this remains secret. Though the change sounds simple, it would involve a cultural revolution at the I.M.F., which has operated more as an exclusive club of nations than a conduit of information to outsiders.
The fund welcomed Mr. Summers's comments in a statement issued today. "He has touched on a number of critical areas that need to be considered as we draw the lessons of the recent crisis and prepare for the future," the statement said.
But Mr. Camdessus, writing in an I.M.F. publication that predated the Summers speech, said the growth of the fund's lending programs was in response to a need among poor countries. He said proposals to drastically narrow the scope of the fund's work were misguided. "This would obviously be a recipe for irrelevance in today's world," Mr. Camdessus wrote. He could not be reached for comment on the remarks by Mr. Summers.
Some critics of the fund said the proposed changes were on target. But Jeffrey Sachs, who directs Harvard's Institute of International Development and has been a vocal opponent of I.M.F. practices, said that the fund, often with American support, continues to expand its mission in developing countries.
"In practice, the fund seems determined to hold on to a very broad agenda that impacts the lives of hundreds of millions of people," Mr. Sachs said. "The question here is whether we will see follow-through."

HEADLINE: A Divided Venezuela Votes on New Charter Today

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Venezuela has the chance on Wednesday to accelerate what its president, Hugo Chavez, terms a "peaceful revolution," or to reject what his opponents say would be a constitutional dictatorship benefiting Mr. Chavez at the expense of the millions of poor citizens he says he represents.
Rarely has a political fight divided this country, the world's third largest oil exporter and major supplier to the United States, with such passion and invective. 
 Mr. Chavez, elected a year ago on a promise to strip power from Venezuela's traditional parties and its wealthy elite, has branded critics of the constitution that is to be voted upon Wednesday "degenerates," members of "a rancid oligarchy whose only motherland is capital and profits" and "enemies of the nation." They are, he has charged, "a truckload of squealing pigs" and "a batch of bandits who have betrayed, pillaged and humiliated the people."
For its part, the anti-Chavez camp has sought to link the president to Fidel Castro and Cuban Communism, using Mr. Chavez's own words against him. "I feel happy to follow the path of Fidel," he said during a state visit to Havana last month, adding that Venezuela was swimming "toward the same sea as the Cuban people," which he described as "a sea of happiness, social justice and true peace."
To the alarm of those already suspicious of Mr. Chavez, the new charter, drafted in less than four months by an elected Constitutional Assembly in which his supporters won 90 percent of the seats, would significantly extend the powers of the executive branch of government. It abolishes the Senate, one of the two existing houses of Congress, and gives the president authority to dissolve the legislature in certain specified circumstances. The presidential term of office would expand to six years from five, and Mr. Chavez would be allowed to seek immediate re-election, which is prohibited under the current 1961 Constitution.
In addition, the powers of states and municipalities would be significantly curbed, and the role of the military and its ability to take part in government and politics would increase.
"In many basic respects, this constitution is a step backward from the democratic change the country has been demanding," said Allan Brewer Carias, a prominent lawyer here and an opposition member of the Constitutional Assembly. "It opens the door to authoritarianism, and the authoritarian provisions it contains are certainly going to be used, if not by Chavez, then by someone else."
Even the constitution's main intellectual author has now begun to express doubts about the document. Hermann Escarra, a prominent professor of constitutional law and chairman of the committee that drafted the charter, said he still planned to vote yes in the referendum on Wednesday, joining what opinion polls indicate will be strong support for the document.
But Mr. Escarra describes the final product as "a populist model under military tutelage" and says he will immediately introduce amendments to weaken those tendencies.
Mr. Escarra, who has been one of Mr. Chavez's closest legal advisers, said last week in an interview with the Spanish newspaper La Vanguardia that "the constitution has grave incongruencies" that allow the president "to assume all powers," "give privileges to the military" and put them beyond civilian control. A result, he added, will be a "restricted democracy," and "that would be very disturbing."
Since declaring its independence from Spain in 1811, Venezuela, which has the largest oil reserves outside the Middle East, has had 25 constitutions, more than any other country in South America. Mr. Chavez, striking the kind of sweeping note that has prompted many people here to invest in him their hopes of change, says the new charter will define "the future of Venezuelans for the next 200 years."
Supporters point proudly to the broadened guarantees of individual rights that it offers, including greater recognition of the status of women and indigenous peoples. The charter also reorganizes the country's notoriously corrupt judicial system and includes a recall mechanism that in theory would allow voters to replace elected officials who fail to perform their duties properly.
"This is the most modern and advanced constitution in the entire continent and perhaps in the world," Mr. Chavez said recently on his weekly radio program. He described its passage as essential to "putting 40 years of unfettered corruption and incompetence behind us."
But he has also warned of the prospect of an "internal war" if voters do not approve it.
If the constitution is rejected, "I will do everything possible so that the democratic and peaceful road continues," he said last month. But he added, "I do not know if that will be possible."
A recent poll here found that less than 2 percent of voters in this nation of 23 million people had actually read the draft of the new constitution, a floridly written document that has 350 articles. As a result, the vote seems to have become more of a plebiscite on Mr. Chavez, a cashiered army colonel who led an unsuccessful coup attempt in 1992 but was elected to office with a resounding majority.
"I'm going to vote yes because I want to give the people's president the tools he needs to govern," said Gumersindo Alvarez Montilla, a Chavez supporter who was handing out copies of the document at a subway stop here. "I haven't read all of the constitution, but I don't need to. For me, it is enough that this is Chavez's project, that this is what he wants."
But Mr. Chavez's popularity and the apparent support for his charter have not stopped an informal coalition of political, business, religious and human rights groups from focusing on what they see as dangerous flaws in a document they say was hastily and carelessly drafted.
Human rights groups here and abroad, for instance, have expressed concern about a provision that requires news organizations to publish only "truthful, opportune and impartial" reports. They say the provision would open the door to official censorship and intimidation, since it is unclear who would determine what meets those standards.
Most of Venezuela's main business organizations have come out against the charter. They worry about articles that promise workers a "living" wage without specifying how that would be calculated, prohibit "unjustified" dismissals, reduce the work week and guarantee health care and social security benefits to all Venezuelans, even those who have not contributed to the system, without making clear who will pay that cost.
The Central Bank has taken out full-page newspaper ads to warn that its independence and ability to fight inflation would be sapped by a requirement that it subordinate its policies to those of the government. The president of the state oil company, a Chavez ally, has also complained about provisions that forbid privatization of the company and reserve all "strategic" sectors of the economy for the state.

HEADLINE: G.M. Plans a Rebound From a Bad Month

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 14

 BODY:
General Motors is having a bad month.
It started Dec. 2 when industry numbers showed that G.M.'s market share had fallen in November to 27.1 percent, a record low for a second consecutive month -- excluding times of strikes or war -- and well below its internal target of 30 percent to 32 percent. It continued when Wall Street analysts turned on the company, saying that the only reason to own G.M. stock is the hope that the company will break itself apart and spin off its Hughes Electronics subsidiary. Then came rumors that America's biggest company would be the subject of a hostile takeover bid. And finally the ultimate insult: some analysts lowered their earnings estimates and suggested investors sell G.M. stock to buy that of its crosstown rival, Ford. 
 "It's been a very tough month," said John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch.
G.M.'s executives started saying publicly last week that it is all their fault, but today they made clear that they are relying on existing plans to increase market share as redesigned cars and trucks roll out of factories -- next year. Their apparent lack of urgency is causing Wall Street -- and other automotive companies -- to breathe a sigh of relief because many feared G.M. would panic and start a price war that would crimp profits industrywide.
"You don't address these problems overnight," Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman, said today as he rattled off the sport utility vehicles, heavy-duty pickup trucks and other new vehicles that will soon be in dealer showrooms. "I'm satisfied that the plans we have in place -- if well executed -- will put us in a strong position in the market."
"Clearly we need to improve our market share," said Mr. Pearce, who stressed that G.M.'s executives were to blame for the market share shortcomings. "We all feel responsible for market share -- the senior management group," said Mr. Pearce, tapping his chest. "I'm pointing to myself here -- so do all of us."
All year long, G.M. executives have said the company is selling all it can build. But the November sales results, which were released early this month, showed that G.M. inventory levels were strikingly high, suggesting that a lack of demand, not supply, was the problem.
"We don't have a capacity problem now," explained John F. Smith, Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, on Monday evening. "Now we've got to sell what we've got, which is our job to do. We're going to work very hard at that."
Mr. Smith called the rumors that G.M. could be the subject of a hostile takeover bid "beyond anything imaginable." Most other industry executives and analysts agree.
To analysts, the drop in market share is G.M.'s biggest problem. "They are in a very urgent situation," said Rod Lache, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown L.L.C. "If the market turns down or they stop growing inventory, their earnings are going to suffer."
Indeed, there is one short-term benefit to G.M. for building more cars than it can quickly sell. Because auto companies record sales when they deliver new vehicles to dealers, G.M.'s fourth-quarter profits will likely be higher than if production had been in closer alignment with customer demand.
But G.M.'s competitors and analysts worry that the large stocks of unsold vehicles will increase pressure on the company to use rebates to move the metal -- rebates that other auto companies would probably be forced to match, hurting industry profits.
"The risk of incentives creeping up is increasing," said Mr. Lache. "G.M. is overstocked."
Investors, meanwhile, are growing impatient with G.M.'s go-slow approach to spinning off part of Hughes. "They should spin off at least a portion of Hughes immediately to assuage the feelings of the stockholder," said Seth Glickenhaus of the money management firm Glickenhaus & Company, which holds millions of G.M. shares.
He also worries that too many G.M. vehicles are failing to turn heads. "The design of some of their cars should be improved," Mr. Glickenhaus said.
To top it all off, G.M.'s low valuation -- its price-to-earnings ratio is 7.2 percent -- is an embarrassment. But G.M. has an explanation for that. too: the Internet economy. "Now the companies that do best are the ones that lose money," Mr. Smith said. "It is a different world."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Did You Evah? What a Swell Partier She Is

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
IT was the morning after yet another impossibly late night for Denise Hale, this one dancing at the St. Regis Hotel. (The nights before that, in reverse order: the Four Seasons, Michael's, La Grenouille, Swifty's, the Knickerbocker Club.)
Mrs. Hale was curled up like a cold cat on a friend's couch, staring mournfully out the window at a barge on the East River and trying to ward off the afternoon, when she would have to "pour what is left of Denise Hale into the airplane" for a trip back home to San Francisco. 
 It was, again, and too soon, the end of what is denoted on certain calendars around New York as Hale Week, an early December society juggernaut that has become as traditional as Christmas or Hanukkah for the rich, powerful, famous, connected or all-of-the-above Manhattan friends of Mrs. Hale, the widow of Prentis Cobb Hale Jr., the department store millionaire.
Nobody has measured the economic benefit to New York City of these visits, but judging by Mrs. Hale's dinner tabs alone, plus the lavish parties her visits generate, it could rank somewhere between Fleet Week and the United States Open.
For her concentric circles of friends -- she counts within the circles Dominick Dunne, Kenneth Jay Lane, Nan Kempner, Clive Davis and Martha Stewart -- the week is a kind of strenuous, year-end social workout and gossip gantlet before everyone flies off to more picturesque holiday retreats around the world. Mrs. Hale makes sure she gets the most out of the week.
"They say it is called Hale Week," she says in her soft Serbian accent reminiscent of Natasha's in the Rocky and Bullwinkle cartoons. "It just sounds like that. It is really called hell week."
She explains: "Everybody knows I am the biggest pain in the you-know-what. I am the first one to say it."
But she adds that despite her reputation for prickliness -- she loves to recite her most valuable party tip, given to her by Elsa Maxwell, the legendary hostess: "My child, be ruthless. You don't ask people just because they're nice" -- she has maintained strong friendships through decades because "I don't play games with you."
"If I say to you, 'You are very nice, and I like you,' I mean it, and I am not going to, after you leave, say to people, 'Oh my God, can you believe this guy?' If I don't like something, you will know it right away."
As if it was not enough simply to explain this, earlier in the day she took the opportunity to demonstrate. After dancing into the little hours at Harry Platt's annual dinner-dance at the St. Regis, Mrs. Hale welcomed a reporter to the apartment where she was staying in New York, owned by Rose Marie Bravo, the chief executive of Burberry.
WHEN the reporter mentioned that he would bring a photographer, she laughed charmingly and said: "Oh, no, my dear. That is not going to happen at all, and it is something which I will not even discuss." She added, "I am a very vain woman."
You will never catch her apologizing for this. It has, after all, been one of her most valuable assets.
Growing up in Belgrade, raised mostly by her father's parents, she was her grandfather's darling. When she was 7, she says, and the Gestapo was looting the city, she was the only one he told of the hiding place for the family's gold.
When she fled her country after the war, in a rowboat, and was plucked from the Adriatic by a British minesweeper, the captain also took a shine to her. He dropped her at a refugee camp in Bari, Italy, instead of shipping her back home.
When she landed a job in Rome modeling, she quickly caught the eye of her first successful husband, a businessman, who took her around the world. (Like many things about her past, she is willfully vague about details. She gives her age as 63. Others name a higher figure.)
And when she divorced him several years later, she soon met her second successful husband, the director Vincente Minnelli. (She left Mr. Minnelli for Mr. Hale, whom she married in 1971.)
Mr. Dunne met her one week after she married Mr. Minnelli in 1960. "Young, beautiful, great jewels," he recalled yesterday. But he soon discovered that she also had a great knack for rattling the sometimes staid Hollywood social scene by giving parties that mixed the elegantly rich and the famously louche.
"There were a couple of the old guard hostesses who were a little put out with her," he said. "But Denise really knew how to play the scene."
It is no stretch to say she still does. She was recently the subject of a spate of gossip columns that said she was having a fling with Don Johnson, the actor. Both say they are just friends.
During Hale week, you could find her one night with the cosmetics entrepreneur Gale Hayman and the next night with hip-hop royalty at an awards ceremony for Mr. Davis.
It is, to say the least, exceedingly strange to hear Mrs. Hale drop names like Puff Daddy and Q-Tip (they come out as Poof Daahhdy and Coo-Teep). But she manages to impart the impression that she first met them back at El Morocco.
"In my country, there is the fairy tale, right?" she says, trying to explain her life. "It says when a child is born there are three fairy godmothers. And they decide what will be the child's destiny."
"My version," she says, "is that my three fairy godmothers were completely plastered."
