HEADLINE: A Breakdown on the Sales Lot;
Superdealerships Have Trouble Turning a Profit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: CANTON, Mich., Dec. 14

 BODY:
The AutoNation operation here looks more like a gigantic Starbucks than a place to sell used cars.
Acres of parking lots marked by color-coded signs surround a large, high-ceilinged building of tan bricks and glass. Inside, instead of battered desks and lots of pushy sales representatives, the office contains curving cubicles of polished wood, with computers to describe the features of every car on the lot. 
 But as heavy sleet turned to snow this morning in this Detroit suburb, a team of liquidation experts poked through the cavernous showroom, trying to determine what could be sold and how quickly, from the cars to the computers. For while AutoNation has succeeded in creating a cheerful, comfortable place to buy used cars, it has failed to do so in a way that would earn money.
Throughout the century-long history of the auto industry, selling cars -- particularly used cars -- has been a gritty business. Profits usually flowed to the hardest-nosed bargainer, the dealer who negotiated the highest possible price for each automobile while spending as little as possible on amenities like furniture, carpeting and salaries.
AutoNation and other big publicly traded companies captured Wall Street's fancy three years ago by trying to change all that. Now they are struggling as the car sales industry is buffeted by the rise of the Internet, a fall in used car prices and a push by traditional dealers to improve customer services.
Some of these new-wave car sales companies built used car superstores that looked like cafes, not junkyards, and employed computer kiosks and child-care centers to lure customers to immense lots that offered as many as 1,000 late-model cars. The same companies, plus a few others, later created big chains of new-car dealerships that would share ad budgets and back-office staff to build national brand names at relatively modest cost.
But now the used car superstores are disappearing almost as fast as they appeared, while the chains' new-car dealerships try to cut costs after sometimes-lavish expansions.
AutoNation's announcement late Monday that it would close most of its used car superstores and cut costs at its headquarters signals the unraveling of that original vision. To some extent, investors had already seen it coming: With the exception of Lithia Motors, the most old-fashioned of the publicly traded auto dealerships, stocks in those chains had already slumped. Since early 1997, price-earnings multiples for the dealer chains have tumbled from as high as 50 to just 8 or 9, as low as the multiples for auto manufacturers.
But the troubles are far from over. "The initial Wall Street projections were so off base that you had this land rush into the industry," said George Hoffer, an economist at Virginia Commonwealth University.
What went wrong? The publicly traded dealership chains appear to have been buffeted by several forces that few anticipated.
Most notably, the Internet has made car buyers more conscious of what constitutes a fair price and better able to check prices without shuttling among dealerships. These informed consumers give dealers with low costs and little overhead the advantage, because they can afford to sell cars at rockbottom prices.
Meanwhile, largely because prices for new cars have leveled off, prices of late-model used cars have fallen recently, hurting the value of the inventories at used car superstores.
Long-maligned traditional dealers also seem to have improved service, partly to match the competition and partly because of pressure from automakers, including some that are experimenting with operating dealerships themselves.
Finally, dealers have used their muscle in state capitals to strengthen franchise laws. Even where the rules have not been tightened, the laws already make it hard for publicly traded dealership companies, automakers and Internet companies to expand their retailing efforts.
Superdealerships, thus, are undergoing a metamorphosis: auto executives are replacing the financiers who built the chains and are moving quickly to reduce costs. In August, Roger Penske, the car dealer and diesel-engine magnate, took control of the United Auto Group, the nation's second-largest dealership chain, from Marshall Cogan, a financier. Michael Jackson, former head of Mercedes-Benz's North American operations, became AutoNation's chief in October, replacing Steven Berrard, a video-rental executive and friend of H. Wayne Huizenga.
It was Mr. Huizenga who conferred Wall Street credibility on the idea that publicly traded corporations could consolidate the auto dealership industry; Mr. Huizenga had already consolidated the garbage-hauling and video-rental businesses, building first Waste Management and then Blockbuster Entertainment. In 1995, Mr. Huizenga took control of Republic Industries, a small garbage hauler, and set about turning it into what is now AutoNation, the world's largest auto retailer.
He was able to buy hundreds of dealerships with his highflying company stock as he reminded investors and analysts of previous successes. "We want to build a brand just like we did at Blockbuster," the company's 1995 annual report said.
But brand-building has proved difficult, partly because the top-performing dealerships AutoNation bought had already built their own reputations based on loyalty to the original owners. And AutoNation was often prevented by state laws from getting extra volume discounts from automakers that might give it a competitive advantage over other dealers, so the company could do little to make up for the higher costs associated with building an empire.
Mr. Jackson is now laying off virtually all 1,800 employees at the 23 used car superstores being closed and dismissing 225 of 600 employees at AutoNation's headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
Mr. Jackson said he would also sell one of AutoNation's two jets and even look for ways to trim costs at the corporate dining room. "We will create a cost-conscious culture in this company," he said.
But AutoNation, which has 409 dealerships in 19 states and annual sales approaching $20 billion, still has a long way to go. Compare it, for example, with Lithia Motors, essentially a family dealership that has grown into the nation's sixth-biggest publicly traded new car dealership chain with 41 franchises under one corporate umbrella.
Lithia is known for its cheapness. Its corporate headquarters are housed above the parts department of the company's Toyota dealership in Medford, Ore. When an electric motor opens the garage door for the loading dock below, the whir is heard in the offices of the company's top executives. The walls have the original knotty-pine paneling from 1973, and hallways feature exposed pipes.
An executive dining room? "I go to Taco Bell or order in pizza," said Jeff DeBoer, Lithia's vice president of finance. "We order in spaghetti sometimes."
That austerity has been rewarded: Lithia's earnings and stock price have risen even as the stocks of the other big public dealership chains have faltered. Generally speaking, investors have grown disenchanted with the idea of generating rising earnings simply by buying bunches of profitable dealerships.
The only surviving publicly traded chain of used car superstores, out of five two years ago, is CarMax Inc., which is also known for controlling its costs and is 77 percent owned by Circuit City Stores Inc. While Auto Nation said on Monday that its corporate overhead costs had risen 71 percent in the last 12 months, CarMax's overhead has remained flat even as it has slowly expanded, said Austin Ligon, its president.
Mr. Austin attributed AutoNation's problems to excessive growth: "There's a limit to how fast you can do this and still be successful."
AutoNation's rivals have also tried to give considerable autonomy to their dealerships' sales managers, reasoning that every auto market is subtly different and constantly changing. United Auto Group and AutoNation are now moving in the same direction.
Rival dealers say that a lack of feel for local markets hurts the big chains. James Willingham, a Buick, Pontiac and GMC dealer in Long Beach, Calif., said he often drove by an AutoNation used car superstore and was surprised by what was on the lot.
"We see the wrong product," he said. "They're very close to Long Beach University with 30,000 students and they've got big sport utility vehicles, big Cadillacs and Oldsmobiles when they should have Toyotas and Nissans."
AutoNation now sees its future relying to a great extent on the Internet. Two years ago, when it was buying dealerships almost every week, Mr. Berrard said that the company had only begun to work on an Internet strategy. Mr. Jackson now considers the Internet a core part of AutoNation's business, noting in a conference call with analysts and reporters on Monday that customers who first contacted the company through the Internet had bought $1 billion in cars this year.
AutoNation now lists 90,000 cars and their prices on its Web site, www.autonationdirect.com; it has 900 sales agents to handle Internet inquiries. "This is a payoff for economies of scale, because of the single-site advantage to present a wide selection," said Thomas Eggleston, AutoNation's senior vice president for e-commerce.
But while the site offers broad selection, customers are unlikely to buy at dealerships at the other end of the country and wait for delivery.
And for all its size and heft, Auto Nation has found it cannot simply cut margins and try to sell as many cars as possible. The company tried recently in Denver and learned that the automakers' systems for allocating new cars -- another feature of the franchise system -- did not allow dealers to replace cars as fast as they were sold, Mr. Eggleston said. Manufacturers have been leery of shipping so many cars to a single dealer, concerned that the dealer will pursue sales across the franchise territories of other dealers.
The same state franchise laws also make it impossible for AutoNation to start selling new cars at the used car superstores that it is shutting because that would have infringed on the territories of existing dealers.
A few experts have suggested that publicly traded dealership chains join with automakers and Internet companies in a lobbying campaign to overturn the state laws, possibly through Federal legislation.
But traditional dealers are masters not only of low-cost selling but also of using their connections to influence lawmakers. Despite lobbying by automakers, dealers have already persuaded at least five states this year to tighten franchise laws even further. Even as the public dealership companies stagger, traditional dealers are still standing.
"If this were a real fight," said one auto manufacturing executive, "it would have been called."

HEADLINE: Mirror on the Past: Canal's Fate Reflects Shift by U.S.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: MIRAFLORES LOCKS, Panama, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Millennium celebrations may still be a couple of weeks away, but symbolically the American Century ended here today with a ceremony marking the transfer of the Panama Canal to Panama.
In 1903, nothing compared to Washington's decision to build the canal as a statement of the United States' determination to stand as a world power, even if it meant assisting Panama's secession from Colombia. 
 And while the phrase American Century was actually coined by Henry Luce in 1941, it could have been the motto of President Theodore Roosevelt, who dominated the organizational, medical and engineering tour de force that connected the Atlantic and Pacific.
Ninety-six years later, a festive ceremony noting the imminent turnover reflects the more patient and, above all, more cooperative role in the world the United States now says it seeks.
Out of a late 20th-century sense of sovereignty and respect for somebody else's national pride, a great power is in fact voluntarily giving a piece of valuable national property to a tiny nation with no capacity to seize it.
With the end of the cold war, the venturesome role of presidents like the first Roosevelt or Lyndon Johnson seems to have given way, if not fully to the anti-colonial and anti-imperialist views of Woodrow Wilson, then at least to a sense of the importance of consultation and coalition before bombs are dropped. In Korea and Vietnam, the United States acted first, then looked for allies. In the Persian Gulf and Kosovo, it sought allies first.
Even President Clinton's decision to stay away from the ceremony, though it caused disappointment and even criticism here, meant that the United States would not dominate the day.
That star role was left to President Mireya Moscoso of Panama, who used the occasion to build political bridges by hailing the Panamanian architect of the turnover, the late Gen. Omar Torrijos, even though he seized power by a coup that ousted her late husband from the presidency.
Today's events went without a hitch, except for a soloist who mangled the words to the Star Spangled Banner. But these events were entirely symbolic.
The transfer of canal authority has been going on since the treaty was ratified in 1978, and indeed the final step will not be taken until Dec. 31, with far less hoopla.
President Moscoso and former President Jimmy Carter, leading the United States' delegation, signed a piece of paper in essence promising to keep on implementing the transfer treaty.
But the almost casual American approach to giving away the canal that cost it $352 million and 5,609 lives should not obscure the difficulties Mr. Carter had in winning Senate ratification with only a single vote to spare -- even though then, as now, not a single American aircraft carrier would fit into the canal and nuclear submarines never used it.
Ronald Reagan's rhetoric -- "We bought it. We built it. It's ours and we are going to keep it." -- resonated with Republicans (despite support for the treaty from ex-Presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford), and fears of Cuban and Soviet aggression made some votes to ratify into tickets to electoral defeat.
Mr. Carter scoffed today at treaty opponents as "demagogues" and said, "There are still a few of them in my nation today."
But in fact critics of Panama's administration of the canal have made no impact. One longtime foe of the handover, Howard Phillips of the Conservative Caucus, was in Panama today calling for a new treaty to re-establish American bases, and offering to help clean up unexploded ordnance in the jungle in return.
He also demanded that Panama cancel a port-management contract with Hutchison-Whampoa, a worldwide company based in Hong Kong, which he charged would provide a foothold for China to threaten the canal's security.
Most of today's talk was of cooperation. Mrs. Moscoso spoke of efforts to make the canal "a world class enterprise that will permit it to continue offering safe, efficient and competitive service to the international maritime community." Mr. Carter said the United States wanted to be "a full partner, a harmonious partner, an equal partner to answer any request to come from Panama to make the canal even greater in the next millennium."
On most international issues, from global warming to trade to poison gas or atomic bombs, the United States government seeks agreements among many or all nations. It often fails, and frequently does not convince its own people of the need for sacrifice some see in these agreements. But even when it acts unilaterally, as by raising tariffs on some French luxury foods, it follows procedures authorized internationally.
The engineering may have been harder, but the world was a simpler place for Theodore Roosevelt. No one except the Colombians and a few senators, many of whom favored a different canal route, objected to the American help given the Panamanian revolution.
But some things remain the same. The United States could dream of a canal because it was the world's foremost economic power. The huge steel plates for the gates of the Miraflores locks came from Pittsburgh, while the hardware -- bearings, valves, gears and struts -- came from Wheeling, W.Va.
Today the American economy is still the world's greatest.
Nor was boldness the only measure of Roosevelt's foreign policy. In 1905, settling on a new chief engineer for the canal distracted him at least briefly from efforts to mediate the end of the Russo-Japanese war, for which he won the Nobel Peace Prize.
That sort of role has remained a United States value as the American Century ends. President Clinton did not come here today, but he will be trying to help Israel and Syria make peace in Washington on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Once Again, Inflation Is a No-Show

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Despite booming retail sales and strong consumer demand, the Consumer Price Index barely rose in November, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Even gasoline prices did not make their usual contribution to inflation.
Prices rose in a few scattered areas -- like long-distance telephone tolls, airline fares, prescription drugs and housing costs -- but the index, reflecting a great variety of goods and services, was up only 0.1 percent, the smallest increase since June. 
 "There is too much competition and too much deregulation, and as a result companies are finding it virtually impossible to raise prices," said Ed Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, offering an explanation why rising inflation, widely expected on Wall Street, fails month after month to show itself in the numbers.
The weak November inflation number should have sent stock prices soaring, with its suggestion that the Federal Reserve's policy makers will refrain from raising interest rates when they meet next week. Stable prices and interest rates encourage investors to remain in stocks rather than shift to interest-bearing securities.
But instead of focusing on the bland inflation data, investors responded to two other government reports that reflected the economy's strength and for that reason seemed to portend higher interest rates, if not next week then soon enough. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 32.42, to 11,160.17, and interest rates on Treasury securities rose slightly.
The Commerce Department, in one report, said retail sales jumped by a robust 0.9 percent, a result of holiday spending and a surge in auto purchases in a strong economy. In the second report, the nation's current-account deficit, a measure of what Americans owe to foreign lenders, rose in the third quarter to $89.95 billion, up 11.2 percent from the second quarter. Higher interest rates, in Wall Street's view, would cut into these trends by raising the cost of credit. Spending would slow not only for domestic goods but also for imports, the main reason for the rising foreign debt.
While Mr. Yardeni attributed the mild inflation numbers to competition and deregulation -- of the telecommunications industry in the mid-1990's and banks and financial services companies this fall -- others said the stock market might be playing a dual and somewhat contradictory role.
Rising stock prices encourage spending and demand, trends that could in time produce inflationary shortages. But notoriously unprofitable Internet companies are using money raised from investors to subsidize discount pricing. Amazon.com, for instance, floats shares in a rising market, and the money it raises covers huge annual losses. Meanwhile, the company maintains its discount pricing. And the discounts, in turn, keep prices down in bookstores.
Something similar is happening in other industries, says Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo in Minneapolis. "Many people check toy prices on the Internet and ask toy stores to match them," he said. "Or they see the merchandise at a store and go home and buy it for less on the Internet."
Gasoline prices would have fed into the inflation rate, producing a higher price index, if the Bureau of Labor Statistics had continued its price surveys for another week instead of ending them on Nov. 22. The bureau followed its usual practice of shortening the surveys to three weeks from four in November and December, to interfere as little as possible with holiday shopping.
Gasoline prices dipped in late October, and "there was not enough of a rebound by the time we had finished our pricing," said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist in the office that handles the price index. The December report is likely to reflect the rebound, perhaps adding as much as one-tenth of a point.
With energy excluded from the November report, the price index rose only 0.2 percent. That was also the case when both food and energy prices were excluded.
Economists focus on this restricted figure because they consider energy and food prices volatile -- subject to sharp fluctuations that can distort the overall ndex. With those exclusions, the index increased 2.1 percent for the 12 months ending last month. By this measure, the annual inflation rate has fallen from 2.4 percent last year.
The overall index is another matter, rising 2.6 percent over the last 12 months, a full percentage point more than the annual rate as of last December. Rising petroleum prices accounted for all of the increase, particularly as it shows up in gasoline, aircraft fuel and heating oil. Elsewhere, petroleum has not affected the prices of other products yet, although it is a major building block for plastics used in toys and many other products.
Toy makers and others who use plastics may simply be absorbing the higher cost, at the expense of profits, or offsetting the cost through greater productivity -- in effect getting more production from employees for the same wage.
"Productivity would have to rise at an accelerating rate to maintain this balance, and that is questionable," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities.
Despite strong sales last month, the prices of new vehicles were unchanged, on a seasonally adjusted basis, and over the last 12 months they fell 0.3 percent. Apparel costs fell last month, reflecting discounting that usually precedes Christmas. But rents and the cost of owning a home rose -- each by a strong 0.4 percent.
"You have a lot of demand for housing," Mr. Jackman said, "and that is affecting monthly costs."

HEADLINE: Reducing Audits of the Wealthy, I.R.S. Turns Eye on Working Poor

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service is reducing its efforts to find cheating by businesses and high-income individuals, and stepping up investigations into two forms of cheating that are more likely to involve the working poor than the affluent.
Under pressure from Congress to stress customer service, the I.R.S. is also reassigning employees who had audited companies and high-income individuals to work at counters in walk-in centers, answer telephones around the clock and resolve the tax disputes of estranged couples. 
 But some I.R.S. agents say that many of the changes will tie their hands and in effect shift the focus of audits to those without professional advisers or political connections.
The principal sponsor of legislation overhauling the I.R.S., Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican, said in a statement that the changes taking place were the kind of transitory issues that should be expected when an agency is undergoing a major transformation.
The number of audits in the fiscal year that began this autumn will be cut by 30 percent to 40 percent from the record low number of two years ago, the latest for which data are available, the I.R.S. commissioner, Charles O. Rossotti, said. Fewer than one in 300 tax returns will be audited this fiscal year, down from one in 217 two years ago and one in 63 in 1981. For wealthy individuals with gross income of $100,000 or more, fewer than an estimated one in 150 returns will be audited this year compared to one in 33 in 1992.
The I.R.S. plans to continue giving its highest priority to auditing the 1,600 largest corporations. But it will sharply reduce audits of the other 16 million businesses in America, the vast majority of them privately owned, and of the rapidly increasing ranks of high-income Americans, who tend to file complex returns. The percentage of corporate returns that are audited is expected to fall to just above 1 percent for the current fiscal year from just under 3 percent in 1992.
The effort to find tax cheating is being reduced even more than these numbers suggest, according to more than four dozen I.R.S. employees. In interviews they described pressure from managers to avoid upsetting taxpayers, to overlook complex issues and to close audits quickly. Some agents have coined a term for these once-over-lightly examinations of tax returns: audit lite.
Despite these sharp cuts in personnel to enforce the tax laws, the tax agency is planning a new assault on abuse of the Earned Income Tax Credit, in which the working poor can collect up to $323 for single people and up to $3,556 for a family of four. The credit was created to offset the sharp rise in Social Security tax rates that began two decades ago. Some people make false claims to increase their payment from the government. The credit has been a target of Republican Congressional leaders for the last five years.
The I.R.S. also plans a major new hunt for people who failed to file tax returns. Tax workers said the last such search, early in this decade, focused on people of modest means, and they expect the same this time. The I.R.S. says it intends to focus this search on people who owe substantial amounts.
More than one-fifth of I.R.S. employees, the equivalent of 21,000 people working full time, will be assigned to customer service, up from 12,000 four years ago by one measure and nearly 18,000 by another. By either measure there are thousands fewer workers available to conduct audits and collect overdue taxes.
The tax agency plans one new initiative aimed squarely at the wealthy, an attack on the creation of improper trusts to avoid estate taxes, but this program will not begin until 2001.
Except for the crackdown on abusive trusts, these changes all grow out of a series of new tax laws sponsored by the Republicans who control Congress. The most significant of these laws, the I.R.S. Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998, was passed after Senate Finance Committee hearings in which the I.R.S. was described as out of control and routinely abusive of taxpayers. Much of the most explosive testimony has since been discredited and a subsequent General Accounting Office report found no evidence of systematic mistreatment of taxpayers.
The hearings, the new laws and Mr. Rossotti's policies together have had a profound effect on the agency's employees, especially the low-level managers whose daily decisions determine how the tax laws are administered. Many of these managers have concluded that they are supposed to wilt before the rich and powerful, especially those who can get a politician on the telephone.
"Don't aggravate taxpayers -- that's what our managers are telling us," said one longtime revenue agent in New York. As he spoke six colleagues nodded in agreement and offered similar comments from their bosses.
A revenue agent in Florida said his manager told him: "Don't probe deeply. Just find three or four obvious items and close the case."
An I.R.S. worker in Nashville said anyone there could get a tax case resolved favorably if the taxpayer had enough influence to get a senator or congressman to complain to the I.R.S. "We just collapse," the 14-year veteran said.
"Please don't call us tax collectors in the newspaper," one longtime revenue officer in New York said. "We don't collect taxes anymore. We aren't allowed to."
The chief of I.R.S. operations, John Dalrymple, said "none of these comments shock me."
He was given a synopsis of comments from interviews with I.R.S. workers in California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Michigan, New York, Tennessee, Texas and Washington, nearly all of whom spoke on condition that they not be identified.
"I also am hearing things that have the same general tone," he said, adding that he would characterize their comments this way: "Hey, what is the service's policy going to be around compliance and enforcement? And how are we going to balance the need for good customer service on an individual basis with our responsibility to make sure that people are paying their fair share?"
"Frankly, it is a discussion that we have been having at the highest levels of the organization," he said.
Mr. Dalrymple said he and other leading agency executives had traveled the country telling I.R.S. workers that enforcement was important and that all taxpayers were to be treated alike, without regard to their economic or social standing. He said that this message was not getting through and that efforts had failed to stamp out the mistaken belief that policy favored the wealthy.
"Charles and I have been talking about this for quite some time," he said, adding that Mr. Rossotti agreed with him that the only way to change such a widely held belief was for the commissioner to personally make repeated, clear and forceful corrective statements, which he said Mr. Rossotti began doing in May.
"Managers and employees are looking for some definitive statements from Charles about what to do in certain circumstances that are fairly egregious in terms of not complying with the law," Mr. Dalrymple said.
Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said in a statement responding to questions about the changes: "Without question, it will take time for I.R.S. agents who have done things one way for the past 40 years to learn the new approach, which is built on better serving taxpayers."
The emphasis on serving customers, as taxpayers are now called, comes not only from Congress but also from Commissioner Rossotti, a management and computer systems expert who was brought in two years ago to modernize the agency.
Mr. Rossotti has said that for decades the I.R.S. has relied too heavily on audits and on pursuing tax cheats and that the key to increasing tax revenues and maintaining popular support is to help taxpayers meet their obligations through better service delivered by a better-trained staff and improved technology.
In his first and so far only mission statement for the agency, which focused on helping people pay their taxes, Mr. Rossotti made no mention of enforcing the law or collecting taxes, omissions that have been viewed widely within the agency as reflecting a decreased emphasis on enforcement.
But now even Mr. Rossotti is worried that enforcement has slipped too far. He told a Senate subcommittee in October that such a low audit rate "poses the risk of increased unfairness in administration of the law, and, ultimately, undermining our entire system of voluntary tax compliance."
Mr. Rossotti has had to strip down audit units to obey Congressional dictates to expand customer service and resolve a deluge of so-called innocent spouse cases, most of which involve divorced women who say their former husbands cheated on their taxes and left them holding the tax bill. Whole audit teams in Brooklyn, Seattle and elsewhere have been reassigned to innocent spouse cases, and corporate audit teams across the country that once had as many as 12 highly trained examiners have shrunk to as few as 4 people, tax workers said.
Highly trained I.R.S. auditors who are paid up to $77,000 annually to examine corporate tax returns have been detailed to answer telephones and greet people at I.R.S. offices, even though their years of specialized work have left them ill equipped to handle mundane questions from the public. One I.R.S. customer service clerk said these auditors needed so much time to research answers to questions that when she was away, it took five of them to do her job.
Across the country, revenue officers, whose job is to collect taxes past due, said they were having difficulty getting supervisors to approve enforcement actions, like foreclosing on property, because of a perception by managers that they were not to upset customers, even if they are major tax cheats. In the year ended Sept. 30, the I.R.S. seized property 161 times, down from 10,000 two years earlier. Levies on bank accounts and paychecks fell to 504,000 from 3.1 million two years earlier.
Two revenue officers outlined cases they had built against individuals who each cheated the Government out of millions of dollars in taxes, only to be frustrated by the refusal of their superiors to back them up. These officers described elaborate schemes to place assets in the names of relatives to thwart tax collection and, presumably, hide money from creditors. "Every badge of fraud was there, but Criminal Investigation Division told me the U.S. Attorney was not interested," one of these officers said.
The revenue officer said that because the case was rejected for prosecution, requests for permission to force the taxpayer to pay, which Congress now requires be approved by high-level managers, have been ignored. "No one will do anything" to collect the taxes, the officer said.
Mr. Dalrymple said he had heard, fourth or fifth hand, similar tales of inaction and was troubled by them. He said he would like to hear directly from revenue officers who think their superiors are failing in their duty to enforce collection.
The effect of the cuts in audits is amplified by other factors, including a steady rise in the number of tax returns and a very sharp increase in returns filed by high-income Americans, who are the most likely to have income and deductions from businesses and investments, which can involve complex audit issues.
The number of returns reporting an income of $1 million or more jumped to 142,500 in 1997 from 87,000 two years earlier. These returns often include income from businesses the taxpayer controls, capital gains and other sources not subject to the mandatory reporting systems that apply to the forms of income reported by most people, like wages, interest on savings and dividends.
But under tight budgets set by Congress, the full-time I.R.S. staff has shrunk to about 82,000 people, down 14 percent from 1995. When the growing number of tax returns, the increased volume of money and the 1,260 tax code changes that Congress enacted in 1997 and 1998 are taken into account, Mr. Rossotti calculates, the I.R.S. has had its resources cut nearly 29 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1793 words

HEADLINE: A Perpetual Winner Found Liberation in a Near Failure

SERIES: LOOKING BACK: Bradley vs. Whitman

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
It once seemed that the word "failure" was not a part of Bill Bradley's lexicon. He had been a Rhodes scholar, an Olympic gold medalist, a two-time N.B.A. champion and, on his first foray into politics in 1978, the winner of a Senate seat from New Jersey. In 1984, during the Reagan landslide, he won re-election in a walk.
So in 1990, when Mr. Bradley came within three percentage points of losing his once-safe bastion to an unknown, poorly financed Republican named Christine Todd Whitman, he was devastated. For weeks, he wandered the state in a sullen funk, asking friends what had gone wrong. Over coffee, Michael J. Breslin, a Hackensack lawyer, summed it up for him in one word. 
 "I said, 'The public thought you were arrogant,' " Mr. Breslin recalled, referring to voters' anger with Mr. Bradley for not taking a position on a $2.8 billion state tax increase that year. "He looked at me as if he was startled. Because he can't stand arrogant people. I said, 'Nobody's told you that?' And he said, 'No, you're the first guy to mention that word, arrogant.' "
To many of Mr. Bradley's critics and supporters alike, the disastrous 1990 campaign -- both sides use the adjective -- represents the most important event in his political life. Almost no one had expected the race to be close. Mr. Bradley had been widely considered a presidential contender, and he outspent Mrs. Whitman by 12 to 1. Yet he nearly lost.
The election he later called "a terrible blow" shook his confidence in himself and his staff, causing an intense bout of introspection that helped change the course of his career, Mr. Bradley and his friends say.
Within months, he revamped his Washington staff and cut his ties with some of his oldest political advisers. He removed his name from the list of 1992 presidential contenders. His interest in the Senate waned, and he began work on a memoir, "Time Present, Time Past," which eventually consumed more of his time than legislating. By 1995, he had decided to retire, announcing in a now-famous speech that "politics is broken."
After two lucrative years of consulting, teaching and lecturing, Mr. Bradley returned to the political arena as a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. Yet as much as ever, the 1990 race continues to color his view of politics, and his critics' views of him.
In 1990, Mr. Bradley says, he relied too much on expensive pollsters and consultants who failed to notice the electorate's fury. "The lesson of 1990," he said recently, "is you can have too much money in a campaign."
He says the race also helped him understand the importance of listening more directly to voters, of speaking from his heart and not worrying about the advice of handlers, of being bold. All are lessons he says he has incorporated into his current race, where he has campaigned against conventional politics and made campaign finance reform a central issue.
"He would never be where he is today if not for 1990," said Michael Kaye, Mr. Bradley's media adviser in 1990. "He had to fail. To see that that could happen, and that he could be humiliated. And I think 1990 totally liberated him. He said to himself, 'From this point on, I'm going to do it the way I want to do it.' "
But Republicans say they took a somewhat different lesson from 1990. To them, Mr. Bradley's refusal to distance himself from Gov. Jim Florio's tax plan -- the issue Mrs. Whitman built her campaign around -- simply proved that he was too aloof to understand the anger of average voters and too regimented to adjust when he finally did.
"I was expecting him to blow me out of the water any day, which he could have done with just a couple of sentences distancing himself from that tax hike," said Mrs. Whitman, now in her second term as New Jersey's governor. "But the fact that he didn't became a bigger issue. If you are going to represent the people of New Jersey, you have to respond to their concerns, you have to listen to them. He just never responded."
She added, "The impression I got was that once he locks onto a game plan, he won't change it."
Though Mrs. Whitman entered the Senate race in January 1990, the campaign really began in March, when Mr. Florio, a first-term Democrat, unveiled his plan to close a yawning state budget gap with a $2.8 billion tax increase.
The proposal, coming in the midst of a spreading economic downturn, touched off a storm of protests. Angry homeowners rallied outside the State House, "Impeach Florio" bumper stickers spread like brush fire and radio talk shows devoted hours to railing against the governor.
Even before Mr. Florio released his proposal, Mrs. Whitman's campaign strategists had mapped out a plan for attacking Mr. Bradley as an out-of-touch Washington insider more concerned about global affairs and presidential politics than his home state. The tax plan provided more fodder than they ever had hoped for.
Over the summer, Mrs. Whitman began demanding that Mr. Bradley take a position on the tax increase, which was in the news almost daily as Mr. Florio pushed it through the Legislature. To the delight of the Whitman campaign, Mr. Bradley refused time and time again, saying it was a state issue that had no place in a United States Senate race.
"For this self-styled tax expert to say, 'I have an opinion but I'm not going to say it, I'm not going to tell you,' well, people thought that was unbelievably arrogant," said William Palatucci, a New Jersey lawyer who was Mrs. Whitman's principal political consultant then.
For Mr. Bradley, the tax issue raised some difficult political and personal problems. His aides say he really believed that it was improper for him to weigh in on a state issue, even though he told them privately that he thought the tax increase was "too much, too fast."
But more than that, Mr. Bradley felt deep loyalty to Mr. Florio, who had bucked Democratic Party leaders by supporting Mr. Bradley in 1978 over the state organization's favored Senate candidate.
"Some people said we had to answer these Florio questions," said Bob McHugh, Mr. Bradley's campaign press secretary at the time. "But Bradley just wasn't going to go there."
Moreover, one of Mr. Bradley's closest political advisers, Douglas Berman, his 1984 campaign manager, was Mr. Florio's state treasurer and an architect of the tax increase. It would have been hard for Mr. Bradley to criticize the plan without appearing to repudiate his old friend, now the chief strategist for Mr. Bradley's campaign.
The fact that several relatively inexperienced consultants were running Mr. Bradley's campaign instead of Mr. Berman was an indication to many people that Mr. Bradley was not worried about Mrs. Whitman.
Nicholas Donatiello Jr., Mr. Bradley's 30-year-old Senate press secretary, was the manager, though he had never run a campaign before. Mr. Kaye, the media consultant, spent much of the year in Santa Fe, N.M., and Los Angeles. And Joseph Peritz, the pollster, was a specialist in consumer products.
"This was not a campaign people were anxious to run, because expectations were sky high," Mr. Donatiello said in a recent interview. "You couldn't beat them."
Many of Mr. Bradley's friends also say he seemed to be more interested in the 1992 presidential campaign than in his re-election. Leading up to the 1990 campaign, he had spent $1 million polling voters around the country and buying computer equipment to analyze the data. He also raised much of his $12 million Senate war chest outside of New Jersey, particularly in California, an indication that he was trying to create a national base of supporters.
All of those things fit neatly into Mrs. Whitman's line of attack. Yet by the fall, polls showed Mr. Bradley still leading by 20 points or more. So his advisers maintained their cautious strategy of refusing to engage Mrs. Whitman and running positive advertisements about Mr. Bradley.
But even those commercials seemed to fall flat. One spot featured Mr. Bradley in his Senate office, kicking his sneaker-clad feet up onto his desk; another showed him sinking a basketball shot before cheering students. In both cases, the commercials seemed oddly out of sync with the bad mood of the electorate.
"It looked frivolous," Mr. Kaye said recently.
Mr. Bradley also often seemed slow or ineffective at responding to Mrs. Whitman's repeated thrusts on issues, ranging from his campaign contributions to his environmental record. When she challenged him to take a position on flag burning, he spent two weeks studying the matter before announcing that he considered it a constitutional right.
By the last two weeks of the campaign, Mr. Bradley, who had been in Washington for Senate votes much of the fall, finally returned home for full-time campaigning. For the first time, he heard voters' anger in person. Soon after, his campaign ran its first negative ad against Mrs. Whitman, accusing her of supporting higher taxes as a Somerset County freeholder. He defended the ad with a line he still uses, "Get an elbow, give an elbow."
By and large, however, Mr. Bradley did little to alter his strategy down the stretch. Yet more and more voters were switching their allegiances to Mrs. Whitman every day, and Mr. Bradley had no knowledge of it. His campaign had stopped doing tracking polls in October, confident that his big lead would hold.
"It was amazing, but no one smelled the coffee," Mr. McHugh said.
After the election, Mr. Bradley became withdrawn, his friends and former aides say. He blamed his advisers, himself and even voters.
"For many months to come," he wrote in "Time Present, Time Past" (Knopf, 1996), "I looked at each person who approached me as if he or she had voted against me."
Gradually, as his disappointment lifted, he came to look at the 1990 election as "the best thing that ever happened in my political career," he wrote. "It forced me to face up to what I needed to change, both organizationally and personally. It forced me to go deeper into my emotions and to speak from values and convictions in ways I had avoided before."
Mr. Bradley's friends say they think Mr. Bradley has become more playful and unbuttoned as a result of 1990, doing little things like grabbing the glasses off Larry King's face or asking Sam Donaldson whether he ever smoked marijuana.
But some also wonder whether he completely understands what happened in 1990 and whether he has accepted his own role in his poor showing.
"He felt betrayed," one friend said. "And he blamed everyone. He saw how vulnerable he was to people giving him advice. I felt bad for him because I saw how wounded he was. But in the end, he's the boss. They gave him bad advice, but he's the one who took it."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);

COMPANY: SENATE (US) NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION (83%);

HEADLINE: House Panel to Question Democratic Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
After years of investigations, partisan vitriol and accusations of stonewalling leveled at the Clinton White House, Republicans in Congress will at last get what they have long sought, a hearing on Wednesday to publicly question a Democratic fund-raiser at the epicenter of the 1996 campaign fund-raising controversy: John Huang.
Protected by a grant of immunity, Mr. Huang is scheduled to begin three days of testimony before the House Government Reform Committee led by its Republican chairman, Representative Dan Burton of Indiana -- an event that Republicans hope will prove uncomfortable for President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. 
 Republicans may be disappointed. In Mr. Huang's opening statement, a copy of which was provided to The New York Times, the former fund-raiser said he knew of no wrongdoing by either Mr. Clinton or Mr. Gore. Mr. Huang said he might have escaped "the terrible ordeal" had he implicated them, but, he said: "I never had a basis upon which to do so. In fact, I maintain very high regard for each of these dedicated men."
In August, Mr. Huang pleaded guilty to engaging in a conspiracy to defraud the Federal Election Commission by arranging for employees of the Lippo Group, an Indonesian-based conglomerate run by the powerful Riady family, to be reimbursed for contributions in the 1992 and the 1994 elections. He was sentenced to probation and agreed to cooperate with the federal authorities.
Mr. Huang played a significant role in the 1996 campaign. Of the $2.8 million in improper contributions that the Democrats were forced to return after the 1996 election, almost 80 percent were raised by Mr. Huang and Yah Lin Trie, both of whom were longtime friends of Mr. Clinton and raised large sums based on their personal relationships with the president. In 1997, when the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee began its investigation, Mr. Huang refused to testify, invoking his constitutional right against self-incrimination.
Today, White House officials repeated their frequently expressed skepticism about the objectivity of Mr. Burton's panel and questioned its impartiality in questioning Mr. Huang. Jim Kennedy, a White House spokesman, said: "Three things in life are certain. Death, taxes and partisan hearings chaired by Dan Burton."
But Mr. Huang's testimony -- re-examining the frenzy of Democratic fund-raising in 1996 -- comes at a time when campaign finance issues seem to be catching fire in the presidential race and could help sharpen demands for changes in the country's system of raising money for federal candidates and parties.
Those demands are already central issues for insurgent presidential candidates like Bill Bradley, the former Democratic senator from New Jersey, and John McCain, the Republican senator from Arizona. In an unusual step, Mr. Bradley and Mr. McCain have scheduled a joint appearance on Thursday in New Hampshire to pledge that if nominated they would call on their parties to refuse unrestricted "soft money" contributions for party-building activities. Many of the large contributions raised by Mr. Huang in 1996 flowed into the Democratic National Committee in soft-money checks.
In his written testimony, Mr. Huang does not suggest that he will add important new details to his activities, which have been the subject of lengthy Senate, House and Justice Department investigations. Last month, Mr. Burton's committee released lengthy notes taken by F.B.I. agents in their investigation of campaign finance matters.
Instead, in his prepared remarks, Mr. Huang, who once worked at the Commerce Department and later at the Democratic National Committee, portrayed himself as a victim of partisan politics, a rising tide of anti-Asian sentiment and grossly unfair news accounts, including reports of lawmakers who falsely accused him of economic espionage. "People seeking publicity have lied about me repeatedly in the press and even before this committee without consequence."
But he admitted that he had made mistakes. "Embarrassed and saddened though I am by the unfortunate attention my conduct and notoriety brought upon my community, the dated and isolated offenses, which I have openly acknowledged, will not deter me from my career-long efforts to promote understanding between the citizens of the United States and those of China, Taiwan and the rest of Asia."
Investigations have found that Mr. Huang first met Mr. Clinton in the 1980's, through a mutual friend, James Riady, the head of the Lippo Group. By 1992, when Mr. Huang was employed by the Lippo Bank in California, he began to raise money for the Democratic Party.
After Mr. Clinton's election, Mr. Huang used his contacts to get a job at the Commerce Department. In 1995, as the president's re-election campaign began, Mr. Huang left Commerce to begin fund-raising for the Democrats, although some party officials had reservations from the start about whether Mr. Huang might be raising money from contributors overseas.
Throughout 1996, Mr. Huang organized fund-raising events, some attended by foreign contributors and Mr. Clinton. Mr. Huang and another fund-raiser, Maria Hsia, organized one such event on April 29, 1997, at the Hsi Lai temple in Hacienda Heights, Calif., which was attended by Mr. Gore, whose shifting statements about his knowledge of the purpose of the event dogged the vice president for many months.

HEADLINE: McCain Unveils HealthPlan Calling for Modest Changes

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 14

 BODY:
Calling the nation's health care system "too costly, too inaccessible and too bureaucratic," Senator John McCain today set out a plan of "tailored reforms" that included a federal program to help the low-income elderly pay for prescription drugs and a limited right to sue health maintenance organizations.
Mr. McCain's plan, offered in a speech to the Charleston Rotary Club, was part of an effort to capitalize on his surge in New Hampshire by fleshing out his positions on issues. Health care -- and most particularly the soaring costs of prescription drugs -- has emerged as one of the hottest topics on the campaign trail this year, and until now it has been a policy arena largely dominated by the Democrats. 
 "Our health care system today often fails to reflect our values," Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican, said, as he began two days of campaigning in one of the crucial early primary states where he is hoping to upset the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. "Too many Americans go to sleep at night desperately fearing illness or injury to themselves or a family member because they are without health insurance to pay their bills."
But even while he identified access to affordable, quality health care as one of the most pressing problems facing American families, Mr. McCain stopped well short of the kinds of more far-reaching legislation that Vice President Al Gore, former Senator Bill Bradley and Congressional Democrats are running on. Aides were still calculating the cost of his program hours after his program. Tonight they said the entire health care plan would cost $7.6 billion when fully in effect in its fifth year.
Mr. McCain's plan for regulating health maintenance organizations would extend a limited right to sue to people in managed health care plans regulated by the federal government. But that would not include suits for punitive damages. His prescription drug plan would offer federal money to states that chose to participate and match the amounts instead of making it a new benefit for all Medicare recipients.
He proposed nothing resembling Mr. Bradley's plan for subsidies and tax credits for children and affordable coverage for adults through the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program.
"Getting there does not require some grand experiment in social engineering," Mr. McCain said, "or a death-by-a-thousand-cuts, gradual government takeover of the health care system. We need only to consult our values and enact tailored reforms that build on the strengths of the current system."
Mr. McCain's effort to find an ideological middle ground was most clear in his proposal for reducing the spiraling costs of prescription drugs to the elderly. Unlike President Clinton's plan for a broad expansion of the Medicare program at a cost of $118 billion to the federal government, Mr. McCain called for a block grant that would cost the government only $5.1 billion when fully in place in its fifth year, matched by those states that chose to participate in the program. Currently, 14 states provide drug cost aid to the elderly.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley both have proposed a Medicare benefit for prescription drugs.
Although Medicaid covers most prescription drug costs for the elderly poor, Mr. McCain's aides said his plan would help an estimated 10 million of the near-poor elderly with incomes of up to two times the poverty level of $8,240 for an individual and $11,060 per couple.
Mr. McCain also said that he would create regional pilot projects costing $1 billion a year when fully implemented to test programs of assistance to the elderly regardless of income when they face catastrophic drug costs "that can cruelly snatch away a life's savings."
The speech gave Mr. McCain a new opportunity to tie his signature issue -- the overhaul of the campaign finance laws -- to broader social concerns.
"Taking the $100,000 special interest checks out of politics is the gateway through which all other reforms including the reform of our health care system must pass," he said.
He blamed both parties' fidelity to special interests for Congressional gridlock on regulating managed care, saying: "Republicans want to protect the insurance companies from lawsuits. The Democrats want to let the trial lawyers sue anyone for anything."
Mr. McCain found a middle ground, calling for more protections than Republican legislation that passed the Senate, but stopping short of the right to sue contained in a bipartisan bill that the House passed.
At a news conference later, Mr. McCain said he would like to see independent state panels set up to review cases when consumers were denied care by a health maintenance organization. His aides said that under his proposal the 48 million Americans in the managed care plans that fall under federal regulation would be given a somewhat broader right to sue than they now have, if they were unsatisfied with the review. Those in such federally regulated managed care plans now are allowed to sue only for the cost of denied medical care.
They would be barred from receiving punitive damages. But they would be allowed to seek unlimited damages for economic suffering like lost wages. Dan Schnur, the senator's communications director, said Mr. McCain would also propose legislation to put a $250,000 cap on noneconomic damages, like awards for pain and suffering.
When the Senate debated managed care regulation this year, Mr. McCain voted for the Republican bill, which did not include an expanded right to sue. His aides said he had supported the legislation because he did not want to see the issue die in the Senate.
To extend health insurance coverage to more of the nation's 44 million uninsured, Mr. McCain like many Republicans called for an expansion of medical savings accounts, tax-free accounts that could be used to cover medical costs, and for a more general tax reduction to give people more money to buy insurance. He also called for a more aggressive effort to encourage small businesses to band together in insurance purchasing pools, as well as a greater effort to enroll children in a federal program established two years ago for children in families not poor enough for Medicaid but not affluent enough to buy private insurance. Mr. McCain also called for increased spending on veterans' health care programs.
Mr. McCain's speech made him the first Republican to set out a detailed health care plan. Mr. Bush has spoken only generally of extending coverage and pointed to the program in Texas for regulating H.M.O.'s.
The issue has been more hotly debated in the Democratic presidential contest because of Mr. Bradley's call for a vast system of subsidies and tax credits that would cost $65 billion a year. Mr. Gore has aggressively picked apart the plan.

HEADLINE: GERMANS TO SET UP $5.1 BILLION FUND FOR NAZIS' SLAVES

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Dec. 14

 BODY:
After months of bitter negotiations, German industry and government officials agreed today to establish a fund of $5.1 billion to compensate people who were slave laborers during the Nazi regime.
Although important details were still being negotiated, people on both sides of the negotiations said tonight that they had reached an agreement on the central question, to raise the amount of money that had been proposed. They settled the figure at 10 billion marks. 
 The scope of the effort could ultimately affect more than one million surviving victims of Nazi Germany's systematic use of forced labor, although nobody is sure how many people may ultimately file claims.
American officials estimate that there are 240,000 surviving slave laborers, about half Jewish, who were held in concentration camps and forced to work under nightmarish conditions.
The fund would also compensate a much larger number of "forced" laborers, most of whom were not Jewish and were brought from the Soviet Union, Poland and other East European countries.
Officials estimate that group at 700,000 to 1.5 million.
Although fewer than 100,000 of the former forced workers are Americans, the negotiations were driven almost entirely by American class-action lawyers and Jewish groups, as well as the United States government.
German executives have been worried about the suits, but even more by the prospect of a conflict with American customers and business partners. American and German officials said they hoped to finish negotiating the main elements of the plan on Friday in Berlin. German corporations would pay at least half the money for the new humanitarian fund and the German government the rest.
American companies with German subsidiaries, including General Motors and Ford, are also expected to participate.
In principle, the fund could provide up to $7,500 for each surviving slave laborer, and most likely smaller amounts for forced laborers.
But lawyers involved in the talks predicted bruising disputes about the rules on how former workers would qualify for the payments.
"We have an agreement, there is absolutely no doubt about that," said Michael Witti, a lawyer in Munich for former workers. "But anybody who thinks this will all go through smoothly is living in a dream world."
Although three-quarters of the money from the fund would compensate forced workers, the settlement is also intended to resolve other open claims arising from the Nazi era. The fund would also be used to compensate Jewish victims of so-called "Aryanization" programs, Jews and other non-Germans who were forced by the Nazis to sell their property at fire-sale prices.
And the fund would be used to handle lingering claims against insurance companies.
The deal was reached after marathon bargaining over the telephone among Jewish groups, American lawyers, German industry and the German government.
It was mediated by Stuart Eizenstat, the United States deputy treasury secretary, and Otto Lambsdorff, a former economics minister in West Germany. The two men are to arrive in Berlin on Friday to work out final details and formally announce an agreement.
In exchange for paying the fund, German companies like DaimlerChrysler, Siemens and Volkswagen would receive immunity from future lawsuits over the use of forced labor. German banks would be freed from claims arising from the "Aryanization programs."
All companies would give money to a common fund set up by an independent German foundation, which would transfer money to designated organizations that represent surviving workers in the United States, as well as in Central and Eastern Europe.
"I can confirm that an agreement has been reached," said a spokesman for the German industry foundation, Wolfgang Gibowski. "I hope that the money will come relatively quickly to the surviving victims."
Part of the total compensation will probably come from American companies with German subsidiaries that used forced labor in the war. The most notable of those are likely to be Adam Opel, a company that General Motors bought more than 70 years ago.
Both companies have long acknowledged that their German factories used forced laborers in the war, but had argued that they had no liability because the Nazi government took over the businesses.
Lawyers for the former workers, who stand to make many millions of dollars in fees from the settlement, said they thought the German government would provide some of the money being added to bring the settlement to 10 billion marks.
Lawyers for the former workers had sought 20 billion marks.
German negotiators, as well as Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, had insisted as recently as last week that there would be no money beyond the 8 billion marks proposed last month.
Today, advocates for former workers said they were satisfied.
"This is a measure of justice for slave laborers who have waited a very long time," said Gideon Taylor, executive vice president of the Jewish Conference on Material Claims Against Germany.
The group has been collecting and distributing money from Germany on behalf of forced workers for several decades.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Eizenstat was optimistic that there would be a definitive acceptance of the 10 billion mark figure, but he cautioned that the German government had yet to accept the plan officially.
"It would be a wonderful way for Germany to make a moral statement at the end of the century that would have lasting effects into the next century," he said of the emerging terms.
Mr. Eizenstat is to meet Mr. Lambsdorff in Berlin on Thursday and Friday in the hope of wrapping up the details, according to Susan Elbow, a spokeswoman for Mr. Eizenstat.
Melvyn Weiss, an American class-action lawyer, said he was unhappy about accepting 10 billion marks, but felt he had no choice.
"I don't feel good about it," Mr. Weiss said. "But it is a pragmatic decision. At this point, we don't have a choice because of the needs of aging victims and the pressure from governments to get this resolved."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: THE BENCH MARKS;
At 14.3 Percent Over 3 Years Raise for Transit Workers Beats the Average

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
The agreement struck this morning with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will give transit workers a 14.3 percent increase in wages and benefits over three years, union officials said, an increase that generally eclipses raises for public employees in the New York region in recent years.
In typical fashion, the city transit workers began the negotiations by making a high-end demand of 9 percent annual wage increases, or a 27 percent total raise over a three-year contract. In equally typical fashion, the M.T.A., which runs the city's subways and buses, started out with a low-ball offer of less than 2.4 percent annual wage increases over four years. The average transit worker makes $39,000. 
 But deals reached earlier this year between the M.T.A. and workers on the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Railroad, and between the Pataki administration and state university professors and administrators, resulted in wage increases ranging from 3 to 4 percent a year.
The railroad workers accepted a deal that will pay them an 11 percent total raise over three years, or 3.67 percent per year. In September, state university employees agreed to a deal that pays them 3 percent annual raises for four years, along with bonuses and health and insurance benefits that bring the increase in total annual compensation to more than that. The average SUNY employee makes $53,500 a year.
Three years ago, the transit union accepted a total wage increase of only 3.75 percent over three years because the M.T.A. faced a large deficit at the time.
With the M.T.A.'s finances now in far better shape, Willie James, the president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, had argued that larger raises were in order. He also pointed to recent raises for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other top elected officials. "The mayor gave himself and other officials a 28 percent raise," he said. "So, I don't see why he says it's unreasonable for me to ask 27 percent for the members when they've done so much to increase productivity."
Nationwide, from September 1998 to September 1999, wages for state and local government workers rose 3.3 percent and benefits rose 2 percent, an increase in total compensation of 2.9 percent, according to the federal Labor Department.
The federal figures, reflected in the Employment Cost Index, also show that since 1994, local and state government employees have received average annual wage increases of just under 3 percent and average annual benefits increases of 2.3 percent, for a average annual increase of 2.8 percent in total compensation. Raises have tended to be larger in recent years, as the economy strengthened.
In the early years of the Giuliani administration, when the city's economy was weaker, the city's uniformed employees, including police officers, supervisors and correction officers, agreed to two years of wage freezes followed by two annual increases of 3 percent and an increase of 6 percent in the final year of their five-year contracts.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
More Jobs in New Jersey

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
New Jersey's sizzling economy helped job growth expand to record levels in November, while the unemployment rate dropped for the fifth month in a row, the state's Labor Department reported yesterday.
According to preliminary figures, unemployment fell by 0.2 of a percentage point in November to 4.3 percent, marking the 25th consecutive month that unemployment was below 5 percent. 
 The number of working New Jerseyans rose by 6,300 in November, for the 10th straight month of record-high employment. The state reached a seasonally adjusted employment level of 3,888,300 last month, a record.
The retail sector led the employment growth, with 2,200 more jobs in November.

HEADLINE: France Halts U.N. Debate On Monitors For Iraqi Arms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Hours before the Security Council was to vote today on a new arms-inspection system for Iraq, France suddenly asked to stop the clock, stunning council members and irritating some by calling for more talks on a resolution that had been under discussion for more than six months.
A United Nations official described the move as tragic, coming as it did just after Russia's deputy representative here, Gennadi Gatilov, told reporters that Russia would abstain, thereby removing the threat of veto from a measure that could send arms inspectors back to Iraq for the first time in a year. 
 No new date was set for a vote.
"This is not about the resolution," one diplomat said, adding that France appeared unable to take a stand that might damage its relations with Iraq.
"People are very irritated, very angry that France is prolonging this needlessly," the diplomat said. Another envoy said the council was being held hostage to "domestic French politics."
Iraq, which demands that a nine-year-old embargo be lifted before inspections begin, threatened France last week with a diplomatic break and the loss of oil contracts if France supported the resolution.
The French decision was conveyed late in the day in London to the British, the sponsor of the resolution setting up the new inspection commission. Britain also holds the presidency of the Security Council this month.
The British and Americans offered no explanation why they acquiesced to the French, after insisting for the past week that the resolution was ready for a vote and that there would be no further negotiations. Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief United States representative, has not been involved in the talks, saying he had other pressing affairs.
The new inspection plan has been fine-tuned several times to take Russian and French concerns into account, including the addition of provisions that arms control experts say could reduce the monitors' independence.
Today Secretary General Kofi Annan appeared to confirm these apprehensions when he told reporters that the United Nations disarmament department would help him draw up a list of staff members for the new commission. Arms experts say that should be left to the commission's executive chairman, who is to be chosen by Mr. Annan.
The unexpected council setback on Iraq came as the International Atomic Energy Agency, which is responsible for all nuclear inspections in Iraq, was also meeting resistance in Baghdad as it tried to carry out monitoring unrelated to any United Nations inspections.
The agency said that if Iraq did not allow inspectors to check stores of low-enriched uranium this week, President Saddam Hussein would again be in violation of the 1968 nuclear nonproliferation treaty. Iraq violated the treaty consistently before the gulf war in 1991, but those violations were not discovered until after the war, when clandestine caches of highly enriched uranium and plutonium were removed from the country by United Nations inspectors.
This week the agency assembled a team to make a routine annual inspection of Iraq's permitted uranium stocks, which must be regularly monitored, said David Kyd, a spokesman for the agency. But Iraq has not issued them visas.
Although the Clinton administration has said it does not have proof that the Iraqis have resumed building prohibited weapons -- nuclear, biological or chemical -- independent disarmament experts say that given a year without international inspections, it is more than likely that Iraq has continued to look for ways to reconstruct programs.
No atomic agency inspectors have been permitted to work in Iraq since they and the United Nations team, which monitored biological, chemical and missile systems, were evacuated just before American and British air strikes resumed a year ago this week.
Mr. Kyd said that under the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, which Iraq signed, the atomic energy agency is required to keep track of 1.8 tons of low-enriched uranium and other stocks of natural uranium in Iraq's possession.
At the Nuclear Control Institute, an independent organization in Washington, Paul L. Leventhal, the president, said that the 1.8 tons had already been enriched to 2.3 percent or 3 percent and could be used to create bomb-grade uranium "if they had a clandestine centrifuge enrichment plant -- which, by the way, no one is ruling out."
"That is, of course, the technology they were working on when the whole program was stopped by the gulf war," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 17, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a delay in the Security Council's vote on a resolution renewing arms inspections of Iraq misstated the degree to which the country is said to have enriched a supply of uranium. According to David Kyd, a spokesman for the International Atomic Energy Agency, it is 2.6 percent, not 2.3 or 3 percent.
Also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to a comment by Paul L. Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute, an independent organization in Washington. He said that uranium enriched to 3 percent from 2.3 could be used to create bomb-grade uranium. He did not say that an Iraqi supply of 1.8 tons of uranium had been enriched to 2.3 or 3 percent.
The headline on the article misstated France's action. France did not halt debate on the resolution; it delayed a vote.
Because of another editing error, an article yesterday about Iraq's refusal to admit inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency misstated the year the United Nations imposed economic sanctions on the country. It was 1990, after Iraq invaded Kuwait -- not 1991, the year of the Persian Gulf war.
