HEADLINE: Shaping Cities, Pixels to Bricks

BYLINE: By NINA TEICHOLZ 

 BODY:
MIKE ROSEN, an architect, first glimpsed the future of his profession in an unlikely spot -- the video game arcade at a nightclub. At the time, Mr. Rosen, who is the head of his own firm in Philadelphia, was having trouble getting local approval for a planned community he had designed in Chester County, Pa.
The problem was on his mind at the nightclub as he donned a virtual-reality helmet to play the game Virtuosity, hunting pterodactyls in a spare geometric environment. "I thought, this is a perfect visualization tool for architects," he recalls. 
 Mr. Rosen is part of a small cadre of architects who create three-dimensional models of cities on computer screens, a technique called urban simulation. It takes state-of-the-art virtual reality techniques, many of them borrowed from military flight simulation technology, and applies them to the basic business of urban planning.
The results are virtual cities: digital, three-dimensional models of cities like Los Angeles, Washington, New York and New Orleans. Mr. Rosen built a model of Philadelphia. "People can't read architectural drawings and they can't relate to models," Mr. Rosen said. "But I realized they found virtual-reality technology cool and that maybe I could relate to clients that way."
Some of the models are extremely detailed: a model of Los Angeles created by Bill Jepson, director of the Urban Simulation Laboratory at the University California at Los Angeles, is accurate down to the graffiti on the buildings and the signs in store windows.
Depending on the sophistication of the program, viewers can navigate through these models as they would through a video game, flying over buildings, spinning 360 degrees and even changing features of the landscape with a mouse click. Some of the models are also "smart," that is, connected to a database. If you click on a building, you can get information on the building's owner, the principal tenants, even the current cost for each square foot.
These models are already changing the way real estate developers do business, said Michael Kwartler, director of the Environmental Simulation Center in Manhattan. For example, he built a three-dimensional model of a SoHo neighborhood for a developer seeking to build a hotel there. "We showed the model to the community, let them fly around it and look at things from different angles," Mr. Kwartler said, "and we sailed through the public hearing. After all, it's much easier to do urban planning by consensus than by injunction."
In the not-so-distant future, the models should be so sophisticated that you could wander through the virtual streets looking for that little Italian restaurant you visited years ago, recognize the window display and click on it to look at the menu or perhaps make a reservation. Police and fire departments will probably be able to set up virtual command centers in virtual cities; critical information like floor plans and the locations of fire hydrants and hose bibs could be updated easily.
"This isn't just in the realm of imagination," Mr. Jepson said. "We're pushing hard to develop these emergency response applications."
Mr. Jepson's laboratory is also building a virtual version of ancient Rome. The purpose is primarily educational: faculty and students could meet as avatars on Roman soil and perhaps get a history lesson from an actor playing Julius Caesar.
Two people looking at the same blueprint may imagine the object in radically different ways.
"Architects typically get fired in the middle of projects," said Joel Orr, an urban simulation consultant, "usually because the owner and architect think they have a shared assumption about how something will look, which is not true." Virtual tools, he added, "permit a far greater opening of communication channels between humans than has ever before been possible."
The first city to be simulated was an imaginary one, created at U.C.L.A. in the 1970's. NASA had given the school a grant to develop applications for the technology used to simulate the Apollo moon missions. Until modeling became common in the industry, architects would slide video cameras through physical models to try to capture the pedestrian perspective. The heat of the lights caused all the photographs to peel off the little model buildings, said a clearly un-nostalgic Mr. Kwartler.
Today, urban simulation technology is so persuasive that the National Capital Planning Commission now requires architects to submit three-dimensional computer models of all proposed projects on Washington public land. These projects are then integrated into the citywide model. "It allows us to control what we're going to see as opposed to what the applicant wants us to see," said Michael Sherman, a community planner for the commission.
Mr. Sherman used the example of the proposed World War II memorial on the Washington Mall: "We were able to evaluate the impact much earlier on. We could see whether the views of the Lincoln Memorial and other historical landmarks were blocked. It was very helpful to see the memorial from the perspective of a pedestrian, which you can't do with a physical model."
The basic tools for urban simulation are now within the reach of most architects. While more photorealistic modeling still demands a high-end Unix station costing at least $15,000, many architects can do less sophisticated work on a Pentium-class PC with a $300 graphics card. Software is more expensive. The programs for building a 3-D world (for example, Viz by Autodesk, MicroStation by Bentley Systems and Creator by MultiGen-Paradigm) and for real-time simulation (like Vega and GameGen by MultiGen-Paradigm) add up to about $15,000.
That money can save on costly construction fiascos. Before ground was ever broken on the mammoth Bellagio hotel in Las Vegas, for example, the developer made hundreds of changes based on reactions to the virtual model. In Philadelphia, developers of a new baseball stadium for the Phillies averted a minor disaster by consulting a virtual model built by Mr. Rosen.
"When we built the model and got down onto the field and looked toward the sky, we realized that the huge scoreboard hid a piece of the city skyline," Mr. Rosen said. So he moved the stadium over 40 feet and rotated it so that the developers had the design and view they wanted. "There was no other way to visualize that problem until the stadium was built," he said. "By then it would have been too late."
Virtual modeling is also aiding in the laborious search for rooftop or office space. When Chase Manhattan Bank was looking for 20,000 square feet of space recently, it went to Urban Data Solutions, a firm that has built a model, accurate to within a meter, of most of New York City. Telecommunication companies have hired Urban Data to scout out rooftop locations for their antennas and receivers. Standing atop any virtual building, a viewer can see if other buildings will block signal sight lines. Andrew Lerner, president of Urban Data, said he planned to use his model for emergency personnel training and maybe even for virtual backdrops for movies.
Some of the field's most innovative work is being done by New York's Environment Simulation Center. Mr. Kwartler has developed modeling software that works on a Pentium-class PC with an inexpensive graphics card, thereby enabling communities to do planning on their own. The software is like a 19th-century pattern book, with a kit of parts -- houses, garages, trees, streets -- that a town planner can use to paste together various development schemes. Each element is "smart," so when a new set of houses is placed on a street, the software immediately calculates the additional tax revenue versus the new cost of road and utility maintenance.
The model can even make sophisticated predictions about outcomes. Build an upscale mall in your town, for example, and the software will project what kinds of people might shop there, how much money the mall might generate, and so on. Build a low-end mall, and the model will assume that some nearby homeowners would move out of town.
"It creates a kind of accountability," Mr. Kwartler said. "You can't be seduced by someone's perhaps overly optimistic vision."
The town Mr. Kwartler has modeled most extensively is Ascutney, Vt., (population: 1,000), which is considering several ways to develop its tiny downtown. Mr. Kwartler's group presented its simulated models during the summer. "It was like someone flipped on a light switch in the room," said Gary Smith, a consultant who is gathering data for the project. "People who would barely talk to each other because they couldn't agree on where to build new roads suddenly had at least a willingness to explore more."
For the architects and developers accustomed to controlling what people see, these advances can be threatening. "Normally, an architect goes to a meeting with three drawings -- each of them a very manipulative view that's favorable to the developer," Mr. Kwartler said. But modeling technology levels the playing field; a client can visualize just as well as an architect. "Architects find this technology very uncomfortable," said Mr. Sherman at the National Capital Planning Commission. "We're running into a lot of resistance because they don't want to give the government their 3-D files. They don't want to lose control of what's seen."
Other critics say computer models fail to capture the tactile quality of a development landscape. "I get the criticism we even make all the ugly stuff look good," Mr. Kwartler said. The limited power behind most models means that they can't show every gritty detail -- cabs honking, trash cans overflowing, power lines. "If you saw a model I did of Chinatown," Mr. Kwartler said, "absent all its hustle and bustle, and then you went to the real place, you'd be totally shocked."
Mr. Rosen blames high expectations among viewers of the technology for some of the criticism. "They've come to want the photorealism of 'Toy Story' and 'Jurassic Park,' " he said. "That's just too expensive for us."
But three-dimensional modeling is a giant step toward allowing cities and towns to have meaningful conversations about aesthetics. The whole point, Mr. Kwartler said, is to avoid the experience of someone saying, "Gee, I didn't know it would look like this!"

HEADLINE: Vanishing Oases

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In these booming economic times, it is truly a tragedy that the world-class city of New York still cannot ensure the protection and care of the wondrous modern spaces like those noted in "When It Goes It's Gone: Manhattan's Vanishing Oases" (Dec. 2). In addition to the respite for which they were intended, these plazas add immeasurable value, inspiring both up-and-coming and veteran designers in all fields, not just architecture and landscaping but crossing into textiles, home accessories and even fashion. 
 I have spent time since childhood in each one of these oases and others. Truly, these small jewels enriched my aesthetic sense and delighted me. My parents introduced me to them all, traveling from Brooklyn and the Bronx in the 1960's and 1970's to enjoy the unlimited, virtually free cultural offerings around the city. As an adult I continued to visit them, during lunch hours, waiting for a friend. They were never empty. These were defining experiences, contributing to my professional and personal interests today.
There was an excuse during New York's fiscal crisis. What is it now? It is a fact that with adequate care for parks and plazas, crime there disappears. One individual's newly acquired Internet wealth could sustain all the plazas in an endowment. Adoption of a plaza by a local corporation is still an attractive vehicle. An adequate budget for the Parks Department, combined with a private partnership, could solve the whole problem. These spaces are part of New York's and the country's unique architectural history.
 
LISA BLOCK
Maplewood, N.J.

HEADLINE: Irate Customers Say Stamford Needs Their Old Diner, Not Another Tower

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 15

 BODY:
Sculptured and streamlined by years of urban renewal, the downtown business district here is a futuristic landscape of corporate office towers and a windowless, fortresslike mall.
Then there's Curley's Diner, a bustling, aluminum-plated, neon-signed outpost of Stamford's past. 
 "It is one of the few constants left in Stamford," said Jim Stevenson, 63, who was finishing his breakfast in a booth at the diner, across West Park Place from several new, more upscale restaurants. "Yuppie-type restaurants come and go downtown, but Curley's remains the same, a place where you can get food at reasonable prices around the clock, and as Stamford's ultimate forum for discussion of most any topic by people from all walks of life."
But to others, including city officials, Curley's is an impediment to further development in this corporate mecca, whose population of about 100,000 doubles each workday. The Stamford Urban Redevelopment Commission has condemned the 58-year-old diner to clear the way for an 11-story building to house stores and 418 apartments, 80 percent of them high-rent units.
The commission, using its powers of eminent domain, has offered Maria Aposporos and her sister, Eleni Begetis, $233,000 for the building and its land, both of which they own, and which many people think is worth considerably more. Even the chairman of the commission, Stephen Osman, conceded in an interview that a Boston developer, Corcoran Jennison Companies, was paying the city $4.625 million for the 1,700-square-foot diner and its 5,736-square-foot land along with several other old buildings to the west and northwest.
But the diner's owners say that whatever the financial offer, they have decided to stay put. Today, they and 35 supporters marched a quarter-mile from the restaurant to the Stamford Government Center to protest the move. About 7,000 people have signed a petition to preserve the diner, which draws customers from surrounding communities as well as from nearby offices.
"Just what Stamford needs, another high-rise with expensive apartments," John Murphy, a retired building administrator for I.B.M., said as he finished a breakfast of bacon, eggs, hash browns, toast and several cups of coffee, all for $2.60, with no charge for the coffee refills. "To tear this place down to put up a high-rise is outrageous."
Acquisition of the diner is part of a 19-year-old plan by the redevelopment commission to acquire property in what it describes as a blighted area covering two blocks just west of the Old Town Hall, in the heart of the business district. The property will be sold to a developer who has nearly completed the first building in the three-building project. The commission has offered to lease the diner space in the new buildings, but the diner's owners say the rents would be too expensive.
For many customers, the fight for Curley's Diner is about more than just a quick, cheap meal. Some are concerned about the loss of old buildings in Stamford, a former factory town where longtime residents still talk about the sudden demolition of the pre-World War I National Guard Armory on Washington Boulevard, just before Christmas 15 years ago.
For the diner's supporters, Curley's is an even greater landmark, indispensable for its food and homey atmosphere. But they are equally moved by the plight of Mrs. Aposporos, a 52-year-old Greek immigrant, for whom they share a warm affection.
"People are very angry about this because they love Maria and her diner," said Dee Denton, the head of a marketing firm in nearby Darien and a customer for two decades, who began the petition drive. "She's a very spunky woman and she's not giving up without a fight."
Mrs. Aposporos has waged her fight with signs placed in the diner's front window. "U.R.C. offers $240,000 for my business. Very generous," reads one, while another describes Mayor Dannel P. Malloy as "the Grinch who stole Curley's Diner."
Mr. Malloy, who said he was unaware of the sign and had not been in Curley's since he was a child, did not seem overly sympathetic to Mrs. Aposporos's plight. He said she should have known about the threatened condemnation of the diner when she bought the property. "After all," he said, "this plan has been on the books for decades."
But Mrs. Aposporos's lawyer, John Wayne Fox, a state representative who, like the mayor, is a Democrat, said it wasn't until 1988, 12 years after Mrs. Aposporos bought the diner and its property, that the commission's plan was amended to include the diner site.
Mrs. Aposporos and her sister bought the diner in 1976 from its original owner, Herluf Svenningsen, known as Curley. A former waitress at another demolished downtown restaurant, the Coney Island Grill on Atlantic Street, Mrs. Aposporos waits on customers, works the cash register and plays a role that goes beyond the diner.
"Not only is Maria a wonderful and warm hostess who serves very good food at very reasonable prices, but she is both a fighter and a giver," said Bill Arnone, 53, an accountant who works nearby and comes in for lunch several times a week. "She brings meals to prisoners in the city lockup, to people in a nearby senior residence, and feeds customers who are down on their luck."
Mrs. Aposporos, who immigrated from Greece in 1962, and whose husband, an engineer, died nine years later, has been known to deliver meals to longtime customers while they are ill.
"A few years ago, after I had suffered a heart attack, Maria found out about it and, without so much as calling me, brought me a hot lunch, and I live in Shippan, two and a half miles away," said Carroll A. Great house, 82, the retired president of a venture capital company that had its offices in Stamford.
It is not unusual for Mrs. Aposporos -- who has two grown children, one of whom, a daughter, Eleni, is a waitress in the diner -- to work up to 15 hours a day at Curley's, where she spends all of Thanksgiving and Christmas greeting customers, many of whom live at the nearby Y.M.C.A.
"This is my life, and I love my customers," Mrs. Aposporos said as Louis Maldonado, a customer in his 30's who was moving to Miami the next day, went over to give her a farewell hug and a kiss. "Now they want to take my little diner -- a place where mayors, but not the present one, and judges and all kinds of people have been coming for years -- and sell it for millions of dollars to a rich developer who will make more millions. It is not fair."
Mrs. Aposporos's lawyer, Mr. Fox, says the city's offer for the diner and its property is inadequate, and has hired his own appraiser. While conceding that the city has the right to invoke its power of eminent domain, Mr. Fox says that the agency may be ignoring guidelines set by the Board of Representatives, Stamford's main governing body. "For one thing, the board specified in a resolution in 1988 that affordable housing was to be a primary component in any further development by the U.R.C.," he said. "And yet only 20 percent of the apartments in the high-rise scheduled to be built on the diner's site will be affordable. That comes out to about 83 apartments. That's not what the board had in mind."
Some have suggested that the city build around Curley's. But Mr. Osman, the chairman of the redevelopment commission, said that was not feasible.
"I sympathize with Mrs. Aposporos, but sometimes small properties have to give way to larger developments," he said. "And we think the appraiser has set a fair price."
But most of Curley's regulars seem to feel that the diner is priceless.
"This is a historic place and Maria deserves to keep it right here," said Philip M. French, a lawyer, while having lunch, as he does every workday, with his wife, Judy, who is the office manager of his law firm. "It means a lot to an awful lot of people, many of whom can't afford to eat anywhere else. And besides that, it's like no other place in town."

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
Using Market Forces To Model Election Races

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
For years, professors at the University of Iowa have provided political junkies a financial outlet for their wild speculation. The Iowa Electronic Markets is an online system that enables people to bid on the presidential or congressional candidates they think are most likely to win. Anyone could jump in -- as long as he was willing to spend at least $5 and had a Telnet connection to the Internet.
Now the markets are available on the Web (www.biz.uiowa.edu/iem), and an increasing number of prognosticators are putting their money where their mouths are. 
 When Robert Forsythe, an economics professor, and several other Iowa professors started the project in 1988, fewer than 200 traders got involved. This year about 3,900 people have signed up. The total investment is more than $86,000. Anyone online can place bids, worth up to $500, on the outcomes of the Republican and Democratic presidential nominations, the makeup of the Senate and House of Representatives, and the outcome in the United States Senate race in New York between Hillary Clinton and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York.
If a selected candidate wins, the trader who bid on that candidate receives $1 for every share purchased. For example, if Hillary Clinton wins the New York race, those who bid for her at 30 cents a share (her going price on Wednesday) will make a 70 cent profit on each share.
In 1996, the going price for President Clinton was only one percentage point away from the percentage of people who actually voted for him, a prediction that many pollsters would envy. LISA GUERNSEY 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: IOWA, USA (95%); NEW YORK, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In Asia, Nasdaq Inspires Rush for Technology Stocks

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Dec. 15

 BODY:
It's beginning to look a lot like Nasdaq on Asia's stock markets.
Never mind that there are few dot-com companies to speak of. Fever over anything to do with the growth of the Internet has spread to this part of the world, fueling a boom in stocks of electronics and telecommunications companies. 
 The reason for the rush into high-technology Asian stocks appears to lie in Nasdaq's record-setting jumps this month. A technology-led rally in Singapore pushed the benchmark Straits Times index up 8 percent to record highs. Mirrored in Hong Kong and Seoul, the trend was repeated within a week in markets in Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok. Even some telecommunications stocks in Indonesia appear to be swept up in the enthusiasm.
"If you talk about anything other than tech, investors just aren't interested," said Chang Chiew Yee, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
The Nasdaq has also shown it can pull Asian stocks down. Reacting to the 2.36 percent retreat in the Nasdaq on Tuesday, the Straits Times index fell 1.68 percent today, the benchmark index in Hong Kong fell 2.81 percent, and the Seoul index fell 3.90 percent. For the year, however, they all show strong performances, comparable to the 63 percent advance in the Nasdaq.
Asia's markets have long responded reflexively to big moves on Wall Street, but it usually has been large changes in the Dow Jones industrial average that energized investors here on the other side of the Pacific: signs of economic health in the United States are a good omen for Asia's export-dependent economies.
That Asian markets are beginning to track the technology-heavy Nasdaq market rather than the Dow average illustrates not only the evolving character of American corporate might, but also a shift in attitudes about where this region's economic future lies.
The rally partly reflects the fact that computers, telecommunications equipment, mobile phones and the parts that go into them represent a large share of Asia's exports and the belief that demand for such products will continue to grow. The rally also embodies a belief that the region is transforming itself in the aftermath of its two-year financial crisis to more closely resemble America's so-called new economy, in which the Internet forms the basis of an electronic marketplace.
At the same time, the new fascination with Internet-related investments has been accompanied by the same nagging doubts many market experts have about the United States boom, particularly the consequences for an economy where capital accrues fastest to money-losing enterprises. More troubling to skeptics in Asia is that most of this region's economies, while improving, can hardly be called healthy. The largest corporations are still buried in debts, and many banks are feeble.
"People are still at the talking stage for all this new-economy stuff in Asia," said David Fernandez, an economist at J. P. Morgan.
The mess in Asia's banks means less money is available for corporate expansion. According to Merrill Lynch, only Singapore and Hong Kong have regained financial health. The banking systems in South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand are still insolvent. But the story for Asia's electronics exports is compelling. Most economists foresee continued economic growth in the United States next year, and they think that will fuel orders for Asian electronics, which are already near their highest level in 20 years, according to Merrill Lynch. That should benefit electronics manufacturers as well as help finance Asia's bank bailouts and its overall economic recovery.
More demand, economists predict, is likely to come from within Asia itself as consumer spending accelerates with economic recovery. Asia is one of the fastest-growing markets for cellular phones.
"It's a glorious situation out there," said Janardan Menon, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities in Singapore. "There's a global shortage in semiconductors; hand-phone sales are still shooting through the roof; PC sales are strong. All put together there's no signs of any weakness."
And in contrast to times before the crisis, when Asian companies and banks lagged the United States in exploiting technology, most Asian governments have adopted policies to encourage companies and individuals to catch up with the West. Many are also trying to create their own versions of Silicon Valley, complete with a freewheeling entrepreneurial culture. The International Data Corporation predicts that electronic commerce in Asia will grow from 0.01 percent of the region's gross domestic product to 0.59 percent in the next five years.
Shares of Sapura Telecommunications Bhd., a Malaysian telephone equipment maker, have risen nearly 50 percent this month. Since October, Shinawatra Satellite of Thailand has climbed more than 60 percent, and the South Korean telephone company-cum-Internet service Dacom has more than doubled. Investors are even buying into the Malaysian telephone operator Telekom Malaysia, pushing its stock up nearly 16 percent this month. Chip-company stocks are also soaring.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE ISRAEL-SYRIA TALKS;
In the Three Main Players' Words: A Sense of Their Moment in History

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from statements on Mideast talks today by President Clinton, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription service:
 
PRESIDENT CLINTON
When the history of this century is written, some of its most illustrious chapters will be the stories of men and women who put old rivalries and conflicts behind them and looked ahead to peace and reconciliation for their children.
What we are witnessing today is not yet peace, and getting there will require bold thinking and hard choices. But today is a big step along that path. Prime Minister Barak and Foreign Minister Shara are about to begin the highest level meeting ever between their two countries. They are prepared to get down to business. For the first time in history, there is a chance of a comprehensive peace between Israel and Syria and indeed all its neighbors. . . .
We should be clear, of course. The success of the enterprise we embark upon today is not guaranteed. The road to peace is no easier and in many ways it is harder than the road to war. There will be challenges along the way. But we have never had such an extraordinary opportunity to reach a comprehensive settlement.
Prime Minister Barak, an exceptional hero in war, is now a determined soldier for peace. He knows a negotiated peace, one that serves the interests of all sides, is the only way to bring genuine security to the people of Israel, to see that they are bound by a circle of peace. President Assad, too, has known the cost of war. From my discussion with him in recent months, I am convinced he knows what a true peace could do to lift the lives of his people and give them a better future. . . .
 
PRIME MINISTER BARAK
We came here to put behind us the horrors of war and to step forward toward peace. We are fully aware of the opportunity of the building of responsibility and of the seriousness, determination and devotion that will be needed in order to begin this march together with our Syrian partners to make a different Middle East, where nations are living side by side in peaceful relationship and in mutual respect and good neighborliness.
We are determined to do whatever we can to put an end and to bring about the dreams of children and mothers all around the region to see a better future of the Middle East at the entrance to the new millennium.
 
MR. SHARA
Your announcement, Mr. President, was warmly welcomed both in Syria and in the Arab world and its positive echoes resonated in the world at large. That is because it promises for the first time the dawn of a real hope to achieve an honorable and just peace in the Middle East.
And as you have mentioned in your letter of Oct. 12, 1999, to President Assad, the issues have crystallized and difficulties defined. That is why, if these talks are to succeed as rapidly as we all desire, no one should ignore what has been achieved until now or what still needs to be achieved. It goes without saying that peace for Syria means the return of all its occupied land. While for Israel, peace will mean the end of the psychological fear which the Israelis have been living in as a result of the existence of occupation, which is undoubtedly the source of all adversities and wars.
Hence, ending occupation will be balanced for the first time by eliminating the barrier of fear and anxieties and exchanging it with a true and a mutual feeling of peace and security. Thus, the peace which the parties are going to reach will be established on justice and international legitimacy, and, thus, peace will be the only triumph after 50 years of struggle.
Those who reject to return the occupied territories to their original owners in the framework of international legitimacy send a message to the Arabs that the conflict between Israel and Arabs is a conflict of existence in which bloodshed can never stop, and not a conflict about borders, which can be ended as soon as parties get the rights, as President Assad has stressed to these meetings more than once before and after Middle East peace conference. We are approaching -- we are approaching the moment of truth, as you have said. And there is no doubt that everyone realizes that a peace agreement between Syria and Israel and between Lebanon and Israel would indeed mean for our region the end of a history of wars and conflicts and may well usher in a dialogue of civilization and an honorable competition in various domains -- the political, cultural, scientific and economy.
Peace will certainly pose new questions to all sides, especially for the Arab side, who will wonder, after reviewing the past 50 years, whether the Arab-Israeli conflict was the one which solely defied the Arab unity or the one which frustrated it. During the last half-century, in particular, the vision of the Arabs and their suffering were totally ignored, due to the lack of immediate opportunity for them to convey their points of view to international opinion.
And the last example of this is what we have witnessed during the last four days of attempts to muster international sympathy for a few thousand settlers in the Golan, ignoring totally more than half a million Syrian people who were uprooted from tens of villages on the Golan, where their forefathers lived for thousands of years and their villages were totally wiped out from existence.
The image formulated in the minds of Western people and which formulated in public opinion was that Syria was the aggressor and Syria was the one who shelled settlements from the Golan prior to the 1967 war. These claims carry no grain of truth in them.
As Moshe Dayan has explained in his memoirs, it was the other side who insisted on provoking the Syrians until they clashed together and then claimed that the Syrians are the aggressors.
Mr. President, the peace talks between Israel and Syria have been ongoing for the last eight years, off and on, of course. We hope that this is going to be the last resumption of negotiations, which will be concluded with a peace agreement, a peace based on justice and comprehensivity, an honorable peace for both sides that preserves rights, dignity and sovereignty. Because only honorable and just peace will be embraced by future generations. And it is the only peace that shall open new horizons for totally new relations between peoples of the region.
President Assad announced many years ago that peace is the strategic option of Syria, and we hope that peace has become the strategic option for others today in order to have or to leave future generations a region that is not torn with wars, a region whose sky is not polluted by the smell of the blood and destruction.
We all here agree that we are at a threshold of a historic opportunity, an opportunity for the Arabs and Israelis alike, and for the United States and the world at large. Therefore we all have to be objective and show a high sense of responsibility in order to achieve a just and comprehensive peace, a peace that has been so long awaited by all the peoples of our region and the world at large.

HEADLINE: Senate Legislation Proposes To Close Puerto Rico Base

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The Senate will hold hearings next month on a bill to close the $3 billion naval station in Puerto Rico, a move that would clearly hurt the Puerto Rican economy, if the commonwealth refuses to allow live-fire exercises to resume on the island of Vieques.
The governor of Puerto Rico today called the legislation a "petty political move" that would cause major economic damage to the commonwealth, his spokesman said. But the bill's sponsor, Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, said naval operations in Puerto Rico would not make sense without use of the Vieques range. 
 And in a sign of the Clinton administration's concern over the diminishing prospects for a settlement, John Podesta, the White House chief of staff, will meet a top official in the administration of Puerto Rico's governor, Pedro J. Rossello, on Thursday to prepare for a meeting next week between Governor Rossello and President Clinton, Puerto Rican officials said. The Clinton administration declined to answer questions about the base closing proposal or the upcoming meetings.
Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said in an interview today that it made sense to close the Roosevelt Roads naval station on the main island of Puerto Rico if the commonwealth refused to allow training on the smaller island of Vieques.
"We're clearly of the view that if the range is lost, it is highly likely that we would close Roosevelt Roads," Senator Warner said.
That naval station serves the Navy battle groups and marines that train in Vieques and open waters around Puerto Rico. Roosevelt Roads provides $300 million to Puerto Rico's economy each year and employs 2,500 civilians and 2,400 military personnel.
Earlier this month, President Clinton ordered a halt to live-fire military training on Vieques to help resolve an eight-month dispute between the Navy and Puerto Rico. In April, a Puerto Rican civilian guard was killed in a bombing accident, leading to political protests that have united Puerto Rico as no other issue has.
Since then, the Navy and Marine Corps have been prevented for the first time since 1941 from using the range for exercises they consider essential training for combat readiness.
Governor Rossello rejected Mr. Clinton's compromise offer, which included restricting exercises on Vieques to non-explosive, or inert, ordnances, reducing by half the number of days that exercises would be held and ending all exercises within five years unless the local residents agreed to an extension. Mr. Clinton also offered Vieques a $40 million economic revival package to demonstrate that the Navy understood it must "repair relations" with the people of Vieques.
Angel Morey, Puerto Rico's secretary of state, will meet with Mr. Podesta on Thursday to arrange a meeting as early as next week among the governor, Mr. Clinton, and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, said Alfonso Aguilar, press secretary for the governor.
"Just the fact that the White House is receiving Mr. Morey, and eventually the governor, shows the president is making a great effort to look out for the welfare of the people of Vieques," Mr. Aguilar said. "This is a positive first step showing the president and the White House are still in the dialogue and willing to compromise."
But, senior administration and military officials said, a settlement has to be reached in the next several weeks to allow the Navy to plan for alternatives if the battle groups can no longer train on Vieques.
Even without the pending legislation in the Senate, the Navy would automatically examine closing Roosevelt Roads station if Vieques was lost, a senior Naval official said.
"The relationship between Roosevelt Roads and the mission of Vieques range is very close," the official said. "If we lose Vieques, it would be cause for a review of the value of keeping Roosevelt Roads."
This year the Pentagon failed to persuade Congress to approve a new round of base closings at installations around the country that have lost their use in the post-cold-war era but continue to cost billions of dollars to maintain. Now several senators are proposing to close Roosevelt Roads if there are no more exercises at Vieques.
"Put yourself in the position of a senator or representative who closed a military installation," Senator Inhofe said. "Politically, you can't resist closing down Roosevelt Roads. It's a no-brainer."
Governor Rossello was not surprised that the Senate is threatening to close Roosevelt Roads, Mr. Aguilar said, adding, "The governor has known for some time that this argument would be used against him."
Puerto Rican officials said that Roosevelt Roads was important even without Vieques and was used in the war against drugs as well as other military training.
Since this summer, the Navy has been searching for alternatives to Vieques for training exercises. But military officials say they have yet to find anything to duplicate the "unique qualities" of Vieques.
Earlier this month, the Navy and Marine Corps put together a "patchwork" of training for the aircraft carrier Eisenhower and its battle group, including a Marine detachment, which leaves for its next assignment to the Mediterranean in February without training at Vieques. Instead they used bases in Florida and North Carolina for pilots to drop bombs and marines to storm the beach, as well as temporary naval artillery training on Cape Wrath in Scotland.

HEADLINE: NATO Meets on European Plan for Strike Force

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The United States and other non-European Union members of NATO sought assurances today that the European Union's decision to develop its own military arm will not eventually split the alliance.
At their year-end meeting, the NATO foreign ministers also condemned Russia for its military campaign in Chechnya. 
 And the European NATO members pressed the United States for more information on its plans for a missile defense system to guard against attacks by rogue states.
Much of the meeting, however, focused on the decision the 15 European Union countries made last week to give the body a military capability.
The Europeans want a military capability separate from NATO so they can respond to security crises that the United States wants to stay out of.
At their meeting last week, European Union leaders set a deadline of 2003 to develop a rapid-reaction corps of 50,000 to 60,000 troops.
The 19-nation NATO alliance generally approves of the plan, believing that anything that increases military power is good for NATO. The United States also accepts the idea. But there is concern in Washington that a European military arm could grow away from NATO, splitting the alliance.
Eight NATO members are not members of the European Union -- the United States, Canada, Turkey, Norway, Iceland, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Most of the non-European Union members from Europe are concerned that they could be left out of decision-making on European security.
Washington has been pressing the European allies to increase their military capabilities. The allies have declared their willingness to do so, but that has yet to be translated into expanded military budgets.
"Intentions are all very good, and new institutions are very useful, but it's results that count," said NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson.
Also today, European NATO members expressed concern about how they will be affected if the United States deploys the limited ballistic missile defense system it is now developing.
The United States has told its allies that with the new system, it would be just as ready to come to Europe's aid.

HEADLINE: Bucharest Journal;
A Glutton for Kitsch, Gorging Happily in Romania

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Dec. 13

 BODY:
What kind of man specializes in buying up the tchotchkes of a Stalinist dictator who was prevented only by an untimely rendezvous with a firing squad from holding the world's tackiest yard sale?
Well, the kind of man whose name is Dr. Kassem Nour of Orlando, Fla. Or Dr. Ru Ru of Bucharest, depending on which one of his business cards he hands you. 
 "Oh, I have more than one name," he says reassuringly, fishing out a second card when the first does not match the introduction.
Dr. Nour, or whatever, an affable man whose face can explode into a carnival-poster smile at the approach of a camera, claims to own a "Renoir that's not in any book" and to have drunk cheap wine with Salvador Dali, whose work he says he collected.
When asked where he is from, he goes a little vague and spins diverting family yarns. (His grandfather from Russia, a better-late-than-never type, married at 60, fathered 10 children by 96, died age 106. Car crash. No, he wasn't driving.)
Dr. Nour is still childless at 72, but evinces an obvious appreciation for the fabled beauty of Romanian women even during pauses while looking at the -- we will do best to call it "stuff." As he and his translator play chess with one of many hand-carved sets on sale, he makes a move: "I love Romanian girls! I love you!"
"I don't believe you," she replies, with a skepticism that sounds even better in a Transylvanian accent.
This past weekend saw the fourth of the continuing auctions of stuff that once belonged to Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, who ruled Romania from 1965 to 1989 with iron fists concealed in custom-made deerskin gloves. For a few of those years they were the darlings of the West for defying the Soviet Union over its invasion of Czechoslovakia, and they had the Buicks given them by President Nixon to prove it. (Not to mention a tie-tack key to Chattanooga, Tenn., inscribed "Pat Rose, Mayor.")
In their latter years, after a trip to North Korea, they became obsessed with building their cults of personality; they were barely literate but styled themselves the Great Builder and Hunter (he) and the Great Scientist (she) as well as the Beloved Comrades of the People. And they had all sorts of stuff to prove that: A yard-tall wooden amphora carved with their portraits, gift of a local party chapter. A microscope and a model of an atom from local schools, to aid Elena in her "research." A 9-inch model of an oil well's pressure valve. Rugs woven with their likenesses. (The editor of a political humor magazine bought one so his staff could tread on it.) Several sets of deer-butchering instruments with handles made of stag horn.
And a large set of cobalt blue china from Mikhail Gorbachev, of which Dr. Nour is the proud owner, for $320. He also wears Mr. Ceausescu's sealskin coat, his gray Italian woven leather shoes and his hats. "They fit perfectly -- his head is like my head," Dr. Nour said. "The only difference is mentality."
These first four auctions have raised almost $700,000 for the government.
Dr. Nour has bought about half the items. Asked about the source of his income, he says he gave up life as a surgeon -- "Where? Oh, I operate everywhere -- America, Middle East . . . " -- to make a fortune in marble and granite, and owns hotels in America and the Far East. He is a bit vague about his plans for his purchases: "I'm a collector. I love, I love, I enjoy. I'm planning to do a museum. They're more valuable if you keep them some time."
He seeks uniqueness first, but has an appraiser's eye: he knocked down his potential bid for the amphora (floor price $500) because it wasn't of one piece of wood. (It didn't sell.) He passed on a Belgian cut-crystal vase because nothing about it said "previously owned by tyrant." He bids higher if another household name is attached -- the mother-of-pearl table from Yasir Arafat, for example.
He ignored big items like the aging yacht Snagov 2, which seats 57 but has not been gassed up in a decade. And he was outbid for the 3,000-pound bronze bust of Nicolae. That went, for $26,000, to an American who would not disclose what he planned to do with it.
"Probably an American museum," said Monica Anghelovici, an economist for the state protocol administration who helps with the auctions because her English is fluent.
What American museum, for Pete's sake? she was asked.
"There are many wax museums in your country, so why should there not be bronze museums?" she said. "In America, in my opinion, anything is possible."
Since the Ceausescus had 41 residences to furnish, from ski dachas to palaces, nothing was too mundane for them to save. One item was described thus in the catalog: "Round bowls of black plastic, painted, with the inscription Niagara Falls." They sold for $17. Average Romanians refer to the collection in terms that would once have sent them to labor camps. But it was Miss Anghelovici who delivered the most damning assessment: "In my opinion, a man receives a gift as he is. I give something special to someone who is special. And I give something stupid to someone I don't care."
Why, she was asked, in this era of $30 million paintings wasn't this sale entrusted to Sotheby's or Christie's, which are used to moving hundreds of items quickly and could probably round up more bidders than will trek to Bucharest? After all, Dr. Nour may be one of a kind, but the collecting mania draws all types.
(In the interests of full disclosure, it must be noted here that this reporter unexpectedly discovered that he is one of those types, and is now the dubiously proud owner of an engraved ceremonial ax and the aforementioned oil-well thingy.)
"I don't know," Miss Anghelovici replied. "We didn't think of it. The government decides, and we just do what we are told."
Sic semper tyrannis, even in yard sales. And only 7,000 items left to go.

HEADLINE: Where the Risk Is Riskier Yet;
A New Breed of Venture Capitalist Scouts Latin America

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Upon arriving in the big Amazon port of Belem several months ago, Patricia Moles, the manager of a venture-capital fund, was faced with an unusual investment-related decision: whether to continue by boat to the hearts-of-palm plantation in which her fund was hoping to acquire a minority stake, a trip that would take 12 hours, or to rent a propeller plane.
"Time was a must so I chose the plane," said Ms. Moles, 33, a native of Mexico, whose Brazil-based employer, Banco Axial, looks for investments in environmentally friendly companies. Although her trip was off the beaten track of the briefcase bankers who stick to financial centers like Sao Paulo, it was indicative of a new investment trend that is sweeping Latin America. 
 Venture capitalists are searching the region for opportunities in young companies, much as they have been doing in Silicon Valley.
Many of these financiers like the challenge of nontraditional investments -- organically produced hearts of palm, for example, grown from custom-selected and -germinated seeds that generate a continuing supply of palm stems.
Yet most venture capitalists investing in companies with a Latin American focus, like those providing seed money to ventures in the United States, are seeking out high technology -- particularly Internet-related companies.
The quest is complicated by the often precarious nature of Latin American economies as well as the relative lack of advanced technology, along with the generally frenetic nature of the young Internet industry.
The growth of venture-capital investing is part of the wider trend of private equity investors focusing on Latin America, a huge market. Though the region has quickly embraced the Internet, it still has a long way to go in terms of wealth and technology to catch up with the richest industrial nations.
Unlike earlier waves of investment, most of which came from abroad or were state-sponsored, the venture-capital investments of the last few years have pitted some of Latin America's richest people against foreigners, particularly from the United States.
Among the Latin Americans are Juan Navarro, president of the Exxel Group, one of Argentina's largest privately owned companies; Jorge Paulo Lemann, founder of Garantia, a big Brazilian investment bank now owned by the Credit Suisse Group, and Carlos Slim Helu, chairman of Telefonos de Mexico. Then there are the people who work for, or are partners in the venture-capital funds controlled by these investors.
Antonio Bonchristiano is an example of this new breed. Six months ago, Mr. Bonchristiano, 32, was a partner in a fund that is part of GP Investimentos, an investment group based here, whose owners include Mr. Lemann. His task was to seek out an appealing Brazilian Internet company and buy it.
What he came up with was BookNet, an online bookseller similar to Amazon.com, and GP acquired a controlling stake. In something of an unusual twist, Mr. Bonchristiano became the company's chief executive, switching roles from venture capitalist to entrepreneur. Using his knowledge of the game, he then went to New York to drum up additional money, and returned with $14.3 million from firms like Warburg Pincus and individual investors like Henry R. Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
BookNet was renamed Submarino, and now the company's headquarters here is brimming with 50 employees working 14-hour days and relieving stress at a couple of pinball and foosball machines. The company has opened offices in Spain, Argentina and Mexico, and aims to become the leading online shopping destination in the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking world.
"This is dreamlike for me as a Brazilian," Mr. Bonchristiano said in English polished during his undergraduate years at Oxford. "Brazil was colonized for so long, either economically, intellectually or technologically, and the Internet is changing that. With new access to investment and technology, the playing field is leveled."
Latin America's capitalist structures are still considered relatively backward, though. Domestic stock markets are riddled with labyrinthine regulations that make it hard to buy or sell securities. And some investors, including Dennis Rodrigues, a partner in the Sao Paulo-based firm FIR Capital, see the evolution of domestic capital markets as the key to the success of venture-capital investing in Latin America.
But other investors, as well as many entrepreneurs, are drawn by the possibility of leapfrogging local exchanges and listing their companies on markets in the United States, nearly always Nasdaq, hoping for some of the paper wealth made possible by a market fascinated with dot-coms.
Going public on Nasdaq is a lot easier with help from people who have generous sources of capital and who also know the American regulatory environment. That is where venture capitalists from the United States come in. Among the most active of these is Chase Capital Partners, part of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
Together with Flatiron Partners of New York, Chase Capital Partners has invested in five Internet companies that focus on Latin America. The largest, StarMedia Network, a New York-based portal company for Spanish and Portuguese speakers worldwide that also provides Internet access in some Latin American countries, has been its biggest success so far. After StarMedia went public earlier this year, the initial investment by Chase and Flatiron of $29 million grew to well over $300 million.
While some venture operations, like GP Investimentos, often seek to acquire control of companies, others, including Chase, have invested in Latin America in a way that is closer to the traditional Silicon Valley model of providing seed capital to small companies that then proceed through several rounds of financing before going public. Usually, this model involves the purchase of a minority stake in the company, through which management direction is provided but not dictated.
"Being a venture capitalist in Latin America largely involves adapting what has worked in the United States to what is realistic in countries like Mexico and Brazil," said Susan Segal, head of Latin American operations for Chase Capital Partners.
E-commerce, for instance, is as strong a lure in the region as it is in the United States, and has accounted for some of Chase's bets -- like its recent investment in Mercado Livre, an Internet company hoping to reproduce online some of the fervor of a boisterous open-air market. The Boston Consulting Group estimates that revenue from electronic commerce in Latin America will grow to $3.8 billion in 2003 from $167 million this year.
Yet while most signs point to the growth of purchases over the Internet, and of Latin American Internet use in general, obstacles to such rosy outcomes remain. According to a report by the International Data Corporation, weak credit card processing operations, the high cost of basic Internet service and precarious and costly shipping networks will inhibit the spread of e-commerce.
And the use of computers and even telephones in the region is still relatively low, a limiting factor for all Internet businesses. For instance, in Brazil, Latin America's largest country, there are an estimated 12 telephone lines for each 100 people, compared with more than 50 lines for every 100 people in the United States.
And the entrepreneurial culture that speeds the creation of start-ups in the United States is different in Latin America. "Some entrepreneurs that are used to sealing deals with a handshake don't realize that a lot of rigorous detail is needed to put together a venture-capital deal," said Lisa Krochmal, a lawyer in the Buenos Aires office of Morrison & Foerster, an American firm active in new technology deals.
Another concern is the erratic nature of the Internet industry itself. As in the United States, most young Internet companies in Latin America lose money. This, coupled with the boom-and-bust cycles of Latin American economies, makes some investors wary of betting on the region's young companies.
"A lot of people are going to get burned when they realize that transforming an interesting idea in Brazil into a stock appealing to retail investors in the U.S. is no piece of cake," Mr. Rodrigues of FIR Capital said.
Still, where some people see obstacles, others see opportunities -- opportunities that require capital to realize.
Aiming to bring Internet access to people without a phone or a computer, an American, Terrence Danial, helped found NetKiosk, a Buenos Aires-based company that sells stand-alone units equipped with a PC that allows users to surf the Net for a fee. In addition to sales of the units, which are put in places like hotel lobbies, NetKiosk hopes to gain revenue from selling advertising that appears on the units as well as on the company's portal page. But NetKiosk has had trouble attracting seed money.
"In my view, venture capital in Latin America still has a long way to go," said Mr. Danial, adding that the seed-money industry is not as well developed in the region as it is in the United States and that potential backers are often warier of taking risks. "A lot of investors are still seeing things from traditional business mind-sets," he said.

HEADLINE: THE ISRAEL-SYRIA TALKS: THE OVERVIEW;
SYRIA AND ISRAEL BEGIN PEACE TALKS AFTER 4-YEAR HALT

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Israel and Syria today resumed peace negotiations that stalled nearly four years ago, with the modest goal of surviving two days of breaking the ice in a relationship long frozen by mutual mistrust. That goal appeared likely to be met.
As the day kicked off in a small ceremony in the Rose Garden, it carried the makings of a historic moment, with Israel and Syria standing resolutely on the brink of a new dialogue that could spell the end of a decades-long conflict. The mood quickly soured when the Syrians publicly reiterated well-worn grievances against the Israelis, signaling just how rocky the road ahead may be, but later, behind closed doors, the mood apparently sweetened once more. 
 Today did begin the highest-level Israeli-Syrian talks to date, what President Clinton called "a big step along the path" to peace. First at the White House, then at Blair House, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel met with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria under the auspices of Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
The face-to-face encounter sent a clear signal of intentions as both sides approached the negotiating table with a determination to see things through to an eventual accord. A firm desire to make peace was voiced by both sides, and Mr. Clinton urged them to seize the moment and present him by Thursday with an itinerary for their peacemaking, a senior administration official said.
By late tonight, an Israeli official reported, Mr. Barak was in good spirits, indicating that the atmosphere at the negotiations had been positive and productive, and that both sides seemed willing to go forward.
Early this morning it was almost startling to see the Israeli and Syrian officials file out and take their places side by side in the wet grass behind the White House this morning. One senior Israeli official chatted amiably with one of the Syrians, as if small talk between the two sides were an everyday occurrence.
Then Mr. Barak, Mr. Shara and Mr. Clinton marched out in their somber suits and did a little shuffle. Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara apparently reversed their assigned positions alongside Mr. Clinton, until Mr. Barak said, with a fleeting smile, "I think we have to change," and they did.
From there on, it was downhill, an inauspicious start. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Barak did as planned, giving short, idealistic speeches about the desire for peace and the difficulty of securing it. Mr. Shara, on the other hand, launched into a substantial summary of Syria's grievances.
He cleared his throat, and took advantage of a rare platform. Making excuses for speaking at relative length on such a cold day, Mr. Shara argued that the Israeli occupation was the root of all misery, not just Syrian misery but Israeli misery as well.
"It goes without saying that peace for Syria means the return of all its occupied land," he said, "while for Israel, peace will mean the end of the psychological fear that the Israelis have been living in as a result of the existence of occupation, which is undoubtedly the source of all adversities and wars."
As Mr. Shara spoke those words, Mr. Barak clasped his hands, pursed his lips and stared forward without expression. American officials shifted uneasily from foot to foot. A senior Israeli official later said the Israelis were upset by Mr. Shara's nonconciliatory tone, which quickly and jarringly broke the mood.
Mr. Clinton had talked broadly and hopefully, pronouncing this a juncture unlike any other in the long Israeli-Arab peacemaking effort. "For the first time in history, there is a chance of a comprehensive peace between Israel and Syria, and, indeed, all its neighbors," he said.
He praised the resolve of both Mr. Barak, whom he called "an exceptional hero in war" who is now "a determined soldier for peace," and President Hafez el-Assad of Syria, who also "has known the cost of war." Without such adornments, he referred to Mr. Shara as "an able representative" of his people.
Then, very succinctly, Mr. Barak reiterated his broad intentions in pursuing peace, making a point to refer to the Syrians as "our partners."
"We came here to put behind us the horrors of war and to step forward toward peace," he said in a three-sentence statement.
Mr. Shara, though, refused to be stage-managed. He spoke with apparent awareness of his audience at home and throughout the Arab world. He gave the impression that he could not let himself be manipulated by the Israeli and the Americans into performing on cue, not as he was entering negotiations in which Syria would take the exceptional step of accepting the permanence of the Jewish homeland.
He proclaimed that now as ever before, all Syria wanted was to reclaim "all its occupied land," that is, the Golan Heights, the strategic plateau that Israel seized during the 1967 war. He criticized the media at large for portraying Syria as "the aggressor," the one "who shelled settlements from the Golan prior to the 1967 war.
"These claims carry no grain of truth," he said, taking the inflammatory step of citing the memoirs of Moshe Dayan, the legendary Israeli general, as proof: "As Moshe Dayan himself explained in his memoirs, it was the other side who insisted on provoking the Syrians until they clashed together and then they claimed that the Syrians are the aggressors."
Mr. Shara also made it clear that the Syrians still wanted to pick up negotiations where they felt they had been broken off in 1996. The Syrians maintain that Yitzhak Rabin, the late Israeli prime minister, had promised that Israel would withdraw from the full Golan Heights, down to the border of June 4, 1967.
That, in the Syrians' interpretation, extended to the shoreline of the Sea of Galilee. The Israelis deny that this promise was ever made, and dispute the interpretation of the border.
"If these talks are to succeed as rapidly as we all desire, no one should ignore what has been achieved until now," he said.
At the same time, Mr. Shara did embrace the idealism of peace, which he said could not only end violence in the region but also "usher in a dialogue of civilization and honorable competition in various domains -- the political, cultural, scientific and economic."
And he also posed an intellectual question, as if he were already reflecting backward from the vantage point of a resolved conflict: Would the Israeli-Arab conflict be what "defined" or "frustrated" Arab unity?
In Israeli-Arab peace negotiations, there is often a good deal of public posturing aimed at the audiences back home. Sometimes, belligerent words mask real progress at the table.
Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara met for a total of just under two hours, but never, as had been expected, without the Americans present. They started in a trilateral meeting with Mr. Clinton in the Oval Office, picking up again in a three-way meeting with Ms. Albright. The Israelis and the Syrians agreed to let the White House speak publicly about the very sensitive talks so as not to harm whatever progress was made with public comments.
Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said that in the meeting with Mr. Clinton, both sides "raised their positions and concerns while acknowledging that the other side's concerns needed to be addressed."
"Both parties displayed a serious intent," he said.

HEADLINE: Fund to Help Save Open Space in New Jersey

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Seeking to stem the loss of undeveloped land to suburban growth in the Northeast, the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation will give $14 million to projects protecting fields, marshes and forests in New Jersey and Rhode Island, the most densely populated states in the country, foundation officials said yesterday.
Most of the money, $8.4 million, will be used over the next four years to help private conservation groups buy at least 10,000 acres of land or restrictive easements in parts of central and northern New Jersey where construction threatens two important ecosystems: the Pine Barrens and the ridge of highlands that is the state's western backbone, foundation officials said. 
 They said $950,000 would be given over the same period to two private groups in New Jersey working to strengthen local land trusts and promote land-use planning by local governments that focuses not just on economic growth but also on protecting wetlands and other fragile habitats.
A similar package of grants, totaling $4.7 million, is being made to private groups in Rhode Island, said Peter Howell, the director of environmental programs for the foundation.
The $1.5 billion foundation, based in Manhattan, was established in 1997 by the estate of Ms. Duke to protect the environment and support the arts and medical research.
The $8.4 million for land protection in New Jersey will be split over the next four years between the Nature Conservancy and the Trust for Public Land, two national conservation groups. The grants are contingent on the groups' raising at least $4 in public and private money for each dollar from the Duke foundation, Mr. Howell said.
Yesterday, representatives of the two groups said they were confident that the prospect of the Duke foundation money would make it easier to raise the rest.
Rose Harvey, the senior vice president of the Trust for Public Land, said the extra money would come from other private donors, from New Jersey's recent bond act for protecting open space and from local taxes intended to preserve green tracts in crowded communities.
"This commitment of private funds is a great example and will leverage many more dollars," Ms. Harvey said.
She added that the need to protect land was greater than ever. Housing construction, she said, is threatening the northern Pine Barrens -- a patchwork of stream-laced woods full of rare species -- and spreading up the ridge of rugged hills, west of the state's coastal plain, that forms a green bridge linking many parks and sheltering many species.
The announcement by the Duke foundation was welcomed by environmental groups around the metropolitan region, mainly because it would provide a spur to land preservation in a state that has not seen many large gifts from philanthropists intended for environmental protection, particularly compared with New York.
Just a few dozen miles to the east, in the Hudson River Valley, for example, more than $125 million has been spent over the last decade on preserving land by a single foundation, the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for the Hudson Highlands.
"It's great to see this commitment to New Jersey," said Joe Martens, the president of the Open Space Institute, one of two groups that are conduits for the Wallace fund money, which can be spent only in New York State.
He said the Duke foundation appeared to be establishing a long-term commitment to the region, with the new grants following its gift of $5 million in 1997 to secure the purchase of Sterling Forest, a 16,000-acre wooded tract straddling the New York-New Jersey border.
"The amount of money necessary to curb sprawl and encourage good land use is in short supply," Mr. Martens said, "particularly in places where development is heaviest and land prices are the highest."

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY;
A Lack of Charisma Hurts Devils at Gate

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe 

 BODY:
Rainwater dripped through a hole in the roof at Continental Arena when the Devils played the Los Angeles Kings on Tuesday night. This is the first known leak in the 13-year administration of General Manager Lou Lamoriello.
It created a few puddles in the higher elevations, but no fans got wet. Only 10,807 of them were sprinkled around a building that seats 19,040. For a game between two of the best teams in the National Hockey League, it was the smallest Devils home crowd of the season. 
 This type of scene is becoming commonplace in too many National Hockey League rinks. You expect crowds such as the 6,526 the Islanders drew Tuesday night for Edmonton, because the Long Island franchise is held hostage by miserly owners who run it like Baltic Avenue on the Monopoly board. But the Devils are a better operation.
Their general manager may be tight-fisted and their coach may be tight-lipped, but the players perform in a more freewheeling style than they did in the Jacques Lemaire era. When the Devils swamped the Kings by 7-1 Tuesday night, the building was so empty in the third period that you could hear Coach Robbie Ftorek yelling at the referee. At least he opens up to somebody.
According to the N.H.L., attendance is down, leaguewide, an average of only 32 fans a game, from 16,097 to 16,065. But it has dropped in the Meadowlands from 16,382 to 14,236. Blocks of tickets are available in fancy new arenas in Montreal and Anaheim, which used to sell out in recent seasons. New buildings in Los Angeles and Carolina are rarely filled. All this in an era of economic prosperity. What would happen in a recession?
"I was worried when I was driving to the game with Marty," said Bobby Holik, referring to the Devils' goalie, Martin Brodeur. "I was saying 'We'll be lucky if we break double digits in thousands.' I guess we barely did. All the players can do is play the way we did tonight. That's our part. The rest is up to people in charge of marketing this sport."
Holik spoke in a postgame locker space that was quieter than most losing rooms. No music or chatter could be heard, the way it usually is when hockey teams win. Most Devils stayed apart from the news media in a private lounge. When requested, they came one by one to scrums with reporters.
Some Devils, such as Holik and Ken Daneyko, are verbose and opinionated. Most are polite. But some offer little more than name, rank, uniform number and platitudes. Unlike most Rangers, many Devils are homegrown, raised in franchise ways since their draft days. They know the corporate personality, which is taciturn.
The worst is Ftorek, in his second season as head coach after a long apprenticeship. Ftorek wounds the pride of raw rookies and respected veterans with surprise benchings, sometimes without communication, just so they don't get too big for their britches. Around the news media, you get the feeling Ftorek would be happy if the press box were as empty as the grandstands.
After a romp like Tuesday night's, his postgame briefing was tense, terse and chilly. He revealed that "the game is 60 minutes long." When someone offered him a chance to praise the play of Brodeur at a pivotal point of the game, Ftorek began with a pained sigh and responded, "That's a hypothetical," and added little more.
"Anything else?" Ftorek wanted to know after a couple minutes. Yes, there were a few other questions.
"Apart from the win, what do you take out of this game as the best thing?" someone asked. "I just like the 2 points," Ftorek said.
With all the depth of the roster, someone asked about tough decisions on who to sit out. "Sometimes they are, sometimes they are not," he said, elaborating only slightly with a few empty phrases.
Another voice urged Ftorek to discuss the improvement in the penalty killing. "I don't know," Ftorek said. "You'd have to look at the statistics."
They were trying to get him to praise and promote his team and he acted as if they were auditors questioning his tax return. Ftorek's dialogue with the news media is more contentious than Mike and the Mad Dog on sportstalk radio. (Speaking of WFAN: On most days you can listen for hours and the only reference to hockey, aside from the scores, is from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, in a paid commercial, urging fans to go to Devils games.)
Last spring, in his first postseason with the Devils, Ftorek's tension was palpable and part of the reason his team left the playoffs after one round. Now, in December, with a half-empty building, after an impressive victory, he acted as if promoting his sport was a time-consuming irritation, such as getting a vehicle inspection in the Garden State.
Ftorek is a hockey lifer, smart and dedicated, but lacking a certain stage presence. Perhaps this coach and his bosses should heed the message from the sound of 8,233 empty seats.
