HEADLINE: Silk Stocking's Mystery Hole;
Owner's Demands Keep Prime Manhattan Site Empty

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
For seven years, the dingy, vacant department store loomed over one of the wealthiest neighborhoods in the city like a dark cloud.
In recent months, the huge hulk at Lexington and 59th Street that was once an Alexander's has become a giant hole in the ground. But speculation about the block continues by everyone from the local community board to City Hall because no one knows exactly what is going in the hole and when. 
 Steven Roth, the onetime strip-mall king who controls the property, has wanted to build a magnificent 70-story tower on the site for much of the 1990's. But since 1993, he has gone through four architects and an equal number of possible tenants, including Sotheby's, Christie's, Nordstrom and Ritz-Carlton.
Mr. Roth, who is the largest commercial landlord in Manhattan, has been negotiating with yet another possible tenant, Bloomberg, the financial information services company, for nearly a year. But many people who know him say that Mr. Roth, one of the shrewdest real estate investors in the country, may miss out on the current economic boom because of uncharacteristic indecision.
"Steve is a great friend, but for some reason, he hasn't wanted to push the development forward," said Donald J. Trump, the developer who once wrestled with Mr. Roth for control of the Alexander's chain. "Only Steve knows why. But at some point, the cycle will change and he'll have a nice piece of vacant land."
Mr. Roth, a compact, silver-haired man who relishes a blunt-spoken, tough-guy image, is chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, a publicly traded company valued by Wall Street at $2.7 billion. The company owns 23 buildings and more than 14 million square feet of office space in Manhattan, including One Penn Plaza.
Mr. Roth is also chairman of Alexander's Inc., which owns the two-acre property bounded by Lexington and Third Avenues, 58th and 59th Streets. Most people in the Silk Stocking neighborhood considered the empty six-story building a blight, yet developers and city officials said the parcel, across the street from Bloomingdale's, is one of the most valuable in Manhattan.
"It's a prime location, suitable for just about anything," said Edward Rubin, a member of Community Board 6.
According to those who know him, Mr. Roth has taken a keen personal interest in the property, his first construction project in Manhattan. He is also said to be a fierce competitor and does not like to lose a single round, whether it is at the negotiating table or on the golf course. According to one friend, Mr. Roth was only half kidding when he offered his golf instructor a small shopping center if he could help Mr. Roth reduce his handicap.
Mr. Roth is known as a smart investor and a savvy financier rather than a bricks-and-mortar developer, and real estate executives say he may be afraid of making a mistake. At the same time, he does not want anything less than the richest, most lucrative deal with a tenant. As a result, he has failed to sign one up for the constantly evolving project, leading one executive who knows Mr. Roth well to describe him as "the Hamlet of Lexington Avenue."
"He's smart enough to know that he's entered a realm in which he's not the master," said one prominent real estate broker who has worked closely with Mr. Ross. "There are so many ways to do this project wrong. And no developer starts out by developing a square block in Manhattan."
The broker said Mr. Roth had been unwilling to cede any control to a partner, or to cut a deal with prime tenants. "This is also a guy who can't commit because he is so afraid of leaving a penny on the table," the broker said.
David Mandelbaum, a wealthy New Jersey lawyer who helped Mr. Roth get started in business in 1968 and is now a director of Alexander's, dismissed the criticism, saying that the property has more than doubled in value over the years. In any event, he said, the project is moving forward now.
"It's happening," Mr. Mandelbaum said. "The hole's getting deeper. Steve's a real estate genius; there's no two ways about it. He was better off waiting."
And Wall Street does not mind that Mr. Roth is taking his time.
"He's a brilliant guy, the largest commercial landlord in Manhattan," said Jonathan Litt, a stock analyst with PaineWebber. "He will experience phenomenal growth as rents roll up. You almost don't care about Alexander's."
But for those who do, Mr. Roth is still mum about what he is planning for the site. He declined to be interviewed and few of his friends or critics were willing to discuss him or the project for the record, either because they do business together or want to do business with him. Mr. Roth has also not discussed his plans with city officials or the community board.
Contractors demolished the old six-story department store building earlier this year and halted work. Then, Joseph Rose, chairman of the city's planning department, announced plans to overhaul the zoning code and impose restrictions on building heights. (Those plans were unveiled last week.)
Mr. Roth quickly obtained an excavation permit and moved to build a foundation for a tower while the site is still subject to the old zoning code. Mr. Roth wants an 800-foot tower, according to executives involved with the project. If he had waited until next summer when the zoning proposal is expected to be adopted, the building would have been cut to 495 feet. "There's no doubt in my mind he will have a foundation in the ground before that law passes," Mr. Litt said. "He's too smart to lose that scale."
The 1.2-million-square-foot project would mix about 200,000 square feet of stores with office space, a hotel and luxury condominiums, according to real estate executives who have talked to Mr. Roth. But the plans are not final, said one person involved in the project, "because the building changes shape depending on which piece is largest."
Cesar Pelli, the architect who designed the world's tallest buildings, the Petronas Towers in Malaysia, has drawn plans for a 64-story tower, as well as a taller skyscraper, according to brokers who have talked to Mr. Roth and several people involved in the project. Mr. Pelli succeeded Sir Norman Foster, Gary Handel of Millennium Partners and the architects at Beyer Blinder Belle, all of whom worked on sketches at one time or another.
Mr. Roth has had substantive discussions with the owners of the Savoy hotel group of London, according to an executive with the hoteliers. And Hennes & Mauritz, the Swedish clothing retailer, has agreed to open a 40,000-square-foot store if the tower is built. But that may not be enough to get such a large building -- one slightly smaller than the General Electric Building at Rockefeller Center -- off the ground. Some brokers also question whether condominium prices will still be soaring three years from now, when the new tower would open.
Mr. Roth has also been meeting with Bloomberg for a year about leasing 400,000 square feet in the tower. But Bloomberg is frustrated with Mr. Roth's rent demands, according to real estate executives, and recently began exploring another option: expanding its current headquarters at Park Avenue, and in the adjacent building at 110 East 59th Street. Talks with Mr. Roth, however, continued last week.
"You can't get every last ounce of blood," said one executive who has negotiated recently with Mr. Roth, echoing a half-dozen others. "It's very hard to live that way."
Mr. Roth first gained control of the ailing Alexander's chain in 1991. He took the company into bankruptcy court, closed the stores and turned it into a real estate operation, much as he did with the Two Guys discount chain a decade earlier.
Mr. Roth met with the Milsteins, the Roses, the Resnicks and other major real estate families in New York in the hopes of finding a partner who had the expertise to develop the Alexander's site. But after hearing his complex financial plan, the families turned him down.
Mr. Roth then spent nearly two years with Sotheby's on a plan to move the auction house into a new home in the existing department store building, while he built an apartment tower overhead. But when Mr. Roth's ideas for the project changed, he dumped Sotheby's, and by December 1995 he was close to signing a deal with the auction house's biggest rival, Christie's. He also talked about buying Millennium Partners to act as his developer.
But neither happened. A frustrated Christie's decided to move to Rockefeller Center.
After losing a bid to buy the Coliseum property at Columbus Circle last year, Mr. Roth nearly formed a joint venture with Millennium Partners, which had a deal with the Ritz-Carlton hotel chain and Reebok sports club for the site. Once again, Mr. Roth pulled out at the last minute, wanting to do the project on his own. Vornado, however, did recently hire a headhunter to find a director of development for the company, said executives contacted by the firm.
In the meantime, Mr. Roth spent more than $2 billion buying office buildings in Manhattan and transforming Vornado, which had been focused on far less glamorous suburban shopping centers.
More recently, the Nordstrom department store chain, which has long sought a home in Manhattan, tried to strike a deal with Mr. Roth. The retailers expected Mr. Roth to compromise on the rent in exchange for landing an upscale anchor tenant.
During the negotiations, said one person involved in the talks, "Steve liked to begin by saying, 'Your worst nightmare just walked into the room.' He loves to play Mr. Tough Guy. But they were very far apart on the numbers." Nordstrom is now talking to the developer Douglas Durst about his proposed tower at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas.
Mr. Rubin, the community board member who has been watching from the sidelines, asked whether Mr. Roth wasn't his own worst enemy here: "He's a smart guy, but isn't he going to miss the market if he doesn't get his act together?"

HEADLINE: Manufacturers' Output Grew by 0.3% in November, Fed Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The nation's industrial output edged up 0.3 percent in November, indicating that the economy is heading into the new year on solid footing, government figures showed today.
Gains were widespread except for utilities, where output fell, the Federal Reserve Board said. Unusually warm weather last month depressed demand for electricity and natural gas. 
 Industrial production was 4.3 percent higher than in November 1998.
"That is indicative of a solid manufacturing base, which is what the economy is looking for as it approaches the end of the year and heads into a new millennium," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at the Argus Research Corporation.
Because of concerns about the Year 2000 computer changeover, many economists have said they expect the Fed to leave interest rates unchanged when policy makers meet next week.
Having raised interest rates three times this year to slow the economy and keep inflation under control, the Fed will, however, probably raise rates again in February or March because the economy is still growing at a pace that could set off inflation down the road, economists said.
The advance in industrial output, which was in line with many economists' forecasts, followed a surge of 0.8 percent in October.
Output at factories rose by a strong 0.5 percent in November. "Manufacturing's growth continues unabated and looks strong as we think about next year," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Operating capacity held steady at 81 percent, the same as in October, well below levels associated with a pickup in inflation, economists said.
Generally, an operating capacity of 84 percent would alarm economists, indicating that factories just cannot produce fast enough -- which could lead to price increases.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that stockpiles of goods rose 0.2 percent in October, to $1.26 trillion, an increase that was smaller than expected and represents the slowest growth since April. The increase in September was 0.4 percent.
Inventories rose 0.3 percent at wholesalers and at factories but were flat at retailers.
Some economists said the inventory numbers suggested that companies were having trouble keeping up with strong sales.

HEADLINE: Wall Street's Embrace of Diversity Lauded Despite Its Poor Record

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Despite their poor track record on hiring and promoting women and minorities, firms on Wall Street deserve credit for having started to embrace diversity, a study from the United States Commission on Civil Rights stated.
"The numbers show a dismal lack of progress," said Mary Frances Berry, chairwoman of the commission. "It is still true that white males dominate the most remunerative jobs and opportunities on Wall Street. But I cannot infer, legally, that anybody has been discriminated against." 
 Rather than dwell on those statistics, the commission applauded the efforts of some firms -- Citigroup, Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company -- to recruit more women and minorities and to consider them for promotion to high-paying jobs, Ms. Berry said, summarizing the conclusions of the commission's study of economic opportunities in New York.
The report on Wall Street grew out of hearings the commission held four years ago, Ms. Berry said. The commission gathered employment data from the firms after those hearings, and again a few years later, she said.
"However slowly, change is occurring," she said. "By and large, the message is that things are a lot better than they used to be but not as good as they should be."
The firms accepted the report with a degree of relief in the wake of several lawsuits that have contended that Wall Street firms have systematically discriminated against women. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is reviewing hiring and pay data from Morgan Stanley, after a bond saleswoman at the firm claimed that she was denied a promotion because of her sex.
A spokesman for the Securities Industry Association, a Wall Street trade group, declined to comment yesterday.
But, in a prepared statement sent to firms, the group's president, Marc Lackritz, said, "As the report notes, we have already made significant progress in these areas."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: THE OVERVIEW;
Transit Pact Raises Pay by 18% And May Influence Other Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The tentative contract that the transit workers union reached early yesterday would effectively increase pay by more than 18 percent over three years, giving subway and bus workers the largest annual raises received by any of New York City's public-employee unions in more than a decade.
The agreement enabled Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to declare victory over transit workers who favored a strike. But the contract's sizable pay increases could create problems for the city in next year's bargaining with unions representing 300,000 municipal workers, although the mayor insisted that the transit contract would have no influence on the talks. 
 The deal reached with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority just minutes after a threatened midnight strike deadline averted a much-feared walkout and allowed the city to return to normal yesterday, except for a few disruptions during the morning rush hour. A strike would have left the 3.5 million riders who use the transit system every day scrambling to find other means of transportation.
With the agreement giving transit workers a 7 percent compensation increase on average in the first year, union leaders immediately said it would at a minimum influence the city's contract negotiations and might serve as a model.
After accounting for inflation, several union officials said it was easily the most generous contract involving city workers since the early 1980's, except for a tentative contract reached yesterday for the city's school principals. That one-of-a-kind deal awards a 33 percent pay increase in exchange for the principals' giving up tenure and working longer hours.
Several labor experts said the transit workers' contract could signal a pendulum swing, bringing substantial raises for public-employee unions in an era of budget surpluses and economic boom. This would follow eight years of lean times and deficits when these unions accepted concessions, pay freezes and modest raises.
Officials of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union said they would begin mailing ratification ballots to members this week, with the outcome announced in the second half of January. But several leaders of a militant dissident faction said they would campaign hard for rejection because, in their view, the contract was not generous enough and contained concessions on work rules.
The agreement, reached at 1 a.m. yesterday after five days of negotiations, includes an increase in base wages of 5 percent in the first year, 3 percent in the second and 4 percent in the third, for a total increase of about 12.5 percent. It would raise the average salary for a transit worker over the three years to nearly $44,000 from the current $39,000.
The deal also provides for a further increase in paychecks -- amounting to more than 6 percent over three years -- by allowing workers to greatly reduce their pension contributions.
Several labor experts said the overall package would increase New York City Transit's labor costs by slightly more than 20 percent if the M.T.A.'s increased contributions for health coverage were included with the cost of the wage and pension changes.
"They came out with a much better contract than anybody thought they'd get," said Denis M. Hughes, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Whenever there is a contract agreement that is this prominent, the amount they get, the 4 or 5 percent, becomes the minimum of what other unions want to accept. It sets the tone."
At a morning news conference, Mr. Giuliani praised the union leaders for deciding not to strike, but he took pains to argue that the contract agreement would have no influence on the city's labor negotiations.
"It's not our settlement," Mr. Giuliani said. "The Transit Authority is a state agency, not a city agency."
Anticipating that other unions would look to the transit workers' contract as a model, he warned municipal labor leaders that he would not accept a similar contract.
"The overall percentages would be much too high for the city and it would cause significant deficits that would add to a deficit the city already has in out years," he said. "Whatever pattern is set is one for the state to have to deal with. It has nothing to do with us."
Tom Kelly, an M.T.A. spokesman, said the authority's top negotiators, after being up most of the night, were not available for interviews yesterday. M.T.A. officials said on Tuesday that they could afford the wage increases included in the accord, adding that they had achieved their chief goal of getting the union to agree to more flexible work rules that would help hold down costs.
For example, union rules that limit certain bus mechanics to engine work will be loosened so that they can also do chassis or brake repairs.
The union's executive board approved the deal in a close partisan vote, despite the pact's sizable wage increases, shortly before dawn yesterday, after the union's exhausted negotiators explained the details to the board. The vote was 25 to 20 for the agreement, with 1 abstention.
The union's militant New Directions faction, which had pushed for a strike, holds 22 of the board's 46 seats and voted almost unanimously against the agreement, calling it a sellout by the union's leadership. One of its board members voted for the contract and one abstained.
"There's a good chance that this contract will be defeated," said Tim Schermerhorn, a New Directions leader, who narrowly lost a race for the union's presidency last year. "People will be unhappy with the raises. The givebacks will kill it."
At his news conference, Mr. Giuliani continued to take a hard line against New Directions, calling its leaders irresponsible agitators and threatening to have the group's members arrested if they continued calling for a strike.
About 300 New Directions members marched across the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon, urging rejection of the contract and the impeachment of Mr. Giuliani, who obtained a court injunction that threatened union members with millions of dollars in fines if they went on strike. The New Directions marchers refrained from calling for a strike.
Arthur Schwartz, a New Directions lawyer, asked Justice Michael L. Pesce of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to vacate his Tuesday injunction, arguing that it violated union members' First Amendment rights by barring them from speaking in favor of a strike.
Justice Pesce affirmed his order. Later, Mr. Schwartz appealed to Justice Guy J. Mangano of New York State Second Appellate Division to stay the order, but he refused.
Mr. Giuliani said a suspicious package that looked like a bomb was placed in a tunnel near New York City Transit's Brooklyn headquarters and caused delays of more than an hour on the A line shortly after 8 a.m.
The mayor denounced any labor-related disruptions and said he would seek heavy fines against any union member who violated the court order against disrupting service.
Albert O'Leary, a transit authority spokesman, said efforts to help a sick passenger, and not labor problems, caused major delays yesterday morning near Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn on the 2, 3, 4 and 5 trains.
"It was a normal day in the New York City subways," he said.
In the labor agreement, the M.T.A. pledged to back state legislation to reduce the transit workers' pension burden. Workers now paying 5.3 percent of their wages toward their pensions would have to pay only 2 percent, while another tier of workers paying 3 percent of wages in pension contributions would also pay 2 percent.
For many workers, this would mean that in the first year, their paychecks would increase by 8.3 percent -- a 5 percent raise and a 3.3 percent reduction in pension contributions.
Nonetheless, some workers voiced disappointment that the increase in base wages did not average more than 4 percent a year. Zulma Figueroa, a subway station agent in the Bronx, said: "I was rooting for 5-5-5, but this is not bad. I'm happy today. I'm happy we didn't go on strike."
Municipal labor leaders said they were impressed by the contract negotiated by Willie James, president of the transit workers union.
"It's a pretty healthy settlement," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers. "It's interesting that the mayor distanced himself from it and said it has no impact. Obviously, every settlement in and around the metropolitan area is going to have an impact on our negotiations, and to say otherwise is ludicrous."
Lee Saunders, the director of District Council 37, the largest union of municipal workers, agreed that the pact would affect next year's bargaining with the Giuliani administration. "None of us are operating in a vacuum," he said. "It's going to have some kind of impact."
But Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine, the mayor's chief labor negotiator, insisted that the transit accord would prove irrelevant to next year's talks. "This will have no impact on the city's labor negotiations," he said in an interview. "The M.T.A. negotiations never had any impact on the city. As the mayor said, this deal is too rich for the city."
Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-backed watchdog group, questioned whether New York City Transit could afford the agreement.
"It puts pressure on the fare," she said. "There's no two ways around that. If all the public gets out of this agreement is a more expensive transit system, then it's a terrible deal. But if the M.T.A. got work-rule changes that make the system run more efficiently, that would change the equation."
Many commuters rejoiced yesterday that there was an agreement rather than a strike. Robert Jones, a Microsoft-New York general manager who lives in Fairfield, Conn., said, "I mostly use cabs to get around the city, and if there had been a strike it would have been nearly impossible to get one today, so it's a big relief."
Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls the M.T.A.'s board, called on union members to approve the contract.
"A strike would have caused significant chaos in the city and would have been illegal," he said. "I urge all of the members to keep this in mind as they consider this contract."

Chart: "OVERVIEW: The Subways Kept Rolling"
Crucial terms of the transit workers' contract.
 
LENGTH -- Three years, expiring Dec. 15, 2002
JOB SECURITY -- No layoffs of unionized employees for the duration of the contract.
WAGES
 Increase of 5 percent on Dec. 15, 1999.
 Increase of 9 percent on Dec. 15, 2000.
 Increase of 4 percent on Dec. 15, 2001.
 
PENSIONS -- The M.T.A. agrees to support state legislation that will reduce transit workers' contributions to their pension plan as follows: those paying contributions equal to 5.3 percent of their wages will pay 2 percent and those making a 3 percent contribution will pay 2 percent -- all without reducing their pensions.
HEALTH CARE -- The M.T.A. agrees to increase its contribution to health coverage by 6 percent a year as well as add an additional $3.75 million a year -- a move that union officials say will mean that workers will not have to increase their out-of-pocket expenses for premiums or co-payments. Union officials say the health plan will begin providing unlimited chiropractic coverage to the union as well as to begin providing some orthodontic coverage.
DISCIPLINARY PROCEDURES -- The M.T.A. agrees to ease some of its strict disciplinary rules. With the M.T.A.'s progressive disciplinary system in which workers face greater punishment for each new infraction, the M.T.A. agrees to give less weight to past infractions for those workers who go a year or more without any violations.
WORK RULES -- The M.T.A. says it will cut costs by obtaining more flexibility in assigning responsibilities to its workers. For example, mechanics who repair bus engines will now also be allowed to repair bus chassis.
(Sources: Contract language, Transport Workers Union, M.T.A.)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Investment Bankers Offered a Tax Break

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Connecticut has offered tax concessions to Warburg Dillon Read if it agrees to expand its headquarters and bring more jobs to the state.
Warburg Dillon Read, the investment banking arm of the Swiss banking giant UBS, could increase its work force from 3,0000 to 5,000 people by consolidating its United States operations in Stamford. 
 The proposal for up to $50 million in tax credits, which was made to the company on Tuesday by the State Department of Economic Development, is subject to approval by the General Assembly.
The company moved its North American headquarters from New York City to Stamford in 1997, after the legislature approved $145 million in tax incentives.
Ted Meyer, a company spokesman, declined comment beyond a prepared statement that said the company was growing rapidly and was always evaluating options to accommodate its needs.

HEADLINE: Retailers and Governors Attack Proposal to Make the Internet a Tax-Free Zone

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Proposals to make the Internet a tax-free zone came under withering attack today by major retailers, shopping-center owners and state and local officials in testimony before a commission created by Congress to study the question.
Wal-Mart Stores, Federated Department Stores, the International Council of Shopping Centers and other members of a hastily formed alliance calling itself the E-Fairness Coalition said it would be wrong for government to discriminate against bricks-and-mortar retailers and in favor of those operating online. 
 "Proposals to make the Internet a sales-tax-free zone are attractive," the coalition told the panel, the Advisory Commission on Electronic Commerce, "but have potentially devastating economic, tax and social consequences."
Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota, speaking on behalf of state and local governments whose largest source of revenue is sales taxes, said, "America can't survive if we have discriminatory taxes."
"We cannot adopt a tax policy that assists in wiping out small-town merchants," he said.
Witnesses spoke at the commission's third set of hearings this year amid growing indications that the 18-member commission is divided into three firmly entrenched camps. A consensus appears unlikely to develop before an April deadline for the group to recommend a national policy on taxing electronic commerce.
One faction, led by Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, the commission chairman, favors a blanket tax exemption for Internet commerce. Declaring that the Internet's growth "must not be thwarted by taxation," he would have the federal government increase grants to the states to make up for revenue losses.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah and other commission members favor a plan by the National Association of Governors and by local governments to create a national clearinghouse, financed by the states, to process sales taxes and turn them over to the 6,527 state and local agencies that impose sales taxes.
A third faction, led by Dean Andal, chairman of the California Board of Equalization, a state tax agency, favors maintaining the system in which online sales are subject to sales tax only when the merchant has a physical presence, like a retail store or warehouse, in a state where it ships goods.
The commission heard from several panels of witnesses who said that complying with different tax rates from place to place, and different rules on which items are taxable, would be a costly administrative nightmare.
Mayor Ron Kirk of Dallas, a commission member, ridiculed those arguments. "These companies can reduce every color in the universe to digits and put the complete details of building a car into a computer but they can't handle sales taxes?" he asked, mockingly. "Totally incongruent."
Another member, Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform, criticized state governments for going on a spending spree and said taxes from online sales would just allow more profligacy. Mr. Norquist said making the Internet a tax-free zone would force state and local governments to lower sales tax rates, which often total 8 to 9 percent in industrial states, to a range of 3 to 5 percent.
But Governor Janklow said the states had cut spending by $25 billion in this decade, mostly by lowering income and property tax rates. He said making the Internet a tax-free zone would diminish the power of the states and increase the power of the federal government.
Governor Janklow's testimony drew a rebuke from Citizens Against Government Waste, a Washington group calling itself the nation's largest tax watchdog. "South Dakota governor proposes Gestapo tactics to collect the state sales tax," the group said in a press release, calling e-commerce "the vanguard of America's current economic growth."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: December 21, 1999, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about retailers who told a tax study commission that they oppose making the Internet a tax-free zone included one company erroneously among the group, known as the e-Fairness Coalition. Federated Department Stores is not a member and does not agree with the coalition's views.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 30; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2224 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.
 
Now Playing
 
* "ALL ABOUT MY MOTHER," starring Cecilia Roth, Marisa Paredes, Antonia San Juan and Penelope Cruz. Directed by Pedro Almodovar (R, 101 minutes). A whole new order of Almodovar extravaganza. The antic fizz and theatrical exaggeration of this filmmaker's earlier work have blossomed into a newly sophisticated style, one that is far more wise and deeply felt. Lovingly dedicated to actresses who have played actresses, this film weaves its own soap opera around "A Streetcar Named Desire" and tells of splendidly resilient women; Mr. Almodovar has aptly described his material as "screwball drama." Rich and entertaining, this story celebrates the power of artifice and impersonation to transcend ordinary truth. The irrepressible Ms. San Juan, a Spanish nightclub performer, plays a transsexual named Agrado and is the film's biggest treat (Janet Maslin). 

* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hilary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of the year's best (Maslin).
 
* "THE CIDER HOUSE RULES," starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron and Delroy Lindo. Directed by Lasse Halstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope, and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with a Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent raised in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Michael Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 40's "David Copperfield" (Stephen Holden).
 
"CRADLE WILL ROCK," starring Emily Watson, John Turturro, Ruben Blades, John Cusack, Joan Cusack, Bill Murray and Vanessa Redgrave. Written and directed by Tim Robbins (R, 132 minutes). This huge Depression-era story features well-known figures from Orson Welles to Nelson Rockefeller to Diego Rivera, and it works them into an ambitious "Ragtime"-like tableau. Though too many figures in this landscape are reduced to naive caricature, Mr. Robbins and his impressive cast bring strong passions to bear upon this (mostly) true story of a legendary event: the trouble-fraught production by Welles and John Houseman of the banner-waving 1936 agitprop musical "The Cradle Will Rock." Mr. Robbins and his cast play out all sides of this event with the certitude that its importance lives on (Maslin).
 
* "THE END OF THE AFFAIR," starring Ralph Fiennes, Julianne Moore, Stephen Rea and Ian Hart. Directed by Neil Jordan (R, 105 minutes). Mr. Jordan's intoxicating version of Graham Greene's 1951 novel, in which an illicit affair becomes a far greater gamble than either lover could have imagined. For this fearlessly eclectic filmmaker, this is one more intelligent, brooding love story with a secret twist. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Moore breathe life into this story with a dreamy, erotic intensity that in no way trivializes the film's underlying ideas about religious faith. Period detail (the setting is London in the mid-1940's) is sumptuously heightened by the inspired costume designer Sandy Powell ("Shakespeare in Love") (Maslin).
 
"END OF DAYS," starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Robin Tunney, Gabriel Byrne and Kevin Pollak. Directed by Peter Hyams (R, 118 minutes). The star modestly tackles the role of a new savior who may just keep mankind free of Satan for the next thousand years. And that's not even the worst thing about this pointlessly nasty would-be thriller. The material is so derivative that it amounts to a tag sale of used parts from better apocalyptic films, with special credit owed to "The Exorcist" for grisly sacrilegious tricks. Mr. Hyams favors a jack-in-the-box approach to delivering shock value. The star dutifully protects a nice young woman from demonic forces. But Mr. Byrne plays the swaggering embodiment of pure evil and has the better role (Maslin).
 
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).
 
* "LIBERTY HEIGHTS," starring Adrien Brody, Joe Mantegna and Ben Foster. Directed and written by Barry Levinson (R, 134 minutes). This semi-autobiographical comedy-drama remembering teenage life, anti-Semitism and racism in mid-1950's Baltimore is the fourth movie by Mr. Levinson to be set in his native city. A deeply felt nostalgia trip, the movie adroitly captures the look and social attitudes of the city 45 years ago. But the screenplay and performances are too muted for the movie to come to terms with growing pains cushioned in the nostalgic haze (Holden).
 
* "MANSFIELD PARK," starring Frances O'Connor and Jonny Lee Miller. Written and directed by Patricia Rozema (PG-13, 105 minutes). In Ms. Rozema's skillful screen adaptation of Jane Austen's third novel, the protagonist Fanny Price (Ms. O'Connor) has been sharpened into a proto-feminist heroine who triumphs over the materialist, patriarchal values of her wealthy relatives through a combination of wit, beauty and daring. Without bearing down too heavily, the screenplay (which incorporates fragments of Austen's letters and diaries) equates early 19th-century slave trading with the oppression of women. The message is leavened with smart humor and warm three-dimensional performances (Holden).
 
"MISS JULIE," starring Saffron Burrows and Peter Mullan. Directed by Mike Figgis (R, 100 minutes). As directed by Mr. Figgis, whose previous films "Internal Affairs" and "The Loss of Sexual Innocence" dwelled obsessively on the darker aspects of sex, August Strindberg's late-19th-century drama becomes a bleak study of the sexual disgust shared by a rebellious aristocrat (Ms. Burrows) and the upwardly mobile footman (Mr. Mullan) she taunts into having sex. But the movie's contemporary cinema-verite style is at odds with the story and its setting. And Ms. Burrows's coldly haughty title character is far less compelling than Mr. Mullan's earthy, cunning footman (Holden).
 
"SLEEPY HOLLOW," starring Johnny Depp, Christina Ricci, Miranda Richardson, Michael Gambon, Jeffrey Jones, Michael Gough and Christopher Walken. Written by Andrew Kevin Walker and directed by Tim Burton (R, 110 minutes). This ornate visual fantasy, artfully concocted using a palette that suggests nuclear winter, has little to do with Washington Irving's story and everything to do with Mr. Burton's macabre vision. Mr. Depp makes a dashing hero as the film's shy detective, but the story (by the writer of "Seven" and "Fight Club") is determined to put the ick into Ichabod Crane. A first-rate cast and extraordinary technical talents are attention-getting here, but so is the film's penchant for sardonic beheadings. It's possible to admire Mr. Burton immensely for the secret tenderness and rich imagination of his work without wanting to peer at the exposed brain stems of his characters (Maslin).
 
"SWEET AND LOWDOWN," starring Sean Penn, Samantha Morton and Uma Thurman. Directed by Woody Allen (PG-13, 95 minutes). In homage to the kind of jaunty 1930's jazz that has been heard on many of his other films' soundtracks, Mr. Allen imagines a consummate jazz character: Emmet Ray (played with gusto by Mr. Penn), who can play the guitar as gorgeously as Django Reinhardt but lacks certain interpersonal skills when it comes to his private life. Borrowing attributes of various real musicians, the film turns Emmet into another one of Mr. Allen's cad-geniuses and gives him a long-suffering mute laundress as a sweetheart. (Ms. Morton works miracles in her wordless role.) But on the storytelling level, the film remains flimsy. It's the musical interludes, frequent and lovingly presented, that keep it alive (Maslin).
 
* "TOY STORY 2," with the voices of Tom Hanks and Tim Allen. Directed by John Lasseter; a Pixar Animated Studios film (G, 98 minutes). A wonderfully playful sequel, sustaining the first film's wit and novelty while bringing new sophistication to computer-generated animation. And here is welcome proof that Hollywood can still make movies to please audiences of any age or persuasion. From its opening (a perfectly adorable "Star Wars" parody) to its Capraesque conclusion, this is seamless work with more metaphorical cleverness than that usually found in the toy bin. Colorful new characters and more adventurous action enhance the story of how Woody falls into the clutches of a sleazy toy dealer, experiences newfound celebrity and needs to be rescued by his old friends (Maslin).
 
* "TUMBLEWEEDS," starring Janet McTeer and Kimberly J. Brown. Directed by Gavin O'Connor (PG-13, 100 minutes). An astoundingly vital performance by the British actress Janet McTeer makes this small, beautifully acted slice of contemporary Americana a must-see film. Ms. McTeer is Mary Jo Walker, a sexy, free-spirited woman with four marriages behind her who travels across the country with her 12-year-old daughter, Ava (Ms. Brown). Like few other films, this one captures an intimately loving (though not conflict-free) relationship between a parent and child without becoming saccharine. The director plays Mary Jo's trucker boyfriend, who is only the latest in a series of romantic disasters (Holden).
 
* "THE WAR ZONE," starring Freddie Cunliffe, Ray Winstone, Tilda Swinton and Lara Belmont. Directed by Tim Roth (not rated, 99 minutes). Mr. Roth is an actor known for roles in tough films, but never for anything quite as raw as this. In this searing first feature, the title battlefield is a rural English home where a teenage boy looks upon his own family with helpless rage and astonishment. Sensing the incestuous relationship between his father and older sister, the film's wordless, baleful young hero struggles to come to terms with this household horror. Understated but extremely graphic at times, and shot with mournfully expressive simplicity by Seamus McGarvey (Maslin).
 
"THE WORLD IS NOT ENOUGH," starring Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Dame Judi Dench, Robert Carlyle and Denise Richards. Directed by Michael Apted (PG-13, 128 minutes). This director is much admired for his "Up" series chronicling the lives of former schoolchildren as they mature. And he has managed to make James Bond grow up a little, too. Mr. Brosnan has grown much more comfortable with the role of Bond, and most of the other characters are also more interesting than might have been expected. Ms. Marceau slinks memorably through the role of a treacherous oil heiress. Ms. Richards seemed a lot smarter playing high school vixens than she does as a brilliant scientist here. The itinerary roams from Scotland to Central Asia. And Mr. Apted handles the action as well as he does the talk (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
BOGART RETROSPECTIVE. He was a gangster. He was a private eye. He skippered a fishing boat and ran a cafe in Casablanca. He was, of course, Humphrey Bogart (1899-1957), the son of a Manhattan surgeon and a magazine illustrator who achieved stardom in Hollywood. Now, on the occasion of the centennial of his birth, he is the subject of a retrospective in BAMcinematek, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Rose Cinemas' repertory program at 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in Fort Greene. This weekend offers two of his best: tomorrow, Raoul Walsh's "They Drive by Night," about two truckers framed for murder; and on Sunday, John Huston's "Maltese Falcon," with Bogart as the private detective Sam Spade, drawn into the intrigue surrounding a murder and a priceless statuette. Each film is to be shown at 3, 6 and 9 p.m. Screening times are subject to change. Admission to "Bogie at BAM," through Jan. 30, is $8.50 for adults and $5 for people over 62, children under 12 and students with valid identification. Information: (718) 623-2770 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: Fixing a Building, Building a Career

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA ROWE 

DATELINE: KINGSTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
For decades this city's grand old City Hall a national historic landmark -- sat boarded up and abandoned, decaying from the inside. Passersby would shake their heads at the brick edifice splattered with pigeon dung, and students at Kingston High School across the street would avert their eyes.
Among those most bothered was T. R. Gallo, who lived two blocks away and had grown up smarting at the inescapable symbolism of a city building left to rot. 
 "Every Kingstonian who passed it had to wonder where the city was heading," Mr. Gallo said. "Is that our future, a boarded-up derelict building in the heart of our city?"'
He kept his feelings to himself for a while, at least until he could become mayor of this city beside the Hudson River. It didn't take long: In 1993, at the age of 33, the Democrat was elected, presumably as Kingston's last mayor. A referendum passed that year decreed that whoever was elected would serve a two-year term and then hand over the reins to a city manager.
But Mr. Gallo would not be so easily removed. He turned his mayoralty into a 24-hour-a-day post, knowing that the sight of a mayor riding snowplows at 5 a.m. and blacktopping the streets alongside city workers would make an impression. It was the first hint of Mr. Gallo's staunch belief in the power of perception, and in the way perception can become reality.
Indeed, Kingston's residents changed their minds about wanting a city manager and resoundingly re-elected Mr. Gallo in 1995 with 85 percent of the vote. Last month, they elected him again: Mr. Gallo had become the only mayor in Kingston's 127-year history to run unopposed.
"T. R. Gallo is the consummate politician," said Jim Thompson, chairman of Kingston's Republican Party, who even considered cross-endorsing the mayor in last month's election. "He's young, he's aggressive and he gives the voters what they want."
What the mayor, still baby-faced at 39, has given them is a lesson in showmanship powerful enough to win millions of dollars from the federal government for high-profile projects like the reconstruction of the old City Hall. Yet his critics say it is exactly that focus on image that leaves less glamorous concerns -- like full-throttle economic development -- to fall by the wayside. City-sponsored historic-house tours and Christmas parties are nice, they say, but not enough.
"Tourism just doesn't cut it," said Robert Senor, a Republican member of the Common Council and a frequent critic of the mayor.
While many economically sluggish Hudson Valley cities are racing to build strip malls and entice superstores, Kingston, under Mr. Gallo's leadership, is trying to turn back the clock, to make its history a source of economic strength.
This was the first capital of New York, the burial place of the state's first governor, George Clinton, and the site of the courthouse where Sojourner Truth sued and won her son's freedom from slavery. The Gallo administration has sponsored re-enactments of the city's 1777 burning by the British, rehabilitated elegant old buildings and built a trolley to shuttle visitors between two historic districts. (The intersection of John and Crown Streets is the only place in America where 18th-century stone houses stand at all four corners.)
Mr. Gallo's restoration of old City Hall is the apex of that effort. Even in the dusty plaster of reconstruction, it has a sense of Titanic-like, ghostly grandeur.
Built in the 1870's in High Victorian Gothic style and refurbished after a fire in 1927, it has staircases of salmon-colored marble. The entranceway that leads a visitor's eye up to the 25-foot ceilings is ornate wrought steel.
Back in his current, somewhat drab City Hall office, T. R. Gallo -- the initials stand for Thomas Robert -- mused about the inauguration he plans to hold there for himself next month. (The current City Hall, built long and low in typical 1970's prefab style, will become a police station and city court.)
"To start the millennium in that historic room, I think, would just be awesome," said Mr. Gallo, who plans to move city offices there in the spring. The construction site is the first place he takes visitors, and he finds an excuse to stop by himself nearly every day. Every detail, down to doorknobs, fascinates him. "This is my favorite part of being mayor," he said. "It's possibly the greatest thing I've ever accomplished in my life."
Most of that life has been spent in public buildings. Mr. Gallo, the son of a city alderman, has been a government employee since the age of 21, when he dropped out of the State University of New York at New Paltz several credits shy of graduation because the Democratic Party offered him a job as the city's civil service director.
His lack of experience outside the public sector is not lost on Mr. Gallo's critics. They say the mayor is out of touch with the struggles of business owners and has become bull-headed with his success.
"I find most politicians have never owned their own business and they've never had to deal with their own money," said Karen Vetere, who runs a real estate agency and says taxes in Kingston have become untenable for many local merchants. (Even the city's most inviting areas are pocked with empty storefronts.)
"I suppose for every good city to move along there has to be a strong person at the helm, and when T. R. came along he was young, he was full of energy," Ms. Vetere said. "But unfortunately, what motivates a lot of politicians is their ego, and now our mayor's ego is larger than the whole city of Kingston."
It is that self-assurance, Ms. Vetere conceded, that gave Mr. Gallo the gumption to tackle a project as ambitious as restoring City Hall to its Victorian glory. And even his most vocal detractors are impressed by the mayor's grant-getting success. In six years, he has won $25 million in state and federal funds for small businesses, historic renovation and the arts, which, like everything else, Mr. Gallo appraises as a strategist.
The mayor "may not have a sophisticated view of what the arts are," said Ron Marquette, executive artistic director of the Ulster Performing Arts Center, who has been the recipient of many mayoral grants. "But he recognizes the bottom line. He recognizes that the arts mean business." Last month, Mr. Marquette named Mayor Gallo the Arts Advocate of the Year.
No aesthete, Mr. Gallo is, however, an unabashed showman. Last year, when B. B. King was scheduled to perform at the arts center and the blues legend refused to get off his tour bus, Mr. Gallo marched on to demand why. It seemed Mr. King's treasured guitar, "Lucille," was en route to Kingston on another bus and had not yet arrived. Mr. Gallo dispatched city police officers to find Lucille, whose driver was wandering lost through the city, and set up a police escort to zoom the guitar to the theater.
"Well, the police come tearing up Broadway with this bus that had nothing on it but a guitar and the crowd roars and then B.B. runs on stage, holding the guitar above his head and says, 'I want to thank the mayor of Kingston for saving my Lucille,' " recalled Mr. Marquette, fairly choking with laughter. "It made the news in Paris."
But not all of Mr. Gallo's efforts have met with such success. While he persuaded the Common Council to build a $3 million industrial park for Huck Industries, Kingston's largest private employer, the rest of the complex sits vacant three years later. Meanwhile, taxes are going up, the city has borrowed money to pay its end-of-year bills, and Mr. Gallo is asking for a $15,000 pay raise. (In six years, he has increased his annual salary to $50,000 from $37,500.)
"On the surface, yes, he's a good mayor, giving parties to the seniors and putting out planters with flowers," said Mr. Senor, the Republican council member. "But he's using City Hall, which is a good project in many ways, as a tool to make himself look good while there are some serious problems that aren't being addressed."
Mr. Gallo is so busy with city minutiae that he relies on his secretary to keep track of everything from political obligations to weekend visits with his 10-year-old daughter, Nicole. But he is undaunted by the pace or the criticism.
"I love this job," he said. "I love talking with people. I love dealing with people. I've thought about running for higher office, like the Assembly, but debating social policy with 150 people in Albany just isn't as rewarding as blacktopping the street or rebuilding City Hall."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate In New York Drops to 5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 16

 BODY:
New York State's unemployment rate dipped to 5 percent in November, down slightly from October's 5.2 percent, State Labor Department officials said today.
The unemployment rate in November of last year was 5.5 percent. 
 The national unemployment rate for last month was 4.1 percent.
State officials said the one-year job growth stood at 166,200 jobs, a 2 percent increase.
Here is a breakdown for major metropolitan areas in the state, not seasonally adjusted:
*New York City, 217,400 jobless or 6.3 percent, compared with 6.9 percent in October and 7.8 percent in November of last year.
*Albany area, 14,600 or 3.2 percent, compared with 3.3 percent and 3.1 percent.
*Binghamton area, 4,200 or 3.3 percent, compared with 3.4 and 3.4.
*Buffalo area, 26,600 or 4.7 percent, compared with 4.6 and 4.5.
*Elmira area, 2,100 or 4.7 percent, compared with 4.7 and 3.7.
*Poughkeepsie area, 3,700 or 3.1 percent, compared with 3.3 and 2.9.
*Rochester area, 22,200 or 3.9 percent, compared with 3.8 and 3.5.
*Syracuse area, 14,900 or 4.1 percent, compared with 3.9 and 3.4.
*Utica-Rome area, 5,600 or 4.0 percent, compared with 3.6 and 3.9.
*Nassau County, 19,500 or 2.8 percent, compared with 2.9 and 2.4.
*Suffolk County, 23,500 or 3.2 percent, compared with 3.3 and 3.0.
*Westchester County, 13,600 or 3.0 percent, compared with 3.3 and 2.8.
*Rockland County, 4,600 or 3.1 percent, compared with 3.4 and 2.8.
*Putnam County, 1,300 or 2.5 percent, compared with 2.8 and 2.3.
"Record numbers of jobs and record rates of growth continue pushing the state's economy ahead at a strong and steady pace," said Thomas Rodick, director of the Labor Department's research and statistics division.
